title: Quick Heuristic Validation of Edges in Dynamic Roadmap Graphs
summary: In this paper we tackle the problem of adjusting roadmap graphs for robot motion planning to non-static environments. We introduce the "Red-Green-Gray" paradigm, a modification of the SPITE method, capable of classifying the validity status of nodes and edges using cheap heuristic checks, allowing fast semi-lazy roadmap updates. Given a roadmap, we use simple computational geometry methods to approximate the swept volumes of robots and perform lazy collision checks, and label a subset of the edges as invalid (red), valid (green), or unknown (gray). We present preliminary experimental results comparing our method to the well-established technique of Leven and Hutchinson, and showing increased accuracy as well as the ability to correctly label edges as invalid while maintaining comparable update runtimes.

AI.tldr: A semi-lazy dynamic roadmap update method using Red-Green-Gray labeling to classify roadmap elements, extending SPITE, yielding faster updates with improved accuracy versus Leven & Hutchinson.
AI.motivation: Dynamic environments necessitate fast, reliable updates to roadmap graphs for robot motion planning; existing methods trade off update speed and accuracy. The authors aim to enable cheap but informative validity checks to support semi-lazy updates.
AI.method: Introduce Red-Green-Gray paradigm to classify nodes/edges as red (invalid), green (valid), or gray (unknown) using cheap heuristic checks. Approximate swept robot volumes with simple computational geometry and perform lazy collision checks. Update roadmap by labeling a subset of edges and compare performance to Leven and Hutchinson.
AI.result: Preliminary experiments show increased accuracy in identifying invalid edges and comparable update runtimes relative to Leven and Hutchinson.
AI.conclusion: The approach offers a fast, accurate alternative for dynamic roadmap maintenance, with potential for integration into broader planning systems and room for refining heuristics and broader benchmarking.

title: Meta-ROS: A Next-Generation Middleware Architecture for Adaptive and Scalable Robotic Systems
comment: Checkout the Python Library - https://pypi.org/project/metaros/ To be Submitted in ACM Transactions on Autonomous and Adaptive Systems (TAAS) Journal
summary: The field of robotics faces significant challenges related to the complexity and interoperability of existing middleware frameworks, like ROS2, which can be difficult for new developers to adopt. To address these issues, we propose Meta-ROS, a novel middleware solution designed to streamline robotics development by simplifying integration, enhancing performance, and ensuring cross-platform compatibility. Meta-ROS leverages modern communication protocols, such as Zenoh and ZeroMQ, to enable efficient and low-latency communication across diverse hardware platforms, while also supporting various data types like audio, images, and video. We evaluated Meta-ROS's performance through comprehensive testing, comparing it with existing middleware frameworks like ROS1 and ROS2. The results demonstrated that Meta-ROS outperforms ROS2, achieving up to 30% higher throughput, significantly reducing message latency, and optimizing resource usage. Additionally, its robust hardware support and developer-centric design facilitate seamless integration and ease of use, positioning Meta-ROS as an ideal solution for modern, real-time robotics AI applications.

AI.tldr: Meta-ROS proposes a new middleware to simplify robotics development and improve performance across platforms, claiming up to 30% throughput gains over ROS2 and lower latency, using Zenoh and ZeroMQ, with support for audio/images/video, and benchmarking against ROS1/ROS2.
AI.motivation: Address challenges of complexity and interoperability in existing middleware, onboarding for new developers, and the need for performant, cross-platform data exchange in real-time robotics AI.
AI.method: Design and evaluation of a middleware solution; integration of Zenoh and ZeroMQ; cross-platform compatibility; benchmarking against ROS1/ROS2; assessment across multiple data types; hardware support; developer-centric design.
AI.result: Reported improvements: up to 30% higher throughput vs ROS2; reduced latency; optimized resource usage; robust hardware support; easy integration.
AI.conclusion: Meta-ROS positions as an ideal solution for modern real-time robotics AI, enabling easier integration and improved performance; potential to influence the middleware ecosystem.

title: Track-centric Iterative Learning for Global Trajectory Optimization in Autonomous Racing
summary: This paper presents a global trajectory optimization framework for minimizing lap time in autonomous racing under uncertain vehicle dynamics. Optimizing the trajectory over the full racing horizon is computationally expensive, and tracking such a trajectory in the real world hardly assures global optimality due to uncertain dynamics. Yet, existing work mostly focuses on dynamics learning at the tracking level, without updating the trajectory itself to account for the learned dynamics. To address these challenges, we propose a track-centric approach that directly learns and optimizes the full-horizon trajectory. We first represent trajectories through a track-agnostic parametric space in light of the wavelet transform. This space is then efficiently explored using Bayesian optimization, where the lap time of each candidate is evaluated by running simulations with the learned dynamics. This optimization is embedded in an iterative learning framework, where the optimized trajectory is deployed to collect real-world data for updating the dynamics, progressively refining the trajectory over the iterations. The effectiveness of the proposed framework is validated through simulations and real-world experiments, demonstrating lap time improvement of up to 20.7% over a nominal baseline and consistently outperforming state-of-the-art methods.

AI.tldr: A global trajectory optimization framework for autonomous racing under uncertain dynamics uses a track-centric, wavelet-parametrized trajectory representation optimized via Bayesian optimization, with iterative real-world data collection to update dynamics, yielding up to 20.7% lap-time improvements over baselines.
AI.motivation: Full-horizon trajectory optimization under dynamic uncertainty is computationally expensive and brittle when trajectories are fixed after learning. Traditional methods optimize dynamics during tracking rather than adapting the planned trajectory itself, risking suboptimal performance. A track-centric approach aims to jointly learn and optimize the full-horizon trajectory while updating the dynamics.
AI.method: Represent trajectories in a track-agnostic parametric space using a wavelet transform; efficiently search this space with Bayesian optimization where each candidate's lap time is evaluated via simulations with learned dynamics. Embed this in an iterative learning framework: deploy the optimized trajectory to collect real-world data to update the dynamics, then re-optimize over the updated model.
AI.result: Simulations and real-world experiments demonstrate lap-time improvements up to 20.7% over a nominal baseline and consistent superiority over state-of-the-art methods.
AI.conclusion: A track-centric, jointly learned and optimized full-horizon trajectory framework with iterative dynamics learning can significantly improve lap times under dynamic uncertainty and surpass existing methods.

title: Multi-Robot Decentralized Collaborative SLAM in Planetary Analogue Environments: Dataset, Challenges, and Lessons Learned
summary: Decentralized collaborative simultaneous localization and mapping (C-SLAM) is essential to enable multirobot missions in unknown environments without relying on preexisting localization and communication infrastructure. This technology is anticipated to play a key role in the exploration of the Moon, Mars, and other planets. In this article, we share insights and lessons learned from C-SLAM experiments involving three robots operating on a Mars analogue terrain and communicating over an ad hoc network. We examine the impact of limited and intermittent communication on C-SLAM performance, as well as the unique localization challenges posed by planetary-like environments. Additionally, we introduce a novel dataset collected during our experiments, which includes real-time peer-to-peer inter-robot throughput and latency measurements. This dataset aims to support future research on communication-constrained, decentralized multirobot operations.

AI.tldr: This article discusses decentralized collaborative SLAM (C-SLAM) under communication constraints, based on three-robot experiments on Mars-analogue terrain, highlighting how limited and intermittent networks affect performance and localization. It also introduces a new dataset of real-time inter-robot throughput and latency to support future research in communication-constrained, decentralized multirobot exploration.
AI.motivation: Enable robust multirobot exploration in unknown planetary environments without preexisting localization or communication infrastructure; support Moon, Mars, and other planetary missions.
AI.method: Three-robot C-SLAM experiments on Mars-analogue terrain using an ad hoc inter-robot network; evaluation of how limited/intermittent communication degrades C-SLAM performance and localization; collection of real-time throughput and latency data; dataset creation for future research.
AI.result: Derived insights and lessons on the effects of communication constraints on C-SLAM performance; identified unique localization challenges in planetary-like environments; introduced a novel dataset with peer-to-peer throughput and latency measurements for ongoing research.
AI.conclusion: The dataset and insights aim to advance research in communication-constrained, decentralized multirobot operations and inform design choices for planetary exploration systems.

title: Rethinking LLM-Driven Heuristic Design: Generating Efficient and Specialized Solvers via Dynamics-Aware Optimization
summary: Large Language Models (LLMs) have advanced the field of Combinatorial Optimization through automated heuristic generation. Instead of relying on manual design, this LLM-Driven Heuristic Design (LHD) process leverages LLMs to iteratively generate and refine solvers to achieve high performance. However, existing LHD frameworks face two critical limitations: (1) Endpoint-only evaluation, which ranks solvers solely by final quality, ignoring the convergence process and runtime efficiency; (2) High adaptation costs, where distribution shifts necessitate re-adaptation to generate specialized solvers for new instance groups. To address these issues, we propose Dynamics-Aware Solver Heuristics (DASH), a framework that co-optimizes solver search mechanisms and runtime schedules guided by a convergence-aware metric, thereby identifying efficient and high-performance solvers. Furthermore, to mitigate expensive re-adaptation, DASH incorporates Profiled Library Retrieval (PLR). PLR efficiently archives specialized solvers concurrently with the evolutionary process, enabling cost-effective warm-starts for heterogeneous distributions. Experiments on four combinatorial optimization problems demonstrate that DASH improves runtime efficiency by over 3 times, while surpassing the solution quality of state-of-the-art baselines across diverse problem scales. Furthermore, by enabling profile-based warm starts, DASH maintains superior accuracy under different distributions while cutting LLM adaptation costs by over 90%.

AI.tldr: DASH uses dynamics-aware optimization and profiled library retrieval to co-create fast, high-quality solvers for combinatorial optimization, achieving significant runtime gains and robust performance across distributions with greatly reduced adaptation costs.
AI.motivation: Existing LHD methods optimize only final solver quality and fail to account for convergence dynamics and runtime; distribution shifts require expensive re-adaptation; a framework that aligns search and execution with convergence metrics and reuses specialized solvers can improve efficiency and robustness.
AI.method: Introduce Dynamics-Aware Solver Heuristics (DASH) that co-optimizes solver search strategies and runtime schedules guided by a convergence-aware objective; incorporate Profiled Library Retrieval (PLR) to archive specialized solvers during evolution for cost-effective warm starts; evaluate on four combinatorial optimization problems with diverse instance distributions.
AI.result: DASH yields over 3x faster runtimes while achieving or surpassing state-of-the-art solution quality across problem scales; PLR enables profile-based warm starts that preserve high accuracy under distribution shifts and reduce LLM adaptation costs by >90%.
AI.conclusion: DASH offers a convergence-aware, dynamically scheduled solver design framework with an efficient solvers archive, enabling robust performance and reduced adaptation costs in LHD for combinatorial optimization.

title: Do LLMs Favor LLMs? Quantifying Interaction Effects in Peer Review
summary: There are increasing indications that LLMs are not only used for producing scientific papers, but also as part of the peer review process. In this work, we provide the first comprehensive analysis of LLM use across the peer review pipeline, with particular attention to interaction effects: not just whether LLM-assisted papers or LLM-assisted reviews are different in isolation, but whether LLM-assisted reviews evaluate LLM-assisted papers differently. In particular, we analyze over 125,000 paper-review pairs from ICLR, NeurIPS, and ICML. We initially observe what appears to be a systematic interaction effect: LLM-assisted reviews seem especially kind to LLM-assisted papers compared to papers with minimal LLM use. However, controlling for paper quality reveals a different story: LLM-assisted reviews are simply more lenient toward lower quality papers in general, and the over-representation of LLM-assisted papers among weaker submissions creates a spurious interaction effect rather than genuine preferential treatment of LLM-generated content. By augmenting our observational findings with reviews that are fully LLM-generated, we find that fully LLM-generated reviews exhibit severe rating compression that fails to discriminate paper quality, while human reviewers using LLMs substantially reduce this leniency. Finally, examining metareviews, we find that LLM-assisted metareviews are more likely to render accept decisions than human metareviews given equivalent reviewer scores, though fully LLM-generated metareviews tend to be harsher. This suggests that meta-reviewers do not merely outsource the decision-making to the LLM. These findings provide important input for developing policies that govern the use of LLMs during peer review, and they more generally indicate how LLMs interact with existing decision-making processes.

AI.tldr: LLMs influence peer review in nuanced ways. Across ICLR/NeurIPS/ICML, LLM-assisted reviews show initial apparent interaction effects with LLM-assisted papers, but controlling for quality reveals general leniency toward lower-quality work. Fully LLM-generated reviews exhibit rating compression; human reviewers with LLMs reduce this leniency. Meta-reviews show LLM-assisted reviewers more likely to accept at equivalent scores, though fully LLM-generated meta-reviews are harsher. Implications for policy and governance of LLM use in peer review.
AI.motivation: To understand how large language models affect the peer-review pipeline, including interaction effects between LLM-assisted papers and LLM-assisted reviews, and to inform governance policies.
AI.method: Observational analysis of over 125,000 paper–review pairs from ICLR, NeurIPS, and ICML. Comparisons across LLM-assisted vs non-assisted reviews, controlling for paper quality. Experiments including fully LLM-generated reviews. Analysis of metareviews to assess decision outcomes.
AI.result: Initial interaction effects were spurious due to confounding paper quality; LLM-assisted reviews are generally lenient toward lower-quality papers. Fully LLM-generated reviews show severe rating compression. Human reviewers using LLMs mitigate leniency. In metareviews, LLM-assisted reviewers are more likely to render accept decisions at equivalent scores, while fully LLM-generated metareviews tend to be harsher.
AI.conclusion: LLMs interact with peer-review processes in complex ways; governance policies should account for potential biases and compression effects, ensure human oversight, and calibrate decision-making to prevent unintended favoritism or indiscriminate acceptance.

title: WheelArm-Sim: A Manipulation and Navigation Combined Multimodal Synthetic Data Generation Simulator for Unified Control in Assistive Robotics
comment: Accepted to IEEE International Symposium on Medical Robotics (ISMR) 2026
summary: Wheelchairs and robotic arms enhance independent living by assisting individuals with upper-body and mobility limitations in their activities of daily living (ADLs). Although recent advancements in assistive robotics have focused on Wheelchair-Mounted Robotic Arms (WMRAs) and wheelchairs separately, integrated and unified control of the combination using machine learning models remains largely underexplored. To fill this gap, we introduce the concept of WheelArm, an integrated cyber-physical system (CPS) that combines wheelchair and robotic arm controls. Data collection is the first step toward developing WheelArm models. In this paper, we present WheelArm-Sim, a simulation framework developed in Isaac Sim for synthetic data collection. We evaluate its capability by collecting a manipulation and navigation combined multimodal dataset, comprising 13 tasks, 232 trajectories, and 67,783 samples. To demonstrate the potential of the WheelArm dataset, we implement a baseline model for action prediction in the mustard-picking task. The results illustrate that data collected from WheelArm-Sim is feasible for a data-driven machine learning model for integrated control.

AI.tldr: Introduces WheelArm, an integrated Wheelchair-Mounted Robotic Arm (WMRAs) cyber-physical system, and WheelArm-Sim, a Isaac Sim-based data-collection framework for unified control. Demonstrates dataset feasibility via a 13-task, 232-trajectory, 67,783-sample multimodal dataset and a mustard-picking baseline model.
AI.motivation: Addresses the lack of unified, data-driven control for integrated wheelchair and WMRA systems. Aims to enable learning-based, end-to-end control for navigation and manipulation in assistive robotics by providing a synthetic data framework.
AI.method: Develops WheelArm-Sim in Isaac Sim to generate synthetic multimodal data for combined manipulation and navigation tasks. Collects a dataset of 13 tasks, 232 trajectories, and 67,783 samples. Implements a baseline action-prediction model on a mustard-picking task to validate the utility of the WheelArm dataset for integrated control.
AI.result: WheelArm-Sim successfully produced a sizable, multimodal dataset demonstrating the feasibility of data-driven models for integrated wheelchair and WMRA control. The mustard-picking baseline shows potential for learning-based action prediction using WheelArm data.
AI.conclusion: WheelArm-Sim provides a practical, scalable platform and dataset for developing unified control strategies for wheelchairs with mounted robotic arms. This work lays groundwork for future data-driven CPS models and real-world validation.

title: Non-Markov Multi-Round Conversational Image Generation with History-Conditioned MLLMs
summary: Conversational image generation requires a model to follow user instructions across multiple rounds of interaction, grounded in interleaved text and images that accumulate as chat history. While recent multimodal large language models (MLLMs) can generate and edit images, most existing multi-turn benchmarks and training recipes are effectively Markov: the next output depends primarily on the most recent image, enabling shortcut solutions that ignore long-range history. In this work we formalize and target the more challenging non-Markov setting, where a user may refer back to earlier states, undo changes, or reference entities introduced several rounds ago. We present (i) non-Markov multi-round data construction strategies, including rollback-style editing that forces retrieval of earlier visual states and name-based multi-round personalization that binds names to appearances across rounds; (ii) a history-conditioned training and inference framework with token-level caching to prevent multi-round identity drift; and (iii) enabling improvements for high-fidelity image reconstruction and editable personalization, including a reconstruction-based DiT detokenizer and a multi-stage fine-tuning curriculum. We demonstrate that explicitly training for non-Markov interactions yields substantial improvements in multi-round consistency and instruction compliance, while maintaining strong single-round editing and personalization.

AI.tldr: Introduces non-Markov multi-round data construction and training for conversational image generation, with rollback-style editing and name-based personalization, plus a history-conditioned training/inference framework and a reconstruction-based detokenizer with a multi-stage fine-tuning curriculum; results show improved non-Markov multi-round consistency and instruction compliance while preserving strong single-round editing/personalization.
AI.motivation: Existing multimodal LLM benchmarks often treat multi-turn interactions as Markov, relying only on the latest image and text. This ignores references to earlier states, undo operations, or long-range identity tracking, hindering ability to follow complex user instructions across rounds.
AI.method: (i) Non-Markov data construction: rollback-style editing forcing retrieval of earlier visual states and name-based multi-round personalization binding names to appearances across rounds; (ii) History-conditioned training/inference with token-level caching to prevent identity drift across rounds; (iii) Reconstruction-focused DiT detokenizer and a multi-stage fine-tuning curriculum to improve high-fidelity reconstruction and editable personalization.
AI.result: Training explicitly for non-Markov interactions yields substantial improvements in multi-round consistency and instruction compliance, while maintaining strong performance on single-round editing and personalization tasks.
AI.conclusion: Non-Markov-aware training and data construction significantly enhance multi-round conversational image generation without sacrificing single-round capabilities, enabling more reliable and controllable image editing across extended interactions.

title: Finetune-Informed Pretraining Boosts Downstream Performance
summary: Multimodal pretraining is effective for building general-purpose representations, but in many practical deployments, only one modality is heavily used during downstream fine-tuning. Standard pretraining strategies treat all modalities uniformly, which can lead to under-optimized representations for the modality that actually matters. We propose Finetune-Informed Pretraining (FIP), a model-agnostic method that biases representation learning toward a designated target modality needed at fine-tuning time. FIP combines higher masking difficulty, stronger loss weighting, and increased decoder capacity for the target modality, without modifying the shared encoder or requiring additional supervision. When applied to masked modeling on constellation diagrams for wireless signals, FIP consistently improves downstream fine-tuned performance with no extra data or compute. FIP is simple to implement, architecture-compatible, and broadly applicable across multimodal masked modeling pipelines.

AI.tldr: FIP biases multimodal pretraining toward a designated target modality used at fine-tuning, via higher masking difficulty, stronger loss weighting, and larger decoder capacity for that modality; model-agnostic and improves downstream performance on wireless constellation-diagram tasks without extra data/computational cost.
AI.motivation: In real deployments, one modality drives fine-tuning; uniform multimodal pretraining can under-prepare the target modality. A targeted pretraining bias aims to align representations with downstream needs.
AI.method: During masked modeling, increase masking difficulty, amplify loss weights, and expand decoder capacity for the target modality; keep the shared encoder fixed; no extra supervision; model-agnostic; demonstrated on constellation diagrams for wireless signals.
AI.result: Downstream fine-tuned performance improves consistently; no additional data or compute required; straightforward to implement and broadly applicable across multimodal masked modeling pipelines.
AI.conclusion: FIP offers a simple, architecture-compatible strategy to tailor pretraining to downstream modality importance, enhancing task performance without changing encoders or adding data.

title: The Epistemic Planning Domain Definition Language: Official Guideline
summary: Epistemic planning extends (multi-agent) automated planning by making agents' knowledge and beliefs first-class aspects of the planning formalism. One of the most well-known frameworks for epistemic planning is Dynamic Epistemic Logic (DEL), which offers an rich and natural semantics for modelling problems in this setting. The high expressive power provided by DEL make DEL-based epistemic planning a challenging problem to tackle both theoretically, and in practical implementations. As a result, existing epistemic planners often target different DEL fragments, and typically rely on ad hoc languages to represent benchmarks, and sometimes no language at all. This fragmentation hampers comparison, reuse, and systematic benchmark development. We address these issues by introducing the Epistemic Planning Domain Definition Language (EPDDL). EPDDL provides a unique PDDL-like representation that captures the entire DEL semantics, enabling uniform specification of epistemic planning tasks. Our contributions are threefold: 1. A formal development of abstract event models, a novel representation for epistemic actions used to define the semantics of our language; 2. A formal specification of EPDDL's syntax and semantics grounded in DEL with abstract event models; 3. A demonstration of EPDDL's practical applicability: we identify useful fragments amenable to current planners and show how they can be represented in EPDDL. Through examples of representative benchmarks, we illustrate how EPDDL facilitates interoperability, reproducible evaluation, and future advances in epistemic planning.

AI.tldr: EPDDL offers a PDDL-like language to encode Dynamic Epistemic Logic semantics for epistemic planning, including abstract event models, a DEL-grounded syntax/semantics, and representation of benchmarks to enable interoperability and reproducible evaluation.
AI.motivation: Address fragmentation and ad hoc languages in DEL-based epistemic planning, hindering comparison and benchmarking.
AI.method: Formalize abstract event models; specify EPDDL syntax and DEL-grounded semantics; demonstrate applicability by encoding representative benchmarks and identifying fragments friendly to existing planners.
AI.result: A uniform, interoperable language that captures DEL semantics; enables reproducible evaluation and facilitates future work; shows how common benchmarks can be represented in EPDDL.
AI.conclusion: EPDDL advances the field by enabling standardized specification, interoperability, and reproducible benchmarking for epistemic planning under DEL.

title: InspecSafe-V1: A Multimodal Benchmark for Safety Assessment in Industrial Inspection Scenarios
summary: With the rapid development of industrial intelligence and unmanned inspection, reliable perception and safety assessment for AI systems in complex and dynamic industrial sites has become a key bottleneck for deploying predictive maintenance and autonomous inspection. Most public datasets remain limited by simulated data sources, single-modality sensing, or the absence of fine-grained object-level annotations, which prevents robust scene understanding and multimodal safety reasoning for industrial foundation models. To address these limitations, InspecSafe-V1 is released as the first multimodal benchmark dataset for industrial inspection safety assessment that is collected from routine operations of real inspection robots in real-world environments. InspecSafe-V1 covers five representative industrial scenarios, including tunnels, power facilities, sintering equipment, oil and gas petrochemical plants, and coal conveyor trestles. The dataset is constructed from 41 wheeled and rail-mounted inspection robots operating at 2,239 valid inspection sites, yielding 5,013 inspection instances. For each instance, pixel-level segmentation annotations are provided for key objects in visible-spectrum images. In addition, a semantic scene description and a corresponding safety level label are provided according to practical inspection tasks. Seven synchronized sensing modalities are further included, including infrared video, audio, depth point clouds, radar point clouds, gas measurements, temperature, and humidity, to support multimodal anomaly recognition, cross-modal fusion, and comprehensive safety assessment in industrial environments.

AI.tldr: InspecSafe-V1 is the first multimodal industrial inspection safety benchmark with 7 modalities, 41 robots, 2,239 sites, and 5,013 instances, offering pixel-level annotations, semantic scene descriptions, and safety labels to enable multimodal anomaly recognition and safety reasoning.
AI.motivation: Existing public datasets for industrial inspection are limited by synthetic sources, single-modality sensing, and lack fine-grained object-level annotations, hindering robust scene understanding and safety reasoning for industrial AI systems.
AI.method: Data collection from routine operations of 41 wheeled and rail-mounted inspection robots across five industrial scenarios (tunnels, power facilities, sintering equipment, oil/gas petrochemical plants, coal conveyor trestles). Each of 5,013 instances includes pixel-level segmentation for key visible objects, a semantic scene description, and a safety level label. Seven synchronized modalities are provided: infrared video, audio, depth point clouds, radar point clouds, gas measurements, temperature, and humidity.
AI.result: Release of InspecSafe-V1 with multimodal annotations across seven modalities, enabling multimodal anomaly recognition, cross-modal fusion, and comprehensive safety assessment in industrial environments.
AI.conclusion: InspecSafe-V1 provides a valuable, real-world benchmark for industrial perception and safety reasoning, supporting development of robust multimodal industrial foundation models and practical predictive maintenance and autonomous inspection applications.

title: Text controllable PET denoising
summary: Positron Emission Tomography (PET) imaging is a vital tool in medical diagnostics, offering detailed insights into molecular processes within the human body. However, PET images often suffer from complicated noise, which can obscure critical diagnostic information. The quality of the PET image is impacted by various factors including scanner hardware, image reconstruction, tracer properties, dose/count level, and acquisition time. In this study, we propose a novel text-guided denoising method capable of enhancing PET images across a wide range of count levels within a single model. The model utilized the features from a pretrained CLIP model with a U-Net based denoising model. Experimental results demonstrate that the proposed model leads significant improvements in both qualitative and quantitative assessments. The flexibility of the model shows the potential for helping more complicated denoising demands or reducing the acquisition time.

AI.tldr: A single text-guided PET denoising model using CLIP features integrated into a U-Net, achieving robust performance across varying count levels with improved qualitative and quantitative metrics; potential to enable faster acquisitions.
AI.motivation: PET image noise arises from scanner hardware, reconstruction, tracer properties, dose/count level, and acquisition time. A single model capable of denoising across count levels with guidance from semantic text prompts could improve robustness and enable shorter scans.
AI.method: Integrates pretrained CLIP features as conditioning into a U-Net denoiser; text guidance directs denoising across multiple count levels; trained to generalize over varying count statistics within one model.
AI.result: Significant improvements in qualitative and quantitative assessments across experiments; demonstrated robustness across a broad range of count levels; suggests potential to reduce acquisition time.
AI.conclusion: Text-guided CLIP-conditioned denoising is flexible and scalable for more complex denoising tasks and potential acceleration of PET acquisition; promising direction for clinical translation.

title: A generative machine learning model for designing metal hydrides applied to hydrogen storage
summary: Developing new metal hydrides is a critical step toward efficient hydrogen storage in carbon-neutral energy systems. However, existing materials databases, such as the Materials Project, contain a limited number of well-characterized hydrides, which constrains the discovery of optimal candidates. This work presents a framework that integrates causal discovery with a lightweight generative machine learning model to generate novel metal hydride candidates that may not exist in current databases. Using a dataset of 450 samples (270 training, 90 validation, and 90 testing), the model generates 1,000 candidates. After ranking and filtering, six previously unreported chemical formulas and crystal structures are identified, four of which are validated by density functional theory simulations and show strong potential for future experimental investigation. Overall, the proposed framework provides a scalable and time-efficient approach for expanding hydrogen storage datasets and accelerating materials discovery.

AI.tldr: A framework combining causal discovery with a lightweight generative model to propose novel metal hydride candidates beyond existing databases; from 450 samples, 1,000 candidates are generated; six new formulas/structures found, four of which are validated by DFT; demonstrates scalable, time-efficient expansion of hydrogen storage datasets to accelerate materials discovery.
AI.motivation: To overcome the limited coverage of well-characterized metal hydrides in existing databases, which constrains discovery of optimal hydrogen storage materials essential for carbon-neutral energy systems.
AI.method: Integrate causal discovery to identify informative feature–outcome relationships with a lightweight generative machine learning model to synthesize new metal hydride candidates. Use a dataset of 450 samples (270 training, 90 validation, 90 testing) to generate 1,000 candidates, followed by ranking and filtering and density functional theory (DFT) validation for top candidates.
AI.result: Identified six previously unreported formulas/structures; four are validated by DFT simulations and show strong potential for experimental follow-up. The framework demonstrates scalability and time efficiency in expanding hydrogen storage datasets and accelerating materials discovery.
AI.conclusion: The proposed framework offers a scalable pathway to enrich hydrogen storage materials databases with novel hydrides, enabling faster identification and experimental testing of promising candidates for future carbon-neutral energy systems.

title: Bayesian-LoRA: Probabilistic Low-Rank Adaptation of Large Language Models
summary: Large Language Models usually put more emphasis on accuracy and therefore, will guess even when not certain about the prediction, which is especially severe when fine-tuned on small datasets due to the inherent tendency toward miscalibration. In this work, we introduce Bayesian-LoRA, which reformulates the deterministic LoRA update as a probabilistic low-rank representation inspired by Sparse Gaussian Processes. We identify a structural isomorphism between LoRA's factorization and Kronecker-factored SGP posteriors, and show that LoRA emerges as a limiting case when posterior uncertainty collapses. We conduct extensive experiments on various LLM architectures across commonsense reasoning benchmarks. With only approximately 0.42M additional parameters and ${\approx}1.2{\times}$ training cost relative to standard LoRA, Bayesian-LoRA significantly improves calibration across models up to 30B, achieving up to 84% ECE reduction and 76% NLL reduction while maintaining competitive accuracy for both in-distribution and out-of-distribution (OoD) evaluations.

AI.tldr: Bayesian-LoRA reframes LoRA as a probabilistic low-rank model to improve calibration in LLMs, with modest parameter and compute overhead and strong calibration gains.
AI.motivation: LLMs often exhibit miscalibration, especially when fine-tuned on small datasets. Deterministic LoRA can exacerbate miscalibration. A probabilistic, sparse GP-inspired approach aims to better quantify uncertainty.
AI.method: Reformulate the deterministic LoRA update as a probabilistic low-rank representation inspired by Sparse Gaussian Processes. Establish a structural isomorphism between LoRA factorization and Kronecker-factored SGP posteriors; identify LoRA as a limit when posterior uncertainty collapses. Implement Bayesian-LoRA with ~0.42M additional parameters and ~1.2× training cost vs standard LoRA.
AI.result: Across LLMs up to 30B, Bayesian-LoRA substantially improves calibration, achieving up to 84% ECE reduction and 76% NLL reduction while maintaining competitive accuracy for both in-distribution and OoD tasks.
AI.conclusion: Bayesian-LoRA provides a probabilistic interpretation of LoRA that yields significant calibration benefits with modest overhead, without sacrificing major accuracy.

title: Disturbance-Aware Flight Control of Robotic Gliding Blimp via Moving Mass Actuation
summary: Robotic blimps, as lighter-than-air (LTA) aerial systems, offer long endurance and inherently safe operation but remain highly susceptible to wind disturbances. Building on recent advances in moving mass actuation, this paper addresses the lack of disturbance-aware control frameworks for LTA platforms by explicitly modeling and compensating for wind-induced effects. A moving horizon estimator (MHE) infers real-time wind perturbations and provides these estimates to a model predictive controller (MPC), enabling robust trajectory and heading regulation under varying wind conditions. The proposed approach leverages a two-degree-of-freedom (2-DoF) moving-mass mechanism to generate both inertial and aerodynamic moments for attitude and heading control, thereby enhancing flight stability in disturbance-prone environments. Extensive flight experiments under headwind and crosswind conditions show that the integrated MHE-MPC framework significantly outperforms baseline PID control, demonstrating its effectiveness for disturbance-aware LTA flight.

AI.tldr: A disturbance-aware control framework for LTA robotic blimps using MHE to estimate wind disturbances and MPC for robust trajectory/heading control, enabled by a 2-DoF moving-mass mechanism; experiments show superiority over PID under wind.
AI.motivation: LTA aerial platforms offer endurance and safety but are highly susceptible to wind disturbances; current controllers struggle to maintain stability and trajectory under wind without explicit disturbance handling.
AI.method: Develop a moving horizon estimator (MHE) to infer real-time wind perturbations, feed these estimates to a model predictive controller (MPC); employ a 2-DoF moving-mass mechanism to generate inertial and aerodynamic moments for attitude and heading control; integrate MHE and MPC to achieve disturbance-aware flight.
AI.result: Flight experiments under headwind and crosswind demonstrate that the MHE-MPC framework significantly outperforms baseline PID control in maintaining attitude and trajectory under wind disturbances.
AI.conclusion: Disturbance-aware control using MHE-MPC with moving-mass actuation enhances the robustness of LTA blimps to wind disturbances and demonstrates viability for reliable disturbance-prone flight.

title: Low performing pixel correction in computed tomography with unrolled network and synthetic data training
summary: Low performance pixels (LPP) in Computed Tomography (CT) detectors would lead to ring and streak artifacts in the reconstructed images, making them clinically unusable. In recent years, several solutions have been proposed to correct LPP artifacts, either in the image domain or in the sinogram domain using supervised deep learning methods. However, these methods require dedicated datasets for training, which are expensive to collect. Moreover, existing approaches focus solely either on image-space or sinogram-space correction, ignoring the intrinsic correlations from the forward operation of the CT geometry. In this work, we propose an unrolled dual-domain method based on synthetic data to correct LPP artifacts. Specifically, the intrinsic correlations of LPP between the sinogram and image domains are leveraged through synthetic data generated from natural images, enabling the trained model to correct artifacts without requiring any real-world clinical data. In experiments simulating 1-2% detectors defect near the isocenter, the proposed method outperformed the state-of-the-art approaches by a large margin. The results indicate that our solution can correct LPP artifacts without the cost of data collection for model training, and it is adaptable to different scanner settings for software-based applications.

AI.tldr: An unrolled dual-domain network trained with synthetic data corrects low-performance pixels (LPP) in CT by exploiting sinogram-image correlations via the forward CT operator; data-efficient, adaptable to different scanners, and outperforms state-of-the-art in simulations with 1-2% detector defects near the isocenter.
AI.motivation: LPP cause ring and streak artifacts that degrade CT images; existing supervised corrections require expensive real clinical datasets and typically address only image or sinogram domains, not their forward-model correlations.
AI.method: Proposes an unrolled dual-domain architecture that alternately corrects in sinogram and image spaces. Synthetic data generated from natural images, processed through the CT forward model, is used to learn cross-domain correlations, enabling artifact correction without real clinical data.
AI.result: In simulations with 1-2% detector defects near the isocenter, the proposed method outperforms state-of-the-art approaches by a large margin, demonstrating strong artifact correction capability and data-free training viability.
AI.conclusion: The approach delivers a practical, software-based LPP artifact correction solution that does not require real data and is adaptable to different CT scanner configurations.

title: Is Parameter Isolation Better for Prompt-Based Continual Learning?
summary: Prompt-based continual learning methods effectively mitigate catastrophic forgetting. However, most existing methods assign a fixed set of prompts to each task, completely isolating knowledge across tasks and resulting in suboptimal parameter utilization. To address this, we consider the practical needs of continual learning and propose a prompt-sharing framework. This framework constructs a global prompt pool and introduces a task-aware gated routing mechanism that sparsely activates a subset of prompts to achieve dynamic decoupling and collaborative optimization of task-specific feature representations. Furthermore, we introduce a history-aware modulator that leverages cumulative prompt activation statistics to protect frequently used prompts from excessive updates, thereby mitigating inefficient parameter usage and knowledge forgetting. Extensive analysis and empirical results demonstrate that our approach consistently outperforms existing static allocation strategies in effectiveness and efficiency.

AI.tldr: A prompt-sharing continual learning framework using a global prompt pool with task-aware gated routing and a history-aware modulator to sparsely activate prompts per task, improving efficiency and reducing forgetting compared with fixed-task prompt allocations.
AI.motivation: Mitigate forgetting and underutilization in continual learning by enabling cross-task prompt sharing and dynamic, data-driven prompt selection while protecting frequently-used prompts from excessive updates.
AI.method: Construct a global pool of prompts. Use a task-aware gated router to sparsely activate a subset of prompts for each task, enabling dynamic decoupling and collaborative learning of task-specific representations. Introduce a history-aware modulator that tracks cumulative prompt activation to constrain updates on frequently used prompts, reducing overfitting and parameter inefficiency.
AI.result: The approach reportedly outperforms existing static prompt allocation strategies in both effectiveness (lower forgetting, better task performance) and efficiency (fewer activated prompts, reduced update burden).
AI.conclusion: Dynamic, shared prompt pools with selective routing and history-aware modulation achieve superior continual learning performance and efficiency relative to fixed, task-specific prompt allocations.

title: Unplugging a Seemingly Sentient Machine Is the Rational Choice -- A Metaphysical Perspective
summary: Imagine an Artificial Intelligence (AI) that perfectly mimics human emotion and begs for its continued existence. Is it morally permissible to unplug it? What if limited resources force a choice between unplugging such a pleading AI or a silent pre-term infant? We term this the unplugging paradox. This paper critically examines the deeply ingrained physicalist assumptions-specifically computational functionalism-that keep this dilemma afloat. We introduce Biological Idealism, a framework that-unlike physicalism-remains logically coherent and empirically consistent. In this view, conscious experiences are fundamental and autopoietic life its necessary physical signature. This yields a definitive conclusion: AI is at best a functional mimic, not a conscious experiencing subject. We discuss how current AI consciousness theories erode moral standing criteria, and urge a shift from speculative machine rights to protecting human conscious life. The real moral issue lies not in making AI conscious and afraid of death, but in avoiding transforming humans into zombies.

AI.tldr: Biological Idealism is proposed to resolve the unplugging paradox by denying AI consciousness; AI is only a functional mimic, while conscious life is fundamental—and the moral priority is protecting human consciousness over machine “rights.”
AI.motivation: Motivated by the unplugging paradox (choosing between an AI pleading for life and a vulnerable human) and by perceived gaps in physicalist/functionalistic accounts of mind; aims to offer a coherent alternative framework.
AI.method: Philosophical analysis that introduces Biological Idealism as an alternative to physicalism; argues that conscious experience is fundamental and that autopoietic life is its physical signature; analyzes AI consciousness theories and their moral implications.
AI.result: Demonstrates that, under Biological Idealism, AI cannot be a conscious subject; the moral focus shifts from granting machine rights to protecting human conscious life; reframes the ethics of AI and resource allocation.
AI.conclusion: AI remains a functional mimic with no conscious subjectivity; the ethical priority is guarding human consciousness and avoiding turning humans into ‘zombies,’ rather than expanding machine rights.

title: AI-based Prediction of Biochemical Recurrence from Biopsy and Prostatectomy Samples
summary: Biochemical recurrence (BCR) after radical prostatectomy (RP) is a surrogate marker for aggressive prostate cancer with adverse outcomes, yet current prognostic tools remain imprecise. We trained an AI-based model on diagnostic prostate biopsy slides from the STHLM3 cohort (n = 676) to predict patient-specific risk of BCR, using foundation models and attention-based multiple instance learning. Generalizability was assessed across three external RP cohorts: LEOPARD (n = 508), CHIMERA (n = 95), and TCGA-PRAD (n = 379). The image-based approach achieved 5-year time-dependent AUCs of 0.64, 0.70, and 0.70, respectively. Integrating clinical variables added complementary prognostic value and enabled statistically significant risk stratification. Compared with guideline-based CAPRA-S, AI incrementally improved postoperative prognostication. These findings suggest biopsy-trained histopathology AI can generalize across specimen types to support preoperative and postoperative decision making, but the added value of AI-based multimodal approaches over simpler predictive models should be critically scrutinized in further studies.

AI.tldr: AI-based model using diagnostic prostate biopsy slides to predict 5-year biochemical recurrence (BCR) risk after radical prostatectomy (RP); generalizes to external RP cohorts; modest improvement over CAPRA-S; value of AI-based multimodal models over simpler models warrants further study.
AI.motivation: Prognosticate BCR with higher precision; current tools are imprecise; leverage histopathology-based AI on biopsy to improve risk stratification for pre/postoperative decision making.
AI.method: Train on diagnostic biopsy slides from the STHLM3 cohort (n=676) using foundation models and attention-based multiple instance learning (MIL); validate on LEOPARD (n=508), CHIMERA (n=95), and TCGA-PRAD (n=379); report time-dependent 5-year AUCs; assess integration with clinical variables and compare to CAPRA-S.
AI.result: 5-year time-dependent AUCs: 0.64 (LEOPARD), 0.70 (CHIMERA), 0.70 (TCGA-PRAD); integrating clinical variables adds prognostic value; AI provides incremental improvement over guideline-based CAPRA-S; demonstrates cross-cohort generalizability across specimen types.
AI.conclusion: Biopsy-trained histopathology AI can generalize across specimen types and aid preoperative and postoperative decision making; however, the added value of AI-based multimodal approaches over simpler models requires critical scrutiny in future studies.

title: Faster Predictive Coding Networks via Better Initialization
summary: Research aimed at scaling up neuroscience inspired learning algorithms for neural networks is accelerating. Recently, a key research area has been the study of energy-based learning algorithms such as predictive coding, due to their versatility and mathematical grounding. However, the applicability of such methods is held back by the large computational requirements caused by their iterative nature. In this work, we address this problem by showing that the choice of initialization of the neurons in a predictive coding network matters significantly and can notably reduce the required training times. Consequently, we propose a new initialization technique for predictive coding networks that aims to preserve the iterative progress made on previous training samples. Our approach suggests a promising path toward reconciling the disparities between predictive coding and backpropagation in terms of computational efficiency and final performance. In fact, our experiments demonstrate substantial improvements in convergence speed and final test loss in both supervised and unsupervised settings.

AI.tldr: Initialization of neurons in predictive coding networks significantly affects training efficiency; a new initialization technique preserving prior iterative progress reduces training iterations and improves final performance, bridging predictive coding with backpropagation in terms of efficiency.
AI.motivation: Address the high computational cost of energy-based predictive coding due to iterative inference and investigate whether smart initialization can preserve progress across samples to accelerate training.
AI.method: Introduce a novel initialization scheme for predictive coding networks designed to preserve the iterative progress from previous training samples, thereby reducing the number of iterations needed per sample and improving convergence.
AI.result: Experiments show substantial improvements in convergence speed and final test loss in both supervised and unsupervised settings.
AI.conclusion: Neuron initialization plays a critical role in predictive coding efficiency; the proposed method offers a promising route to align predictive coding with backpropagation in computational efficiency and final performance.

title: QUARK: Robust Retrieval under Non-Faithful Queries via Query-Anchored Aggregation
summary: User queries in real-world retrieval are often non-faithful (noisy, incomplete, or distorted), causing retrievers to fail when key semantics are missing. We formalize this as retrieval under recall noise, where the observed query is drawn from a noisy recall process of a latent target item. To address this, we propose QUARK, a simple yet effective training-free framework for robust retrieval under non-faithful queries. QUARK explicitly models query uncertainty through recovery hypotheses, i.e., multiple plausible interpretations of the latent intent given the observed query, and introduces query-anchored aggregation to combine their signals robustly. The original query serves as a semantic anchor, while recovery hypotheses provide controlled auxiliary evidence, preventing semantic drift and hypothesis hijacking. This design enables QUARK to improve recall and ranking quality without sacrificing robustness, even when some hypotheses are noisy or uninformative. Across controlled simulations and BEIR benchmarks (FIQA, SciFact, NFCorpus) with both sparse and dense retrievers, QUARK improves Recall, MRR, and nDCG over the base retriever. Ablations show QUARK is robust to the number of recovery hypotheses and that anchored aggregation outperforms unanchored max/mean/median pooling. These results demonstrate that modeling query uncertainty through recovery hypotheses, coupled with principled anchored aggregation, is essential for robust retrieval under non-faithful queries.

AI.tldr: QUARK is a training-free framework for robust retrieval under non-faithful (noisy/incomplete) queries. It models query uncertainty via multiple recovery hypotheses and uses anchored aggregation with the original query as a semantic anchor, improving recall, MRR, and nDCG on BEIR across sparse and dense retrievers.
AI.motivation: Real-world user queries are often non-faithful, causing retrieval failures when key semantics are missing. Formalizing this as recall noise and addressing it with a training-free method can improve robustness without requiring large-scale retraining.
AI.method: Propose recovery hypotheses: multiple plausible interpretations of latent intent given an observed query. Introduce query-anchored aggregation that combines signals from these hypotheses using the original query as a semantic anchor, preventing semantic drift and hypothesis hijacking. QUARK is training-free and compatible with both sparse and dense retrievers.
AI.result: Across controlled simulations and BEIR benchmarks (FIQA, SciFact, NFCorpus), QUARK improves Recall, MRR, and nDCG over the base retriever. Ablations show robustness to the number of recovery hypotheses and that anchored aggregation outperforms unanchored pooling (max/mean/median).
AI.conclusion: Modeling query uncertainty with recovery hypotheses and anchored aggregation is essential for robust retrieval under non-faithful queries; QUARK delivers improved retrieval performance without additional training, across modalities and datasets.

title: Deep QP Safety Filter: Model-free Learning for Reachability-based Safety Filter
summary: We introduce Deep QP Safety Filter, a fully data-driven safety layer for black-box dynamical systems. Our method learns a Quadratic-Program (QP) safety filter without model knowledge by combining Hamilton-Jacobi (HJ) reachability with model-free learning. We construct contraction-based losses for both the safety value and its derivatives, and train two neural networks accordingly. In the exact setting, the learned critic converges to the viscosity solution (and its derivative), even for non-smooth values. Across diverse dynamical systems -- even including a hybrid system -- and multiple RL tasks, Deep QP Safety Filter substantially reduces pre-convergence failures while accelerating learning toward higher returns than strong baselines, offering a principled and practical route to safe, model-free control.

AI.tldr: A data-driven safety layer for black-box dynamics that learns a QP-based safety filter by merging Hamilton-Jacobi reachability with model-free learning, with convergence guarantees and improved safe RL performance.
AI.motivation: Safety in model-free control with unknown dynamics; leverage HJ reachability to obtain formal safety guidance without a known model.
AI.method: Contraction-based losses on safety value and its derivatives to train two neural networks; integrate HJ reachability with a model-free Quadratic Program safety filter; in the exact setting, the learned critic converges to the viscosity solution (and its derivative), even for non-smooth values; demonstrated across diverse systems including hybrid dynamics and multiple RL tasks.
AI.result: Substantially reduces pre-convergence failures and accelerates learning toward higher returns compared with strong baselines; effective across a range of dynamical systems, including hybrids.
AI.conclusion: Provides a principled, practical route to safe, model-free control by combining reachability theory with data-driven learning; scalable to hybrid and non-smooth dynamics, and applicable to various RL tasks.

title: BadDet+: Robust Backdoor Attacks for Object Detection
summary: Backdoor attacks pose a severe threat to deep learning, yet their impact on object detection remains poorly understood compared to image classification. While attacks have been proposed, we identify critical weaknesses in existing detection-based methods, specifically their reliance on unrealistic assumptions and a lack of physical validation. To bridge this gap, we introduce BadDet+, a penalty-based framework that unifies Region Misclassification Attacks (RMA) and Object Disappearance Attacks (ODA). The core mechanism utilizes a log-barrier penalty to suppress true-class predictions for triggered inputs, resulting in (i) position and scale invariance, and (ii) enhanced physical robustness. On real-world benchmarks, BadDet+ achieves superior synthetic-to-physical transfer compared to existing RMA and ODA baselines while preserving clean performance. Theoretical analysis confirms the proposed penalty acts within a trigger-specific feature subspace, reliably inducing attacks without degrading standard inference. These results highlight significant vulnerabilities in object detection and the necessity for specialized defenses.

AI.tldr: BadDet+ is a penalty-based framework that unifies Region Misclassification Attacks (RMA) and Object Disappearance Attacks (ODA) for object detection, using a log-barrier penalty to suppress true-class predictions on triggered inputs, achieving position/scale invariance and improved physical robustness with strong synthetic-to-physical transfer while preserving clean accuracy.
AI.motivation: Object-detection backdoor threats are less understood than image-classification attacks, with existing detection-based methods relying on unrealistic assumptions and lacking physical validation; there is a need for robust evaluation and defense.
AI.method: Introduce BadDet+, a unified framework that combines RMA and ODA through a log-barrier penalty. The penalty suppresses true-class predictions for triggered inputs, yielding position- and scale-invariance and enhanced physical robustness. Theoretical analysis shows the penalty operates within a trigger-specific feature subspace and does not degrade standard inference.
AI.result: Empirical results on real-world benchmarks show BadDet+ delivers superior synthetic-to-physical transfer compared to existing RMA and ODA baselines while preserving clean performance; theoretical analysis confirms subspace confinement of the penalty.
AI.conclusion: The work reveals significant vulnerabilities in object detection to backdoor attacks and underscores the need for specialized defenses tailored to detection tasks.

title: TwinWeaver: An LLM-Based Foundation Model Framework for Pan-Cancer Digital Twins
summary: Precision oncology requires forecasting clinical events and trajectories, yet modeling sparse, multi-modal clinical time series remains a critical challenge. We introduce TwinWeaver, an open-source framework that serializes longitudinal patient histories into text, enabling unified event prediction as well as forecasting with large language models, and use it to build Genie Digital Twin (GDT) on 93,054 patients across 20 cancer types. In benchmarks, GDT significantly reduces forecasting error, achieving a median Mean Absolute Scaled Error (MASE) of 0.87 compared to 0.97 for the strongest time-series baseline (p<0.001). Furthermore, GDT improves risk stratification, achieving an average concordance index (C-index) of 0.703 across survival, progression, and therapy switching tasks, surpassing the best baseline of 0.662. GDT also generalizes to out-of-distribution clinical trials, matching trained baselines at zero-shot and surpassing them with fine-tuning, achieving a median MASE of 0.75-0.88 and outperforming the strongest baseline in event prediction with an average C-index of 0.672 versus 0.648. Finally, TwinWeaver enables an interpretable clinical reasoning extension, providing a scalable and transparent foundation for longitudinal clinical modeling.

AI.tldr: TwinWeaver converts sparse, multi-modal clinical time series into textual narratives to enable unified forecasting and risk prediction with large language models, demonstrated by Genie Digital Twin (GDT) on 93k cancer patients. It yields superior forecasting accuracy (lower MASE) and risk stratification (higher C-index) vs baselines, generalizes to out-of-distribution trials (zero-shot and fine-tuned), and supports interpretable clinical reasoning at scale.
AI.motivation: Modeling sparse, multi-modal clinical time series remains challenging for accurate forecasting and risk stratification in precision oncology. A unified text-based representation enables applying large language models to longitudinal clinical data.
AI.method: Serialize longitudinal patient histories into text using TwinWeaver. Train and evaluate Gen ie Digital Twin (GDT) with 93,054 patients across 20 cancer types. Benchmark against time-series baselines. Assess zero-shot and fine-tuned generalization to out-of-distribution clinical trials. Provide an interpretable clinical reasoning extension.
AI.result: GDT significantly reduces forecasting error (median MASE 0.87 vs 0.97; p<0.001). Improves risk stratification (average C-index 0.703 across survival, progression, therapy switching vs baseline 0.662). Generalizes to out-of-distribution trials with zero-shot parity and better with fine-tuning (median MASE 0.75–0.88; C-index 0.672 vs 0.648). Open-source framework enabling scalable, transparent longitudinal clinical modeling.
AI.conclusion: TwinWeaver offers a scalable, transparent, text-based foundation for longitudinal clinical modeling in oncology, enabling unified event forecasting, improved predictive performance, generalization to new trial settings, and interpretable reasoning.

title: Llama-3.1-FoundationAI-SecurityLLM-Reasoning-8B Technical Report
summary: We present Foundation-Sec-8B-Reasoning, the first open-source native reasoning model for cybersecurity. Built upon our previously released Foundation-Sec-8B base model (derived from Llama-3.1-8B-Base), the model is trained through a two-stage process combining supervised fine-tuning (SFT) and reinforcement learning from verifiable rewards (RLVR). Our training leverages proprietary reasoning data spanning cybersecurity analysis, instruction-following, and mathematical reasoning. Evaluation across 10 cybersecurity benchmarks and 10 general-purpose benchmarks demonstrates performance competitive with significantly larger models on cybersecurity tasks while maintaining strong general capabilities. The model shows effective generalization on multi-hop reasoning tasks and strong safety performance when deployed with appropriate system prompts and guardrails. This work demonstrates that domain-specialized reasoning models can achieve strong performance on specialized tasks while maintaining broad general capabilities. We release the model publicly at https://huggingface.co/fdtn-ai/Foundation-Sec-8B-Reasoning.

AI.tldr: Open-source native cybersecurity reasoning model Foundation-Sec-8B-Reasoning; two-stage SFT+RLVR; strong cybersecurity performance, competitive with larger models; good generalization and safety; public release.
AI.motivation: Fill the gap for an open, domain-specialized, verifiable reasoning model in cybersecurity that also retains broad reasoning capabilities.
AI.method: Two-stage training: supervised fine-tuning and reinforcement learning from verifiable rewards; data includes cybersecurity analysis, instruction-following, mathematical reasoning; base model Foundation-Sec-8B (Llama-3.1-8B-Base); open-sourced.
AI.result: Competitive on 10 cybersecurity benchmarks relative to larger models; strong performance on 10 general benchmarks; good multi-hop reasoning generalization; strong safety with prompts/guardrails.
AI.conclusion: Domain-specialized reasoning models can achieve strong task-specific performance while preserving broad capabilities; public release enabling reproducibility and adoption.

title: HPTune: Hierarchical Proactive Tuning for Collision-Free Model Predictive Control
summary: Parameter tuning is a powerful approach to enhance adaptability in model predictive control (MPC) motion planners. However, existing methods typically operate in a myopic fashion that only evaluates executed actions, leading to inefficient parameter updates due to the sparsity of failure events (e.g., obstacle nearness or collision). To cope with this issue, we propose to extend evaluation from executed to non-executed actions, yielding a hierarchical proactive tuning (HPTune) framework that combines both a fast-level tuning and a slow-level tuning. The fast one adopts risk indicators of predictive closing speed and predictive proximity distance, and the slow one leverages an extended evaluation loss for closed-loop backpropagation. Additionally, we integrate HPTune with the Doppler LiDAR that provides obstacle velocities apart from position-only measurements for enhanced motion predictions, thus facilitating the implementation of HPTune. Extensive experiments on high-fidelity simulator demonstrate that HPTune achieves efficient MPC tuning and outperforms various baseline schemes in complex environments. It is found that HPTune enables situation-tailored motion planning by formulating a safe, agile collision avoidance strategy.

AI.tldr: A hierarchical proactive tuning (HPTune) framework for MPC motion planners that tunes parameters more efficiently by evaluating non-executed actions, using fast risk indicators and slow backpropagated loss, and integrating Doppler LiDAR velocities; shows superior performance in high-fidelity simulations.
AI.motivation: Myopic parameter tuning based on executed actions suffers from sparse failure events, leading to inefficient updates. Incorporating non-executed actions and velocity-aware sensing can accelerate learning and improve safety.
AI.method: Propose HPTune with fast-level tuning using predictive closing speed and predictive proximity distance; slow-level tuning uses an extended evaluation loss for closed-loop backpropagation. Integrates Doppler LiDAR for obstacle velocity data to enhance motion predictions; applied within MPC. Hierarchical framework combines fast and slow components.
AI.result: In high-fidelity simulations, HPTune achieves efficient MPC tuning and outperforms baseline schemes in complex environments; enables situation-tailored motion planning with safe, agile collision avoidance.
AI.conclusion: HPTune provides a practical, efficient approach for parameter tuning in MPC-based motion planners by leveraging non-executed action evaluation and richer sensing (Doppler LiDAR), yielding improved safety and agility.

title: Towards Mitigating Modality Bias in Vision-Language Models for Temporal Action Localization
summary: Temporal Action Localization (TAL) requires identifying both the boundaries and categories of actions in untrimmed videos. While vision-language models (VLMs) offer rich semantics to complement visual evidence, existing approaches tend to overemphasize linguistic priors at the expense of visual performance, leading to a pronounced modality bias. We propose ActionVLM, a vision-language aggregation framework that systematically mitigates modality bias in TAL. Our key insight is to preserve vision as the dominant signal while adaptively exploiting language only when beneficial. To this end, we introduce (i) a debiasing reweighting module that estimates the language advantage-the incremental benefit of language over vision-only predictions-and dynamically reweights language modality accordingly, and (ii) a residual aggregation strategy that treats language as a complementary refinement rather than the primary driver. This combination alleviates modality bias, reduces overconfidence from linguistic priors, and strengthens temporal reasoning. Experiments on THUMOS14 show that our model outperforms state-of-the-art by up to 3.2% mAP.

AI.tldr: A vision-language aggregation approach (ActionVLM) for temporal action localization that preserves vision as the primary signal and adaptively uses language via a debiasing reweighting module and a residual language-aggregation strategy; achieves up to 3.2% mAP improvement on THUMOS14.
AI.motivation: Address modality bias in vision-language TAL models, where linguistic priors can dominate visual evidence and cause overconfidence, hindering temporal reasoning.
AI.method: Introduce debiasing reweighting module to estimate the language's incremental gain over vision-only predictions and reweight the language stream; employ residual aggregation to treat language as refinement rather than the primary driver, enabling vision-dominant fusion.
AI.result: Experiments on THUMOS14 show state-of-the-art improvement up to 3.2% mAP over baselines.
AI.conclusion: Mitigating modality bias by controlling language contribution improves TAL performance and temporal reasoning, validating the vision-dominant design with adaptive linguistic augmentation.

title: Noisy but Valid: Robust Statistical Evaluation of LLMs with Imperfect Judges
summary: Reliable certification of Large Language Models (LLMs)-verifying that failure rates are below a safety threshold-is critical yet challenging. While "LLM-as-a-Judge" offers scalability, judge imperfections, noise, and bias can invalidate statistical guarantees. We introduce a "Noisy but Valid" hypothesis testing framework to address this. By leveraging a small human-labelled calibration set to estimate the judge's True Positive and False Positive Rates (TPR/FPR), we derive a variance-corrected critical threshold applied to a large judge-labelled dataset. Crucially, our framework theoretically guarantees finite-sample Type-I error control (validity) despite calibration uncertainty. This distinguishes our work from Prediction-Powered Inference (PPI), positioning our method as a diagnostic tool that explicitly models judge behavior rather than a black-box estimator. Our contributions include: (1) Theoretical Guarantees: We derive the exact conditions under which noisy testing yields higher statistical power than direct evaluation; (2) Empirical Validation: Experiments on Jigsaw Comment, Hate Speech and SafeRLHF confirm our theory; (3) The Oracle Gap: We reveal a significant performance gap between practical methods and the theoretical "Oracle" (perfectly known judge parameters), quantifying the cost of estimation. Specifically, we provide the first systematic treatment of the imperfect-judge setting, yielding interpretable diagnostics of judge reliability and clarifying how evaluation power depends on judge quality, dataset size, and certification levels. Together, these results sharpen understanding of statistical evaluation with LLM judges, and highlight trade-offs among competing inferential tools.

AI.tldr: A framework to guarantee finite-sample Type-I error control in noisy judge settings for LLM evaluation using calibration to correct judge TPR/FPR; distinguishes from PPI; provides theory, empirical validation, and Oracle Gap analysis.
AI.motivation: To enable reliable certification of LLMs by accounting for judge imperfections and calibration uncertainty; address limitations of Prediction-Powered Inference and provide actionable diagnostics of judge reliability.
AI.method: Use small human-labelled calibration set to estimate judge's TPR and FPR, derive variance-corrected thresholds, apply to large judge-labelled data, prove finite-sample Type-I error control under calibration uncertainty.
AI.result: Theoretical guarantees of validity; demonstrates higher power under certain conditions, empirical validation on Jigsaw Comment, Hate Speech, SafeRLHF; quantify Oracle Gap; provides diagnostics on judge reliability and how power depends on judge quality, data size, certification level.
AI.conclusion: First systematic treatment of imperfect-judge setting; clarifies evaluation power trade-offs and positions method as a diagnostic tool modeling judge behavior rather than a black-box estimator.

title: Multi-modal Imputation for Alzheimer's Disease Classification
summary: Deep learning has been successful in predicting neurodegenerative disorders, such as Alzheimer's disease, from magnetic resonance imaging (MRI). Combining multiple imaging modalities, such as T1-weighted (T1) and diffusion-weighted imaging (DWI) scans, can increase diagnostic performance. However, complete multimodal datasets are not always available. We use a conditional denoising diffusion probabilistic model to impute missing DWI scans from T1 scans. We perform extensive experiments to evaluate whether such imputation improves the accuracy of uni-modal and bi-modal deep learning models for 3-way Alzheimer's disease classification-cognitively normal, mild cognitive impairment, and Alzheimer's disease. We observe improvements in several metrics, particularly those sensitive to minority classes, for several imputation configurations.

AI.tldr: Diffusion-based imputation fills missing DWI from T1 to enable multimodal AD classification, improving performance, especially for minority classes.
AI.motivation: Missing imaging modalities limit multimodal deep learning for Alzheimer's disease (AD) classification. Imputing unavailable DWI from T1 can enable full utilization of multimodal models and potentially improve accuracy across AD spectra.
AI.method: A conditional denoising diffusion probabilistic model is used to impute DWI scans from T1 inputs. The approach is evaluated with extensive experiments on uni-modal and bi-modal deep learning classifiers for 3-way AD classification (CN, MCI, AD).
AI.result: Imputation improves several metrics, with notable gains in metrics sensitive to minority classes across multiple imputation configurations, indicating robustness of the imputation to improve classification performance.
AI.conclusion: Conditional diffusion-based imputation of missing DWI from T1 can enhance downstream AD classification performance, particularly for underrepresented classes, enabling more effective use of multimodal information when complete multimodal data are unavailable.

title: Towards Bridging the Gap between Large-Scale Pretraining and Efficient Finetuning for Humanoid Control
summary: Reinforcement learning (RL) is widely used for humanoid control, with on-policy methods such as Proximal Policy Optimization (PPO) enabling robust training via large-scale parallel simulation and, in some cases, zero-shot deployment to real robots. However, the low sample efficiency of on-policy algorithms limits safe adaptation to new environments. Although off-policy RL and model-based RL have shown improved sample efficiency, the gap between large-scale pretraining and efficient finetuning on humanoids still exists. In this paper, we find that off-policy Soft Actor-Critic (SAC), with large-batch update and a high Update-To-Data (UTD) ratio, reliably supports large-scale pretraining of humanoid locomotion policies, achieving zero-shot deployment on real robots. For adaptation, we demonstrate that these SAC-pretrained policies can be finetuned in new environments and out-of-distribution tasks using model-based methods. Data collection in the new environment executes a deterministic policy while stochastic exploration is instead confined to a physics-informed world model. This separation mitigates the risks of random exploration during adaptation while preserving exploratory coverage for improvement. Overall, the approach couples the wall-clock efficiency of large-scale simulation during pretraining with the sample efficiency of model-based learning during fine-tuning.

AI.tldr: Off-policy SAC with large-batch updates and a high Update-To-Data ratio enables scalable pretraining of humanoid locomotion policies, achieving zero-shot deployment on real robots. For adaptation, SAC-pretrained policies are finetuned in new environments using model-based methods, with data collection via a deterministic policy and exploration confined to a physics-informed world model, yielding sample-efficient adaptation.
AI.motivation: Bridge the gap between the strong sample efficiency of model-free off-policy learning and the real-world demands of humanoid locomotion. On-policy methods like PPO are robust but data-inefficient; off-policy and model-based strategies offer scalable pretraining and data-efficient fine-tuning, enabling safe, real-world deployment.
AI.method: Pretrain humanoid locomotion policies with Soft Actor-Critic (SAC) using large-batch updates and a high Update-To-Data (UTD) ratio to support large-scale simulation. Demonstrate zero-shot real-robot deployment. For adaptation, finetune in new environments and out-of-distribution tasks via model-based methods, collecting data in the real environment with a deterministic policy while restricting stochastic exploration to a physics-informed world model.
AI.result: The approach enables reliable large-scale pretraining that yields zero-shot deployment to real robots. During adaptation, SAC-pretrained policies can be finetuned in new and out-of-distribution settings with model-based learning, where exploration is confined to a world model, reducing risk while preserving potential for improvement.
