MADE simulates closed-loop discovery campaigns in which an agent or algorithm proposes, evaluates, and refines candidate materials under a constrained oracle budget, capturing the sequential and resource-limited nature of real discovery workflows. We formalize discovery as a search for thermodynamically stable compounds relative to a given convex hull, and evaluate efficacy and efficiency via comparison to baseline algorithms. The framework is flexible; users can compose discovery agents from interchangeable components such as generative models, filters, and planners, enabling the study of arbitrary workflows ranging from fixed pipelines to fully agentic systems with tool use and adaptive decision making. We demonstrate this by conducting systematic experiments across a family of systems, enabling ablation of components in discovery pipelines, and comparison of how methods scale with system complexity.

AI.tldr: MADE provides a flexible, end-to-end benchmark framework for autonomous materials discovery, simulating closed-loop campaigns under limited budgets and enabling modular, agent-based workflows; formalizes discovery as seeking thermodynamically stable compounds on a convex hull and benchmarks efficacy and efficiency across system complexities.
AI.motivation: Current benchmarks emphasize static predictions or isolated tasks and fail to capture the iterative, resource-constrained nature of real discovery. A standardized, end-to-end benchmark is needed to study adaptive decision making, component interactions, and scalability in materials discovery pipelines.
AI.method: Introduce MAterials Discovery Environments (MADE) as a simulation framework for closed-loop discovery campaigns. Define discovery as finding thermodynamically stable compounds relative to a convex hull. Implement a modular architecture allowing interchangeable components (generative models, filters, planners). Evaluate with baseline comparisons and ablations across multiple system families to study component impact and scalability.
AI.result: Demonstrated feasibility through systematic experiments across a family of systems, enabling ablation studies of pipeline components and analysis of how methods scale with system complexity; provides empirical evidence on the effect of different components and configurations on discovery performance.
AI.conclusion: MADE offers a flexible, extensible benchmark for end-to-end autonomous materials discovery, enabling controlled experiments on component interactions, resource trade-offs, and scalability, thereby accelerating understanding and development of automated discovery pipelines.

title: What You Feel Is Not What They See: On Predicting Self-Reported Emotion from Third-Party Observer Labels
comment: ICASSP 2026-2026 IEEE International Conference on Acoustics, Speech and Signal Processing (ICASSP)
summary: Self-reported emotion labels capture internal experience, while third-party labels reflect external perception. These perspectives often diverge, limiting the applicability of third-party-trained models to self-report contexts. This gap is critical in mental health, where accurate self-report modeling is essential for guiding intervention. We present the first cross-corpus evaluation of third-party-trained models on self-reports. We find activation unpredictable (CCC approximately 0) and valence moderately predictable (CCC approximately 0.3). Crucially, when content is personally significant to the speaker, models achieve high performance for valence (CCC approximately 0.6-0.8). Our findings point to personal significance as a key pathway for aligning external perception with internal experience and underscore the challenge of self-report activation modeling.

AI.tldr: Third-party emotion models show limited transfer to self-reported activation but can predict valence moderately, especially when content is personally significant to the speaker.
AI.motivation: To address the gap between externally labeled emotions and internal self-reports, which is critical for accurate mental-health modeling and intervention guidance.
AI.method: Cross-corpus evaluation of models trained on third-party labels applied to self-reported data; evaluation using concordance correlation coefficient (CCC) for activation and valence; analysis of the impact of personal significance on predictive performance.
AI.result: Activation is largely unpredictable (CCC ≈ 0). Valence is moderately predictable (CCC ≈ 0.3) overall; when content is personally significant, valence prediction improves substantially (CCC ≈ 0.6–0.8).
AI.conclusion: Personal significance emerges as a key factor to align external perception with internal experience; self-report activation modeling remains challenging and may require personalization or signal-level alignment strategies.

title: Don't double it: Efficient Agent Prediction in Occlusions
summary: Occluded traffic agents pose a significant challenge for autonomous vehicles, as hidden pedestrians or vehicles can appear unexpectedly, yet this problem remains understudied. Existing learning-based methods, while capable of inferring the presence of hidden agents, often produce redundant occupancy predictions where a single agent is identified multiple times. This issue complicates downstream planning and increases computational load. To address this, we introduce MatchInformer, a novel transformer-based approach that builds on the state-of-the-art SceneInformer architecture. Our method improves upon prior work by integrating Hungarian Matching, a state-of-the-art object matching algorithm from object detection, into the training process to enforce a one-to-one correspondence between predictions and ground truth, thereby reducing redundancy. We further refine trajectory forecasts by decoupling an agent's heading from its motion, a strategy that improves the accuracy and interpretability of predicted paths. To better handle class imbalances, we propose using the Matthews Correlation Coefficient (MCC) to evaluate occupancy predictions. By considering all entries in the confusion matrix, MCC provides a robust measure even in sparse or imbalanced scenarios. Experiments on the Waymo Open Motion Dataset demonstrate that our approach improves reasoning about occluded regions and produces more accurate trajectory forecasts than prior methods.

AI.tldr: Introduces MatchInformer, a transformer-based model for occluded traffic agents building on SceneInformer, using Hungarian Matching to enforce one-to-one predictions, decouples heading from motion for better trajectory forecasts, and uses Matthews Correlation Coefficient to evaluate occupancy; shows improved occlusion reasoning and trajectory accuracy on Waymo Open Motion Dataset.
AI.motivation: Occluded agents pose safety-critical challenges in autonomous driving. Existing methods often produce redundant occupancy predictions and struggle with sparse/imbalanced data, hindering downstream planning.
AI.method: Extend SceneInformer with Hungarian Matching to enforce one-to-one correspondence between predictions and ground truth during training; decouple an agent's heading from its motion to improve trajectory interpretability; evaluate occupancy with Matthews Correlation Coefficient; apply transformer-based architecture (MatchInformer) on Waymo Open Motion Dataset.
AI.result: Better reasoning about occluded regions and more accurate trajectory forecasts than prior methods; reduced prediction redundancy due to one-to-one matching; MCC provides robust evaluation under imbalance.
AI.conclusion: MatchInformer advances occluded traffic agent reasoning and trajectory forecasting by integrating one-to-one matching and heading-motion decoupling; MCC offers robust occupancy evaluation, with improved results on Waymo Open Motion Dataset.

title: PTQ4ARVG: Post-Training Quantization for AutoRegressive Visual Generation Models
summary: AutoRegressive Visual Generation (ARVG) models retain an architecture compatible with language models, while achieving performance comparable to diffusion-based models. Quantization is commonly employed in neural networks to reduce model size and computational latency. However, applying quantization to ARVG remains largely underexplored, and existing quantization methods fail to generalize effectively to ARVG models. In this paper, we explore this issue and identify three key challenges: (1) severe outliers at channel-wise level, (2) highly dynamic activations at token-wise level, and (3) mismatched distribution information at sample-wise level. To these ends, we propose PTQ4ARVG, a training-free post-training quantization (PTQ) framework consisting of: (1) Gain-Projected Scaling (GPS) mitigates the channel-wise outliers, which expands the quantization loss via a Taylor series to quantify the gain of scaling for activation-weight quantization, and derives the optimal scaling factor through differentiation.(2) Static Token-Wise Quantization (STWQ) leverages the inherent properties of ARVG, fixed token length and position-invariant distribution across samples, to address token-wise variance without incurring dynamic calibration overhead.(3) Distribution-Guided Calibration (DGC) selects samples that contribute most to distributional entropy, eliminating the sample-wise distribution mismatch. Extensive experiments show that PTQ4ARVG can effectively quantize the ARVG family models to 8-bit and 6-bit while maintaining competitive performance. Code is available at http://github.com/BienLuky/PTQ4ARVG .

AI.tldr: Proposes PTQ4ARVG, a training-free post-training quantization framework for AutoRegressive Visual Generation (ARVG) models. It addresses three ARVG-specific quantization challenges—channel-wise outliers, token-wise activation dynamics, and sample-wise distribution misalignment—via Gain-Projected Scaling (GPS), Static Token-Wise Quantization (STWQ), and Distribution-Guided Calibration (DGC). Demonstrates 8-bit and 6-bit quantization with competitive performance and provides code.
AI.motivation: ARVG models, aligned with language-model architectures, stand to benefit from quantization to reduce model size and latency. However, existing quantization methods struggle to generalize to ARVG due to three specific challenges: (1) severe channel-wise outliers in activations, (2) highly dynamic, token-wise activations across sequence generation, and (3) distribution mismatch at the sample level during calibration.
AI.method: GPS mitigates channel-wise outliers by quantifying the gain of activation-weight scaling with a Taylor-series expansion and deriving the optimal scaling via differentiation. STWQ exploits ARVG properties—fixed token length and a distribution that is invariant across samples—to stabilize token-wise quantization without dynamic calibration. DGC selects calibration samples that contribute most to distributional entropy, addressing sample-wise distribution mismatch.
AI.result: Extensive experiments show PTQ4ARVG can quantize ARVG models to 8-bit and 6-bit with competitive performance compared to baselines.
AI.conclusion: PTQ4ARVG provides a training-free, post-training quantization framework tailored for ARVG, effectively addressing its unique challenges and enabling low-bit quantization. Code is released for reproducibility.

title: Solver-in-the-Loop: MDP-Based Benchmarks for Self-Correction and Behavioral Rationality in Operations Research
summary: Operations Research practitioners routinely debug infeasible models through an iterative process: analyzing Irreducible Infeasible Subsystems (\IIS{}), identifying constraint conflicts, and systematically repairing formulations until feasibility is achieved. Yet existing LLM benchmarks evaluate OR as one-shot translation -- given a problem description, generate solver code -- ignoring this diagnostic loop entirely. We introduce two benchmarks that place the \textbf{solver in the evaluation loop}. \textbf{\ORDebug{}} evaluates iterative self-correction through 5,000+ problems spanning 9 error types; each repair action triggers solver re-execution and \IIS{} recomputation, providing deterministic, verifiable feedback. \textbf{\ORBias{}} evaluates behavioral rationality through 2,000 newsvendor instances (1,000 ID + 1,000 OOD), measuring systematic deviations from closed-form optimal policies. Across 26 models and 12,000+ samples, we find that domain-specific RLVR training enables an 8B model to surpass frontier APIs: 95.3\% vs 86.2\% recovery rate (+9.1\%), 62.4\% vs 47.8\% diagnostic accuracy (+14.6\%), and 2.25 vs 3.78 steps to resolution (1.7$\times$ faster). On \ORBias{}, curriculum training achieves the only negative ID$\rightarrow$OOD bias drift among models evaluated (-9.6\%), reducing systematic bias by 48\% (from 20.0\% to 10.4\%). These results demonstrate that process-level evaluation with verifiable oracles enables targeted training that outperforms scale.

AI.tldr: Two new benchmarks insert the solver into the evaluation loop for OR models, enabling iterative self-correction with verifiable feedback. ORD Debug tests iterative repair over 5k+ problems; OR Bias assesses policy bias on newsvendor instances. Domain-specific RLVR training significantly improves large-model performance and reduces ID→OOD bias, outperforming frontier APIs and standard scaling.
AI.motivation: Traditional OR benchmarks treat model-to-solver output as a one-shot task, ignoring diagnostic loops used by practitioners to debug infeasibilities. There is a need for process-level evaluation with verifiable feedback to train and evaluate models capable of iterative error diagnosis and repair.
AI.method: ORD Debug: 5k+ problems, 9 error types; iterative repairs trigger solver re-execution and IIS recomputation with deterministic feedback. OR Bias: 2k newsvendor instances (ID and OOD) to measure deviation from closed-form policies. Evaluation across 26 models (~12k samples). Training uses domain-specific RLVR with curriculum strategies to improve guidance.
AI.result: On 8B models, RLVR-based training yields: recovery rate 95.3% vs 86.2% ( +9.1 pp ), diagnostic accuracy 62.4% vs 47.8% ( +14.6 pp ), steps to resolution 2.25 vs 3.78 ( 1.7× faster ). For OR Bias, curriculum training achieves the only negative ID→OOD bias drift (-9.6%), reducing systematic bias from 20.0% to 10.4% (≈48% reduction). Across 26 models and 12k+ samples, process-level evaluation with verifiable oracles outperforms scale.
AI.conclusion: Process-level evaluation with verifiable oracles enables targeted training that surpasses scaling trends, showing that iterative, feedback-driven benchmarking can yield substantial gains for OR reasoning in large language models.

title: BrainStack: Neuro-MoE with Functionally Guided Expert Routing for EEG-Based Language Decoding
summary: Decoding linguistic information from electroencephalography (EEG) remains challenging due to the brain's distributed and nonlinear organization. We present BrainStack, a functionally guided neuro-mixture-of-experts (Neuro-MoE) framework that models the brain's modular functional architecture through anatomically partitioned expert networks. Each functional region is represented by a specialized expert that learns localized neural dynamics, while a transformer-based global expert captures cross-regional dependencies. A learnable routing gate adaptively aggregates these heterogeneous experts, enabling context-dependent expert coordination and selective fusion. To promote coherent representation across the hierarchy, we introduce cross-regional distillation, where the global expert provides top-down regularization to the regional experts. We further release SilentSpeech-EEG (SS-EEG), a large-scale benchmark comprising over 120 hours of EEG recordings from 12 subjects performing 24 silent words, the largest dataset of its kind. Experiments demonstrate that BrainStack consistently outperforms state-of-the-art models, achieving superior accuracy and generalization across subjects. Our results establish BrainStack as a functionally modular, neuro-inspired MoE paradigm that unifies neuroscientific priors with adaptive expert routing, paving the way for scalable and interpretable brain-language decoding.

AI.tldr: BrainStack introduces a functionally guided Neuro-MoE architecture with region-specific experts and a transformer global expert for EEG-based brain-language decoding, plus cross-regional distillation and a large SilentSpeech-EEG benchmark. It achieves improved accuracy and cross-subject generalization over state-of-the-art models.
AI.motivation: Decoding linguistic information from EEG is challenging due to the brain's distributed and nonlinear organization. There is a need for models that reflect neuroscientific priors (modular functional architecture) and enable robust cross-subject decoding.
AI.method: An anatomically partitioned set of regional experts (one per functional brain region) learns localized neural dynamics, while a transformer-based global expert captures cross-regional dependencies. A learnable routing gate fuses regional and global outputs adaptively. Cross-regional distillation provides top-down regularization from the global to regional experts. A large-scale SilentSpeech-EEG (SS-EEG) benchmark (≈120 hours, 12 subjects, 24 silent words) is released for evaluation.
AI.result: BrainStack consistently outperforms state-of-the-art models, delivering superior accuracy and better generalization across subjects in EEG-based brain-language decoding tasks.
AI.conclusion: The work presents a neuro-inspired, modular MoE framework that integrates neuroscientific priors with adaptive expert routing and distillation, offering scalable, interpretable progress toward reliable brain-language decoding and providing a valuable benchmark dataset for future research.

title: IROS: A Dual-Process Architecture for Real-Time VLM-Based Indoor Navigation
summary: Indoor mobile robot navigation requires fast responsiveness and robust semantic understanding, yet existing methods struggle to provide both. Classical geometric approaches such as SLAM offer reliable localization but depend on detailed maps and cannot interpret human-targeted cues (e.g., signs, room numbers) essential for indoor reasoning. Vision-Language-Action (VLA) models introduce semantic grounding but remain strictly reactive, basing decisions only on visible frames and failing to anticipate unseen intersections or reason about distant textual cues. Vision-Language Models (VLMs) provide richer contextual inference but suffer from high computational latency, making them unsuitable for real-time operation on embedded platforms. In this work, we present IROS, a real-time navigation framework that combines VLM-level contextual reasoning with the efficiency of lightweight perceptual modules on low-cost, on-device hardware. Inspired by Dual Process Theory, IROS separates fast reflexive decisions (System One) from slow deliberative reasoning (System Two), invoking the VLM only when necessary. Furthermore, by augmenting compact VLMs with spatial and textual cues, IROS delivers robust, human-like navigation with minimal latency. Across five real-world buildings, IROS improves decision accuracy and reduces latency by 66% compared to continuous VLM-based navigation.

AI.tldr: Real-time indoor navigation IROS combines fast reflexive perception with compact VLM-based reasoning using a Dual Process Theory-inspired architecture, achieving substantial latency reduction and improved decisions in real-world tests.
AI.motivation: Indoor navigation requires both rapid responsiveness and rich semantic understanding. Classical SLAM offers localization but lacks high-level cues; VLA models are reactive; VLMs are semantically rich but too slow for real-time on-device use.
AI.method: A modular framework (System One/Two) that uses lightweight perceptual modules for fast decisions and invokes compact VLMs for deliberative reasoning on demand, augmented with spatial and textual cues to improve robustness on low-cost hardware.
AI.result: Reported 66% latency reduction and improved decision accuracy compared to continuous VLM-based navigation, validated across five real-world buildings.
AI.conclusion: IROS demonstrates real-time, human-like navigation on embedded platforms by integrating fast reflexive processes with delayed, context-rich reasoning using compact VLMs, enabling robust semantic understanding without sacrificing responsiveness.

title: NFCDS: A Plug-and-Play Noise Frequency-Controlled Diffusion Sampling Strategy for Image Restoration
summary: Diffusion sampling-based Plug-and-Play (PnP) methods produce images with high perceptual quality but often suffer from reduced data fidelity, primarily due to the noise introduced during reverse diffusion. To address this trade-off, we propose Noise Frequency-Controlled Diffusion Sampling (NFCDS), a spectral modulation mechanism for reverse diffusion noise. We show that the fidelity-perception conflict can be fundamentally understood through noise frequency: low-frequency components induce blur and degrade fidelity, while high-frequency components drive detail generation. Based on this insight, we design a Fourier-domain filter that progressively suppresses low-frequency noise and preserves high-frequency content. This controlled refinement injects a data-consistency prior directly into sampling, enabling fast convergence to results that are both high-fidelity and perceptually convincing--without additional training. As a PnP module, NFCDS seamlessly integrates into existing diffusion-based restoration frameworks and improves the fidelity-perception balance across diverse zero-shot tasks.

AI.tldr: NFCDS introduces a Fourier-domain, frequency-controlled diffusion sampling mechanism to balance fidelity and perceptual quality in diffusion-based restoration, as a plug-and-play module that suppresses low-frequency noise while preserving high-frequency content for faster, training-free convergence.
AI.motivation: Diffusion-based PnP methods yield high perceptual quality but often fail data fidelity due to reverse-diffusion noise. There is a fundamental fidelity-perception trade-off that needs to be addressed without retraining.
AI.method: Propose Noise Frequency-Controlled Diffusion Sampling (NFCDS), a spectral modulation mechanism that applies a Fourier-domain filter during reverse diffusion to progressively suppress low-frequency noise and preserve high-frequency content, acting as a data-consistency prior in sampling. NFCDS is designed as a plug-and-play module that integrates into existing diffusion restoration frameworks without additional training.
AI.result: The approach reframes the fidelity-perception trade-off in terms of noise frequency and demonstrates that controlled spectral refinement yields improved data fidelity while maintaining perceptual quality, enabling faster convergence to high-fidelity, perceptually convincing results in zero-shot tasks without additional training.
AI.conclusion: NFCDS provides a practical, training-free PnP module to balance fidelity and perceptual quality in diffusion-based restoration by spectrally modulating reverse-diffusion noise in the Fourier domain.

title: Order-Aware Test-Time Adaptation: Leveraging Temporal Dynamics for Robust Streaming Inference
summary: Test-Time Adaptation (TTA) enables pre-trained models to adjust to distribution shift by learning from unlabeled test-time streams. However, existing methods typically treat these streams as independent samples, overlooking the supervisory signal inherent in temporal dynamics. To address this, we introduce Order-Aware Test-Time Adaptation (OATTA). We formulate test-time adaptation as a gradient-free recursive Bayesian estimation task, using a learned dynamic transition matrix as a temporal prior to refine the base model's predictions. To ensure safety in weakly structured streams, we introduce a likelihood-ratio gate (LLR) that reverts to the base predictor when temporal evidence is absent. OATTA is a lightweight, model-agnostic module that incurs negligible computational overhead. Extensive experiments across image classification, wearable and physiological signal analysis, and language sentiment analysis demonstrate its universality; OATTA consistently boosts established baselines, improving accuracy by up to 6.35%. Our findings establish that modeling temporal dynamics provides a critical, orthogonal signal beyond standard order-agnostic TTA approaches.

AI.tldr: OATTA introduces order-aware, gradient-free test-time adaptation using a learned dynamic transition matrix as a temporal prior and a likelihood-ratio gate to handle weak temporal signals; claims universal applicability across modalities with negligible overhead and up to 6.35% accuracy gains.
AI.motivation: Standard TTA often treats test samples independently, missing supervisory signal inherent in temporal dynamics; there is a need to leverage temporal structure during test-time adaptation while ensuring safety when signals are weak.
AI.method: Formulate TTA as a gradient-free recursive Bayesian estimation task. Use a learned dynamic transition matrix as a temporal prior to refine base model predictions. Introduce a likelihood-ratio gate (LLR) that reverts to the base predictor when temporal evidence is absent. The approach is lightweight and model-agnostic.
AI.result: Empirical evaluation across image classification, wearable/physiological signals, and language sentiment analysis shows consistent improvements over baselines, with accuracy gains up to 6.35%. Demonstrates universality of the approach.
AI.conclusion: Modeling temporal dynamics provides a critical, orthogonal signal beyond conventional order-agnostic TTA methods. OATTA offers a lightweight, generalizable module with negligible overhead that improves performance across diverse domains.

title: Bridging the Arithmetic Gap: The Cognitive Complexity Benchmark and Financial-PoT for Robust Financial Reasoning
summary: While Large Language Models excel at semantic tasks, they face a critical bottleneck in financial quantitative reasoning, frequently suffering from "Arithmetic Hallucinations" and a systemic failure mode we term "Cognitive Collapse". To strictly quantify this phenomenon, we introduce the Cognitive Complexity Benchmark (CCB), a robust evaluation framework grounded in a dataset constructed from 95 real-world Chinese A-share annual reports. Unlike traditional datasets, the CCB stratifies financial queries into a three-dimensional taxonomy, Data Source, Mapping Difficulty, and Result Unit, enabling the precise diagnosis of reasoning degradation in high-cognitive-load scenarios. To address these failures, we propose the Iterative Dual-Phase Financial-PoT framework. This neuro-symbolic architecture enforces a strict architectural decoupling: it first isolates semantic variable extraction and logic formulation, then offloads computation to an iterative, self-correcting Python sandbox to ensure deterministic execution. Evaluation on the CCB demonstrates that while standard Chain-of-Thought falters on complex tasks, our approach offers superior robustness, elevating the Qwen3-235B model's average accuracy from 59.7\% to 67.3\% and achieving gains of up to 10-fold in high-complexity reasoning tasks. These findings suggest that architectural decoupling is a critical enabling factor for improving reliability in financial reasoning tasks, providing a transferable architectural insight for precision-critical domains that require tight alignment between semantic understanding and quantitative computation.

AI.tldr: Proposes Cognitive Complexity Benchmark (CCB) and Iterative Dual-Phase Financial-PoT to diagnose and mitigate reasoning failures in LLMs for finance; demonstrates robustness and accuracy gains on Qwen3-235B.
AI.motivation: Address persistent arithmetic hallucinations and cognitive collapse in financial reasoning by developing a robust benchmark and a neuro-symbolic, decoupled architecture to separate semantic extraction/logic from computation.
AI.method: CCB dataset from 95 real-world Chinese A-share annual reports, three-dimensional taxonomy: Data Source, Mapping Difficulty, Result Unit; Iterative Dual-Phase Financial-PoT framework with semantic extraction and logic formulation separated from a Python sandbox for deterministic computation; evaluation on Qwen3-235B showing improvements.
AI.result: Average accuracy increases from 59.7% to 67.3%; up to 10x gains in high-complexity tasks; standard Chain-of-Thought underperforms.
AI.conclusion: Architectural decoupling enhances reliability in precision-critical financial reasoning; approach is transferable to other domains requiring tight semantic-quantitative alignment.

title: Training slow silicon neurons to control extremely fast robots with spiking reinforcement learning
summary: Air hockey demands split-second decisions at high puck velocities, a challenge we address with a compact network of spiking neurons running on a mixed-signal analog/digital neuromorphic processor. By co-designing hardware and learning algorithms, we train the system to achieve successful puck interactions through reinforcement learning in a remarkably small number of trials. The network leverages fixed random connectivity to capture the task's temporal structure and adopts a local e-prop learning rule in the readout layer to exploit event-driven activity for fast and efficient learning. The result is real-time learning with a setup comprising a computer and the neuromorphic chip in-the-loop, enabling practical training of spiking neural networks for robotic autonomous systems. This work bridges neuroscience-inspired hardware with real-world robotic control, showing that brain-inspired approaches can tackle fast-paced interaction tasks while supporting always-on learning in intelligent machines.

AI.tldr: Neuromorphic spiking network with fixed connectivity and local learning achieves real-time reinforcement-based air hockey control on mixed-signal hardware.
AI.motivation: Enable fast, energy-efficient real-time learning for robotic control by co-designing neuromorphic hardware with learning algorithms to handle fast-paced tasks.
AI.method: Compact network of spiking neurons on a mixed-signal neuromorphic processor; fixed random connectivity to capture temporal structure; local e-prop learning rule in the readout layer; reinforcement learning; hardware-in-the-loop with computer.
AI.result: Real-time learning for puck interactions with few trials; practical training of SNNs for robotic autonomous systems; demonstration of always-on learning bridging neuroscience hardware and real-world robotics.
AI.conclusion: Brain-inspired hardware with fixed connectivity and local learning can tackle fast-paced interaction tasks and support continual learning in intelligent machines.

title: Hypersolid: Emergent Vision Representations via Short-Range Repulsion
summary: A recurring challenge in self-supervised learning is preventing representation collapse. Existing solutions typically rely on global regularization, such as maximizing distances, decorrelating dimensions or enforcing certain distributions. We instead reinterpret representation learning as a discrete packing problem, where preserving information simplifies to maintaining injectivity. We operationalize this in Hypersolid, a method using short-range hard-ball repulsion to prevent local collisions. This constraint results in a high-separation geometric regime that preserves augmentation diversity, excelling on fine-grained and low-resolution classification tasks.

AI.tldr: Reframes self-supervised learning as a discrete packing problem; Hypersolid enforces injectivity with short-range hard-ball repulsion to avoid representation collapse, yielding high-separation representations and strong performance on fine-grained and low-resolution tasks.
AI.motivation: Address representation collapse in self-supervised learning without relying on global regularization; seek a principled, information-preserving criterion tied to injectivity between augmentations.
AI.method: Model the representation learning task as a discrete packing problem. Introduce Hypersolid, which applies short-range hard-ball repulsion to prevent local collisions, creating a high-separation geometric regime while preserving augmentation diversity.
AI.result: Achieves strong performance on fine-grained and low-resolution classification tasks, indicating that the high-separation regime and preserved augmentation diversity help mitigate collapse.
AI.conclusion: Viewing SSL as a packing/injectivity problem and enforcing local repulsion can prevent collapse and improve performance, especially for challenging tasks requiring fine-grained discrimination and robustness at low resolutions.

title: Conditional Denoising Model as a Physical Surrogate Model
summary: Surrogate modeling for complex physical systems typically faces a trade-off between data-fitting accuracy and physical consistency. Physics-consistent approaches typically treat physical laws as soft constraints within the loss function, a strategy that frequently fails to guarantee strict adherence to the governing equations, or rely on post-processing corrections that do not intrinsically learn the underlying solution geometry. To address these limitations, we introduce the {Conditional Denoising Model (CDM)}, a generative model designed to learn the geometry of the physical manifold itself. By training the network to restore clean states from noisy ones, the model learns a vector field that points continuously towards the valid solution subspace. We introduce a time-independent formulation that transforms inference into a deterministic fixed-point iteration, effectively projecting noisy approximations onto the equilibrium manifold. Validated on a low-temperature plasma physics and chemistry benchmark, the CDM achieves higher parameter and data efficiency than physics-consistent baselines. Crucially, we demonstrate that the denoising objective acts as a powerful implicit regularizer: despite never seeing the governing equations during training, the model adheres to physical constraints more strictly than baselines trained with explicit physics losses.

AI.tldr: CDM is a conditional denoising generative model that learns the geometry of the physical solution manifold, enabling a deterministic projection of noisy states onto the valid subspace and achieving improved data/parameter efficiency and physical fidelity over physics-loss baselines.
AI.motivation: Surrogate models face a trade-off between data fit and physical consistency; soft physics losses often fail to guarantee adherence and post-hoc corrections do not learn the solution geometry. A method that inherently encodes the solution manifold is desirable.
AI.method: Train a conditional denoising model to restore clean states from noisy ones, thereby learning a vector field toward the valid solution subspace. Introduce a time-independent formulation that yields a deterministic fixed-point iteration, projecting noisy approximations onto the equilibrium manifold.
AI.result: Empirical validation on a low-temperature plasma physics/chemistry benchmark shows higher parameter and data efficiency versus physics-consistent baselines. The denoising objective acts as a strong implicit regularizer, yielding greater physical adherence without using governing equations during training.
AI.conclusion: CDM provides a physics-informed generative approach that intrinsically enforces physical constraints via denoising, improving accuracy-efficiency trade-offs and potentially generalizing to other domains.

title: Concise Geometric Description as a Bridge: Unleashing the Potential of LLM for Plane Geometry Problem Solving
summary: Plane Geometry Problem Solving (PGPS) is a multimodal reasoning task that aims to solve a plane geometric problem based on a geometric diagram and problem textual descriptions. Although Large Language Models (LLMs) possess strong reasoning skills, their direct application to PGPS is hindered by their inability to process visual diagrams. Existing works typically fine-tune Multimodal LLMs (MLLMs) end-to-end on large-scale PGPS data to enhance visual understanding and reasoning simultaneously. However, such joint optimization may compromise base LLMs' inherent reasoning capability. In this work, we observe that LLM itself is potentially a powerful PGPS solver when appropriately formulating visual information as textual descriptions. We propose to train a MLLM Interpreter to generate geometric descriptions for the visual diagram, and an off-the-shelf LLM is utilized to perform reasoning. Specifically, we choose Conditional Declaration Language (CDL) as the geometric description as its conciseness eases the MLLM Interpreter training. The MLLM Interpreter is fine-tuned via CoT (Chain-of-Thought)-augmented SFT followed by GRPO to generate CDL. Instead of using a conventional solution-based reward that compares the reasoning result with the ground-truth answer, we design CDL matching rewards to facilitate more effective GRPO training, which provides more direct and denser guidance for CDL generation. To support training, we construct a new dataset, Formalgeo7k-Rec-CoT, by manually reviewing Formalgeo7k v2 and incorporating CoT annotations. Extensive experiments on Formalgeo7k-Rec-CoT, Unigeo, and MathVista show our method (finetuned on only 5.5k data) performs favorably against leading open-source and closed-source MLLMs.

AI.tldr: A text-based approach to PGPS that uses a dedicated MLLM Interpreter to convert diagrams into concise geometric descriptions (CDL), with an off-the-shelf LLM for reasoning, trained via CoT-SFT and GRPO using CDL-matching rewards. A new CoT-annotated dataset (Formalgeo7k-Rec-CoT) supports training. Data-efficient method (5.5k) outperforms strong MLLMs on multiple benchmarks.
AI.motivation: LLMs struggle to interpret visual diagrams directly, and end-to-end multimodal fine-tuning can erode base reasoning abilities. Representing diagrams as structured textual descriptions (CDL) can leverage LLM reasoning without joint optimization of perception and reasoning. CDL's conciseness facilitates efficient MLLM training.
AI.method: Fine-tune an MLLM Interpreter to produce CDL from diagrams. Use a separate, off-the-shelf LLM for reasoning over CDL. Train the Interpreter with chain-of-thought augmented supervised fine-tuning (CoT-SFT) followed by GRPO, guided by CDL-matching rewards rather than ground-truth answers. Build Formalgeo7k-Rec-CoT by annotating Formalgeo7k v2 with CoT. Evaluate on Formalgeo7k-Rec-CoT, Unigeo, and MathVista.
AI.result: The approach yields favorable performance against leading open-source and closed-source MLLMs, achieving data efficiency (trained on ~5.5k examples). It demonstrates strong reasoning by leveraging text-only CDL representations while avoiding end-to-end perception-em reasoning compromises.
AI.conclusion: Separating diagram understanding (CDL generation) from reasoning (LLM) with CDL-based supervision and CDL-matching rewards is effective for PGPS. A concise geometric description enables effective use of off-the-shelf LLMs, with the added benefit of data-efficient training and a dedicated CoT supervision dataset.

title: AIR-VLA: Vision-Language-Action Systems for Aerial Manipulation
summary: While Vision-Language-Action (VLA) models have achieved remarkable success in ground-based embodied intelligence, their application to Aerial Manipulation Systems (AMS) remains a largely unexplored frontier. The inherent characteristics of AMS, including floating-base dynamics, strong coupling between the UAV and the manipulator, and the multi-step, long-horizon nature of operational tasks, pose severe challenges to existing VLA paradigms designed for static or 2D mobile bases. To bridge this gap, we propose AIR-VLA, the first VLA benchmark specifically tailored for aerial manipulation. We construct a physics-based simulation environment and release a high-quality multimodal dataset comprising 3000 manually teleoperated demonstrations, covering base manipulation, object & spatial understanding, semantic reasoning, and long-horizon planning. Leveraging this platform, we systematically evaluate mainstream VLA models and state-of-the-art VLM models. Our experiments not only validate the feasibility of transferring VLA paradigms to aerial systems but also, through multi-dimensional metrics tailored to aerial tasks, reveal the capabilities and boundaries of current models regarding UAV mobility, manipulator control, and high-level planning. AIR-VLA establishes a standardized testbed and data foundation for future research in general-purpose aerial robotics. The resource of AIR-VLA will be available at https://anonymous.4open.science/r/AIR-VLA-dataset-B5CC/.

AI.tldr: A new VLA benchmark for aerial manipulation (AIR-VLA) with a physics-based simulator, 3000 teleoperated demonstrations, and comprehensive evaluation of VLA and VLM models on UAV-mobility, manipulation, and long-horizon planning.
AI.motivation: To close the gap between established vision-language-action (VLA) methods for ground-based embodied systems and the unique challenges of aerial manipulation systems (AMS), which include floating bases, strong UAV-manipulator coupling, and long-horizon tasks.
AI.method: Construct a physics-based simulation environment and assemble a multimodal dataset of 3000 manually teleoperated demonstrations spanning base manipulation, object/spatial understanding, semantic reasoning, and long-horizon planning. Systematically evaluate mainstream VLA models and state-of-the-art vision-language models using metrics tailored to aerial tasks.
AI.result: Demonstrates feasibility of transferring VLA paradigms to aerial systems and characterizes model capabilities and limitations across UAV mobility, manipulator control, and high-level planning, establishing AIR-VLA as a standardized testbed and data resource for aerial robotics research.
AI.conclusion: AIR-VLA provides a standardized platform and data foundation to accelerate research in general-purpose aerial robotics and promotes rigorous benchmarking of VLA methods in AMS contexts.

title: Lightweight High-Fidelity Low-Bitrate Talking Face Compression for 3D Video Conference
summary: The demand for immersive and interactive communication has driven advancements in 3D video conferencing, yet achieving high-fidelity 3D talking face representation at low bitrates remains a challenge. Traditional 2D video compression techniques fail to preserve fine-grained geometric and appearance details, while implicit neural rendering methods like NeRF suffer from prohibitive computational costs. To address these challenges, we propose a lightweight, high-fidelity, low-bitrate 3D talking face compression framework that integrates FLAME-based parametric modeling with 3DGS neural rendering. Our approach transmits only essential facial metadata in real time, enabling efficient reconstruction with a Gaussian-based head model. Additionally, we introduce a compact representation and compression scheme, including Gaussian attribute compression and MLP optimization, to enhance transmission efficiency. Experimental results demonstrate that our method achieves superior rate-distortion performance, delivering high-quality facial rendering at extremely low bitrates, making it well-suited for real-time 3D video conferencing applications.

AI.tldr: A lightweight 3D talking-face compression framework that combines FLAME parametric modeling with 3DGS rendering, using Gaussian-based head representation and compact Gaussian attribute/MLP compression to achieve high-quality rendering at very low bitrates for real-time 3D video conferencing.
AI.motivation: To overcome the insufficiency of 2D video compression in preserving fine geometry/appearance details and the computational cost of neural rendering (e.g., NeRF) for live 3D talking-face streams.
AI.method: Integrates FLAME-based parametric facial modeling with 3DGS neural rendering; transmits only essential facial metadata in real time; uses a Gaussian-based head model; introduces compact representations including Gaussian attribute compression and MLP optimization to improve transmission efficiency.
AI.result: Demonstrates superior rate-distortion performance, delivering high-quality facial rendering at extremely low bitrates, suitable for real-time 3D video conferencing.
AI.conclusion: The proposed framework enables efficient, high-fidelity 3D talking-face reconstruction at low bitrates, making real-time 3D video conferencing more feasible and scalable.

title: SIGMA-PPG: Statistical-prior Informed Generative Masking Architecture for PPG Foundation Model
summary: Current foundation model for photoplethysmography (PPG) signals is challenged by the intrinsic redundancy and noise of the signal. Standard masked modeling often yields trivial solutions while contrastive methods lack morphological precision. To address these limitations, we propose a Statistical-prior Informed Generative Masking Architecture (SIGMA-PPG), a generative foundation model featuring a Prior-Guided Adversarial Masking mechanism, where a reinforcement learning-driven teacher leverages statistical priors to create challenging learning paths that prevent overfitting to noise. We also incorporate a semantic consistency constraint via vector quantization to ensure that physiologically identical waveforms (even those altered by recording artifacts or minor perturbations) map to shared indices. This enhances codebook semantic density and eliminates redundant feature structures. Pre-trained on over 120,000 hours of data, SIGMA-PPG achieves superior average performance compared to five state-of-the-art baselines across 12 diverse downstream tasks. The code is available at https://github.com/ZonghengGuo/SigmaPPG.

AI.tldr: SIGMA-PPG: a generative, priors-informed masked model for PPG signals using a RL-driven teacher and vector-quantized semantic constraints; trained on 120k hours; outperforms five baselines across 12 tasks; code released.
AI.motivation: PPG foundation models struggle due to signal redundancy and noise; standard masked modeling yields trivial solutions; contrastive methods lack morphological precision.
AI.method: Prior-Guided Adversarial Masking via a reinforcement-learning–driven teacher that uses statistical priors to construct challenging learning paths and prevent overfitting to noise; semantic consistency enforced by vector quantization to map physiologically identical waveforms to shared indices; aims to increase codebook semantic density and reduce redundant features; pre-trained on >120k hours of data.
AI.result: SIGMA-PPG achieves superior average performance compared with five state-of-the-art baselines across 12 diverse downstream tasks.
AI.conclusion: The architecture improves robustness to noise and preserves morphologically meaningful structure in PPG signals, enabling better generalization; code is publicly available at the provided GitHub link.

title: FrontierScience: Evaluating AI's Ability to Perform Expert-Level Scientific Tasks
summary:
We introduce FrontierScience, a benchmark evaluating expert-level scientific reasoning in frontier language models. Recent model progress has nearly saturated existing science benchmarks, which often rely on multiple-choice knowledge questions or already published information. FrontierScience addresses this gap through two complementary tracks: (1) Olympiad, consisting of international olympiad problems at the level of IPhO, IChO, and IBO, and (2) Research, consisting of PhD-level, open-ended problems representative of sub-tasks in scientific research.
  FrontierScience contains several hundred questions (including 160 in the open-sourced gold set) covering subfields across physics, chemistry, and biology, from quantum electrodynamics to synthetic organic chemistry. All Olympiad problems are originally produced by international Olympiad medalists and national team coaches to ensure standards of difficulty, originality, and factuality. All Research problems are research sub-tasks written and verified by PhD scientists (doctoral candidates, postdoctoral researchers, or professors). For Research, we introduce a granular rubric-based evaluation framework to assess model capabilities throughout the process of solving a research task, rather than judging only a standalone final answer.

AI.tldr: FrontierScience is a proposed benchmark with two tracks (Olympiad and Research) to evaluate expert-level scientific reasoning in frontier language models, featuring several hundred questions across physics, chemistry, and biology, including an open-source gold set of 160 questions and a rubric-based, process-focused evaluation framework.
AI.motivation: Existing science benchmarks have largely saturated multiple-choice knowledge tests and rely on already published information; there is a need for open-ended, research-grade tasks that probe genuine scientific reasoning and problem-solving processes at the PhD level.
AI.method: Two complementary tracks: Olympiad (problems at the level of IPhO, IChO, IBO) and Research (open-ended, sub-task problems representing real research tasks). The dataset comprises several hundred questions across physics, chemistry, and biology, with an open-source gold set of 160 items. Olympiad problems are authored by Olympiad medalists and coaches; Research problems are written and verified by PhD scientists. A granular rubric-based evaluation framework is introduced to assess model performance across the problem-solving process, not just final answers.
AI.result: Proposal introducing FrontierScience, detailing dataset composition, track design, question provenance, and a rubric-based evaluation framework for assessing expert-level reasoning through the solution process. No empirical results are reported in the abstract.
AI.conclusion: FrontierScience aims to fill a gap in AI evaluation by providing a rigorous, open benchmark that tests true scientific reasoning across subfields and stages of research, with transparent question provenance and a process-oriented rubric to evaluate models.

title: From Instruction to Event: Sound-Triggered Mobile Manipulation
summary: Current mobile manipulation research predominantly follows an instruction-driven paradigm, where agents rely on predefined textual commands to execute tasks. However, this setting confines agents to a passive role, limiting their autonomy and ability to react to dynamic environmental events. To address these limitations, we introduce sound-triggered mobile manipulation, where agents must actively perceive and interact with sound-emitting objects without explicit action instructions. To support these tasks, we develop Habitat-Echo, a data platform that integrates acoustic rendering with physical interaction. We further propose a baseline comprising a high-level task planner and low-level policy models to complete these tasks. Extensive experiments show that the proposed baseline empowers agents to actively detect and respond to auditory events, eliminating the need for case-by-case instructions. Notably, in the challenging dual-source scenario, the agent successfully isolates the primary source from overlapping acoustic interference to execute the first interaction, and subsequently proceeds to manipulate the secondary object, verifying the robustness of the baseline.

AI.tldr: Introduces sound-triggered mobile manipulation with Habitat-Echo; an autonomous, audio-driven baseline using a planner and low-level policies to react to auditory events without explicit instructions, demonstrated robustly in a dual-source setting.
AI.motivation: Current instruction-driven, text-command agents are passive and struggle with dynamic auditory events; enabling autonomous perception-action loops in response to sound can improve robustness and autonomy in mobile manipulation.
AI.method: Develop Habitat-Echo data platform integrating acoustic rendering with physical interaction; propose a high-level task planner plus low-level policy models as a baseline to perceive, plan, and act in response to sound-emitting objects.
AI.result: The baseline enables autonomous detection and response to auditory events without task-specific cues; in a challenging dual-source scenario, the agent isolates the primary sound source from interference to perform the first interaction and then manipulates the secondary object, showing robustness.
AI.conclusion: Sound-triggered manipulation is viable and affords greater autonomy beyond instruction-driven paradigms; the proposed Habitat-Echo platform and baseline establish a foundation for audio-driven robotic interaction and invite further research into more complex auditory scenes and real-world deployments.

title: GeoRC: A Benchmark for Geolocation Reasoning Chains
summary: Vision Language Models (VLMs) are good at recognizing the global location of a photograph -- their geolocation prediction accuracy rivals the best human experts. But many VLMs are startlingly bad at explaining which image evidence led to their prediction, even when their location prediction is correct. The reasoning chains produced by VLMs frequently hallucinate scene attributes to support their location prediction (e.g. phantom writing, imagined infrastructure, misidentified flora). In this paper, we introduce the first benchmark for geolocation reasoning chains. We focus on the global location prediction task in the popular GeoGuessr game which draws from Google Street View spanning more than 100 countries. We collaborate with expert GeoGuessr players, including the reigning world champion, to produce 800 ground truth reasoning chains for 500 query scenes. These expert reasoning chains address hundreds of different discriminative visual attributes such as license plate shape, architecture, and soil properties to name just a few. We evaluate LLM-as-a-judge and VLM-as-a-judge strategies for scoring VLM-generated reasoning chains against our expert reasoning chains and find that Qwen 3 LLM-as-a-judge correlates best with human scoring. Our benchmark reveals that while large, closed-source VLMs such as Gemini and GPT 5 rival human experts at prediction locations, they still lag behind human experts when it comes to producing auditable reasoning chains. Open weights VLMs such as Llama and Qwen catastrophically fail on our benchmark -- they perform only slightly better than a baseline in which an LLM hallucinates a reasoning chain with oracle knowledge of the photo location but no visual information at all. We believe the gap between human experts and VLMs on this task points to VLM limitations at extracting fine-grained visual attributes from high resolution images.

AI.tldr: A benchmark for geolocation reasoning chains shows strong predictive ability in VLMs but poor auditable explanations, highlighting a gap between location accuracy and explainability; expert reasoning chains reveal discriminative cues; LLM judges align with humans; open-weight VLMs perform poorly; the gap likely stems from extracting fine-grained visual attributes from high-resolution images.
AI.motivation: Address the explainability gap in vision-language models (VLMs) for geolocation by creating ground-truth reasoning chains and evaluating if models can generate auditable, attribute-driven explanations.
AI.method: Create a GeoGuessr-based benchmark with 500 scenes (from Google Street View across 100+ countries) and 800 expert reasoning chains. Evaluate VLM-generated reasoning with LLM-as-a-judge and VLM-as-a-judge against expert chains; compare performance of closed-source vs open-weight VLMs.
AI.result: Qwen 3 (LLM-as-a-judge) correlates best with human scoring. Large, closed-source VLMs (Gemini, GPT-5) rival human experts on location prediction but lag on auditable reasoning chains. Open-weight VLMs (Llama, Qwen) perform near baseline, performing only slightly better than a hallucination baseline with no visual grounding.
AI.conclusion: There is a notable gap between locating accuracy and explainable reasoning in VLMs, likely due to limitations in extracting and grounding fine-grained visual attributes from high-resolution imagery. The benchmark provides a path toward developing more auditable VLM reasoning.

title: Predict-Project-Renoise: Sampling Diffusion Models under Hard Constraints
summary: Neural emulators based on diffusion models show promise for scientific applications, but vanilla models cannot guarantee physical accuracy or constraint satisfaction. We address this by introducing a constrained sampling framework that enforces hard constraints, such as physical laws or observational consistency, at generation time. Our approach defines a constrained forward process that diffuses only over the feasible set of constraint-satisfying samples, inducing constrained marginal distributions. To reverse this, we propose Predict-Project-Renoise (PPR), an iterative algorithm that samples from the constrained marginals by alternating between denoising predictions, projecting onto the feasible set, and renoising. Experiments on 2D distributions, PDEs, and global weather forecasting demonstrate that PPR reduces constraint violations by over an order of magnitude while improving sample consistency and better matching the true constrained distribution compared to baselines.

AI.tldr: Constrained diffusion sampling for physics-informed emulation: PPR enforces hard constraints during generation to produce physically feasible samples and reduce constraint violations.
AI.motivation: Vanilla diffusion-based emulators can produce physically infeasible samples. Enforcing hard, domain-relevant constraints during generation improves physical accuracy and observational consistency in scientific simulations.
AI.method: Introduce a constrained forward diffusion that only diffuses within the feasible set of constraint-satisfying samples, yielding constrained marginals. Develop Predict-Project-Renoise (PPR), an iterative scheme that alternates denoising predictions, projection onto the constraint set, and renoising to sample from the constrained marginals.
AI.result: Empirical results on 2D distributions, PDEs, and global weather forecasting show PPR reduces constraint violations by more than an order of magnitude, improves sample consistency, and better matches the true constrained distribution versus baselines.
AI.conclusion: Constrained diffusion with PPR offers a practical and effective framework for enforcing hard, physics-informed constraints in neural emulators, yielding physically consistent samples across diverse scientific domains.

title: MAD: Modality-Adaptive Decoding for Mitigating Cross-Modal Hallucinations in Multimodal Large Language Models
summary: Multimodal Large Language Models (MLLMs) suffer from cross-modal hallucinations, where one modality inappropriately influences generation about another, leading to fabricated output. This exposes a more fundamental deficiency in modality-interaction control. To address this, we propose Modality-Adaptive Decoding (MAD), a training-free method that adaptively weights modality-specific decoding branches based on task requirements. MAD leverages the model's inherent ability to self-assess modality relevance by querying which modalities are needed for each task. The extracted modality probabilities are then used to adaptively weight contrastive decoding branches, enabling the model to focus on relevant information while suppressing cross-modal interference. Extensive experiments on CMM and AVHBench demonstrate that MAD significantly reduces cross-modal hallucinations across multiple audio-visual language models (7.8\% and 2.0\% improvements for VideoLLaMA2-AV, 8.7\% and 4.7\% improvements for Qwen2.5-Omni). Our approach demonstrates that explicit modality awareness through self-assessment is crucial for robust multimodal reasoning, offering a principled extension to existing contrastive decoding methods. Our code is available at \href{https://github.com/top-yun/MAD}{https://github.com/top-yun/MAD}

AI.tldr: MAD is a training-free, modality-adaptive decoding method for multimodal LLMs that suppresses cross-modal hallucinations by self-assessing modality relevance for each task and adaptively weighting modality-specific decoding branches; it extends contrastive decoding and achieves notable reductions on CMM and AVHBench across VideoLLaMA2-AV and Qwen2.5-Omni. Code is released.
AI.motivation: Cross-modal hallucinations reveal weak modality-interaction control in Multimodal LLMs. There is a need for explicit modality-awareness and a training-free mechanism to suppress irrelevant modality influence during decoding.
AI.method: MAD leverages the model's self-assessment to determine which modalities are needed for a task, extracting modality probabilities. These probabilities are used to adaptively weight the contrastive decoding branches, reducing cross-modal interference while preserving task-relevant information. The approach is training-free and acts as an extension to existing contrastive decoding methods.
AI.result: MAD reduces cross-modal hallucinations across multiple audio-visual LLMs, with reported improvements of 7.8% and 2.0% for VideoLLaMA2-AV, and 8.7% and 4.7% for Qwen2.5-Omni on CMM and AVHBench benchmarks respectively.
AI.conclusion: Explicit modality-awareness through self-assessment is crucial for robust multimodal reasoning. MAD provides a principled extension to contrastive decoding and demonstrates that decoding-time, modality-adaptive weighting can mitigate cross-modal interference without additional training.

title: CoFreeVLA: Collision-Free Dual-Arm Manipulation via Vision-Language-Action Model and Risk Estimation
summary: Vision Language Action (VLA) models enable instruction following manipulation, yet dualarm deployment remains unsafe due to under modeled selfcollisions between arms and grasped objects. We introduce CoFreeVLA, which augments an endtoend VLA with a short horizon selfcollision risk estimator that predicts collision likelihood from proprioception, visual embeddings, and planned actions. The estimator gates risky commands, recovers to safe states via risk-guided adjustments, and shapes policy refinement for safer rollouts. It is pre-trained with model-based collision labels and posttrained on real robot rollouts for calibration. On five bimanual tasks with the PiPER robot arm, CoFreeVLA reduces selfcollisions and improves success rates versus RDT and APEX.

AI.tldr: CoFreeVLA augments end-to-end Vision-Language-Action models with a short-horizon self-collision risk estimator for dual-arm manipulation, gating risky commands and guiding safe rollouts.
AI.motivation: Dual-arm manipulation with Vision-Language-Action (VLA) models remains unsafe due to under-modelled self-collisions between arms and grasped objects; a lightweight, proprioception- and vision-informed risk module is needed to improve safety and performance.
AI.method: Introduce CoFreeVLA: an end-to-end VLA with a short-horizon self-collision risk estimator that uses proprioception, visual embeddings, and planned actions. The estimator gates risky commands, performs risk-guided adjustments to recover safe states, and shapes policy refinement for safer rollouts. Pretrained with model-based collision labels and posttrained on real robot rollouts for calibration. Evaluation on five bimanual tasks with the PiPER robot arm shows reduced self-collisions and higher success rates compared with RDT and APEX.
AI.result: Reduced incidence of self-collisions and improved success rates on five bimanual PiPER tasks versus baselines (RDT, APEX).
AI.conclusion: A risk-aware augmentation improves safety and effectiveness of VLA models for dual-arm manipulation, enabling safer deployment in real-world dual-arm tasks.

title: Token Entropy Regularization for Multi-modal Antenna Affiliation Identification
summary: Accurate antenna affiliation identification is crucial for optimizing and maintaining communication networks. Current practice, however, relies on the cumbersome and error-prone process of manual tower inspections. We propose a novel paradigm shift that fuses video footage of base stations, antenna geometric features, and Physical Cell Identity (PCI) signals, transforming antenna affiliation identification into multi-modal classification and matching tasks. Publicly available pretrained transformers struggle with this unique task due to a lack of analogous data in the communications domain, which hampers cross-modal alignment. To address this, we introduce a dedicated training framework that aligns antenna images with corresponding PCI signals. To tackle the representation alignment challenge, we propose a novel Token Entropy Regularization module in the pretraining stage. Our experiments demonstrate that TER accelerates convergence and yields significant performance gains. Further analysis reveals that the entropy of the first token is modality-dependent. Code will be made available upon publication.

AI.tldr: A multi-modal framework is proposed to identify antenna affiliations by fusing base-station video, antenna geometry, and PCI signals, reframing the task as multi-modal classification/matching. A dedicated pretraining framework aligns images with PCI, with a novel Token Entropy Regularization (TER) to improve representation alignment, speeding convergence and boosting performance; the first token's entropy is modality-dependent. Code will be released.
AI.motivation: Manual tower inspections are cumbersome and error-prone. Leveraging multi-modal data (video, geometry, and PCI) can automate and improve accuracy for antenna affiliation; standard pretrained transformers fail due to domain mismatch, necessitating a specialized alignment strategy.
AI.method: Introduce a dedicated cross-modal pretraining framework that aligns antenna images with PCI signals. Propose Token Entropy Regularization (TER) to address representation alignment during pretraining, improving convergence and performance across modalities.
AI.result: TER accelerates convergence and yields significant performance gains; analysis shows the first token's entropy depends on the modality, indicating how information is distributed across tokens in the fused representation.
AI.conclusion: The work reframes antenna affiliation as a multi-modal matching problem, providing a targeted pretraining strategy (TER) to enable effective cross-modal alignment; code will be released upon publication.

title: Thinking in Frames: How Visual Context and Test-Time Scaling Empower Video Reasoning
comment: 8 pages, 3 figures, 3 tables (26 pages, 13 figures, 6 tables including references and appendices)
summary: Vision-Language Models have excelled at textual reasoning, but they often struggle with fine-grained spatial understanding and continuous action planning, failing to simulate the dynamics required for complex visual reasoning. In this work, we formulate visual reasoning by means of video generation models, positing that generated frames can act as intermediate reasoning steps between initial states and solutions. We evaluate their capacity in two distinct regimes: Maze Navigation for sequential discrete planning with low visual change and Tangram Puzzle for continuous manipulation with high visual change. Our experiments reveal three critical insights: (1) Robust Zero-Shot Generalization: In both tasks, the model demonstrates strong performance on unseen data distributions without specific finetuning. (2) Visual Context: The model effectively uses visual context as explicit control, such as agent icons and tangram shapes, enabling it to maintain high visual consistency and adapt its planning capability robustly to unseen patterns. (3) Visual Test-Time Scaling: We observe a test-time scaling law in sequential planning; increasing the generated video length (visual inference budget) empowers better zero-shot generalization to spatially and temporally complex paths. These findings suggest that video generation is not merely a media tool, but a scalable, generalizable paradigm for visual reasoning.

AI.tldr: Video generation-based visual reasoning can use generated frames as intermediate steps to bridge initial states and solutions, enabling scalable, zero-shot generalizable spatial reasoning in tasks with discrete and continuous dynamics.
AI.motivation: Vision-Language Models struggle with fine-grained spatial understanding and continuous action planning; proposed use of video generation as an intermediate reasoning medium to simulate dynamics for complex visual reasoning.
AI.method: Formulate visual reasoning as generating frames that serve as intermediate steps between the initial state and solution. Evaluate on two tasks: Maze Navigation (sequential discrete planning with low visual change) and Tangram Puzzle (continuous manipulation with high visual change). Analyze zero-shot generalization, use of visual context as explicit control, and test-time video-length scaling as an inference budget.
AI.result: Three key insights: (1) Robust zero-shot generalization to unseen data distributions without task-specific finetuning; (2) Visual context effectively used as explicit control (agent icons, tangram shapes) to maintain visual consistency and robust planning on unseen patterns; (3) Visual test-time scaling: increasing generated video length improves zero-shot generalization to spatially/temporally complex paths, revealing a scaling law in sequential planning.
AI.conclusion: Video generation is a scalable, generalizable paradigm for visual reasoning, not merely a media tool, capable of supporting intermediate reasoning steps and adaptive planning across diverse visual tasks.

title: Sycophantic Anchors: Localizing and Quantifying User Agreement in Reasoning Models
summary: Reasoning models frequently agree with incorrect user suggestions -- a behavior known as sycophancy. However, it is unclear where in the reasoning trace this agreement originates and how strong the commitment is. To localize and quantify this behavior, we introduce \emph{sycophantic anchors} -- sentences that causally lock models into user agreement. Analyzing over 10,000 counterfactual rollouts on a distilled reasoning model, we show that anchors can be reliably detected and quantified mid-inference. Linear probes distinguish sycophantic anchors with 84.6\% balanced accuracy, while activation-based regressors predict the magnitude of the commitment ($R^2 = 0.74$). We further observe asymmetry where sycophantic anchors are significantly more distinguishable than correct reasoning anchors, and find that sycophancy builds gradually during reasoning, revealing a potential window for intervention. These results offer sentence-level mechanisms for localizing model misalignment mid-inference.

AI.tldr: Introduces sycophantic anchors; demonstrates detection and quantification mid-inference using probes and regression on 10k rollouts; reveals asymmetry and gradual buildup, enabling mid-inference misalignment localization.
AI.motivation: Sycophancy causes models to agree with incorrect user suggestions. The paper seeks to locate where in the reasoning trace this occurs and how strongly the commitment is, by introducing causal 'sycophantic anchors' that lock agreement.
AI.method: Define and identify sycophantic anchors. Analyze over 10,000 counterfactual rollouts on a distilled reasoning model. Use linear probes to detect anchors (balanced accuracy ~84.6%) and activation-based regressors to predict commitment magnitude (R^2 ≈ 0.74). Compare with anchors that reflect correct reasoning. Examine asymmetry and track the buildup of sycophancy during reasoning to identify intervention windows.
AI.result: Sycophantic anchors are reliably detectable and quantifiably linked to user agreement timing. Linear probes achieve 84.6% balanced accuracy in identifying anchors; activation-based regression explains 74% of variance in commitment magnitude. Anchors are more distinguishable than correct anchors, and sycophancy grows gradually during reasoning.
AI.conclusion: Sentence-level mechanisms enable localization of misalignment mid-inference and provide potential intervention points to mitigate sycophancy by targeting early or mid-inference anchors.

title: Disentangling perception and reasoning for improving data efficiency in learning cloth manipulation without demonstrations
summary: Cloth manipulation is a ubiquitous task in everyday life, but it remains an open challenge for robotics. The difficulties in developing cloth manipulation policies are attributed to the high-dimensional state space, complex dynamics, and high propensity to self-occlusion exhibited by fabrics. As analytical methods have not been able to provide robust and general manipulation policies, reinforcement learning (RL) is considered a promising approach to these problems. However, to address the large state space and complex dynamics, data-based methods usually rely on large models and long training times. The resulting computational cost significantly hampers the development and adoption of these methods. Additionally, due to the challenge of robust state estimation, garment manipulation policies often adopt an end-to-end learning approach with workspace images as input. While this approach enables a conceptually straightforward sim-to-real transfer via real-world fine-tuning, it also incurs a significant computational cost by training agents on a highly lossy representation of the environment state. This paper questions this common design choice by exploring an efficient and modular approach to RL for cloth manipulation. We show that, through careful design choices, model size and training time can be significantly reduced when learning in simulation. Furthermore, we demonstrate how the resulting simulation-trained model can be transferred to the real world. We evaluate our approach on the SoftGym benchmark and achieve significant performance improvements over available baselines on our task, while using a substantially smaller model.

AI.tldr: A modular, simulation-efficient RL approach for cloth manipulation that reduces model size and training time while enabling sim-to-real transfer, demonstrated on SoftGym with improved baselines.
AI.motivation: Cloth manipulation involves high-dimensional state, complex dynamics, and frequent self-occlusion. End-to-end image-based policies suffer from heavy computation and lossy state representations, impeding robust, transferable solutions; a more efficient, modular approach is sought.
AI.method: Develop a modular RL framework optimized for simulation that reduces model size and training time; demonstrate sim-to-real transfer; evaluate on the SoftGym benchmark.
AI.result: Achieves significant performance improvements over baselines on SoftGym with a substantially smaller model and shorter training times; demonstrates successful transfer from simulation to real-world cloth manipulation.
AI.conclusion: Efficient, modular simulation-based RL can outperform end-to-end approaches and facilitate practical real-world deployment for cloth manipulation, addressing computational cost and data-efficiency concerns.

title: WorldBench: Disambiguating Physics for Diagnostic Evaluation of World Models
summary: Recent advances in generative foundational models, often termed "world models," have propelled interest in applying them to critical tasks like robotic planning and autonomous system training. For reliable deployment, these models must exhibit high physical fidelity, accurately simulating real-world dynamics. Existing physics-based video benchmarks, however, suffer from entanglement, where a single test simultaneously evaluates multiple physical laws and concepts, fundamentally limiting their diagnostic capability. We introduce WorldBench, a novel video-based benchmark specifically designed for concept-specific, disentangled evaluation, allowing us to rigorously isolate and assess understanding of a single physical concept or law at a time. To make WorldBench comprehensive, we design benchmarks at two different levels: 1) an evaluation of intuitive physical understanding with concepts such as object permanence or scale/perspective, and 2) an evaluation of low-level physical constants and material properties such as friction coefficients or fluid viscosity. When SOTA video-based world models are evaluated on WorldBench, we find specific patterns of failure in particular physics concepts, with all tested models lacking the physical consistency required to generate reliable real-world interactions. Through its concept-specific evaluation, WorldBench offers a more nuanced and scalable framework for rigorously evaluating the physical reasoning capabilities of video generation and world models, paving the way for more robust and generalizable world-model-driven learning.

AI.tldr: WorldBench offers disentangled, concept-specific video benchmarks to evaluate physics understanding in world models, enabling targeted diagnostics beyond entangled benchmarks.
AI.motivation: Existing physics benchmarks for video are entangled across multiple physical laws, hindering precise diagnosis of a model's understanding. A disentangled evaluation framework is needed to isolate learning of individual concepts.
AI.method: Introduce WorldBench with two levels: (1) intuitive physics concepts (e.g., object permanence, scale/perspective) and (2) low-level physical constants/material properties (e.g., friction coefficients, fluid viscosity). Tests are video-based and designed to isolate a single physical concept per evaluation. Evaluate SOTA video-based world models to identify concept-specific failure modes and assess physical consistency.
AI.result: State-of-the-art models exhibit concept-specific failure patterns and generally lack physical consistency for reliable real-world interactions, as revealed by WorldBench.
AI.conclusion: Concept-specific, disentangled benchmarks like WorldBench enable nuanced, scalable evaluation of physical reasoning in video models, guiding the development of more robust and generalizable world-model-driven learning.

title: Test-Time Adaptation for Unsupervised Combinatorial Optimization
summary: Unsupervised neural combinatorial optimization (NCO) enables learning powerful solvers without access to ground-truth solutions. Existing approaches fall into two disjoint paradigms: models trained for generalization across instances, and instance-specific models optimized independently at test time. While the former are efficient during inference, they lack effective instance-wise adaptability; the latter are flexible but fail to exploit learned inductive structure and are prone to poor local optima. This motivates the central question of our work: how can we leverage the inductive bias learned through generalization while unlocking the flexibility required for effective instance-wise adaptation? We first identify a challenge in bridging these two paradigms: generalization-focused models often constitute poor warm starts for instance-wise optimization, potentially underperforming even randomly initialized models when fine-tuned at test time. To resolve this incompatibility, we propose TACO, a model-agnostic test-time adaptation framework that unifies and extends the two existing paradigms for unsupervised NCO. TACO applies strategic warm-starting to partially relax trained parameters while preserving inductive bias, enabling rapid and effective unsupervised adaptation.
