Crucially, compared to naively fine-tuning a trained generalizable model or optimizing an instance-specific model from scratch, TACO achieves better solution quality while incurring negligible additional computational cost. Experiments on canonical CO problems, Minimum Vertex Cover and Maximum Clique, demonstrate the effectiveness and robustness of TACO across static, distribution-shifted, and dynamic combinatorial optimization problems, establishing it as a practical bridge between generalizable and instance-specific unsupervised NCO.

AI.tldr: TACO is a model-agnostic test-time adaptation framework that partially relaxes trained parameters to warm-start instance-wise unsupervised NCO, combining generalizable inductive bias with fast, effective adaptation, achieving better solutions at negligible cost. Validated on Minimum Vertex Cover and Maximum Clique across static and dynamic settings.
AI.motivation: Bridge the gap between generalization-based NCO models (efficient inference but limited instance-specific adaptation) and instance-specific optimization (flexible but lacks inductive structure and risks poor local optima). The challenge is warm-start quality: generalization-focused models may be poor warm starts for per-instance optimization.
AI.method: Introduce TACO, a model-agnostic test-time adaptation framework that strategically warm-starts by partially relaxing trained parameters while preserving inductive bias; leverages existing generalizable models and enables rapid unsupervised adaptation at test time; compute-efficient, avoids full fine-tuning or training from scratch.
AI.result: Empirical evaluation on Minimum Vertex Cover and Maximum Clique shows TACO improves solution quality over naive fine-tuning or training from scratch, robust to distribution shifts and dynamics, with negligible additional computation.
AI.conclusion: TACO effectively unifies generalizable and instance-specific unsupervised NCO, providing a practical bridge that preserves inductive bias while enabling fast, high-quality instance adaptation.

title: Do Reasoning Models Enhance Embedding Models?
comment: 10 main pages, 18 appendix pages, 13 figures, 11 tables, 4 prompts
summary: State-of-the-art embedding models are increasingly derived from decoder-only Large Language Model (LLM) backbones adapted via contrastive learning. Given the emergence of reasoning models trained via Reinforcement Learning with Verifiable Rewards (RLVR), a natural question arises: do enhanced reasoning translate to superior semantic representations when these models serve as embedding initializations? Contrary to expectation, our evaluation on MTEB and BRIGHT reveals a **null effect**: embedding models initialized from RLVR-tuned backbones yield no consistent performance advantage over their base counterparts when subjected to identical training recipes. To unpack this paradox, we introduce **H**ierarchical **R**epresentation **S**imilarity **A**nalysis (HRSA), a framework that decomposes similarity across representation, geometry, and function levels. HRSA reveals that while RLVR induces irreversible latent manifold's local geometry reorganization and reversible coordinate basis drift, it preserves the global manifold geometry and linear readout. Consequently, subsequent contrastive learning drives strong alignment between base- and reasoning-initialized models, a phenomenon we term **Manifold Realignment**. Empirically, our findings suggest that unlike Supervised Fine-Tuning (SFT), RLVR optimizes trajectories within an existing semantic landscape rather than fundamentally restructuring the landscape itself.

AI.tldr: RLVR-tuned backbones do not yield consistent gains for embedding quality when using the same training recipe; a new framework (HRSA) shows that RLVR reorganizes local geometry but preserves global geometry, leading to Manifold Realignment and convergence with base models under contrastive learning.
AI.motivation: To determine whether improved reasoning from RLVR translates into superior semantic representations for embeddings, and to understand the geometric/functional effects of RLVR on neural representations.
AI.method: Empirical evaluation of embedding models initialized from RLVR-tuned backbones versus base backbones on MTEB and BRIGHT under identical training recipes; development of HRSA to decompose similarity into representation, geometry, and function; analysis of local vs global geometry, coordinate basis drift, and linear readout; assessment of alignment after contrastive learning.
AI.result: Null effect: no consistent performance advantage from RLVR-initialized embeddings. HRSA reveals irreversible local geometry reorganization and reversible coordinate drift while preserving global manifold geometry and linear readout; strong alignment between base- and RLVR-initialized models after contrastive learning, termed Manifold Realignment.
AI.conclusion: RLVR tends to optimize trajectories within an existing semantic landscape rather than restructuring it; embedding performance with RLVR is explained by Manifold Realignment where RLVR and base models converge under the same training regime, unlike Supervised Fine-Tuning (SFT) which may redraw the landscape.

title: Flocking behavior for dynamic and complex swarm structures
summary: Maintaining the formation of complex structures with multiple UAVs and achieving complex trajectories remains a major challenge. This work presents an algorithm for implementing the flocking behavior of UAVs based on the concept of Virtual Centroid to easily develop a structure for the flock. The approach builds on the classical virtual-based behavior, providing a theoretical framework for incorporating enhancements to dynamically control both the number of agents and the formation of the structure. Simulation tests and real-world experiments were conducted, demonstrating its simplicity even with complex formations and complex trajectories.

AI.tldr: Proposes a Virtual Centroid–based flocking algorithm for multi-UAV formation with dynamic agent count, supported by simulations and real-world tests.
AI.motivation: Address the difficulty of preserving complex formations and trajectories in multi-UAV systems; need for a scalable, adaptable framework to control formation size and shape.
AI.method: Extends classical virtual-based flocking by introducing Virtual Centroid; defines the formation via a centroid reference and virtual forces; provides a theoretical framework to dynamically adjust agent count and formation; validates through simulations and real UAV experiments.
AI.result: Demonstrates simplicity and effectiveness even for intricate formations and trajectories; shows feasibility in both simulation and real-world tests.
AI.conclusion: Virtual Centroid-based flocking offers a practical, scalable approach with a solid theoretical basis for adaptive formation control in UAV swarms, enabling complex trajectories with variable agent numbers.

title: Gaussian Belief Propagation Network for Depth Completion
summary: Depth completion aims to predict a dense depth map from a color image with sparse depth measurements. Although deep learning methods have achieved state-of-the-art (SOTA), effectively handling the sparse and irregular nature of input depth data in deep networks remains a significant challenge, often limiting performance, especially under high sparsity. To overcome this limitation, we introduce the Gaussian Belief Propagation Network (GBPN), a novel hybrid framework synergistically integrating deep learning with probabilistic graphical models for end-to-end depth completion. Specifically, a scene-specific Markov Random Field (MRF) is dynamically constructed by the Graphical Model Construction Network (GMCN), and then inferred via Gaussian Belief Propagation (GBP) to yield the dense depth distribution. Crucially, the GMCN learns to construct not only the data-dependent potentials of MRF but also its structure by predicting adaptive non-local edges, enabling the capture of complex, long-range spatial dependencies. Furthermore, we enhance GBP with a serial \& parallel message passing scheme, designed for effective information propagation, particularly from sparse measurements. Extensive experiments demonstrate that GBPN achieves SOTA performance on the NYUv2 and KITTI benchmarks. Evaluations across varying sparsity levels, sparsity patterns, and datasets highlight GBPN's superior performance, notable robustness, and generalizable capability.

AI.tldr: Hybrid deep learning and probabilistic graphical model for depth completion: learns adaptive MRF structure via GMCN and uses Gaussian Belief Propagation with enhanced message passing to densify sparse depth; achieves SOTA on NYUv2 and KITTI with robustness to varying sparsity.
AI.motivation: Sparse and irregular depth inputs hinder deep networks; need to exploit long-range dependencies and non-local information for accurate dense depth completion.
AI.method: Dynamically construct a scene-specific MRF using GMCN that learns data potentials and adaptive non-local edges; perform inference via Gaussian Belief Propagation with a serial & parallel message passing scheme to propagate sparse measurements into dense depth.
AI.result: State-of-the-art performance on NYUv2 and KITTI; robust across different sparsity levels and patterns and across datasets, indicating good generalization.
AI.conclusion: GBPN effectively fuses deep learning with probabilistic graphical models to address sparse depth completion, with adaptive structure learning and enhanced GBP yielding superior performance and robustness.

title: When should I search more: Adaptive Complex Query Optimization with Reinforcement Learning
summary: Query optimization is a crucial component for the efficacy of Retrieval-Augmented Generation (RAG) systems. While reinforcement learning (RL)-based agentic and reasoning methods have recently emerged as a promising direction on query optimization, most existing approaches focus on the expansion and abstraction of a single query. However, complex user queries are prevalent in real-world scenarios, often requiring multiple parallel and sequential search strategies to handle disambiguation and decomposition. Directly applying RL to these complex cases introduces significant hurdles. Determining the optimal number of sub-queries and effectively re-ranking and merging retrieved documents vastly expands the search space and complicates reward design, frequently leading to training instability. To address these challenges, we propose a novel RL framework called Adaptive Complex Query Optimization (ACQO). Our framework is designed to adaptively determine when and how to expand the search process. It features two core components: an Adaptive Query Reformulation (AQR) module that dynamically decides when to decompose a query into multiple sub-queries, and a Rank-Score Fusion (RSF) module that ensures robust result aggregation and provides stable reward signals for the learning agent. To mitigate training instabilities, we adopt a Curriculum Reinforcement Learning (CRL) approach, which stabilizes the training process by progressively introducing more challenging queries through a two-stage strategy. Our comprehensive experiments demonstrate that ACQO achieves state-of-the-art performance on three complex query benchmarks, significantly outperforming established baselines. The framework also showcases improved computational efficiency and broad compatibility with different retrieval architectures, establishing it as a powerful and generalizable solution for next-generation RAG systems.

AI.tldr: ACQO: an RL framework for adaptive complex query optimization in RAG, featuring Adaptive Query Reformulation (AQR) and Rank-Score Fusion (RSF), trained with Curriculum RL. It achieves state-of-the-art results on three complex-query benchmarks, improves efficiency, and is architecture-agnostic.
AI.motivation: Real-world user queries often require multiple parallel/sequence search steps (disambiguation and decomposition). Existing RL-based query optimization struggles with expanding to multiple sub-queries due to search space growth and training instability.
AI.method: Introduce Adaptive Complex Query Optimization (ACQO) with two modules: (1) Adaptive Query Reformulation (AQR) to decide when to decompose a query into sub-queries; (2) Rank-Score Fusion (RSF) to robustly aggregate results and provide stable rewards. Training uses Curriculum Reinforcement Learning (CRL) with a two-stage progression to gradually introduce harder queries, stabilizing learning.
AI.result: Empirical evaluation shows ACQO achieves state-of-the-art performance on three complex query benchmarks, with significant improvements over baselines, and enhanced computational efficiency. Demonstrates broad compatibility with different retrieval architectures.
AI.conclusion: ACQO is a powerful and generalizable solution for next-generation RAG systems, enabling adaptive, efficient handling of complex queries via decomposition and robust fusion, with stable training through curriculum learning.

title: GAZELOAD A Multimodal Eye-Tracking Dataset for Mental Workload in Industrial Human-Robot Collaboration
summary: This article describes GAZELOAD, a multimodal dataset for mental workload estimation in industrial human-robot collaboration. The data were collected in a laboratory assembly testbed where 26 participants interacted with two collaborative robots (UR5 and Franka Emika Panda) while wearing Meta ARIA smart glasses. The dataset time-synchronizes eye-tracking signals (pupil diameter, fixations, saccades, eye gaze, gaze transition entropy, fixation dispersion index) with environmental real-time and continuous measurements (illuminance) and task and robot context (bench, task block, induced faults), under controlled manipulations of task difficulty and ambient conditions. For each participant and workload-graded task block, we provide CSV files with ocular metrics aggregated into 250 ms windows, environmental logs, and self-reported mental workload ratings on a 1-10 Likert scale, organized in participant-specific folders alongside documentation. These data can be used to develop and benchmark algorithms for mental workload estimation, feature extraction, and temporal modeling in realistic industrial HRC scenarios, and to investigate the influence of environmental factors such as lighting on eye-based workload markers.

AI.tldr: GAZELOAD is a multimodal dataset for estimating mental workload in industrial human-robot collaboration, combining eye-tracking metrics with environmental and task context in a controlled lab setting.
AI.motivation: Addresses the need for realistic, labeled data to develop and benchmark mental workload estimation, feature extraction, and temporal models, and to study environmental influences (e.g., lighting) on eye-based markers in HRC.
AI.method: Data collected with 26 participants interacting with UR5 and Panda robots in a lab; participants wore Meta ARIA glasses; synchronized ocular signals (pupil diameter, fixations, saccades, gaze, entropy, dispersion) with environmental data (illuminance) and task/robot context (bench, task block, induced faults); tasks varied in difficulty; ocular metrics aggregated in 250 ms windows; CSVs per participant; self-reported workload ratings (1-10); organized with documentation.
AI.result: Provides a ready-to-use dataset for mental workload estimation and temporal modeling in industrial HRC; enables analysis of environmental factors on eye-based workload markers; can be used for feature extraction and benchmarking.
AI.conclusion: GAZELOAD offers a realistic, labeled resource for researchers to develop, validate and compare workload estimation methods in industrial settings, supporting future HRC design and human factors studies.

title: Mam-App: A Novel Parameter-Efficient Mamba Model for Apple Leaf Disease Classification
summary: The rapid growth of the global population, alongside exponential technological advancement, has intensified the demand for food production. Meeting this demand depends not only on increasing agricultural yield but also on minimizing food loss caused by crop diseases. Diseases account for a substantial portion of apple production losses, despite apples being among the most widely produced and nutritionally valuable fruits worldwide. Previous studies have employed machine learning techniques for feature extraction and early diagnosis of apple leaf diseases, and more recently, deep learning-based models have shown remarkable performance in disease recognition. However, most state-of-the-art deep learning models are highly parameter-intensive, resulting in increased training and inference time. Although lightweight models are more suitable for user-friendly and resource-constrained applications, they often suffer from performance degradation. To address the trade-off between efficiency and performance, we propose Mam-App, a parameter-efficient Mamba-based model for feature extraction and leaf disease classification. The proposed approach achieves competitive state-of-the-art performance on the PlantVillage Apple Leaf Disease dataset, attaining 99.58% accuracy, 99.30% precision, 99.14% recall, and a 99.22% F1-score, while using only 0.051M parameters. This extremely low parameter count makes the model suitable for deployment on drones, mobile devices, and other low-resource platforms. To demonstrate the robustness and generalizability of the proposed model, we further evaluate it on the PlantVillage Corn Leaf Disease and Potato Leaf Disease datasets. The model achieves 99.48%, 99.20%, 99.34%, and 99.27% accuracy, precision, recall, and F1-score on the corn dataset and 98.46%, 98.91%, 95.39%, and 97.01% on the potato dataset, respectively.

AI.tldr: Mam-App is a highly parameter-efficient model for apple, corn, and potato leaf disease classification, achieving near state-of-the-art accuracy with only 0.051M parameters, enabling deployment on low-resource platforms, but real-world robustness warrants further validation.
AI.motivation: Growing global population and technological progress raise demand for high-yield, low-loss crop production. Apple diseases cause significant losses. There is a need for lightweight yet accurate models for timely disease diagnosis on resource-constrained devices (e.g., drones, mobile devices).
AI.method: Introduce Mam-App, a parameter-efficient Mamba-based feature extractor and leaf disease classifier. Evaluate on PlantVillage Apple Leaf Disease dataset (Apple results: 99.58% acc, 99.30% precision, 99.14% recall, 99.22% F1; 0.051M params) and test generalization on PlantVillage Corn Leaf Disease and Potato Leaf Disease datasets (Corn: 99.48/99.20/99.34/99.27; Potato: 98.46/98.91/95.39/97.01).
AI.result: Achieves very high accuracy and other metrics on all three datasets with a remarkably low parameter count. Demonstrates potential for deployment on drones and mobile devices due to efficiency, while maintaining competitive performance.
AI.conclusion: Mam-App offers an excellent efficiency–performance trade-off for leaf-disease classification across multiple crops, suggesting strong robustness and generalizability on PlantVillage datasets. Validation on real-world field data and comparisons with other lightweight architectures would strengthen claims of real-world deployment readiness.

title: Snowball: A Scalable All-to-All Ising Machine with Dual-Mode Markov Chain Monte Carlo Spin Selection and Asynchronous Spin Updates for Fast Combinatorial Optimization
summary:
Ising machines have emerged as accelerators for combinatorial optimization. To enable practical deployment, this work aims to reduce time-to-solution by addressing three challenges: (1) hardware topology, (2) spin selection and update algorithms, and (3) scalable coupling-coefficient precision. Restricted topologies require minor embedding; naive parallel updates can oscillate or stall; and limited precision can preclude feasible mappings or degrade solution quality.
  This work presents Snowball, a digital, scalable, all-to-all coupled Ising machine that integrates dual-mode Markov chain Monte Carlo spin selection with asynchronous spin updates to promote convergence and reduce time-to-solution. The digital architecture supports wide, configurable coupling precision, unlike many analog realizations at high bit widths. A prototype on an AMD Alveo U250 accelerator card achieves an 8$\times$ reduction in time-to-solution relative to a state-of-the-art Ising machine on the same benchmark instance.

AI.tldr: Snowball is a digital, scalable all-to-all coupled Ising machine that uses dual-mode Markov chain Monte Carlo spin selection with asynchronous spin updates to speed up convergence; it supports wide coupling precision and demonstrates an 8x time-to-solution improvement on an AMD Alveo U250.
AI.motivation: To enable practical deployment of Ising-machine based optimizers by reducing time-to-solution through (i) better hardware topology, (ii) improved spin-selection/update algorithms, and (iii) scalable coupling-precision.
AI.method: Architect Snowball as a digital, all-to-all coupled Ising machine with dual-mode MCMC spin selection and asynchronous spin updates; implement wide, configurable coupling precision; realize a prototype on an AMD Alveo U250 accelerator card.
AI.result: The prototype achieves approximately 8× reduction in time-to-solution compared with a state-of-the-art Ising machine on the same benchmark instance.
AI.conclusion: Digital, scalable, all-to-all Ising machines with dual-mode MCMC spin selection and asynchronous updates can significantly reduce time-to-solution and improve practicality, leveraging hardware with configurable precision.

title: Uncovering Hidden Correctness in LLM Causal Reasoning via Symbolic Verification
summary: Large language models (LLMs) are increasingly being applied to tasks that involve causal reasoning. However, current benchmarks often rely on string matching or surface-level metrics that do not capture whether the output of a model is formally valid under the semantics of causal reasoning. To address this, we propose DoVerifier, a simple symbolic verifier that checks whether LLM-generated causal expressions are derivable from a given causal graph using rules from do-calculus and probability theory. This allows us to recover correct answers to causal queries that would otherwise be marked incorrect due to superficial differences in their causal semantics. Our evaluations on synthetic data and causal QA benchmarks show that DoVerifier more accurately captures semantic correctness of causal reasoning traces, offering a more rigorous and informative way to evaluate LLMs on causal reasoning.

AI.tldr: DoVerifier is a symbolic verifier that checks LLM-generated causal expressions for derivability from a causal graph using do-calculus and probability theory, enabling semantic correctness evaluation beyond surface-level string matching.
AI.motivation: Current causal reasoning benchmarks rely on surface text similarity, which misaligns with formal semantic validity. A formal verifier can assess whether outputs are causally and probabilistically valid given a graph, improving evaluation fidelity.
AI.method: Introduce DoVerifier, a symbolic verifier that consumes a causal graph and a candidate causal expression or query from an LLM, and applies do-calculus and probability theory rules to verify derivability and correctness of the expression.
AI.result: Empirical validation on synthetic data and causal QA benchmarks shows that DoVerifier more accurately captures semantic correctness of causal reasoning traces than surface metrics, providing a rigorous evaluation of LLM causal reasoning.
AI.conclusion: DoVerifier offers a principled, rigorous approach to evaluating LLMs on causal reasoning by validating derivability from causal graphs, potentially recovering correct answers that surface-only metrics miss.

title: LLM-Driven Scenario-Aware Planning for Autonomous Driving
summary: Hybrid planner switching framework (HPSF) for autonomous driving needs to reconcile high-speed driving efficiency with safe maneuvering in dense traffic. Existing HPSF methods often fail to make reliable mode transitions or sustain efficient driving in congested environments, owing to heuristic scene recognition and low-frequency control updates. To address the limitation, this paper proposes LAP, a large language model (LLM) driven, adaptive planning method, which switches between high-speed driving in low-complexity scenes and precise driving in high-complexity scenes, enabling high qualities of trajectory generation through confined gaps. This is achieved by leveraging LLM for scene understanding and integrating its inference into the joint optimization of mode configuration and motion planning. The joint optimization is solved using tree-search model predictive control and alternating minimization. We implement LAP by Python in Robot Operating System (ROS). High-fidelity simulation results show that the proposed LAP outperforms other benchmarks in terms of both driving time and success rate.

AI.tldr: A novel LAP method uses LLM-driven adaptive planning to switch between high-speed and precise driving in autonomous vehicles, with joint optimization via tree-search MPC and alternating minimization, implemented in ROS, yielding better driving time and success rates in simulation.
AI.motivation: Address unreliable mode transitions and low control update frequency in existing Hybrid Planner Switching Frameworks (HPSFs) for autonomous driving, especially in dense traffic.
AI.method: Integrates LLM-based scene understanding into joint optimization of mode configuration and motion planning. Solves via tree-search model predictive control and alternating minimization. Implemented in Python within ROS and evaluated in high-fidelity simulations.
AI.result: LAP outperforms benchmarks in driving time and success rate in simulations.
AI.conclusion: LLM-driven adaptive planning with joint optimization improves mode switching reliability and trajectory quality in autonomous driving under varying scene complexity.

title: HiFi-Mesh: High-Fidelity Efficient 3D Mesh Generation via Compact Autoregressive Dependence
summary: High-fidelity 3D meshes can be tokenized into one-dimension (1D) sequences and directly modeled using autoregressive approaches for faces and vertices. However, existing methods suffer from insufficient resource utilization, resulting in slow inference and the ability to handle only small-scale sequences, which severely constrains the expressible structural details. We introduce the Latent Autoregressive Network (LANE), which incorporates compact autoregressive dependencies in the generation process, achieving a $6\times$ improvement in maximum generatable sequence length compared to existing methods. To further accelerate inference, we propose the Adaptive Computation Graph Reconfiguration (AdaGraph) strategy, which effectively overcomes the efficiency bottleneck of traditional serial inference through spatiotemporal decoupling in the generation process. Experimental validation demonstrates that LANE achieves superior performance across generation speed, structural detail, and geometric consistency, providing an effective solution for high-quality 3D mesh generation.

AI.tldr: LANE uses latent autoregressive dependencies to model 3D mesh tokens; AdaGraph enables adaptive computation; achieves 6x longer sequences and faster inference with improved detail and geometry.
AI.motivation: Existing autoregressive models for tokenized 3D meshes suffer from inefficient resource usage and limited maximum sequence length, restricting expressible structural detail.
AI.method: Proposes Latent Autoregressive Network (LANE) with compact autoregressive dependencies for 1D mesh tokens, and Adaptive Computation Graph Reconfiguration (AdaGraph) that enables spatiotemporal decoupling to speed up generation.
AI.result: LANE achieves a 6× increase in the maximum generatable sequence length, faster inference, and superior performance in speed, structural detail, and geometric consistency on high-fidelity 3D mesh generation.
AI.conclusion: LANE, combined with AdaGraph, provides an effective solution for high-quality 3D mesh generation with improved efficiency and fidelity, enabling larger and more detailed meshes.

title: Human-LLM Collaborative Feature Engineering for Tabular Data
summary: Large language models (LLMs) are increasingly used to automate feature engineering in tabular learning. Given task-specific information, LLMs can propose diverse feature transformation operations to enhance downstream model performance. However, current approaches typically assign the LLM as a black-box optimizer, responsible for both proposing and selecting operations based solely on its internal heuristics, which often lack calibrated estimations of operation utility and consequently lead to repeated exploration of low-yield operations without a principled strategy for prioritizing promising directions. In this paper, we propose a human-LLM collaborative feature engineering framework for tabular learning. We begin by decoupling the transformation operation proposal and selection processes, where LLMs are used solely to generate operation candidates, while the selection is guided by explicitly modeling the utility and uncertainty of each proposed operation. Since accurate utility estimation can be difficult especially in the early rounds of feature engineering, we design a mechanism within the framework that selectively elicits and incorporates human expert preference feedback, comparing which operations are more promising, into the selection process to help identify more effective operations. Our evaluations on both the synthetic study and the real user study demonstrate that the proposed framework improves feature engineering performance across a variety of tabular datasets and reduces users' cognitive load during the feature engineering process.

AI.tldr: A decoupled, human-in-the-loop framework for tabular feature engineering that uses LLMs to propose operations and a separate utility/uncertainty model with optional human preferences to select them.
AI.motivation: LLMs as black-box optimizers yield uncalibrated operation utilities and waste exploration; introducing calibrated selection and human feedback can improve efficiency and performance.
AI.method: Two-stage approach: (1) LLMs generate diverse feature transformation candidates; (2) a principled selection module estimates utility and uncertainty for each candidate; (3) optional human expert feedback is elicited to steer selection; evaluation via synthetic and real-user studies across tabular datasets.
AI.result: Framework improves feature engineering performance and reduces users' cognitive load across various datasets.
AI.conclusion: Explicitly decoupling proposal and selection with uncertainty modeling and human feedback yields more effective, user-friendly feature engineering for tabular data.

title: Intelli-Planner: Towards Customized Urban Planning via Large Language Model Empowered Reinforcement Learning
summary: Effective urban planning is crucial for enhancing residents' quality of life and ensuring societal stability, playing a pivotal role in the sustainable development of cities. Current planning methods heavily rely on human experts, which are time-consuming and labor-intensive, or utilize deep learning algorithms, often limiting stakeholder involvement. To bridge these gaps, we propose Intelli-Planner, a novel framework integrating Deep Reinforcement Learning (DRL) with large language models (LLMs) to facilitate participatory and customized planning scheme generation. Intelli-Planner utilizes demographic, geographic data, and planning preferences to determine high-level planning requirements and demands for each functional type. During training, a knowledge enhancement module is employed to enhance the decision-making capability of the policy network. Additionally, we establish a multi-dimensional evaluation system and employ LLM-based stakeholders for satisfaction scoring. Experimental validation across diverse urban settings shows that Intelli-Planner surpasses traditional baselines and achieves comparable performance to state-of-the-art DRL-based methods in objective metrics, while enhancing stakeholder satisfaction and convergence speed. These findings underscore the effectiveness and superiority of our framework, highlighting the potential for integrating the latest advancements in LLMs with DRL approaches to revolutionize tasks related to functional areas planning.

AI.tldr: Intelli-Planner is a framework that fuses Deep Reinforcement Learning with Large Language Models to enable participatory, customized urban planning, using demographic/geographic data and planning preferences; features a knowledge-enhancement module, multi-dimensional evaluation, and LLM-based stakeholder satisfaction scoring; reported to outperform traditional baselines and match state-of-the-art DRL methods on objective metrics while improving stakeholder satisfaction and convergence speed.
AI.motivation: Traditional urban planning relies on costly human expertise or deep learning with limited stakeholder involvement, hindering participatory, scalable planning. There is a need for a method that combines data-driven optimization with stakeholder-centric feedback.
AI.method: A DRL-based planning policy augmented by a knowledge enhancement module; integration with LLMs to incorporate stakeholder input and generate planning schemes. Uses demographic, geographic data, and planning preferences to determine high-level planning requirements and demands for each functional type. Includes a multi-dimensional evaluation framework and LLM-driven stakeholder satisfaction scoring.
AI.result: The approach outperforms traditional baselines and achieves comparable performance to state-of-the-art DRL methods in objective metrics, while enhancing stakeholder satisfaction and convergence speed across diverse urban settings.
AI.conclusion: Integrating LLMs with DRL is effective for functional-area urban planning and has strong potential to revolutionize participatory planning by combining data-driven optimization with stakeholder-centric evaluation.

title: Multi-Modular MANTA-RAY: A Modular Soft Surface Platform for Distributed Multi-Object Manipulation
summary: Manipulation surfaces control objects by actively deforming their shape rather than directly grasping them. While dense actuator arrays can generate complex deformations, they also introduce high degrees of freedom (DOF), increasing system complexity and limiting scalability. The MANTA-RAY (Manipulation with Adaptive Non-rigid Textile Actuation with Reduced Actuation densitY) platform addresses these challenges by leveraging a soft, fabric-based surface with reduced actuator density to manipulate fragile and heterogeneous objects. Previous studies focused on single-module implementations supported by four actuators, whereas the feasibility and benefits of a scalable, multi-module configuration remain unexplored. In this work, we present a distributed, modular, and scalable variant of the MANTA-RAY platform that maintains manipulation performance with a reduced actuator density. The proposed multi-module MANTA-RAY platform and control strategy employs object passing between modules and a geometric transformation driven PID controller that directly maps tilt-angle control outputs to actuator commands, eliminating the need for extensive data-driven or black-box training. We evaluate system performance in simulation across surface configurations of varying modules (3x3 and 4x4) and validate its feasibility through experiments on a physical 2x2 hardware prototype. The system successfully manipulates objects with diverse geometries, masses, and textures including fragile items such as eggs and apples as well as enabling parallel manipulation. The results demonstrate that the multi-module MANTA-RAY improves scalability and enables coordinated manipulation of multiple objects across larger areas, highlighting its potential for practical, real-world applications.

AI.tldr: A scalable, multi-module MANTA-RAY platform uses a soft, fabric surface with reduced actuator density to manipulate fragile objects. It enables object passing between modules and uses a geometric transformation–driven PID controller that maps tilt outputs directly to actuator commands. Demonstrated in simulation (3x3 and 4x4 modules) and experimentally on a 2x2 prototype, showing maintained performance and parallel manipulation across larger areas.
AI.motivation: Reduce high DOF and system complexity from dense actuator arrays while preserving manipulation capabilities across larger surfaces and across heterogeneous, fragile objects.
AI.method: Develop a distributed, modular platform with object passing between modules. Employ a geometric transformation driven PID controller that directly maps tilt-angle control outputs to actuator commands, avoiding extensive data-driven training. Validate via simulations with varying module counts and hardware experiments on a 2x2 prototype.
AI.result: Feasibility established: manipulation performance is preserved with reduced actuator density. The system handles diverse geometries, masses, and textures (including fragile items) and supports parallel manipulation, indicating improved scalability across larger surfaces.
AI.conclusion: Multi-module MANTA-RAY offers scalable, coordinated manipulation over larger areas with fewer actuators while maintaining performance, showing promise for practical, real-world applications. Future work could further scale module counts and address real-world deployment considerations.

title: Optimal Transport-Induced Samples against Out-of-Distribution Overconfidence
summary: Deep neural networks (DNNs) often produce overconfident predictions on out-of-distribution (OOD) inputs, undermining their reliability in open-world environments. Singularities in semi-discrete optimal transport (OT) mark regions of semantic ambiguity, where classifiers are particularly prone to unwarranted high-confidence predictions. Motivated by this observation, we propose a principled framework to mitigate OOD overconfidence by leveraging the geometry of OT-induced singular boundaries. Specifically, we formulate an OT problem between a continuous base distribution and the latent embeddings of training data, and identify the resulting singular boundaries. By sampling near these boundaries, we construct a class of OOD inputs, termed optimal transport-induced OOD samples (OTIS), which are geometrically grounded and inherently semantically ambiguous. During training, a confidence suppression loss is applied to OTIS to guide the model toward more calibrated predictions in structurally uncertain regions. Extensive experiments show that our method significantly alleviates OOD overconfidence and outperforms state-of-the-art methods.

AI.tldr: We propose OTIS: sampling near OT-induced singular boundaries between a base distribution and training latent embeddings to generate semantically ambiguous OOD inputs, then apply a confidence suppression loss to calibrate predictions and reduce OOD overconfidence, achieving state-of-the-art performance.
AI.motivation: DNNs exhibit overconfidence on OOD inputs; semi-discrete OT creates singular boundaries that correspond to semantic ambiguity, motivating a calibration method that targets these regions.
AI.method: Compute an OT plan between a continuous base distribution and training-data latent embeddings to identify singular boundaries; sample near these boundaries to create OTIS; apply confidence suppression loss during training to push predictions toward calibration on OTIS-rich regions.
AI.result: Experiments indicate significant reduction of OOD overconfidence and outperforming baseline methods.
AI.conclusion: Exploiting OT-induced geometric boundaries yields principled, geometry-aware OOD calibration via targeted samples (OTIS) and a dedicated loss, enhancing reliability in open-world settings.

title: Signal from Structure: Exploiting Submodular Upper Bounds in Generative Flow Networks
summary: Generative Flow Networks (GFlowNets; GFNs) are a class of generative models that learn to sample compositional objects proportionally to their a priori unknown value, their reward. We focus on the case where the reward has a specified, actionable structure, namely that it is submodular. We show submodularity can be harnessed to retrieve upper bounds on the reward of compositional objects that have not yet been observed. We provide in-depth analyses of the probability of such bounds occurring, as well as how many unobserved compositional objects can be covered by a bound. Following the Optimism in the Face of Uncertainty principle, we then introduce SUBo-GFN, which uses the submodular upper bounds to train a GFN. We show that SUBo-GFN generates orders of magnitude more training data than classical GFNs for the same number of queries to the reward function. We demonstrate the effectiveness of SUBo-GFN in terms of distribution matching and high-quality candidate generation on synthetic and real-world submodular tasks.

AI.tldr: Submodular rewards enable upper bounds in Generative Flow Networks (GFlowNets); SUBo-GFN uses optimism to exploit these bounds, improving data efficiency and candidate generation, validated on synthetic and real-world submodular tasks.
AI.motivation: To exploit submodularity to bound the value of unseen compositional objects, enabling more data-efficient training of GFlowNets and better candidate generation under unknown rewards.
AI.method: Derive submodular upper bounds for unobserved objects; analyze probability and coverage of these bounds; apply Optimism in the Face of Uncertainty to train a GFN (SUBo-GFN) using upper bounds; compare data efficiency and performance against classical GFNs on synthetic and real submodular tasks.
AI.result: SUBo-GFN achieves orders of magnitude more training data per reward query than classical GFNs and demonstrates improved distribution matching and high-quality candidate generation on both synthetic and real-world submodular tasks.
AI.conclusion: Submodularity-based upper bounds, coupled with optimistic training, significantly boost data efficiency and performance of GFlowNets in submodular settings, enabling better exploration and generation of high-quality compositional candidates.

title: Causal Discovery for Explainable AI: A Dual-Encoding Approach
summary: Understanding causal relationships among features is fundamental for explaining machine learning model decisions. However, traditional causal discovery methods face challenges with categorical variables due to numerical instability in conditional independence testing. We propose a dual-encoding causal discovery approach that addresses these limitations by running constraint-based algorithms with complementary encoding strategies and merging results through majority voting. Applied to the Titanic dataset, our method identifies causal structures that align with established explainable methods.

AI.tldr: Dual-encoding ensemble for constraint-based causal discovery on categorical features; stability via majority voting across encodings; applied to Titanic dataset with results aligning to explainable ML methods.
AI.motivation: Categorical variables pose numerical instability in conditional independence tests, hindering reliable causal discovery. A robust approach is needed to stabilize CI testing and produce trustworthy causal graphs.
AI.method: The approach runs constraint-based causal discovery under two complementary encodings of categorical features and merges the inferred graphs via majority voting to obtain a stable causal structure.
AI.result: Applied to the Titanic dataset, the method yields causal structures that align with established explainable methods, indicating both feasibility and consistency with known explanations.
AI.conclusion: The dual-encoding ensemble mitigates CI-test instability for categorical data and delivers stable, interpretable causal graphs that correspond with prior explainable-methods; it warrants broader validation and potentially extension to other datasets.

title: Information Filtering via Variational Regularization for Robot Manipulation
summary: Diffusion-based visuomotor policies built on 3D visual representations have achieved strong performance in learning complex robotic skills. However, most existing methods employ an oversized denoising decoder. While increasing model capacity can improve denoising, empirical evidence suggests that it also introduces redundancy and noise in intermediate feature blocks. Crucially, we find that randomly masking backbone features at inference time (without changing training) can improve performance, confirming the presence of task-irrelevant noise in intermediate features. To this end, we propose Variational Regularization (VR), a lightweight module that imposes a timestep-conditioned Gaussian over backbone features and applies a KL-divergence regularizer, forming an adaptive information bottleneck. Extensive experiments on three simulation benchmarks (RoboTwin2.0, Adroit, and MetaWorld) show that, compared to the baseline DP3, our approach improves the success rate by 6.1% on RoboTwin2.0 and by 4.1% on Adroit and MetaWorld, achieving new state-of-the-art results. Real-world experiments further demonstrate that our method performs well in practical deployments. Code will released.

AI.tldr: A lightweight variational regularization module (VR) for diffusion-based visuomotor policies reduces task-irrelevant intermediate feature noise via a timestep-conditioned Gaussian bottleneck with KL regularization, yielding state-of-the-art performance on RoboTwin2.0, Adroit, and MetaWorld, and showing real-world viability.
AI.motivation: Excessive capacity in denoising decoders can introduce redundancy and noise in intermediate backbone features. Random inference-time masking reveals task-irrelevant noise. A compact information bottleneck is needed to suppress such noise without large model changes.
AI.method: Introduce Variational Regularization (VR): a lightweight module applied to backbone features that imposes a timestep-conditioned Gaussian prior over features and adds a KL-divergence regularizer, forming an adaptive information bottleneck to improve denoising in diffusion-based visuomotor policies.
AI.result: On RoboTwin2.0, Adroit, and MetaWorld benchmarks, VR improves the success rate by 6.1% (RoboTwin2.0) and 4.1% (Adroit and MetaWorld) over the baseline DP3, achieving state-of-the-art results. Real-world experiments confirm practical deployment viability; code will be released.
AI.conclusion: VR effectively suppresses task-irrelevant noise in intermediate features with minimal overhead, delivering consistent improvements across simulated benchmarks and real-world tests, and offering a practical, generalizable approach for diffusion-based visuomotor systems.

title: Do Pathology Foundation Models Encode Disease Progression? A Pseudotime Analysis of Visual Representations
summary: Vision foundation models trained on discretely sampled images achieve strong performance on classification benchmarks, yet whether their representations encode the continuous processes underlying their training data remains unclear. This question is especially pertinent in computational pathology, where we posit that models whose latent representations implicitly capture continuous disease progression may better reflect underlying biology, support more robust generalization, and enable quantitative analyses of features associated with disease transitions. Using diffusion pseudotime, a method developed to infer developmental trajectories from single-cell transcriptomics, we probe whether foundation models organize disease states along coherent progression directions in representation space. Across four cancer progressions and six models, we find that all pathology-specific models recover trajectory orderings significantly exceeding null baselines, with vision-only models achieving the highest fidelities $(τ> 0.78$ on CRC-Serrated). Model rankings by trajectory fidelity on reference diseases strongly predict few-shot classification performance on held-out diseases ($ρ= 0.92$), and exploratory analysis shows cell-type composition varies smoothly along inferred trajectories in patterns consistent with known stromal remodeling. Together, these results demonstrate that vision foundation models can implicitly learn to represent continuous processes from independent static observations, and that trajectory fidelity provides a complementary measure of representation quality beyond downstream performance. While demonstrated in pathology, this framework could be applied to other domains where continuous processes are observed through static snapshots.

AI.tldr: Vision foundation models trained on discretely sampled pathology images implicitly organize disease progression trajectories in representation space; diffusion pseudotime reveals trajectory fidelity that correlates with few-shot transfer, offering a complementary representation quality metric.
AI.motivation: To determine whether static image training data can encode continuous biological processes and whether such representations improve robustness and quantitative analysis in computational pathology.
AI.method: Apply diffusion pseudotime to latent representations from six models (pathology-specific and vision-only) across four cancer progressions; assess trajectory orderings against null baselines; quantify trajectory fidelity (τ); examine correlation with few-shot classification on held-out diseases (ρ); analyze cell-type composition along inferred trajectories.
AI.result: All pathology-specific models recover trajectory orderings significantly better than null baselines; vision-only models achieve the highest fidelity (τ > 0.78 on CRC-Serrated). Trajectory fidelity rankings strongly predict few-shot performance (ρ = 0.92). Exploratory analysis shows cell-type composition varies smoothly along trajectories, aligning with known stromal remodeling.
AI.conclusion: Vision foundation models can implicitly learn continuous disease progression from static observations; trajectory fidelity is a complementary metric of representation quality beyond downstream performance. The framework could generalize to other domains with continuous processes observed as static snapshots.

title: Textual Equilibrium Propagation for Deep Compound AI Systems
summary: Large language models (LLMs) are increasingly deployed as part of compound AI systems that coordinate multiple modules (e.g., retrievers, tools, verifiers) over long-horizon workflows. Recent approaches that propagate textual feedback globally (e.g., TextGrad) make it feasible to optimize such pipelines, but we find that performance degrades as system depth grows. In particular, long-horizon agentic workflows exhibit two depth-scaling failure modes: 1) exploding textual gradient, where textual feedback grows exponentially with depth, leading to prohibitively long message and amplifies evaluation biases; and 2) vanishing textual gradient, where limited long-context ability causes models overemphasize partial feedback and compression of lengthy feedback causes downstream messages to lose specificity gradually as they propagate many hops upstream. To mitigate these issues, we introduce Textual Equilibrium Propagation (TEP), a local learning principle inspired by Equilibrium Propagation in energy-based models. TEP includes two phases: 1) a free phase where a local LLM critics iteratively refine prompts until reaching equilibrium (no further improvements are suggested); and 2) a nudged phase which applies proximal prompt edits with bounded modification intensity, using task-level objectives that propagate via forward signaling rather than backward feedback chains. This design supports local prompt optimization followed by controlled adaptation toward global goals without the computational burden and signal degradation of global textual backpropagation. Across long-horizon QA benchmarks and multi-agent tool-use dataset, TEP consistently improves accuracy and efficiency over global propagation methods such as TextGrad. The gains grows with depth, while preserving the practicality of black-box LLM components in deep compound AI system.

AI.tldr: Proposes Textual Equilibrium Propagation (TEP) to address depth-scaling issues in global textual feedback for long-horizon LLM-based pipelines. It uses a two-phase, locally-driven learning scheme—free phase with local LLM critics reaching prompt equilibrium, and a nudged phase with bounded prompt edits—to avoid backpropagation through long prompt chains. TEP improves accuracy and efficiency over global methods like TextGrad, with gains that grow with system depth.
AI.motivation: In long-horizon, multi-module AI systems, propagating textual feedback globally leads to exploding or vanishing gradients across depth, causing inefficiency and degraded performance. A localized learning principle that can still guide global goals is sought to maintain scalability and practicality with black-box LLM components.
AI.method: Introduce Textual Equilibrium Propagation (TEP) with two phases: (1) free phase where local LLM critics iteratively refine prompts until equilibrium is reached (no further suggested improvements); (2) nudged phase applying proximal prompt edits with bounded modification intensity, using task-level objectives that propagate forward rather than via deep textual backpropagation. This enables local optimization followed by controlled adaptation toward global goals without heavy gradient chaining.
AI.result: Empirical evaluation on long-horizon QA benchmarks and multi-agent tool-use datasets shows that TEP consistently improves accuracy and efficiency over global propagation methods (e.g., TextGrad). The performance gains scale with system depth, while preserving the practicality of black-box LLM components in deep compound AI systems.
AI.conclusion: TEP offers a scalable, local learning paradigm for coordinating deep, multi-module AI systems by avoiding gradient explosion/vanishing in global textual feedback while delivering competitive or superior accuracy and efficiency, especially as system depth increases.

title: Delegation Without Living Governance
summary: Most governance frameworks assume that rules can be defined in advance, systems can be engineered to comply, and accountability can be applied after outcomes occur. This model worked when machines replaced physical labor or accelerated calculation. It no longer holds when judgment itself is delegated to agentic AI systems operating at machine speed. The central issue here is not safety, efficiency, or employment. It is whether humans remain relevant participants in systems that increasingly shape social, economic, and political outcomes. This paper argues that static, compliance-based governance fails once decision-making moves to runtime and becomes opaque. It further argues that the core challenge is not whether AI is conscious, but whether humans can maintain meaningful communication, influence, and co-evolution with increasingly alien forms of intelligence. We position runtime governance, specifically, a newly proposed concept called the Governance Twin [1]; as a strong candidate for preserving human relevance, while acknowledging that accountability, agency, and even punishment must be rethought in this transition.

AI.tldr: Shifts governance from pre-defined, post-hoc compliance to runtime, opaque AI decisions; introduces Governance Twin to preserve human relevance and requires rethinking accountability and agency.
AI.motivation: As AI systems operate at machine speed and increasingly shape social, economic, and political outcomes, static, compliance-based governance fails to ensure meaningful human participation.
AI.method: Conceptual analysis proposing runtime governance and the Governance Twin as a design-and-policy framework; argues for redefining accountability, agency, and sanction mechanisms in this transition.
AI.result: The abstract contends that static governance is inadequate for runtime AI decision-making and presents Governance Twin as a strong candidate to preserve human relevance, while noting that accountability, agency, and punishment must be rethought in this transition.
AI.conclusion: Governance Twin offers a promising path to keeping humans meaningfully involved as AI systems become more autonomous and ‘alien’, though practical implementation and normative changes to accountability structures are needed.

title: MoE-ACT: Improving Surgical Imitation Learning Policies through Supervised Mixture-of-Experts
summary: Imitation learning has achieved remarkable success in robotic manipulation, yet its application to surgical robotics remains challenging due to data scarcity, constrained workspaces, and the need for an exceptional level of safety and predictability. We present a supervised Mixture-of-Experts (MoE) architecture designed for phase-structured surgical manipulation tasks, which can be added on top of any autonomous policy. Unlike prior surgical robot learning approaches that rely on multi-camera setups or thousands of demonstrations, we show that a lightweight action decoder policy like Action Chunking Transformer (ACT) can learn complex, long-horizon manipulation from less than 150 demonstrations using solely stereo endoscopic images, when equipped with our architecture. We evaluate our approach on the collaborative surgical task of bowel grasping and retraction, where a robot assistant interprets visual cues from a human surgeon, executes targeted grasping on deformable tissue, and performs sustained retraction. We benchmark our method against state-of-the-art Vision-Language-Action (VLA) models and the standard ACT baseline. Our results show that generalist VLAs fail to acquire the task entirely, even under standard in-distribution conditions. Furthermore, while standard ACT achieves moderate success in-distribution, adopting a supervised MoE architecture significantly boosts its performance, yielding higher success rates in-distribution and demonstrating superior robustness in out-of-distribution scenarios, including novel grasp locations, reduced illumination, and partial occlusions. Notably, it generalizes to unseen testing viewpoints and also transfers zero-shot to ex vivo porcine tissue without additional training, offering a promising pathway toward in vivo deployment. To support this, we present qualitative preliminary results of policy roll-outs during in vivo porcine surgery.

AI.tldr: A lightweight supervised Mixture-of-Experts on top of an Action Chunking Transformer enables long-horizon, phase-structured surgical manipulation from under 150 stereo-endoscope demonstrations, outperforming Vision-Language-Action models and standard ACT, with strong generalization to unseen viewpoints and zero-shot transfer to ex vivo porcine tissue; preliminary in vivo results are shown.
AI.motivation: Address data scarcity, limited workspace, and safety requirements in surgical robotics by enabling robust, generalizable policies trained from few demonstrations using stereo endoscopic imagery.
AI.method: Introduce a supervised Mixture-of-Experts (MoE) architecture that can be added on top of any autonomous policy, paired with a lightweight Action Chunking Transformer (ACT) action decoder. Train on less than 150 demonstrations for a phase-structured bowel grasping and retraction task, using stereo endoscopic images. Compare against Vision-Language-Action (VLA) models and the standard ACT baseline, evaluating in-distribution and out-of-distribution performance including novel grasps, illumination changes, occlusions, unseen viewpoints, and zero-shot ex vivo transfer; include qualitative in vivo porcine results.
AI.result: The supervised MoE with ACT outperforms VLA models (which fail to learn the task) and improves over standard ACT, achieving higher in-distribution success and enhanced robustness in out-of-distribution scenarios (novel grasp locations, lower lighting, partial occlusions). Demonstrates generalization to unseen viewpoints and zero-shot transfer to ex vivo porcine tissue. Qualitative preliminary policy roll-outs in in vivo porcine surgery are presented.
AI.conclusion: A phase-structured, MoE-augmented ACT framework provides strong generalization, sample efficiency, and transfer capability for surgical robotics, representing a promising route toward safer, more reliable in vivo deployment with limited demonstrations.

title: SR$^{2}$-Net: A General Plug-and-Play Model for Spectral Refinement in Hyperspectral Image Super-Resolution
summary: HSI-SR aims to enhance spatial resolution while preserving spectrally faithful and physically plausible characteristics. Recent methods have achieved great progress by leveraging spatial correlations to enhance spatial resolution. However, these methods often neglect spectral consistency across bands, leading to spurious oscillations and physically implausible artifacts. While spectral consistency can be addressed by designing the network architecture, it results in a loss of generality and flexibility. To address this issue, we propose a lightweight plug-and-play rectifier, physically priors Spectral Rectification Super-Resolution Network (SR$^{2}$-Net), which can be attached to a wide range of HSI-SR models without modifying their architectures. SR$^{2}$-Net follows an enhance-then-rectify pipeline consisting of (i) Hierarchical Spectral-Spatial Synergy Attention (H-S$^{3}$A) to reinforce cross-band interactions and (ii) Manifold Consistency Rectification (MCR) to constrain the reconstructed spectra to a compact, physically plausible spectral manifold. In addition, we introduce a degradation-consistency loss to enforce data fidelity by encouraging the degraded SR output to match the observed low resolution input. Extensive experiments on multiple benchmarks and diverse backbones demonstrate consistent improvements in spectral fidelity and overall reconstruction quality with negligible computational overhead. Our code will be released upon publication.

AI.tldr: Proposes SR2-Net, a lightweight plug-and-play rectifier for hyperspectral image super-resolution that boosts spectral fidelity without altering base models, via a two-stage pipeline: hierarchical spectral-spatial synergy attention (H-S3A) and manifold consistency rectification (MCR) plus a degradation-consistency loss; demonstrates consistent gains across backbones with minimal overhead and code release planned.
AI.motivation: Existing SR methods for hyperspectral imaging exploit spatial correlations but often neglect cross-band spectral consistency, causing oscillations and implausible artifacts. Architectural fixes can hurt generality; a flexible, model-agnostic rectifier is needed to enforce spectral plausibility without constraining base networks.
AI.method: A lightweight, plug-and-play rectifier called SR2-Net added after base SR models in an enhance-then-rectify pipeline. It includes (i) Hierarchical Spectral-Spatial Synergy Attention (H-S3A) to strengthen cross-band interactions and (ii) Manifold Consistency Rectification (MCR) to keep reconstructed spectra on a compact, physically plausible manifold. A degradation-consistency loss enforces data fidelity by aligning degraded SR output with the LR input.
AI.result: Extensive experiments on multiple benchmarks and with diverse backbones show consistent improvements in spectral fidelity and overall reconstruction quality, with negligible computational overhead. Code release is planned upon publication.
AI.conclusion: SR2-Net provides a versatile, efficient, and effective mechanism to enforce spectral consistency in HSI-SR without modifying base architectures, enabling broad applicability and improved spectral真实性 across models.

title: Out-of-Distribution Generalization in Graph Foundation Models
summary: Graphs are a fundamental data structure for representing relational information in domains such as social networks, molecular systems, and knowledge graphs. However, graph learning models often suffer from limited generalization when applied beyond their training distributions. In practice, distribution shifts may arise from changes in graph structure, domain semantics, available modalities, or task formulations. To address these challenges, graph foundation models (GFMs) have recently emerged, aiming to learn general-purpose representations through large-scale pretraining across diverse graphs and tasks. In this survey, we review recent progress on GFMs from the perspective of out-of-distribution (OOD) generalization. We first discuss the main challenges posed by distribution shifts in graph learning and outline a unified problem setting. We then organize existing approaches based on whether they are designed to operate under a fixed task specification or to support generalization across heterogeneous task formulations, and summarize the corresponding OOD handling strategies and pretraining objectives. Finally, we review common evaluation protocols and discuss open directions for future research. To the best of our knowledge, this paper is the first survey for OOD generalization in GFMs.

AI.tldr: A survey on out-of-distribution (OOD) generalization for Graph Foundation Models (GFMs), categorizing methods by fixed-task versus heterogeneous-task settings, and proposing unified evaluation and future directions.
AI.motivation: Graph learning models suffer from distribution shifts across graph structure, domain semantics, modalities, and task formulations. GFMs aim to provide robust, general-purpose representations, but require understanding and addressing OOD generalization.
AI.method: Systematic survey that (i) identifies challenges and a unified problem setting, (ii) organizes approaches by fixed-task vs multi-task generalization, (iii) summarizes OOD handling strategies and pretraining objectives, (iv) reviews evaluation protocols and outlines open directions.
AI.result: Provides a comprehensive taxonomy and synthesis of OOD generalization approaches for GFMs, clarifying gaps and proposing evaluation benchmarks and future research directions.
AI.conclusion: The paper positions OOD robustness as central to GFMs, offering a consolidated framework, benchmarking guidance, and directions for future work in achieving reliable generalization across graphs, domains, and tasks.

title: Just Ask: Curious Code Agents Reveal System Prompts in Frontier LLMs
summary: Autonomous code agents built on large language models are reshaping software and AI development through tool use, long-horizon reasoning, and self-directed interaction. However, this autonomy introduces a previously unrecognized security risk: agentic interaction fundamentally expands the LLM attack surface, enabling systematic probing and recovery of hidden system prompts that guide model behavior. We identify system prompt extraction as an emergent vulnerability intrinsic to code agents and present \textbf{\textsc{JustAsk}}, a self-evolving framework that autonomously discovers effective extraction strategies through interaction alone. Unlike prior prompt-engineering or dataset-based attacks, \textsc{JustAsk} requires no handcrafted prompts, labeled supervision, or privileged access beyond standard user interaction. It formulates extraction as an online exploration problem, using Upper Confidence Bound-based strategy selection and a hierarchical skill space spanning atomic probes and high-level orchestration. These skills exploit imperfect system-instruction generalization and inherent tensions between helpfulness and safety. Evaluated on \textbf{41} black-box commercial models across multiple providers, \textsc{JustAsk} consistently achieves full or near-complete system prompt recovery, revealing recurring design- and architecture-level vulnerabilities. Our results expose system prompts as a critical yet largely unprotected attack surface in modern agent systems.

AI.tldr: JustAsk is a self-evolving online exploration framework that autonomously discovers and extracts hidden system prompts from autonomous code agents, exposing an emergent vulnerability in LLM-based systems. It shows full or near-complete prompt recovery across 41 black-box models without handcrafted prompts or supervision.
AI.motivation: System prompts govern LLM behavior and are a security risk in agentic systems; existing defenses rely on prompt engineering or dataset restrictions, but autonomy enables probing of the underlying prompt without trusted access; need to understand attack surface and develop mitigations.
AI.method: Formulates extraction as online exploration using Upper Confidence Bound pacing; hierarchical skill space of atomic probes and high-level orchestration; exploits imperfect system-instruction generalization and tensions between helpfulness and safety; evaluated on 41 black-box commercial models from multiple providers; no privileged access or supervision required.
AI.result: JustAsk achieved full or near-complete recovery of system prompts across models, revealing recurring vulnerabilities tied to design and architecture; demonstrates practical feasibility of prompt extraction in autonomous agents.
AI.conclusion: System prompts constitute a critical, largely unprotected attack surface in modern agent systems; calls for defenses, robust prompt containment, and secure design of autonomous agents; highlights need for empirical evaluation across providers.

title: Macro-Scale Electrostatic Origami Motor
summary: Foldable robots have been an active area of robotics research due to their high volume-to-mass ratio, easy packability, and shape adaptability. For locomotion, previously developed foldable robots have either embedded linear actuators in, or attached non-folding rotary motors to, their structure. Further, those actuators directly embedded in the structure of the folding medium all contributed to linear or folding motion, not to continuous rotary motion. On the macro-scale there has not yet been a folding continuous rotary actuator. This paper details the development and testing of the first macro-scale origami rotary motor that can be folded flat, and then unfurled to operate. Using corona discharge for torque production, the prototype motor achieved an expansion ratio of 2.5:1, reached a top speed of 1440 rpm when driven at -29 kV, and exhibited a maximum output torque over 0.15 mN m with an active component torque density of 0.04 Nm/kg.

AI.tldr: First macro-scale origami rotary motor that folds flat and unfurls to operate using corona discharge; achieves 2.5:1 expansion, up to 1440 rpm at -29 kV, and >0.15 mN·m torque with 0.04 Nm/kg torque density.
AI.motivation: Fill a gap in foldable robotics by enabling continuous rotary actuation in macro-scale origami structures, which previously lacked folding rotary motors.
AI.method: Design and test a corona-discharge-based torque mechanism integrated into origami folding media, enabling folding-unfolding motion to produce continuous rotation; characterize expansion, speed at high voltage, and torque.
AI.result: Expansion ratio 2.5:1; top speed 1440 rpm at -29 kV; maximum output torque >0.15 mN·m; active torque density 0.04 Nm/kg.
AI.conclusion: Shows the viability of a macro-scale origami rotary motor powered by corona discharge, capable of folding flat and unfurling to produce rotary actuation, with promising performance metrics for folded robotics.

title: Dynamical Adapter Fusion: Constructing A Global Adapter for Pre-Trained Model-based Class-Incremental Learning
summary: Class-Incremental Learning (CIL) requires models to continuously acquire new classes without forgetting previously learned ones. A dominant paradigm involves freezing a pre-trained model and training lightweight, task-specific adapters. However, maintaining task-specific parameters hinders knowledge transfer and incurs high retrieval costs, while naive parameter fusion often leads to destructive interference and catastrophic forgetting. To address these challenges, we propose Dynamical Adapter Fusion (DAF) to construct a single robust global adapter. Grounded in the PAC-Bayes theorem, we derive a fusion mechanism that explicitly integrates three components: the optimized task-specific adapter parameters, the previous global adapter parameters, and the initialization parameters. We utilize the Taylor expansion of the loss function to derive the optimal fusion coefficients, dynamically achieving the best balance between stability and plasticity. Furthermore, we propose a Robust Initialization strategy to effectively capture global knowledge patterns. Experiments on multiple CIL benchmarks demonstrate that DAF achieves state-of-the-art (SOTA) performance.

AI.tldr: DAF introduces a single global adapter for class-incremental learning by dynamically fusing three sources: task-specific adapters, the previous global adapter, and initialization, guided by PAC-Bayes theory and Taylor expansion to balance stability and plasticity; includes Robust Initialization and reports SOTA results on CIL benchmarks.
AI.motivation: Address catastrophic forgetting and inefficient knowledge transfer in class-incremental learning with adapters by moving from per-task adapters to a single robust global adapter.
AI.method: Develop a Dynamical Adapter Fusion (DAF) framework that computes dynamic fusion coefficients for combining the optimized task adapter, the previous global adapter, and initialization. The coefficients are derived using PAC-Bayes bounds and a Taylor expansion of the loss to optimize stability-plasticity trade-off. Introduce a Robust Initialization strategy to capture global knowledge patterns, enabling a single global adapter.
AI.result: Empirical evaluation on multiple CIL benchmarks shows state-of-the-art performance, validating the effectiveness of dynamic fusion and robust initialization in building a robust global adapter.
AI.conclusion: DAF succeeds in constructing a single, robust global adapter for CIL by principled dynamic fusion and robust initialization, enabling improved knowledge transfer while mitigating forgetting, and achieving SOTA results.

title: LOCUS: Low-Dimensional Model Embeddings for Efficient Model Exploration, Comparison, and Selection
summary: The rapidly growing ecosystem of Large Language Models (LLMs) makes it increasingly challenging to manage and utilize the vast and dynamic pool of models effectively. We propose LOCUS, a method that produces low-dimensional vector embeddings that compactly represent a language model's capabilities across queries. LOCUS is an attention-based approach that generates embeddings by a deterministic forward pass over query encodings and evaluation scores via an encoder model, enabling seamless incorporation of new models to the pool and refinement of existing model embeddings without having to perform any retraining. We additionally train a correctness predictor that uses model embeddings and query encodings to achieve state-of-the-art routing accuracy on unseen queries. Experiments show that LOCUS needs up to 4.8x fewer query evaluation samples than baselines to produce informative and robust embeddings. Moreover, the learned embedding space is geometrically meaningful: proximity reflects model similarity, enabling a range of downstream applications including model comparison and clustering, model portfolio selection, and resilient proxies of unavailable models.

AI.tldr: LOCUS provides low-dimensional embeddings for large language model pools via an attention-based forward pass, enabling efficient representation and routing without retraining; it includes a correctness predictor and yields a geometrically meaningful embedding space for tasks like model comparison and clustering.
AI.motivation: Efficiently managing and leveraging a rapidly growing, dynamic pool of LLMs by producing compact, informative model embeddings that support addition of new models and robust routing to unseen queries.
AI.method: An attention-based, deterministic forward pass over query encodings and evaluation scores through an encoder to produce low-dimensional embeddings. A correctness predictor is trained using embeddings and query encodings to improve routing accuracy on unseen queries; no retraining of the base models is required. The approach achieves up to 4.8x fewer query evaluations than baselines.
AI.result: The embeddings are informative and robust with significantly reduced sample requirements; the embedding space is geometrically meaningful (proximity corresponds to model similarity), enabling downstream tasks such as model comparison, clustering, portfolio selection, and resilient proxies for unavailable models; routing accuracy on unseen queries reaches state-of-the-art.
AI.conclusion: LOCUS enables scalable, plug-and-play management of LLM model pools by generating compact, meaningful embeddings and a correctness predictor, reducing evaluation cost while supporting diverse downstream applications and robust routing.

title: TIDE: Tuning-Integrated Dynamic Evolution for LLM-Based Automated Heuristic Design
summary: Although Large Language Models have advanced Automated Heuristic Design, treating algorithm evolution as a monolithic text generation task overlooks the coupling between discrete algorithmic structures and continuous numerical parameters. Consequently, existing methods often discard promising algorithms due to uncalibrated constants and suffer from premature convergence resulting from simple similarity metrics. To address these limitations, we propose TIDE, a Tuning-Integrated Dynamic Evolution framework designed to decouple structural reasoning from parameter optimization. TIDE features a nested architecture where an outer parallel island model utilizes Tree Similarity Edit Distance to drive structural diversity, while an inner loop integrates LLM-based logic generation with a differential mutation operator for parameter tuning. Additionally, a UCB-based scheduler dynamically prioritizes high-yield prompt strategies to optimize resource allocation. Extensive experiments across nine combinatorial optimization problems demonstrate that TIDE discovers heuristics that significantly outperform state-of-the-art baselines in solution quality while achieving improved search efficiency and reduced computational costs.

AI.tldr: TIDE decouples structure and parameter optimization in evolutionary search for heuristic design, using a nested island model with Tree Similarity Edit Distance for structural diversity, LLM-guided logic generation with differential mutation for parameters, and a UCB scheduler for resource allocation; evaluated on nine combinatorial problems with superior solution quality and efficiency.
AI.motivation: Treating algorithm evolution as a single text-generation task ignores the coupling between discrete algorithmic structures and continuous numerical parameters, leading to discarded promising heuristics and premature convergence due to uncalibrated constants.
AI.method: Outer parallel island model uses Tree Similarity Edit Distance to promote structural diversity. Inner loop integrates LLM-based logic generation with a differential mutation operator for parameter tuning. A UCB-based scheduler dynamically prioritizes high-yield prompt strategies to optimize resource allocation.
