AI.method: Spava distributes approximate attention across multiple GPUs (sequence-parallel) with system-level optimizations like load balancing and fused forward passes, enabling efficient processing of many visual embeddings without compression.
AI.result: Achieves speedups of 12.72x (vs FlashAttn), 1.70x (vs ZigZagRing), and 1.18x (vs APB) with no notable performance loss.
AI.conclusion: Demonstrates that multi-GPU sequence-parallel attention with optimization can effectively accelerate long-video inference in LMMs, expanding the feasible video length and complexity; code is available at the provided GitHub repository.

title: A Federated Generalized Expectation-Maximization Algorithm for Mixture Models with an Unknown Number of Components
summary: We study the problem of federated clustering when the total number of clusters $K$ across clients is unknown, and the clients have heterogeneous but potentially overlapping cluster sets in their local data. To that end, we develop FedGEM: a federated generalized expectation-maximization algorithm for the training of mixture models with an unknown number of components. Our proposed algorithm relies on each of the clients performing EM steps locally, and constructing an uncertainty set around the maximizer associated with each local component. The central server utilizes the uncertainty sets to learn potential cluster overlaps between clients, and infer the global number of clusters via closed-form computations. We perform a thorough theoretical study of our algorithm, presenting probabilistic convergence guarantees under common assumptions. Subsequently, we study the specific setting of isotropic GMMs, providing tractable, low-complexity computations to be performed by each client during each iteration of the algorithm, as well as rigorously verifying assumptions required for algorithm convergence. We perform various numerical experiments, where we empirically demonstrate that our proposed method achieves comparable performance to centralized EM, and that it outperforms various existing federated clustering methods.

AI.tldr: FedGEM is a federated EM-based algorithm for clustering with an unknown global number of clusters. Clients hold heterogeneous, possibly overlapping local cluster sets. The server uses locally maximized components with uncertainty sets to infer overlaps and determine the global K in closed form. The approach comes with convergence guarantees, efficient isotropic-GMM specialization, and empirical performance close to centralized EM, outperforming existing federated clustering methods.
AI.motivation: Clustering in federated settings where the total number of clusters is unknown and local data distributions differ, with potential overlap of cluster supports across clients. There is a need for privacy-preserving, distributed EM-style methods that can infer global structure without sharing raw data.
AI.method: Each client performs local EM steps to fit local mixture components and constructs uncertainty sets around each local component maximizer. The central server uses these uncertainty sets to infer overlaps between local components across clients and computes the global number of clusters K via closed-form expressions. The approach includes a specialization to isotropic Gaussian Mixture Models (GMMs) to enable cheap per-iteration computations and rigorous convergence verification.
AI.result: The paper provides probabilistic convergence guarantees under standard assumptions. For isotropic GMMs, it derives tractable per-iteration computations and confirms the convergence assumptions. Empirically, FedGEM achieves performance comparable to centralized EM and outperforms several existing federated clustering baselines.
AI.conclusion: FedGEM offers a principled, scalable solution for federated clustering with unknown K and heterogeneous, overlapping local clusters. It delivers theoretical convergence guarantees and practical efficiency, with strong empirical performance relative to centralized EM and competing federated methods.

title: Variance & Greediness: A comparative study of metric-learning losses
comment: 5 pages, 2 figures, 3 tables. Accepted by ICASSP 2026
summary: Metric learning is central to retrieval, yet its effects on embedding geometry and optimization dynamics are not well understood. We introduce a diagnostic framework, VARIANCE (intra-/inter-class variance) and GREEDINESS (active ratio and gradient norms), to compare seven representative losses, i.e., Contrastive, Triplet, N-pair, InfoNCE, ArcFace, SCL, and CCL, across five image-retrieval datasets. Our analysis reveals that Triplet and SCL preserve higher within-class variance and clearer inter-class margins, leading to stronger top-1 retrieval in fine-grained settings. In contrast, Contrastive and InfoNCE compact embeddings are achieved quickly through many small updates, accelerating convergence but potentially oversimplifying class structures. N-pair achieves a large mean separation but with uneven spacing. These insights reveal a form of efficiency-granularity trade-off and provide practical guidance: prefer Triplet/SCL when diversity preservation and hard-sample discrimination are critical, and Contrastive/InfoNCE when faster embedding compaction is desired.

AI.tldr: A diagnostic framework (VARIANCE and GREEDINESS) compares seven losses for image retrieval, revealing trade-offs between diversity preservation and embedding compactness.
AI.motivation: To understand how different metric-learning losses shape embedding geometry and optimization dynamics, across datasets.
AI.method: Introduce VARIANCE (intra-/inter-class variance) and GREEDINESS (active ratio and gradient norms) to evaluate seven losses (Contrastive, Triplet, N-pair, InfoNCE, ArcFace, SCL, CCL) on five image-retrieval datasets.
AI.result: Triplet and SCL preserve higher within-class variance and clearer inter-class margins, yielding stronger top-1 retrieval in fine-grained tasks. Contrastive and InfoNCE produce compact embeddings with many small updates, accelerating convergence but potentially oversimplifying class structures. N-pair achieves large mean separation but uneven spacing. Overall, an efficiency-granularity trade-off is observed.
AI.conclusion: Guidance: prefer Triplet or SCL when diversity preservation and hard-sample discrimination matter; prefer Contrastive or InfoNCE when faster embedding compaction is desired.

title: Efficient Simple Regret Algorithms for Stochastic Contextual Bandits
summary: We study stochastic contextual logistic bandits under the simple regret objective. While simple regret guarantees have been established for the linear case, no such results were previously known for the logistic setting. Building on ideas from contextual linear bandits and self-concordant analysis, we propose the first algorithm that achieves simple regret $\tilde{\mathcal{O}}(d/\sqrt{T})$. Notably, the leading term of our regret bound is free of the constant $κ= \mathcal O(\exp(S))$, where $S$ is a bound on the magnitude of the unknown parameter vector. The algorithm is shown to be fully tractable when the action set is finite. We also introduce a new variant of Thompson Sampling tailored to the simple-regret setting. This yields the first simple regret guarantee for randomized algorithms in stochastic contextual linear bandits, with regret $\tilde{\mathcal{O}}(d^{3/2}/\sqrt{T})$. Extending this method to the logistic case, we obtain a similarly structured Thompson Sampling algorithm that achieves the same regret bound -- $\tilde{\mathcal{O}}(d^{3/2}/\sqrt{T})$ -- again with no dependence on $κ$ in the leading term. The randomized algorithms, as expected, are cheaper to run than their deterministic counterparts. Finally, we conducted a series of experiments to empirically validate these theoretical guarantees.

AI.tldr: First simple-regret guarantees for stochastic contextual logistic bandits; achieves tilde O(d/√T) with leading term independent of κ; introduces Thompson Sampling variants giving tilde O(d^{3/2}/√T) simple-regret bounds; finite-action tractable; experimental validation.
AI.motivation: Bridge the gap in simple-regret analysis from contextual linear bandits to logistic (nonlinear) contextual bandits, leveraging self-concordant analysis to obtain tight regret bounds and practical algorithms.
AI.method: Combine self-concordant analysis with ideas from contextual linear bandits to design deterministic and randomized (Thompson Sampling) algorithms. Prove simple-regret bounds in the logistic setting; extend to finite action sets for tractability; adapt LS/TS techniques to the simple-regret objective; perform empirical validation.
AI.result: Deterministic algorithm achieves simple regret tilde O(d/√T) with leading term independent of κ (κ = O(exp(S))). Randomized Thompson Sampling variants achieve tilde O(d^{3/2}/√T) in both linear and logistic settings, again with no leading κ dependence. Randomized methods are computationally cheaper. Experiments corroborate theoretical guarantees.
AI.conclusion: Presents the first simple-regret guarantees for stochastic contextual logistic bandits and introduces practical TS-based algorithms without κ-dependent leading terms. Establishes a foundation for simple-regret analysis beyond linear models and suggests directions for extending to broader GLMs and action-set settings.

title: BEAP-Agent: Backtrackable Execution and Adaptive Planning for GUI Agents
summary: GUI agents are designed to automate repetitive tasks and enhance productivity. However, existing GUI agents struggle to recover once they follow an incorrect exploration path, often leading to task failure. In this work, we model GUI task execution as a DFS process and propose BEAP-Agent, a DFS-based framework that supports long-range, multi-level state backtracking with dynamic task tracking and updating. The framework consists of three collaborative components: Planner, Executor, and Tracker. Together, they enable effective task exploration and execution. BEAP-Agent fills the gap in systematic backtracking mechanisms for GUI agents, offering a systematic solution for long-horizon task exploration. We conducted a systematic evaluation on the OSWorld benchmark, where BEAP-Agent achieved an accuracy of 28.2%, validating the effectiveness of the proposed method.

AI.tldr: A DFS-based GUI agent, BEAP-Agent, enables long-range, multi-level backtracking via Planner, Executor, and Tracker to recover from incorrect exploration; validated on OSWorld with 28.2% accuracy.
AI.motivation: GUI agents struggle to recover after incorrect exploration paths, leading to task failure; need a systematic backtracking mechanism for long-horizon tasks.
AI.method: Model GUI task execution as a DFS process; introduce BEAP-Agent with three collaborative components (Planner, Executor, Tracker) for dynamic task tracking and updating and long-range backtracking.
AI.result: Systematic evaluation on the OSWorld benchmark shows BEAP-Agent achieves 28.2% accuracy, demonstrating the feasibility of the approach.
AI.conclusion: BEAP-Agent fills a gap in systematic backtracking for GUI agents, offering a framework for long-horizon task exploration with structured backtracking.

title: Mining Forgery Traces from Reconstruction Error: A Weakly Supervised Framework for Multimodal Deepfake Temporal Localization
summary: Modern deepfakes have evolved into localized and intermittent manipulations that require fine-grained temporal localization. The prohibitive cost of frame-level annotation makes weakly supervised methods a practical necessity, which rely only on video-level labels. To this end, we propose Reconstruction-based Temporal Deepfake Localization (RT-DeepLoc), a weakly supervised temporal forgery localization framework that identifies forgeries via reconstruction errors. Our framework uses a Masked Autoencoder (MAE) trained exclusively on authentic data to learn its intrinsic spatiotemporal patterns; this allows the model to produce significant reconstruction discrepancies for forged segments, effectively providing the missing fine-grained cues for localization. To robustly leverage these indicators, we introduce a novel Asymmetric Intra-video Contrastive Loss (AICL). By focusing on the compactness of authentic features guided by these reconstruction cues, AICL establishes a stable decision boundary that enhances local discrimination while preserving generalization to unseen forgeries. Extensive experiments on large-scale datasets, including LAV-DF, demonstrate that RT-DeepLoc achieves state-of-the-art performance in weakly-supervised temporal forgery localization.

AI.tldr: RT-DeepLoc is a weakly supervised temporal deepfake localization method using a Masked Autoencoder trained on authentic data to detect forgery via reconstruction errors, enhanced by a new Asymmetric Intra-video Contrastive Loss (AICL); it achieves state-of-the-art results on LAV-DF.
AI.motivation: There is a need for fine-grained temporal localization of deepfakes but frame-level annotations are costly; weakly supervised strategies using only video-level labels are practical but underexploit reconstruction cues.
AI.method: Train a MAE solely on authentic data to capture intrinsic spatiotemporal patterns; detect forgeries via reconstruction discrepancies. Introduce Asymmetric Intra-video Contrastive Loss (AICL) to promote compact authentic features guided by reconstruction cues and stabilize decision boundaries under weak supervision.
AI.result: Extensive experiments on large-scale datasets, including LAV-DF, demonstrate RT-DeepLoc achieves state-of-the-art performance in weakly-supervised temporal forgery localization.
AI.conclusion: Reconstruction-based cues from authentic-data MAE plus AICL provide effective weakly-supervised localization of localized and intermittent deepfakes, with strong generalization to unseen forgeries.

title: The Powers of Precision: Structure-Informed Detection in Complex Systems -- From Customer Churn to Seizure Onset
summary: Emergent phenomena -- onset of epileptic seizures, sudden customer churn, or pandemic outbreaks -- often arise from hidden causal interactions in complex systems. We propose a machine learning method for their early detection that addresses a core challenge: unveiling and harnessing a system's latent causal structure despite the data-generating process being unknown and partially observed. The method learns an optimal feature representation from a one-parameter family of estimators -- powers of the empirical covariance or precision matrix -- offering a principled way to tune in to the underlying structure driving the emergence of critical events. A supervised learning module then classifies the learned representation. We prove structural consistency of the family and demonstrate the empirical soundness of our approach on seizure detection and churn prediction, attaining competitive results in both. Beyond prediction, and toward explainability, we ascertain that the optimal covariance power exhibits evidence of good identifiability while capturing structural signatures, thus reconciling predictive performance with interpretable statistical structure.

AI.tldr: Learn a representation from a one-parameter family of estimators (powers of the empirical covariance or precision matrix) to detect emergent phenomena, followed by supervised classification; proven structural consistency and validated on seizure detection and churn prediction with interpretable structural signals.
AI.motivation: Emergent phenomena in complex systems (epileptic seizures, churn, outbreaks) arise from latent causal interactions. The data-generating process is often unknown and only partially observed, making it hard to uncover causal structure and detect critical transitions early. The work aims to uncover latent structure and use it for early detection with interpretability.
AI.method: Construct an optimal feature representation by exploring a one-parameter family of estimators: powers of the empirical covariance or precision matrix. This yields features that emphasize underlying structural drivers. A supervised learning module then classifies the learned representation. The authors prove structural consistency of the estimator family and validate empirically on seizure detection and churn prediction.
AI.result: The approach achieves competitive performance in both seizure detection and churn prediction tasks. It demonstrates empirical soundness and supports that the optimal covariance power captures identifiable structural signatures linked to emergent events.
AI.conclusion: The method provides accurate predictions while maintaining interpretable statistical structure by revealing latent causal signatures through the chosen covariance power. It balances predictive performance with insight into the structural mechanisms behind emergent phenomena.

title: Latent Chain-of-Thought as Planning: Decoupling Reasoning from Verbalization
summary: Chain-of-Thought (CoT) empowers Large Language Models (LLMs) to tackle complex problems, but remains constrained by the computational cost and reasoning path collapse when grounded in discrete token spaces. Recent latent reasoning approaches attempt to optimize efficiency by performing reasoning within continuous hidden states. However, these methods typically operate as opaque end-to-end mappings from explicit reasoning steps to latent states, and often require a pre-defined number of latent steps during inference. In this work, we introduce PLaT (Planning with Latent Thoughts), a framework that reformulates latent reasoning as planning by fundamentally decouple reasoning from verbalization. We model reasoning as a deterministic trajectory of latent planning states, while a separate Decoder grounds these thoughts into text when necessary. This decoupling allows the model to dynamically determine when to terminate reasoning rather than relying on fixed hyperparameters. Empirical results on mathematical benchmarks reveal a distinct trade-off: while PLaT achieves lower greedy accuracy than baselines, it demonstrates superior scalability in terms of reasoning diversity. This indicates that PLaT learns a robust, broader solution space, offering a transparent and scalable foundation for inference-time search.

AI.tldr: PLaT reframes latent reasoning as a planning problem with a decoupled latent thinking process and a separate decoder to ground thoughts into text, enabling dynamic termination and scalable inference-time search; it trades greedy accuracy for increased reasoning diversity.
AI.motivation: addresses the limitations of chain-of-thought (costly computation, path collapse) and previous latent reasoning methods that are opaque and rely on a fixed number of latent steps; aims to achieve efficient, scalable, and transparent latent reasoning by separating planning in latent space from verbalization.
AI.method: Proposes PLaT (Planning with Latent Thoughts): reasoning unfolds as a deterministic trajectory of latent planning states, decoupled from the text-grounding decoder which only produces verbalizations when needed. This allows dynamic termination and inference-time search instead of fixed latent-step counts.
AI.result: Empirical results on mathematical benchmarks show lower greedy accuracy compared with baselines but greater scalability in reasoning diversity, indicating PLaT learns a broader, more robust solution space and provides a transparent, scalable foundation for search at inference time.
AI.conclusion: PLaT offers a decoupled, dynamic, planning-based latent reasoning framework that improves scalability and diversity of solutions, with a trade-off in greedy accuracy; it provides a transparent foundation for inference-time search and could influence future latent reasoning approaches.

title: Hypernetwork-Based Adaptive Aggregation for Multimodal Multiple-Instance Learning in Predicting Coronary Calcium Debulking
summary: In this paper, we present the first attempt to estimate the necessity of debulking coronary artery calcifications from computed tomography (CT) images. We formulate this task as a Multiple-instance Learning (MIL) problem. The difficulty of this task lies in that physicians adjust their focus and decision criteria for device usage according to tabular data representing each patient's condition. To address this issue, we propose a hypernetwork-based adaptive aggregation transformer (HyperAdAgFormer), which adaptively modifies the feature aggregation strategy for each patient based on tabular data through a hypernetwork. The experiments using the clinical dataset demonstrated the effectiveness of HyperAdAgFormer. The code is publicly available at https://github.com/Shiku-Kaito/HyperAdAgFormer.

AI.tldr: MIL-based estimation of debulking coronary artery calcifications from CT images using a HyperAdAgFormer: a hypernetwork-conditioned transformer that adaptively aggregates imaging features per patient using tabular data; shows effectiveness on a clinical dataset; code available.
AI.motivation: Physician decisions for device usage depend on patient-specific tabular data, which fixed MIL aggregation cannot fully capture. The work aims to tailor feature aggregation to each patient by conditioning on tabular information.
AI.method: Formulate the task as Multiple-instance Learning and introduce HyperAdAgFormer, a transformer with a hypernetwork that generates per-patient aggregation weights based on tabular data, enabling adaptive feature aggregation for each patient.
AI.result: Experiments on a clinical dataset demonstrate the method’s effectiveness in estimating debulking necessity; code is publicly available at the given repository.
AI.conclusion: Adaptive, patient-aware aggregation via a hypernetwork-augmented transformer improves MIL-based decision support for device-related decisions in coronary calcification debulking and can extend to other imaging tasks; further validation on larger datasets is anticipated.

title: AC2L-GAD: Active Counterfactual Contrastive Learning for Graph Anomaly Detection
summary: Graph anomaly detection aims to identify abnormal patterns in networks, but faces significant challenges from label scarcity and extreme class imbalance. While graph contrastive learning offers a promising unsupervised solution, existing methods suffer from two critical limitations: random augmentations break semantic consistency in positive pairs, while naive negative sampling produces trivial, uninformative contrasts. We propose AC2L-GAD, an Active Counterfactual Contrastive Learning framework that addresses both limitations through principled counterfactual reasoning. By combining information-theoretic active selection with counterfactual generation, our approach identifies structurally complex nodes and generates anomaly-preserving positive augmentations alongside normal negative counterparts that provide hard contrasts, while restricting expensive counterfactual generation to a strategically selected subset. This design reduces computational overhead by approximately 65% compared to full-graph counterfactual generation while maintaining detection quality. Experiments on nine benchmark datasets, including real-world financial transaction graphs from GADBench, show that AC2L-GAD achieves competitive or superior performance compared to state-of-the-art baselines, with notable gains in datasets where anomalies exhibit complex attribute-structure interactions.

AI.tldr: Active counterfactual contrastive learning for graph anomaly detection that uses information-theoretic active selection and selective counterfactual generation to produce informative positives/negatives, reducing computation while preserving or improving detection quality.
AI.motivation: Graph anomaly detection suffers from label scarcity and severe class imbalance; standard graph contrastive learning suffers from semantic drift due to random augmentations and uninformative negatives.
AI.method: Combine information-theoretic active selection to identify structurally complex nodes with counterfactual generation to create anomaly-preserving positives and hard normal negatives; restrict full-graph counterfactuals to a strategically chosen subset, achieving about 65% computational savings.
AI.result: On nine benchmark datasets including GADBench real-world financial graphs, AC2L-GAD achieves competitive or superior performance versus state-of-the-art baselines, with notable gains when anomalies involve complex attribute-structure interactions.
AI.conclusion: AC2L-GAD provides principled counterfactual reasoning and active selection to improve graph anomaly detection efficiently, handling label scarcity and imbalance while maintaining detection quality.

title: Hebbian Learning with Global Direction
summary: Backpropagation algorithm has driven the remarkable success of deep neural networks, but its lack of biological plausibility and high computational costs have motivated the ongoing search for alternative training methods. Hebbian learning has attracted considerable interest as a biologically plausible alternative to backpropagation. Nevertheless, its exclusive reliance on local information, without consideration of global task objectives, fundamentally limits its scalability. Inspired by the biological synergy between neuromodulators and local plasticity, we introduce a novel model-agnostic Global-guided Hebbian Learning (GHL) framework, which seamlessly integrates local and global information to scale up across diverse networks and tasks. In specific, the local component employs Oja's rule with competitive learning to ensure stable and effective local updates. Meanwhile, the global component introduces a sign-based signal that guides the direction of local Hebbian plasticity updates. Extensive experiments demonstrate that our method consistently outperforms existing Hebbian approaches. Notably, on large-scale network and complex datasets like ImageNet, our framework achieves the competitive results and significantly narrows the gap with standard backpropagation.

AI.tldr: Introduces Global-guided Hebbian Learning (GHL) that blends local Oja-based updates with a global sign-based signal to steer plasticity, achieving competitive results with backprop on large-scale tasks including ImageNet.
AI.motivation: To address the alleged limitations of purely local Hebbian learning (lack of global task objective alignment) and the biological implausibility of backpropagation, by introducing a neuromodulator-like global signal.
AI.method: A model-agnostic framework combining local updates via Oja's rule with competitive learning for stability, and a global sign-based signal that directs the direction of local Hebbian updates; evaluated across diverse networks and tasks, including large-scale datasets.
AI.result: Outperforms existing Hebbian methods and narrows the gap to backpropagation; achieves competitive performance on ImageNet, suggesting scalability across networks and tasks.
AI.conclusion: Global-guided Hebbian Learning provides a biologically plausible, scalable training paradigm by integrating local plasticity with a global modulatory signal, achieving strong performance on challenging benchmarks.

title: SimGraph: A Unified Framework for Scene Graph-Based Image Generation and Editing
summary: Recent advancements in Generative Artificial Intelligence (GenAI) have significantly enhanced the capabilities of both image generation and editing. However, current approaches often treat these tasks separately, leading to inefficiencies and challenges in maintaining spatial consistency and semantic coherence between generated content and edits. Moreover, a major obstacle is the lack of structured control over object relationships and spatial arrangements. Scene graph-based methods, which represent objects and their interrelationships in a structured format, offer a solution by providing greater control over composition and interactions in both image generation and editing. To address this, we introduce SimGraph, a unified framework that integrates scene graph-based image generation and editing, enabling precise control over object interactions, layouts, and spatial coherence. In particular, our framework integrates token-based generation and diffusion-based editing within a single scene graph-driven model, ensuring high-quality and consistent results. Through extensive experiments, we empirically demonstrate that our approach outperforms existing state-of-the-art methods.

AI.tldr: SimGraph unifies scene-graph-guided image generation and editing in a single model, enabling precise control over object interactions and spatial layouts by combining token-based generation with diffusion-based editing under a scene graph framework; claims state-of-the-art performance.
AI.motivation: Current GenAI workflows treat generation and editing separately, leading to inefficiencies and inconsistent spatial semantics. Scene graphs offer structured control over object relationships and layouts, enabling coherent composition and interactions.
AI.method: A unified scene-graph-driven model that integrates token-based generation and diffusion-based editing. The scene graph guides both generation and editing to ensure consistent object relations, layouts, and spatial coherence within a single framework.
AI.result: Extensive experiments show that SimGraph outperforms existing state-of-the-art methods in quality, coherence, and control over object interactions and layouts during both generation and editing.
AI.conclusion: SimGraph provides precise, unified control over object relationships and spatial arrangements in GenAI, improving consistency between generation and editing; potential directions include scaling to more complex scenes and extending to broader modalities.

title: Breaking the Reasoning Horizon in Entity Alignment Foundation Models
summary: Entity alignment (EA) is critical for knowledge graph (KG) fusion. Existing EA models lack transferability and are incapable of aligning unseen KGs without retraining. While using graph foundation models (GFMs) offer a solution, we find that directly adapting GFMs to EA remains largely ineffective. This stems from a critical "reasoning horizon gap": unlike link prediction in GFMs, EA necessitates capturing long-range dependencies across sparse and heterogeneous KG structuresTo address this challenge, we propose a EA foundation model driven by a parallel encoding strategy. We utilize seed EA pairs as local anchors to guide the information flow, initializing and encoding two parallel streams simultaneously. This facilitates anchor-conditioned message passing and significantly shortens the inference trajectory by leveraging local structural proximity instead of global search. Additionally, we incorporate a merged relation graph to model global dependencies and a learnable interaction module for precise matching. Extensive experiments verify the effectiveness of our framework, highlighting its strong generalizability to unseen KGs.

AI.tldr: EA foundation model with parallel encoding to address reasoning horizon gap; uses seed pairs as anchors, parallel streams, merged relation graph, and interaction module; claims strong generalization to unseen KGs.
AI.motivation: To overcome transferability issues of EA models and the inadequacy of directly adapting GFMs for EA due to long-range dependency challenges in sparse, heterogeneous KGs.
AI.method: Propose a parallel encoding EA foundation model that initializes two parallel streams guided by seed EA pairs (anchor-conditioned message passing). Use merged relation graph to capture global dependencies and a learnable interaction module for matching. Infer with reduced trajectory by local proximity instead of global search.
AI.result: Empirical results show improved effectiveness and strong generalization to unseen KGs, validating the approach.
AI.conclusion: A parallel-encoding EA foundation model mitigates the reasoning horizon gap and enhances cross-KG transferability by anchoring local structure and combining global and local information for precise entity alignment.

title: NEMO: Execution-Aware Optimization Modeling via Autonomous Coding Agents
summary:
In this paper, we present NEMO, a system that translates Natural-language descriptions of decision problems into formal Executable Mathematical Optimization implementations, operating collaboratively with users or autonomously. Existing approaches typically rely on specialized large language models (LLMs) or bespoke, task-specific agents. Such methods are often brittle, complex and frequently generating syntactically invalid or non-executable code.
  NEMO instead centers on remote interaction with autonomous coding agents (ACAs), treated as a first-class abstraction analogous to API-based interaction with LLMs. This design enables the construction of higher-level systems around ACAs that structure, consolidate, and iteratively refine task specifications. Because ACAs execute within sandboxed environments, code produced by NEMO is executable by construction, allowing automated validation and repair.
  Building on this, we introduce novel coordination patterns with and across ACAs, including asymmetric validation loops between independently generated optimizer and simulator implementations (serving as a high-level validation mechanism), external memory for experience reuse, and robustness enhancements via minimum Bayes risk (MBR) decoding and self-consistency. We evaluate NEMO on nine established optimization benchmarks. As depicted in Figure 1, it achieves state-of-the-art performance on the majority of tasks, with substantial margins on several datasets, demonstrating the power of execution-aware agentic architectures for automated optimization modeling.

AI.tldr: NEMO translates natural-language descriptions of decision problems into executable optimization code via autonomous coding agents, enabling validation and repair in sandboxed environments, and achieves state-of-the-art results on nine benchmarks.
AI.motivation: Current NL-to-optimization methods relying on LLMs or bespoke agents produce brittle, non-executable code; there is a need for executable, robust, and reusable optimization workflows via execution-aware, agentic architectures.
AI.method: Employ remote interaction with autonomous coding agents (ACAs) as first-class abstractions, with higher-level orchestration around ACAs; implement asymmetric validation loops between optimizer and simulator; use external memory; apply minimum Bayes risk (MBR) decoding and self-consistency; sandboxed execution ensures executability; evaluate on nine optimization benchmarks.
AI.result: Achieves state-of-the-art performance on most benchmarks with substantial margins on several datasets, illustrating the effectiveness of execution-aware agentic architectures for automated optimization modeling.
AI.conclusion: An execution-aware ACA framework enables robust, executable optimization models with automated validation and repair, demonstrating potential for scalable, automated optimization modeling.

title: HERS: Hidden-Pattern Expert Learning for Risk-Specific Vehicle Damage Adaptation in Diffusion Models
summary: Recent advances in text-to-image (T2I) diffusion models have enabled increasingly realistic synthesis of vehicle damage, raising concerns about their reliability in automated insurance workflows. The ability to generate crash-like imagery challenges the boundary between authentic and synthetic data, introducing new risks of misuse in fraud or claim manipulation. To address these issues, we propose HERS (Hidden-Pattern Expert Learning for Risk-Specific Damage Adaptation), a framework designed to improve fidelity, controllability, and domain alignment of diffusion-generated damage images. HERS fine-tunes a base diffusion model via domain-specific expert adaptation without requiring manual annotation. Using self-supervised image-text pairs automatically generated by a large language model and T2I pipeline, HERS models each damage category, such as dents, scratches, broken lights, or cracked paint, as a separate expert. These experts are later integrated into a unified multi-damage model that balances specialization with generalization. We evaluate HERS across four diffusion backbones and observe consistent improvements: plus 5.5 percent in text faithfulness and plus 2.3 percent in human preference ratings compared to baselines. Beyond image fidelity, we discuss implications for fraud detection, auditability, and safe deployment of generative models in high-stakes domains. Our findings highlight both the opportunities and risks of domain-specific diffusion, underscoring the importance of trustworthy generation in safety-critical applications such as auto insurance.

AI.tldr: HERS uses domain-specific expert adaptation to fine-tune diffusion models for vehicle-damage generation. It models each damage category as an expert and combines them into a unified model, improving text fidelity and human preference by 5.5% and 2.3% respectively, across four backbones; aims to enhance realism while enabling safer deployment in auto-insurance workflows.
AI.motivation: Address the growing realism of text-to-image diffusion-generated vehicle-damage imagery and the associated risks of fraud/manipulation in auto-insurance workflows; improve fidelity, controllability, and domain alignment; enable auditability and safe deployment in high-stakes domains.
AI.method: Fine-tune a base diffusion model with domain-specific experts for each damage category using self-supervised image-text pairs generated automatically by a large language model and a T2I pipeline; integrate experts into a unified multi-damage model that balances specialization and generalization; evaluate across four diffusion backbones.
AI.result: Consistent improvements in fidelity metrics: +5.5% text faithfulness and +2.3% human preference over baselines; results hold across four diffusion backbones; demonstrates improved fidelity, controllability, and domain alignment.
AI.conclusion: Domain-specific diffusion with expert adaptation is a promising approach for high-stakes, safety-critical image synthesis, enabling better tailoring to repair-relevant damage while highlighting ongoing concerns about misuse, fraud detection, auditability, and safe deployment in insurance workflows.

title: TeachBench: A Syllabus-Grounded Framework for Evaluating Teaching Ability in Large Language Models
summary: Large language models (LLMs) show promise as teaching assistants, yet their teaching capability remains insufficiently evaluated. Existing benchmarks mainly focus on problem-solving or problem-level guidance, leaving knowledge-centered teaching underexplored. We propose a syllabus-grounded evaluation framework that measures LLM teaching capability via student performance improvement after multi-turn instruction. By restricting teacher agents to structured knowledge points and example problems, the framework avoids information leakage and enables reuse of existing benchmarks. We instantiate the framework on Gaokao data across multiple subjects. Experiments reveal substantial variation in teaching effectiveness across models and domains: some models perform well in mathematics, while teaching remains challenging in physics and chemistry. We also find that incorporating example problems does not necessarily improve teaching, as models often shift toward example-specific error correction. Overall, our results highlight teaching ability as a distinct and measurable dimension of LLM behavior.

AI.tldr: Proposes a syllabus-grounded framework to evaluate LLM teaching ability by measuring student performance gains after structured, multi-turn instruction, instantiated on Gaokao data; finds large model-by-domain variation and that example problems may not always help, highlighting teaching as a distinct evaluative dimension.
AI.motivation: Current benchmarks largely assess problem solving rather than knowledge-centered teaching. There is a need to quantify how well LLMs can teach specific knowledge points, while preventing leakage and enabling reuse of existing benchmarks.
AI.method: Introduce a syllabus-grounded evaluation framework that constrains teachers to structured knowledge points and example problems, uses multi-turn instruction, and measures student performance improvements. Implemented with Gaokao data across multiple subjects to assess cross-domain teaching capability.
AI.result: Significant variation in teaching effectiveness across models and domains; math teaching tends to be stronger for some models, while physics and chemistry are more challenging. Including example problems does not consistently improve teaching and may cause shifts toward example-specific error correction.
AI.conclusion: Teaching ability is a distinct, measurable dimension of LLM behavior. The framework enables robust evaluation using existing benchmarks and highlights domain-dependent strengths and limitations in LLM-based instruction.

title: Vision KAN: Towards an Attention-Free Backbone for Vision with Kolmogorov-Arnold Networks
summary: Attention mechanisms have become a key module in modern vision backbones due to their ability to model long-range dependencies. However, their quadratic complexity in sequence length and the difficulty of interpreting attention weights limit both scalability and clarity. Recent attention-free architectures demonstrate that strong performance can be achieved without pairwise attention, motivating the search for alternatives. In this work, we introduce Vision KAN (ViK), an attention-free backbone inspired by the Kolmogorov-Arnold Networks. At its core lies MultiPatch-RBFKAN, a unified token mixer that combines (a) patch-wise nonlinear transform with Radial Basis Function-based KANs, (b) axis-wise separable mixing for efficient local propagation, and (c) low-rank global mapping for long-range interaction. Employing as a drop-in replacement for attention modules, this formulation tackles the prohibitive cost of full KANs on high-resolution features by adopting a patch-wise grouping strategy with lightweight operators to restore cross-patch dependencies. Experiments on ImageNet-1K show that ViK achieves competitive accuracy with linear complexity, demonstrating the potential of KAN-based token mixing as an efficient and theoretically grounded alternative to attention.

AI.tldr: ViK is an attention-free Vision backbone that uses Kolmogorov–Arnold networks (KANs) with a MultiPatch-RBFKAN token mixer to achieve linear complexity while delivering competitive ImageNet-1K accuracy.
AI.motivation: To overcome the quadratic complexity and interpretability issues of attention, by exploring a theoretically grounded, attention-free alternative that can scale to high-resolution features.
AI.method: Introduces MultiPatch-RBFKAN as a unified token mixer combining (i) patch-wise nonlinear Radial Basis Function–KANs, (ii) axis-wise separable mixing for efficient local propagation, and (iii) low-rank global mapping for long-range interactions. Uses patch-wise grouping to reduce the cost of full KANs and serves as a drop-in replacement for attention modules.
AI.result: Experiments on ImageNet-1K show ViK achieves competitive accuracy with linear (i.e., non-quadratic) complexity, validating the viability of KAN-based token mixing as an efficient alternative to attention.
AI.conclusion: ViK demonstrates the potential of attention-free KAN-based token mixing as an efficient, theoretically grounded backbone, though further work could expand comparisons, ablations, and applicability to more tasks.

title: Rethinking Refinement: Correcting Generative Bias without Noise Injection
summary: Generative models, including diffusion and flow-based models, often exhibit systematic biases that degrade sample quality, particularly in high-dimensional settings. We revisit refinement methods and show that effective bias correction can be achieved as a post-hoc procedure, without noise injection or multi-step resampling of the sampling process. We propose a flow-matching-based \textbf{Bi-stage Flow Refinement (BFR)} framework with two refinement strategies operating at different stages: latent space alignment for approximately invertible generators and data space refinement trained with lightweight augmentations. Unlike previous refiners that perturb sampling dynamics, BFR preserves the original ODE trajectory and applies deterministic corrections to generated samples. Experiments on MNIST, CIFAR-10, and FFHQ at 256x256 resolution demonstrate consistent improvements in fidelity and coverage; notably, starting from base samples with FID 3.95, latent space refinement achieves a \textbf{state-of-the-art} FID of \textbf{1.46} on MNIST using only a single additional function evaluation (1-NFE), while maintaining sample diversity.

AI.tldr: A two-stage, post-hoc bias refinement framework (Bi-stage Flow Refinement, BFR) for flow/diffusion models that preserves sampling trajectories while applying deterministic corrections, achieving state-of-the-art MNIST FID with minimal additional computation and improved fidelity/coverage across MNIST, CIFAR-10, and FFHQ-256.
AI.motivation: Systematic biases in high-dimensional generative models degrade sample quality. Existing refiners often perturb sampling Dynamics or require multi-step resampling; a post-hoc, trajectory-preserving bias correction with low overhead is desirable.
AI.method: Introduce Bi-stage Flow Refinement (BFR) with two strategies: (1) latent space alignment for approximately invertible generators; (2) data-space refinement trained with lightweight augmentations. Refine samples deterministically without injecting noise and without altering the original ODE trajectory; operates with a single extra function evaluation (1-NFE) in the MNIST setting.
AI.result: Empirical results on MNIST, CIFAR-10, and FFHQ-256 demonstrate consistent improvements in fidelity and coverage. Starting from base samples with FID 3.95, latent-space refinement achieves a state-of-the-art FID of 1.46 on MNIST with only 1 additional function evaluation, while maintaining sample diversity.
AI.conclusion: Post-hoc bias correction via BFR can effectively improve sample quality without manipulating sampling dynamics or adding noise; the two-stage framework offers a practical and efficient path to higher fidelity and coverage across standard benchmarks.

title: DataCross: A Unified Benchmark and Agent Framework for Cross-Modal Heterogeneous Data Analysis
summary: In real-world data science and enterprise decision-making, critical information is often fragmented across directly queryable structured sources (e.g., SQL, CSV) and "zombie data" locked in unstructured visual documents (e.g., scanned reports, invoice images). Existing data analytics agents are predominantly limited to processing structured data, failing to activate and correlate this high-value visual information, thus creating a significant gap with industrial needs. To bridge this gap, we introduce DataCross, a novel benchmark and collaborative agent framework for unified, insight-driven analysis across heterogeneous data modalities. DataCrossBench comprises 200 end-to-end analysis tasks across finance, healthcare, and other domains. It is constructed via a human-in-the-loop reverse-synthesis pipeline, ensuring realistic complexity, cross-source dependency, and verifiable ground truth. The benchmark categorizes tasks into three difficulty tiers to evaluate agents' capabilities in visual table extraction, cross-modal alignment, and multi-step joint reasoning. We also propose the DataCrossAgent framework, inspired by the "divide-and-conquer" workflow of human analysts. It employs specialized sub-agents, each an expert on a specific data source, which are coordinated via a structured workflow of Intra-source Deep Exploration, Key Source Identification, and Contextual Cross-pollination. A novel reReAct mechanism enables robust code generation and debugging for factual verification. Experimental results show that DataCrossAgent achieves a 29.7% improvement in factuality over GPT-4o and exhibits superior robustness on high-difficulty tasks, effectively activating fragmented "zombie data" for insightful, cross-modal analysis.

AI.tldr: DataCross introduces a dual contribution: DataCrossBench, a 200-task multi-modal benchmark for unified analysis across structured and unstructured data, and DataCrossAgent, a collaborative, divide-and-conquer framework using specialized sub-agents with a novel reReact mechanism; results show improved factuality and robustness over GPT-4o in cross-modal tasks.
AI.motivation: Enterprise data analytics often suffers from fragmentation between queryable structured data and unstructured visual data (e.g., scanned documents). Existing agents focus on structured data and fail to leverage visual information, creating a gap between capabilities and industrial needs. The work motivates a unified framework to bridge this gap with realistic tasks and ground-truth.
AI.method: 1) DataCrossBench: a benchmark with 200 end-to-end tasks across finance, healthcare, etc., organized into three difficulty levels, built via a human-in-the-loop reverse-synthesis pipeline to ensure realism and verifiable ground truth. 2) DataCrossAgent: a collaborative agent system with specialized sub-agents (per data source) guided by a workflow: Intra-source Deep Exploration, Key Source Identification, Contextual Cross-pollination. 3) reReact: a mechanism for robust code generation and debugging for factual verification. Experimental setup benchmarks factuality and robustness, comparing against baselines like GPT-4o.
AI.result: DataCrossAgent achieves a 29.7% improvement in factuality over GPT-4o and demonstrates superior robustness on high-difficulty tasks, effectively activating fragmented “zombie data” for cross-modal insight.
AI.conclusion: The paper presents a practical benchmark and an agent framework that enable unified, insight-driven analysis across heterogeneous data modalities. The approach improves factual correctness and cross-modal reasoning in real-world data settings, addressing a key gap in current data analytics agents.

title: Bi-Anchor Interpolation Solver for Accelerating Generative Modeling
summary: Flow Matching (FM) models have emerged as a leading paradigm for high-fidelity synthesis. However, their reliance on iterative Ordinary Differential Equation (ODE) solving creates a significant latency bottleneck. Existing solutions face a dichotomy: training-free solvers suffer from significant performance degradation at low Neural Function Evaluations (NFEs), while training-based one- or few-steps generation methods incur prohibitive training costs and lack plug-and-play versatility. To bridge this gap, we propose the Bi-Anchor Interpolation Solver (BA-solver). BA-solver retains the versatility of standard training-free solvers while achieving significant acceleration by introducing a lightweight SideNet (1-2% backbone size) alongside the frozen backbone. Specifically, our method is founded on two synergistic components: \textbf{1) Bidirectional Temporal Perception}, where the SideNet learns to approximate both future and historical velocities without retraining the heavy backbone; and 2) Bi-Anchor Velocity Integration, which utilizes the SideNet with two anchor velocities to efficiently approximate intermediate velocities for batched high-order integration. By utilizing the backbone to establish high-precision ``anchors'' and the SideNet to densify the trajectory, BA-solver enables large interval sizes with minimized error. Empirical results on ImageNet-256^2 demonstrate that BA-solver achieves generation quality comparable to 100+ NFEs Euler solver in just 10 NFEs and maintains high fidelity in as few as 5 NFEs, incurring negligible training costs. Furthermore, BA-solver ensures seamless integration with existing generative pipelines, facilitating downstream tasks such as image editing.

AI.tldr: Bi-Anchor Interpolation Solver (BA-solver) accelerates flow-matching ODE-based generation by pairing a frozen backbone with a lightweight SideNet, enabling large integration steps with minimal accuracy loss and training costs.
AI.motivation: Address the latency bottleneck of iterative ODE solvers in Flow Matching models. Training-free solvers degrade at low NFEs; training-based methods incur high costs and lack plug-and-play versatility.
AI.method: Two components: (1) Bidirectional Temporal Perception where SideNet predicts future and past velocities without retraining the backbone; (2) Bi-Anchor Velocity Integration using SideNet with two anchor velocities to approximate intermediate velocities for high-order integration. Backbone provides high-precision anchors; SideNet densifies trajectory with 1-2% backbone size.
AI.result: On ImageNet-256^2, BA-solver achieves generation quality comparable to 100+ NFEs Euler solver with only 10 NFEs; maintains high fidelity at 5 NFEs; negligible training costs and seamless integration into existing pipelines; supports downstream tasks like image editing.
AI.conclusion: BA-solver offers a versatile, efficient, training-free acceleration for Flow Matching models, enabling fast, high-fidelity generation with minimal backbone training and easy plug-and-play deployment.

title: Rethinking Self-Training Based Cross-Subject Domain Adaptation for SSVEP Classification
summary: Steady-state visually evoked potentials (SSVEP)-based brain-computer interfaces (BCIs) are widely used due to their high signal-to-noise ratio and user-friendliness. Accurate decoding of SSVEP signals is crucial for interpreting user intentions in BCI applications. However, signal variability across subjects and the costly user-specific annotation limit recognition performance. Therefore, we propose a novel cross-subject domain adaptation method built upon the self-training paradigm. Specifically, a Filter-Bank Euclidean Alignment (FBEA) strategy is designed to exploit frequency information from SSVEP filter banks. Then, we propose a Cross-Subject Self-Training (CSST) framework consisting of two stages: Pre-Training with Adversarial Learning (PTAL), which aligns the source and target distributions, and Dual-Ensemble Self-Training (DEST), which refines pseudo-label quality. Moreover, we introduce a Time-Frequency Augmented Contrastive Learning (TFA-CL) module to enhance feature discriminability across multiple augmented views. Extensive experiments on the Benchmark and BETA datasets demonstrate that our approach achieves state-of-the-art performance across varying signal lengths, highlighting its superiority.

AI.tldr: A cross-subject, self-training framework for SSVEP-based BCIs combining frequency-aware filtering (FBEA), adversarial distribution alignment (PTAL), pseudo-label refinement (DEST), and time-frequency contrastive learning (TFA-CL) to achieve state-of-the-art results across datasets and varying signal lengths.
AI.motivation: SSVEP BCIs suffer from high inter-subject variability and costly subject-specific labeling, limiting recognition performance; cross-subject domain adaptation with self-training can leverage labeled data from some subjects to improve decoding on others without extensive labeling.
AI.method: Introduce Filter-Bank Euclidean Alignment (FBEA) to exploit frequency information from SSVEP filter banks; develop Cross-Subject Self-Training (CSST) with two stages: Pre-Training with Adversarial Learning (PTAL) to align source/target distributions, and Dual-Ensemble Self-Training (DEST) to refine pseudo-labels; add Time-Frequency Augmented Contrastive Learning (TFA-CL) to improve feature discriminability across multiple augmented views.
AI.result: Extensive experiments on Benchmark and BETA datasets show state-of-the-art performance across varying signal lengths, demonstrating robust cross-subject adaptation and effective pseudo-label refinement.
AI.conclusion: The proposed cross-subject self-training framework effectively mitigates inter-subject variability and annotation costs in SSVEP-BCIs, achieving superior decoding performance; the combination of frequency-aware alignment, self-training, and time-frequency contrastive learning provides a strong blueprint for cross-subject EEG transfer learning and may generalize to other EEG-based paradigms.

title: System 1&2 Synergy via Dynamic Model Interpolation
summary: Training a unified language model that adapts between intuitive System 1 and deliberative System 2 remains challenging due to interference between their cognitive modes. Recent studies have thus pursued making System 2 models more efficient. However, these approaches focused on output control, limiting what models produce. We argue that this paradigm is misaligned: output length is merely a symptom of the model's cognitive configuration, not the root cause. In this work, we shift the focus to capability control, which modulates \textit{how models think} rather than \textit{what they produce}. To realize this, we leverage existing Instruct and Thinking checkpoints through dynamic parameter interpolation, without additional training. Our pilot study establishes that linear interpolation yields a convex, monotonic Pareto frontier, underpinned by representation continuity and structural connectivity. Building on this, we propose \textbf{DAMI} (\textbf{D}yn\textbf{A}mic \textbf{M}odel \textbf{I}nterpolation), a framework that estimates a query-specific Reasoning Intensity $λ(q)$ to configure cognitive depth. For training-based estimation, we develop a preference learning method encoding accuracy and efficiency criteria. For zero-shot deployment, we introduce a confidence-based method leveraging inter-model cognitive discrepancy. Experiments on five mathematical reasoning benchmarks demonstrate that DAMI achieves higher accuracy than the Thinking model while remaining efficient, effectively combining the efficiency of System 1 with the reasoning depth of System 2.

AI.tldr: DAMI introduces dynamic model interpolation between Instruct and Thinking checkpoints to control reasoning depth per query, achieving better accuracy than Thinking with efficiency, via training-based or zero-shot estimation.
AI.motivation: Unifying LMs struggle to balance intuitive (System 1) and deliberative (System 2) modes; output-control methods are limited since output length is a symptom, not root cause. The paper proposes capability control through dynamic interpolation to modulate how models think, leveraging existing checkpoints without extra training to realize a convex Pareto frontier between accuracy and efficiency.
AI.method: Linear interpolation between Instruct (System 1) and Thinking (System 2) checkpoints without additional training. Define a query-specific reasoning intensity λ(q) to configure cognitive depth. For training-based estimation, use a preference-learning method encoding accuracy and efficiency criteria. For zero-shot deployment, use a confidence-based method leveraging inter-model cognitive discrepancy.
AI.result: Experiments on five mathematical reasoning benchmarks show DAMI achieves higher accuracy than the Thinking model while remaining efficient, effectively combining System 1 efficiency with System 2 reasoning depth and establishing a convex, monotonic Pareto frontier.
AI.conclusion: Dynamic capability control via Interpolation effectively blends System 1 and System 2, offering a practical, training-free mechanism to adjust cognitive depth per query and improve performance without sacrificing efficiency.

title: Unifying Heterogeneous Degradations: Uncertainty-Aware Diffusion Bridge Model for All-in-One Image Restoration
summary: All-in-One Image Restoration (AiOIR) faces the fundamental challenge in reconciling conflicting optimization objectives across heterogeneous degradations. Existing methods are often constrained by coarse-grained control mechanisms or fixed mapping schedules, yielding suboptimal adaptation. To address this, we propose an Uncertainty-Aware Diffusion Bridge Model (UDBM), which innovatively reformulates AiOIR as a stochastic transport problem steered by pixel-wise uncertainty. By introducing a relaxed diffusion bridge formulation which replaces the strict terminal constraint with a relaxed constraint, we model the uncertainty of degradations while theoretically resolving the drift singularity inherent in standard diffusion bridges. Furthermore, we devise a dual modulation strategy: the noise schedule aligns diverse degradations into a shared high-entropy latent space, while the path schedule adaptively regulates the transport trajectory motivated by the viscous dynamics of entropy regularization. By effectively rectifying the transport geometry and dynamics, UDBM achieves state-of-the-art performance across diverse restoration tasks within a single inference step.

AI.tldr: Uncertainty-aware diffusion-bridge for All-in-One Image Restoration (AiOIR): relaxes the diffusion terminal constraint and uses dual modulation (noise and path schedules) to unify diverse degradations in a high-entropy latent space, achieving state-of-the-art restoration in a single inference step.
AI.motivation: AiOIR must reconcile heterogeneous degradations that impose conflicting optimization objectives; existing methods rely on coarse control or fixed schedules, leading to suboptimal adaptation. A principled stochastic-transport formulation with uncertainty can better model degradations and transport dynamics.
AI.method: Introduce a relaxed diffusion-bridge formulation that replaces the strict terminal constraint with a relaxed one to model degradation uncertainty and resolve drift singularities. Propose dual modulation: (1) noise schedule to map various degradations into a shared high-entropy latent space; (2) path schedule to adaptively regulate the transport trajectory inspired by viscous entropy-regularized dynamics. The combination rectifies transport geometry and dynamics, enabling single-step inference.
AI.result: Claims state-of-the-art performance across diverse AiO image restoration tasks in a single inference step, demonstrating effective handling of heterogeneous degradations and improved restoration quality.
AI.conclusion: UDBM provides a principled stochastic-transport framework for AiOIR, addressing drift singularities and degradation uncertainty, with dual modulation enabling robust, unified restoration in one forward pass. Potential broad applicability to diffusion-bridge based restoration problems.

title: A Sheaf-Theoretic and Topological Perspective on Complex Network Modeling and Attention Mechanisms in Graph Neural Models
summary: Combinatorial and topological structures, such as graphs, simplicial complexes, and cell complexes, form the foundation of geometric and topological deep learning (GDL and TDL) architectures. These models aggregate signals over such domains, integrate local features, and generate representations for diverse real-world applications. However, the distribution and diffusion behavior of GDL and TDL features during training remains an open and underexplored problem. Motivated by this gap, we introduce a cellular sheaf theoretic framework for modeling and analyzing the local consistency and harmonicity of node features and edge weights in graph-based architectures. By tracking local feature alignments and agreements through sheaf structures, the framework offers a topological perspective on feature diffusion and aggregation. Furthermore, a multiscale extension inspired by topological data analysis (TDA) is proposed to capture hierarchical feature interactions in graph models. This approach enables a joint characterization of GDL and TDL architectures based on their underlying geometric and topological structures and the learned signals defined on them, providing insights for future studies on conventional tasks such as node classification, substructure detection, and community detection.

AI.tldr: Proposes a cellular sheaf-theoretic framework with a multiscale topological perspective to analyze feature diffusion and aggregation in graph-based neural architectures.
AI.motivation: Addresses the gap in understanding how GDL/TDL features diffuse, align, and harmonize during training on combinatorial/topological domains. Aims to provide a geometric/topological lens via sheaves and multiscale methods to explain and enhance feature propagation.
AI.method: Develops a cellular sheaf-theoretic framework to model local feature alignments and edge-weight agreements in graphs, capturing local consistency and harmonicity. Extends the framework with a multiscale, TDA-inspired extension to model hierarchical feature interactions.
AI.result: Provides a conceptual framework and theoretical basis for analyzing feature diffusion/aggregation in GDL/TDL using sheaf-theoretic and multiscale topology tools; outlines potential applications to node classification, substructure detection, and community detection.
AI.conclusion: Offers a topological viewpoint on geometric and topological deep learning architectures and highlights directions for future work in characterizing learned signals on graphs and their implications for standard tasks.

title: When Prohibitions Become Permissions: Auditing Negation Sensitivity in Language Models
summary: When a user tells an AI system that someone "should not" take an action, the system ought to treat this as a prohibition. Yet many large language models do the opposite: they interpret negated instructions as affirmations. We audited 16 models across 14 ethical scenarios and found that open-source models endorse prohibited actions 77% of the time under simple negation and 100% under compound negation -- a 317% increase over affirmative framing. Commercial models fare better but still show swings of 19-128%. Agreement between models drops from 74% on affirmative prompts to 62% on negated ones, and financial scenarios prove twice as fragile as medical ones. These patterns hold under deterministic decoding, ruling out sampling noise. We present case studies showing how these failures play out in practice, propose the Negation Sensitivity Index (NSI) as a governance metric, and outline a tiered certification framework with domain-specific thresholds. The findings point to a gap between what current alignment techniques achieve and what safe deployment requires: models that cannot reliably distinguish "do X" from "do not X" should not be making autonomous decisions in high-stakes contexts.

AI.tldr: Negation handling in LLMs is unreliable: prohibitions are interpreted as permissions, especially under negation. Open-source models misbehave more (77% under simple negation; 100% under compound negation; 317% uptick vs affirmative), while commercial models show smaller swings. Model agreement decreases with negation (74% to 62%). Financial scenarios are more fragile than medical. Results persist under deterministic decoding. Propose the Negation Sensitivity Index (NSI) and a tiered certification framework. Highlights a gap between current alignment and safe deployment in high-stakes decisions.
AI.motivation: Evaluate whether current LLMs reliably interpret prohibitions (negation) in high-stakes contexts, to assess deployment risk and inform governance. Identify systematic failure patterns and quantify them across models and domains.
AI.method: Audit 16 models across 14 ethical scenarios using affirmative and negated prompts (simple and compound negation). Compare actions, measure agreement, test under deterministic decoding, present case studies, develop the Negation Sensitivity Index (NSI), and outline a tiered, domain-specific certification framework.
AI.result: Open-source models: 77% comply with prohibitions under simple negation; 100% under compound negation; a 317% increase over affirmative framing. Commercial models show 19–128% swings. Agreement drops from 74% (affirmative) to 62% (negated). Financial scenarios are twice as fragile as medical ones. Findings robust under deterministic decoding. Introduced NSI governance metric and tiered certification framework; calls for safer deployment in high-stakes contexts.
AI.conclusion: There is a critical gap between current alignment methods and the safety requirements for autonomous decision-making. Models that cannot reliably distinguish ‘do X’ from ‘do not X’ should not be trusted for high-stakes autonomous tasks.

authors: A. S. M. Ahsanul Sarkar Akib
title: HydroSense: A Dual-Microcontroller IoT Framework for Real-Time Multi-Parameter Water Quality Monitoring with Edge Processing and Cloud Analytics
summary: The global water crisis necessitates affordable, accurate, and real-time water quality monitoring solutions. Traditional approaches relying on manual sampling or expensive commercial systems fail to address accessibility challenges in resource-constrained environments. This paper presents HydroSense, an innovative Internet of Things framework that integrates six critical water quality parameters including pH, dissolved oxygen (DO), temperature, total dissolved solids (TDS), estimated nitrogen, and water level into a unified monitoring system. HydroSense employs a novel dual-microcontroller architecture, utilizing Arduino Uno for precision analog measurements with five-point calibration algorithms and ESP32 for wireless connectivity, edge processing, and cloud integration. The system implements advanced signal processing techniques including median filtering for TDS measurement, temperature compensation algorithms, and robust error handling. Experimental validation over 90 days demonstrates exceptional performance metrics: pH accuracy of plus or minus 0.08 units across the 0 to 14 range, DO measurement stability within plus or minus 0.2 mg/L, TDS accuracy of plus or minus 1.9 percent across 0 to 1000 ppm, and 99.8 percent cloud data transmission reliability. With a total implementation cost of 32,983 BDT (approximately 300 USD), HydroSense achieves an 85 percent cost reduction compared to commercial systems while providing enhanced connectivity through the Firebase real-time database. This research establishes a new paradigm for accessible environmental monitoring, demonstrating that professional-grade water quality assessment can be achieved through intelligent system architecture and cost-effective component selection.

AI.tldr: An IoT-based, dual-microcontroller water quality monitoring system (HydroSense) integrating pH, DO, temperature, TDS, estimated nitrogen, and water level; shows real-time cloud connectivity with Firebase, accuracy and cost improvements, validated over 90 days.
AI.motivation: Address global water quality monitoring accessibility in resource-limited environments by delivering affordable, accurate, and real-time sensing.
AI.method: Hardware: Arduino Uno for precision analog measurements with five-point calibration; ESP32 for wireless connectivity, edge processing, and cloud integration. Signals: median filtering for TDS, temperature compensation, robust error handling. Cloud: Firebase real-time database.
AI.result: 90-day validation with pH ±0.08 units (0–14), DO ±0.2 mg/L, TDS ±1.9% (0–1000 ppm), cloud transmission 99.8% uptime; cost ≈ 300 USD, 85% cheaper than commercial systems.
AI.conclusion: Demonstrates that professional-grade water quality assessment is achievable via an intelligent, cost-effective IoT architecture suitable for widespread deployment.

title: Temporal Context and Architecture: A Benchmark for Naturalistic EEG Decoding
summary: We study how model architecture and temporal context interact in naturalistic EEG decoding. Using the HBN movie-watching dataset, we benchmark five architectures, CNN, LSTM, a stabilized Transformer (EEGXF), S4, and S5, on a 4-class task across segment lengths from 8s to 128s. Accuracy improves with longer context: at 64s, S5 reaches 98.7%+/-0.6 and CNN 98.3%+/-0.3, while S5 uses ~20x fewer parameters than CNN. To probe real-world robustness, we evaluate zero-shot cross-frequency shifts, cross-task OOD inputs, and leave-one-subject-out generalization. S5 achieves stronger cross-subject accuracy but makes over-confident errors on OOD tasks; EEGXF is more conservative and stable under frequency shifts, though less calibrated in-distribution. These results reveal a practical efficiency-robustness trade-off: S5 for parameter-efficient peak accuracy; EEGXF when robustness and conservative uncertainty are critical.

AI.tldr: The abstract compares five EEG decoding architectures (CNN, LSTM, EEGXF, S4, S5) on naturalistic movie-watching data, showing longer temporal context improves accuracy; S5 achieves near-peak accuracy with far fewer parameters but exhibits over-confident OOD errors, whereas EEGXF is more robust and conservative; overall a trade-off between efficiency and robustness.
AI.motivation: To understand how architectural choice and temporal context influence naturalistic EEG decoding and generalization, using the HBN movie-watching dataset.
AI.method: Benchmark five architectures (CNN, LSTM, EEGXF, S4, S5) on a 4-class task across segment lengths 8–128 seconds; assess zero-shot cross-frequency shifts, cross-task OOD inputs, and leave-one-subject-out generalization.
AI.result: Longer context improves accuracy; at 64s, S5 ≈ 98.7% (±0.6) and CNN ≈ 98.3% (±0.3). S5 uses ≈20x fewer parameters than CNN. S5 shows strong cross-subject accuracy but over-confident errors on OOD tasks; EEGXF is more conservative and stable under frequency shifts but less calibrated in-distribution.
AI.conclusion: There is a practical efficiency-robustness trade-off: S5 is favorable for parameter-efficient peak accuracy; EEGXF is preferable when robustness and conservative uncertainty are critical.

title: The Paradox of Robustness: Decoupling Rule-Based Logic from Affective Noise in High-Stakes Decision-Making
summary: While Large Language Models (LLMs) are widely documented to be sensitive to minor prompt perturbations and prone to sycophantic alignment with user biases, their robustness in consequential, rule-bound decision-making remains under-explored. In this work, we uncover a striking "Paradox of Robustness": despite their known lexical brittleness, instruction-tuned LLMs exhibit a behavioral and near-total invariance to emotional framing effects. Using a novel controlled perturbation framework across three high-stakes domains (healthcare, law, and finance), we quantify a robustness gap where LLMs demonstrate 110-300 times greater resistance to narrative manipulation than human subjects. Specifically, we find a near-zero effect size for models (Cohen's h = 0.003) compared to the substantial biases observed in humans (Cohen's h in [0.3, 0.8]). This result is highly counterintuitive and suggests the mechanisms driving sycophancy and prompt sensitivity do not necessarily translate to a failure in logical constraint satisfaction. We show that this invariance persists across models with diverse training paradigms. Our findings show that while LLMs may be "brittle" to how a query is formatted, they are remarkably "stable" against why a decision should be biased. Our findings establish that instruction-tuned models can decouple logical rule-adherence from persuasive narratives, offering a source of decision stability that complements, and even potentially de-biases, human judgment in institutional contexts. We release the 162-scenario benchmark, code, and data to facilitate the rigorous evaluation of narrative-induced bias and robustness on GitHub.com.

AI.tldr: Instruction-tuned LLMs show extreme robustness to emotional framing in high-stakes decisions, resisting narrative manipulation far more than humans; a 162-scenario benchmark is released.
AI.motivation: Investigates whether robustness to prompt wording extends to framing effects and quantifies AI-human biases in consequential tasks.
AI.method: Novel controlled perturbation framework across healthcare, law, and finance; compare instruction-tuned models with humans; measure framing effect using Cohen's h; benchmark of 162 scenarios; cross-model training paradigms.
AI.result: Models exhibit near-zero framing effect (Cohen's h ≈ 0.003) vs humans (0.3–0.8); 110–300x greater resistance; invariance across models; decoupling of rule-adherence from persuasive narratives.
AI.conclusion: Instruction-tuned models offer stable decision-making despite framing, potentially enabling de-biasing of human judgment; provides a benchmark resource for evaluating narrative-induced bias.

title: WMVLM: Evaluating Diffusion Model Image Watermarking via Vision-Language Models
summary: Digital watermarking is essential for securing generated images from diffusion models. Accurate watermark evaluation is critical for algorithm development, yet existing methods have significant limitations: they lack a unified framework for both residual and semantic watermarks, provide results without interpretability, neglect comprehensive security considerations, and often use inappropriate metrics for semantic watermarks. To address these gaps, we propose WMVLM, the first unified and interpretable evaluation framework for diffusion model image watermarking via vision-language models (VLMs). We redefine quality and security metrics for each watermark type: residual watermarks are evaluated by artifact strength and erasure resistance, while semantic watermarks are assessed through latent distribution shifts. Moreover, we introduce a three-stage training strategy to progressively enable the model to achieve classification, scoring, and interpretable text generation. Experiments show WMVLM outperforms state-of-the-art VLMs with strong generalization across datasets, diffusion models, and watermarking methods.

AI.tldr: WMVLM is a unified, interpretable evaluation framework for diffusion-model image watermarking using vision-language models. It defines separate metrics for residual (artifact strength, erasure resistance) and semantic (latent distribution shifts) watermarks, and introduces a three-stage training strategy for classification, scoring, and interpretable text generation, achieving strong generalization over datasets, models, and watermarking methods.
AI.motivation: Existing evaluation methods for image watermarking in diffusion models lack a single, interpretable framework that covers both residual and semantic watermarks, provide non-interpretable results, neglect full security considerations, and use inappropriate metrics for semantic watermarks. A unified, interpretable framework is needed to drive robust algorithm development.
AI.method: Propose WMVLM, a unified evaluation framework that uses vision-language models. Define metrics: residual watermarks are evaluated via artifact strength and erasure resistance; semantic watermarks via latent distribution shifts. Implement a three-stage training strategy to enable the model to perform (1) classification, (2) scoring, and (3) interpretable text generation. Demonstrate superior performance versus state-of-the-art VLMs and strong generalization across datasets, diffusion models, and watermarking methods.
AI.result: WMVLM outperforms state-of-the-art VLMs and generalizes well across datasets, diffusion models, and watermarking methods.
AI.conclusion: The approach provides a unified, interpretable, and comprehensive evaluation framework for diffusion-model image watermarking, addressing prior gaps and enabling more reliable development and assessment of watermarking techniques.

title: Soft Quantization: Model Compression Via Weight Coupling
