First, we bridge the input modality gap by fusing reference appearance and motion cues into a unified latent space, enabling the model to jointly reason about spatial identity and temporal dynamics by leveraging the generative prior of foundational models. Second, we introduce a self-bootstrapped data synthesis pipeline that curates pseudo cross-identity training pairs, facilitating a seamless transition from pose-dependent control to direct, end-to-end RGB-driven animation. This strategy significantly enhances generalization across diverse characters and motion scenarios. To facilitate comprehensive evaluation, we further introduce AW Bench, a versatile benchmark encompassing a wide spectrum of characters types and motion scenarios. Extensive experiments demonstrate that DreamActor-M2 achieves state-of-the-art performance, delivering superior visual fidelity and robust cross-domain generalization. Project Page: https://grisoon.github.io/DreamActor-M2/

AI.tldr: DreamActor-M2 reframes motion conditioning as in-context learning to unify appearance and motion within a latent space, uses self-bootstrapped data synthesis for RGB-driven animation, and introduces AW Bench for evaluation. It claims state-of-the-art performance and strong cross-domain generalization across diverse characters and motions.
AI.motivation: Two core limitations in prior work: (1) suboptimal motion injection causing a “see-saw” between identity preservation and motion consistency; (2) heavy reliance on explicit pose priors (e.g., skeletons) that fail to capture complex dynamics and hinder generalization to non-humanoid characters.
AI.method: A two-stage paradigm: (1) fuse reference appearance and motion cues into a unified latent space to enable joint reasoning about spatial identity and temporal dynamics using generative priors; (2) employ a self-bootstrapped data synthesis pipeline to create pseudo cross-identity training pairs, enabling a transition from pose-dependent control to end-to-end RGB-driven animation.
AI.result: Extensive experiments show DreamActor-M2 achieves state-of-the-art visual fidelity and robust cross-domain generalization, supported by the AW Bench benchmark that covers diverse character types and motion scenarios.
AI.conclusion: DreamActor-M2 offers a universal animation framework that leverages in-context learning and latent fusion to overcome identity-motion trade-offs and to generalize beyond pose priors, with empirical evidence of superior performance and generalization; future work may explore broader benchmarks and real-time applicability.

title: Physics-Guided Tiny-Mamba Transformer for Reliability-Aware Early Fault Warning
comment: Submitted to IEEE Transactions on Reliability
summary: Reliability-centered prognostics for rotating machinery requires early warning signals that remain accurate under nonstationary operating conditions, domain shifts across speed/load/sensors, and severe class imbalance, while keeping the false-alarm rate small and predictable. We propose the Physics-Guided Tiny-Mamba Transformer (PG-TMT), a compact tri-branch encoder tailored for online condition monitoring. A depthwise-separable convolutional stem captures micro-transients, a Tiny-Mamba state-space branch models near-linear long-range dynamics, and a lightweight local Transformer encodes cross-channel resonances. We derive an analytic temporal-to-spectral mapping that ties the model's attention spectrum to classical bearing fault-order bands, yielding a band-alignment score that quantifies physical plausibility and provides physics-grounded explanations. To ensure decision reliability, healthy-score exceedances are modeled with extreme-value theory (EVT), which yields an on-threshold achieving a target false-alarm intensity (events/hour); a dual-threshold hysteresis with a minimum hold time further suppresses chatter. Under a leakage-free streaming protocol with right-censoring of missed detections on CWRU, Paderborn, XJTU-SY, and an industrial pilot, PG-TMT attains higher precision-recall AUC (primary under imbalance), competitive or better ROC AUC, and shorter mean time-to-detect at matched false-alarm intensity, together with strong cross-domain transfer. By coupling physics-aligned representations with EVT-calibrated decision rules, PG-TMT delivers calibrated, interpretable, and deployment-ready early warnings for reliability-centric prognostics and health management.

AI.tldr: A compact physics-guided tri-branch transformer for online bearing prognostics achieving robust early warnings with calibrated EVT-based decision rules and physics-aligned spectral interpretation, demonstrating strong cross-domain transfer and reduced detection latency under imbalance.
AI.motivation: Reliability-centered prognostics require early, accurate warnings under nonstationary operating conditions, domain shifts, and severe class imbalance, while keeping false alarms predictable.
AI.method: Three-branch encoder: (1) depthwise-separable conv stem for micro-transients; (2) Tiny-Mamba state-space branch for near-linear long-range dynamics; (3) lightweight local Transformer for cross-channel resonances. Analytic temporal-to-spectral mapping linking attention spectrum to fault-order bands; band-alignment score for physics plausibility. EVT-based healthy-score exceedances with threshold controlled false-alarm intensity; dual-threshold hysteresis with minimum hold time; leakage-free streaming with right-censoring; evaluation on CWRU, Paderborn, XJTU-SY, industrial pilot.
AI.result: Attains higher precision-recall AUC (primary under imbalance), competitive/better ROC AUC, and shorter mean time-to-detect at matched false-alarm intensity; strong cross-domain transfer.
AI.conclusion: Physics-aligned representations plus EVT-calibrated decision rules yield calibrated, interpretable, deployment-ready early warnings for reliability-centered prognostics and health management.

title: ShardMemo: Masked MoE Routing for Sharded Agentic LLM Memory
summary: Agentic large language model (LLM) systems rely on external memory for long-horizon state and concurrent multi-agent execution, but centralized indexes and heuristic partitions become bottlenecks as memory volume and parallel access grow. We present ShardMemo, a budgeted tiered memory service with Tier A per-agent working state, Tier B sharded evidence with shard-local approximate nearest neighbor (ANN) indexes, and Tier C, a versioned skill library. Tier B enforces scope-before-routing: structured eligibility constraints mask ineligible shards before routing or ANN search. We cast shard probing as masked mixture-of-experts (MoE) routing over eligible shards, probing up to $B_{\mathrm{probe}}$ shards via Top-$B_{\mathrm{probe}}$ or adaptive Top-$P$, and use cost-aware gating over profile/observation/session shard families; the router is trained from evidence-to-shard supervision. On LoCoMo, ShardMemo improves over the strongest baseline (GAM) by +5.11 to +6.82 F1 across question categories. Under a fixed-budget routing setting ($B_{\mathrm{probe}}=3$), ShardMemo improves over cosine-to-prototype shard routing by +6.87 F1 while reducing retrieval work (VecScan 521->414, -20.5%) and p95 latency (95->76 ms). On long-context HotpotQA, ShardMemo achieves 63.41/61.88/57.95 F1 at 56K/224K/448K tokens. On ToolBench, Tier C reaches 0.97 Precision@3 and 1.94 StepRed (+10.2% and +7.2% over embedding-similarity retrieval).

AI.tldr: ShardMemo is a budgeted, tiered memory service for agentic LLMs, combining per-agent working state, sharded evidence with local ANN indexes, and a versioned skill library to enable scalable, cost-aware routing and retrieval.
AI.motivation: As memory volume grows and multi-agent concurrency increases, centralized indexes and simple partitions become bottlenecks; a scalable, tunable memory subsystem is needed for long-horizon reasoning.
AI.method: Proposes a three-tier design: Tier A per-agent working state; Tier B sharded evidence with shard-local ANN indexes and scope-before-routing; Tier C versioned skill library. Routing is cast as masked mixture-of-experts over eligible shards, probing up to B_probe shards via Top-B_probe or adaptive Top-P, with cost-aware gating across shard families; the router is trained with evidence-to-shard supervision.
AI.result: Empirical gains across datasets: LoCoMo shows +5.11 to +6.82 F1 over GAM; under fixed B_probe=3, +6.87 F1 vs cosine-to-prototype routing, with reduced retrieval work (VecScan 521→414, −20.5%) and p95 latency (95→76 ms). HotPotQA long-context: 63.41/61.88/57.95 F1 at 56K/224K/448K tokens. ToolBench Tier C: Precision@3 = 0.97; StepRed = 1.94 (+10.2% and +7.2% over embedding-similarity).
AI.conclusion: ShardMemo demonstrates scalable, cost-aware memory routing for agentic LLMs, delivering higher task accuracy with lower retrieval overhead and latency across multiple benchmarks, by combining tiered memory, scoped routing, and trained evidence-to-shard routing.

title: From Global to Granular: Revealing IQA Model Performance via Correlation Surface
summary: Evaluation of Image Quality Assessment (IQA) models has long been dominated by global correlation metrics, such as Pearson Linear Correlation Coefficient (PLCC) and Spearman Rank-Order Correlation Coefficient (SRCC). While widely adopted, these metrics reduce performance to a single scalar, failing to capture how ranking consistency varies across the local quality spectrum. For example, two IQA models may achieve identical SRCC values, yet one ranks high-quality images (related to high Mean Opinion Score, MOS) more reliably, while the other better discriminates image pairs with small quality/MOS differences (related to $|Δ$MOS$|$). Such complementary behaviors are invisible under global metrics. Moreover, SRCC and PLCC are sensitive to test-sample quality distributions, yielding unstable comparisons across test sets. To address these limitations, we propose \textbf{Granularity-Modulated Correlation (GMC)}, which provides a structured, fine-grained analysis of IQA performance. GMC includes: (1) a \textbf{Granularity Modulator} that applies Gaussian-weighted correlations conditioned on absolute MOS values and pairwise MOS differences ($|Δ$MOS$|$) to examine local performance variations, and (2) a \textbf{Distribution Regulator} that regularizes correlations to mitigate biases from non-uniform quality distributions. The resulting \textbf{correlation surface} maps correlation values as a joint function of MOS and $|Δ$MOS$|$, providing a 3D representation of IQA performance. Experiments on standard benchmarks show that GMC reveals performance characteristics invisible to scalar metrics, offering a more informative and reliable paradigm for analyzing, comparing, and deploying IQA models. Codes are available at https://github.com/Dniaaa/GMC.

AI.tldr: GMC introduces Granularity-Modulated Correlation to analyze IQA models across MOS and MOS-difference, yielding a 3D correlation surface that reveals local performance and mitigates distribution biases; claims to provide more insight than global SRCC/PLCC; code is released.
AI.motivation: Global correlation metrics (PLCC/SRCC) reduce performance to a single scalar and fail to capture local ranking stability across the quality spectrum; they are sensitive to test-set distributions, hindering cross-dataset comparisons.
AI.method: GMC combines two components: a Granularity Modulator that applies Gaussian-weighted correlations conditioned on absolute MOS values and pairwise MOS differences |ΔMOS| to probe local performance, and a Distribution Regulator that regularizes correlations to counter biases from non-uniform quality distributions. It outputs a correlation surface mapping correlation as a function of MOS and |ΔMOS|, effectively a 3D analysis of IQA performance.
AI.result: Experiments on standard benchmarks demonstrate that GMC uncovers performance characteristics invisible to scalar metrics, providing a more informative and reliable framework for analyzing, comparing, and deploying IQA models. The authors release code at the linked GitHub repository.
AI.conclusion: GMC offers a fine-grained, distribution-robust analysis tool for IQA evaluation, enabling deeper understanding of where models excel or falter in different quality regimes and guiding model development and deployment decisions.

title: Missing-Data-Induced Phase Transitions in Spectral PLS for Multimodal Learning
summary: Partial Least Squares (PLS) learns shared structure from paired data via the top singular vectors of the empirical cross-covariance (PLS-SVD), but multimodal datasets often have missing entries in both views. We study PLS-SVD under independent entry-wise missing-completely-at-random masking in a proportional high-dimensional spiked model. After appropriate normalization, the masked cross-covariance behaves like a spiked rectangular random matrix whose effective signal strength is attenuated by $\sqrtρ$, where $ρ$ is the joint entry retention probability. As a result, PLS-SVD exhibits a sharp BBP-type phase transition: below a critical signal-to-noise threshold the leading singular vectors are asymptotically uninformative, while above it they achieve nontrivial alignment with the latent shared directions, with closed-form asymptotic overlap formulas. Simulations and semi-synthetic multimodal experiments corroborate the predicted phase diagram and recovery curves across aspect ratios, signal strengths, and missingness levels.

AI.tldr: Partial Least Squares with SVD (PLS-SVD) under MCAR masking in high-dimensional spiked models exhibits a BBP-type phase transition: effective signal is scaled by sqrt(rho), leading to informative singular vectors only above a threshold; closed-form asymptotic overlaps are derived and validated by simulations and semi-synthetic data.
AI.motivation: To understand how independent entry-wise missingness in both views affects PLS-SVD in high-dimensional multimodal data, and to provide precise phase-transition and alignment characterizations that guide practice.
AI.method: Model the masked cross-covariance as a spiked rectangular random matrix after normalization. Analyze the asymptotic behavior in a proportional high-dimensional regime (dimensions grow with sample size). Derive the BBP-type phase transition and closed-form overlap formulas for the leading singular vectors. Validate via simulations and semi-synthetic experiments across aspect ratios, signal strengths, and missingness levels.
AI.result: A sharp BBP-type phase transition is established: below a critical SNR the leading singular vectors are asymptotically uninformative; above it they align nontrivially with the latent shared directions. The effective signal strength is attenuated by sqrt(rho), where rho is the joint probability of retaining an entry. The authors provide closed-form formulas for asymptotic overlaps and corroborate these findings with simulations and semi-synthetic experiments.
AI.conclusion: The study provides a rigorous characterization of PLS-SVD performance under MCAR missingness in high dimensions, linking missingness, aspect ratio, and signal strength to a quantifiable phase transition and predictable overlap behavior. This informs when PLS-SVD can recover shared structure and how missing data reduce effective signal.

title: Meta Context Engineering via Agentic Skill Evolution
summary: The operational efficacy of large language models relies heavily on their inference-time context. This has established Context Engineering (CE) as a formal discipline for optimizing these inputs. Current CE methods rely on manually crafted harnesses, such as rigid generation-reflection workflows and predefined context schemas. They impose structural biases and restrict context optimization to a narrow, intuition-bound design space. To address this, we introduce Meta Context Engineering (MCE), a bi-level framework that supersedes static CE heuristics by co-evolving CE skills and context artifacts. In MCE iterations, a meta-level agent refines engineering skills via agentic crossover, a deliberative search over the history of skills, their executions, and evaluations. A base-level agent executes these skills, learns from training rollouts, and optimizes context as flexible files and code. We evaluate MCE across five disparate domains under offline and online settings. MCE demonstrates consistent performance gains, achieving 5.6--53.8% relative improvement over state-of-the-art agentic CE methods (mean of 16.9%), while maintaining superior context adaptability, transferability, and efficiency in both context usage and training.

AI.tldr: Meta Context Engineering (MCE) is a bi-level framework that co-evolves CE skills and context artifacts to surpass static CE heuristics, achieving significant accuracy improvements across five domains with better adaptability and efficiency.
AI.motivation: Context engineering for large language models currently relies on manual, rigid workflows that bias context design. A dynamic, co-evolving approach is needed to optimize inputs more flexibly and transferably.
AI.method: A bi-level architecture: a meta-level agent performs agentic crossover and deliberative search over the history of CE skills, their executions, and evaluations to refine CE skills; a base-level agent executes skills, learns from rollouts, and curates context as flexible files and code, enabling adaptive context optimization. Evaluated across five domains in offline and online settings.
AI.result: MCE yields consistent improvements over state-of-the-art agentic CE methods, with 5.6% to 53.8% relative gains (mean ~16.9%), and enhanced context adaptability, transferability, and efficiency in both context usage and training.
AI.conclusion: MCE demonstrates that co-evolving CE skills and context artifacts outperforms static CE heuristics, offering robust gains across domains and settings and improving adaptability and efficiency for context-driven LLM performance.

title: Dynamic Topology Awareness: Breaking the Granularity Rigidity in Vision-Language Navigation
summary: Vision-Language Navigation in Continuous Environments (VLN-CE) presents a core challenge: grounding high-level linguistic instructions into precise, safe, and long-horizon spatial actions. Explicit topological maps have proven to be a vital solution for providing robust spatial memory in such tasks. However, existing topological planning methods suffer from a "Granularity Rigidity" problem. Specifically, these methods typically rely on fixed geometric thresholds to sample nodes, which fails to adapt to varying environmental complexities. This rigidity leads to a critical mismatch: the model tends to over-sample in simple areas, causing computational redundancy, while under-sampling in high-uncertainty regions, increasing collision risks and compromising precision. To address this, we propose DGNav, a framework for Dynamic Topological Navigation, introducing a context-aware mechanism to modulate map density and connectivity on-the-fly. Our approach comprises two core innovations: (1) A Scene-Aware Adaptive Strategy that dynamically modulates graph construction thresholds based on the dispersion of predicted waypoints, enabling "densification on demand" in challenging environments; (2) A Dynamic Graph Transformer that reconstructs graph connectivity by fusing visual, linguistic, and geometric cues into dynamic edge weights, enabling the agent to filter out topological noise and enhancing instruction adherence. Extensive experiments on the R2R-CE and RxR-CE benchmarks demonstrate DGNav exhibits superior navigation performance and strong generalization capabilities. Furthermore, ablation studies confirm that our framework achieves an optimal trade-off between navigation efficiency and safe exploration. The code is available at https://github.com/shannanshouyin/DGNav.

AI.tldr: DGNav proposes a dynamic topological navigation framework for VLN-CE to overcome granularity rigidity by dynamically adjusting map density and edge weights using scene-aware adaptive thresholds and a dynamic graph transformer; shows improved performance on R2R-CE and RxR-CE with ablations.
AI.motivation: Explicit topological maps are useful but sampling rigidity harms performance: over-sampling in easy regions and under-sampling in hard ones; need adaptive density and connectivity.
AI.method: Two components: (1) Scene-Aware Adaptive Strategy to adjust graph thresholds based on dispersion of predicted waypoints to densify on-demand; (2) Dynamic Graph Transformer to fuse visual, linguistic, geometric cues into dynamic edge weights for noise filtering and better instruction adherence.
AI.result: Empirical results on R2R-CE and RxR-CE show superior navigation performance and strong generalization; ablations indicate optimal trade-off between efficiency and safe exploration.
AI.conclusion: DGNav effectively mitigates Granularity Rigidity, providing adaptive, context-aware topological navigation with improved efficiency, safety, and instruction adherence; code released.

title: Grounding and Enhancing Informativeness and Utility in Dataset Distillation
comment: Accepted by ICLR 2026, 20 pages, 9 figures, 11 tables
summary: Dataset Distillation (DD) seeks to create a compact dataset from a large, real-world dataset. While recent methods often rely on heuristic approaches to balance efficiency and quality, the fundamental relationship between original and synthetic data remains underexplored. This paper revisits knowledge distillation-based dataset distillation within a solid theoretical framework. We introduce the concepts of Informativeness and Utility, capturing crucial information within a sample and essential samples in the training set, respectively. Building on these principles, we define optimal dataset distillation mathematically. We then present InfoUtil, a framework that balances informativeness and utility in synthesizing the distilled dataset. InfoUtil incorporates two key components: (1) game-theoretic informativeness maximization using Shapley Value attribution to extract key information from samples, and (2) principled utility maximization by selecting globally influential samples based on Gradient Norm. These components ensure that the distilled dataset is both informative and utility-optimized. Experiments demonstrate that our method achieves a 6.1\% performance improvement over the previous state-of-the-art approach on ImageNet-1K dataset using ResNet-18.

AI.tldr: InfoUtil: a principled dataset distillation framework that balances informativeness and utility, using Shapley-value-based informativeness and gradient-norm-based utility, achieving 6.1% accuracy gain over prior SOTA on ImageNet-1K with ResNet-18.
AI.motivation: The link between original data and distilled data is underexplored; a solid theoretical basis is needed to understand and optimize what makes distilled samples informative and useful for training.
AI.method: Define two principles—Informativeness and Utility—and develop InfoUtil, which uses (1) Shapley-value-based informativeness maximization to extract key information from samples, and (2) gradient-norm-based global utility maximization to select influential samples. The distilled dataset is optimized to balance these factors.
AI.result: Empirical evaluation shows a 6.1% performance improvement over the previous state-of-the-art on ImageNet-1K using ResNet-18.
AI.conclusion: A principled, theory-grounded approach to dataset distillation that balances informativeness and utility can achieve substantial performance gains on large-scale benchmarks, validating the proposed InfoUtil framework.

title: Synthetic-to-Real Domain Bridging for Single-View 3D Reconstruction of Ships for Maritime Monitoring
summary: Three-dimensional (3D) reconstruction of ships is an important part of maritime monitoring, allowing improved visualization, inspection, and decision-making in real-world monitoring environments. However, most state-ofthe-art 3D reconstruction methods require multi-view supervision, annotated 3D ground truth, or are computationally intensive, making them impractical for real-time maritime deployment. In this work, we present an efficient pipeline for single-view 3D reconstruction of real ships by training entirely on synthetic data and requiring only a single view at inference. Our approach uses the Splatter Image network, which represents objects as sparse sets of 3D Gaussians for rapid and accurate reconstruction from single images. The model is first fine-tuned on synthetic ShapeNet vessels and further refined with a diverse custom dataset of 3D ships, bridging the domain gap between synthetic and real-world imagery. We integrate a state-of-the-art segmentation module based on YOLOv8 and custom preprocessing to ensure compatibility with the reconstruction network. Postprocessing steps include real-world scaling, centering, and orientation alignment, followed by georeferenced placement on an interactive web map using AIS metadata and homography-based mapping. Quantitative evaluation on synthetic validation data demonstrates strong reconstruction fidelity, while qualitative results on real maritime images from the ShipSG dataset confirm the potential for transfer to operational maritime settings. The final system provides interactive 3D inspection of real ships without requiring real-world 3D annotations. This pipeline provides an efficient, scalable solution for maritime monitoring and highlights a path toward real-time 3D ship visualization in practical applications. Interactive demo: https://dlr-mi.github.io/ship3d-demo/.

AI.tldr: Efficient single-view 3D ship reconstruction from synthetic data using Splatter Image network, with YOLOv8 segmentation, synthetic-to-real domain bridging, and georeferenced placement on web maps; demonstrated fidelity on synthetic data and qualitative transfer to real ShipSG images, enabling interactive 3D ship inspection without real 3D annotations.
AI.motivation: Enable real-time 3D visualization of ships from a single image without requiring multi-view data or ground-truth 3D annotations, addressing practical maritime monitoring where data is scarce and annotations costly.
AI.method: Train Splatter Image network to represent objects as sparse 3D Gaussians for rapid single-view reconstruction. Fine-tune on synthetic ShapeNet vessels, then refine with a diverse custom 3D ship dataset to bridge the synthetic-real domain gap. Integrate YOLOv8-based segmentation with custom preprocessing. Apply postprocessing: scaling to real-world units, centering, orientation alignment, and georeferenced placement on an interactive web map using AIS metadata and homography-based mapping.
AI.result: Quantitative evaluation on synthetic validation data shows strong reconstruction fidelity. Qualitative results on real maritime images from the ShipSG dataset indicate potential for real-world transfer. An interactive demo is provided, demonstrating practical applicability.
AI.conclusion: The proposed pipeline delivers an efficient, scalable solution for single-view 3D ship visualization and inspection, enabling near real-time deployment in maritime monitoring without requiring real-world 3D annotations.

title: Achieving $\varepsilon^{-2}$ Dependence for Average-Reward Q-Learning with a New Contraction Principle
summary: We present the convergence rates of synchronous and asynchronous Q-learning for average-reward Markov decision processes, where the absence of contraction poses a fundamental challenge. Existing non-asymptotic results overcome this challenge by either imposing strong assumptions to enforce seminorm contraction or relying on discounted or episodic Markov decision processes as successive approximations, which either require unknown parameters or result in suboptimal sample complexity. In this work, under a reachability assumption, we establish optimal $\widetilde{O}(\varepsilon^{-2})$ sample complexity guarantees (up to logarithmic factors) for a simple variant of synchronous and asynchronous Q-learning that samples from the lazified dynamics, where the system remains in the current state with some fixed probability. At the core of our analysis is the construction of an instance-dependent seminorm and showing that, after a lazy transformation of the Markov decision process, the Bellman operator becomes one-step contractive under this seminorm.

AI.tldr: Shows that synchronous/asynchronous Q-learning for average-reward MDPs attains near-optimal sample complexity by using a lazy dynamics transformation and an instance-dependent seminorm to induce contraction in the Bellman operator.
AI.motivation: Average-reward MDPs lack contraction, making non-asymptotic analysis difficult. Prior work relies on strong assumptions or discounted/episodic reductions, which are parameter-dependent or suboptimal. The goal is near-optimal, parameter-free sample complexity guarantees without needing contraction in the original MDP.
AI.method: Introduce lazy dynamics where the process stays in the current state with fixed probability. Analyze a simple variant of synchronous/asynchronous Q-learning under a reachability assumption. Construct an instance-dependent seminorm under which the Bellman operator becomes one-step contractive after the lazy transformation, enabling standard convergence analysis.
AI.result: achieves optimal ø(ε^{-2}) sample complexity (up to logarithmic factors) for the proposed Q-learning variants under lazy dynamics and reachability.
AI.conclusion: The combination of an instance-dependent seminorm and a lazy state-transition transformation yields a contractive Bellman operator and non-asymptotic, near-optimal learning guarantees for average-reward MDP Q-learning without requiring external contraction conditions or discounted/episodic reductions.

title: Chain Of Thought Compression: A Theoritical Analysis
summary: Chain-of-Thought (CoT) has unlocked advanced reasoning abilities of Large Language Models (LLMs) with intermediate steps, yet incurs prohibitive computational costs due to generation of extra tokens. Recent studies empirically show that compressing reasoning steps into latent states, or implicit CoT compression, offers a token-efficient alternative. However, the mechanism behind CoT compression remains unclear. In this paper, we provide the first theoretical analysis of the difficulty of learning to internalize intermediate reasoning steps. By introducing Order-r Interaction, we prove that the learning signal for high-order logical dependencies exponentially decays to solve irreducible problem, where skipping intermediate steps inevitably leads to high-order interaction barriers. To empirically validate this, we introduce NatBool-DAG, a challenging benchmark designed to enforce irreducible logical reasoning and eliminate semantic shortcuts. Guided by our theoretical findings, we propose ALiCoT (Aligned Implicit CoT), a novel framework that overcomes the signal decay by aligning latent token distributions with intermediate reasoning states. Experimental results demonstrate that ALiCoT successfully unlocks efficient reasoning: it achieves a 54.4x speedup while maintaining performance comparable to explicit CoT.

AI.tldr: The paper provides a theoretical and empirical study of latent CoT compression, introducing Order-r Interaction and NatBool-DAG, and presenting ALiCoT, which achieves significant speedups while preserving explicit CoT performance.
AI.motivation: Chain-of-Thought offers improved reasoning but at high token cost; latent, implicit CoT compression promises efficiency, yet its theoretical foundations are unclear. The work aims to understand learning difficulty in internalizing intermediate steps and to develop a practical, efficient implicit reasoning framework.
AI.method: Develop Order-r Interaction to analyze how learning signals for high-order logical dependencies decay; prove an exponential decay leading to irreducible problems. Create NatBool-DAG benchmark to enforce irreducible reasoning and rule out semantic shortcuts. Propose ALiCoT (Aligned Implicit CoT) that aligns latent token distributions with intermediate reasoning states to mitigate signal decay.
AI.result: The authors provide theoretical proofs of signal decay barriers for high-order reasoning in implicit CoT. NatBool-DAG validates irreducible reasoning scenarios. Empirically, ALiCoT achieves about 54.4x speedup while maintaining performance comparable to explicit CoT.
AI.conclusion: ALiCoT effectively overcomes signal decay in implicit CoT, enabling efficient yet accurate reasoning. The work offers both a theoretical lens on CoT compression and a practical framework for scalable, token-efficient reasoning.

title: CG-MLLM: Captioning and Generating 3D content via Multi-modal Large Language Models
summary: Large Language Models(LLMs) have revolutionized text generation and multimodal perception, but their capabilities in 3D content generation remain underexplored. Existing methods compromise by producing either low-resolution meshes or coarse structural proxies, failing to capture fine-grained geometry natively. In this paper, we propose CG-MLLM, a novel Multi-modal Large Language Model (MLLM) capable of 3D captioning and high-resolution 3D generation in a single framework. Leveraging the Mixture-of-Transformer architecture, CG-MLLM decouples disparate modeling needs, where the Token-level Autoregressive (TokenAR) Transformer handles token-level content, and the Block-level Autoregressive (BlockAR) Transformer handles block-level content. By integrating a pre-trained vision-language backbone with a specialized 3D VAE latent space, CG-MLLM facilitates long-context interactions between standard tokens and spatial blocks within a single integrated architecture. Experimental results show that CG-MLLM significantly outperforms existing MLLMs in generating high-fidelity 3D objects, effectively bringing high-resolution 3D content creation into the mainstream LLM paradigm.

AI.tldr: CG-MLLM is a multi-modal LLM capable of 3D captioning and high-resolution 3D generation within a single framework, employing a Mixture-of-Transformer with TokenAR and BlockAR and a 3D VAE latent space integrated with a vision-language backbone; it outperforms prior MLLMs in 3D quality.
AI.motivation: 3D content generation capabilities of LLMs are underexplored and existing methods produce either low-resolution meshes or coarse proxies. A unified model that can caption and generate high-fidelity 3D content in one framework is needed.
AI.method: CG-MLLM uses a Mixture-of-Transformer architecture: a Token-level Autoregressive (TokenAR) Transformer handles token-level content, and a Block-level Autoregressive (BlockAR) Transformer handles block-level content. It integrates a pre-trained vision-language backbone with a specialized 3D VAE latent space to enable long-context interactions between standard tokens and spatial blocks within a single architecture.
AI.result: Experimental results show CG-MLLM significantly outperforms existing MLLMs in generating high-fidelity 3D objects, demonstrating high-resolution 3D content generation within the LLM paradigm.
AI.conclusion: This work brings high-resolution 3D content creation into the mainstream LLM paradigm via a single, integrated CG-MLLM framework that supports 3D captioning and high-quality 3D generation.

title: The Surprising Difficulty of Search in Model-Based Reinforcement Learning
summary: This paper investigates search in model-based reinforcement learning (RL). Conventional wisdom holds that long-term predictions and compounding errors are the primary obstacles for model-based RL. We challenge this view, showing that search is not a plug-and-play replacement for a learned policy. Surprisingly, we find that search can harm performance even when the model is highly accurate. Instead, we show that mitigating distribution shift matters more than improving model or value function accuracy. Building on this insight, we identify key techniques for enabling effective search, achieving state-of-the-art performance across multiple popular benchmark domains.

AI.tldr: Search in model-based RL is not a plug-and-play fix for learned policies; search can hurt even with accurate models. The main benefit comes from mitigating distribution shift rather than improving model or value-function accuracy, leading to state-of-the-art results with appropriate techniques.
AI.motivation: Reevaluate the claimed bottlenecks in model-based RL and isolate the actual cause of performance gaps when using search, arguing that distribution shift is more critical than model or value function errors.
AI.method: Empirical analysis across multiple benchmark domains to compare search-based planning against learned policies, with ablations to separate effects of model accuracy, value estimation, and distribution shift. Identification of techniques that mitigate distribution shift to enable effective search.
AI.result: Findings show that search can degrade performance even with highly accurate models; addressing distribution shift yields the primary performance gains, enabling state-of-the-art results.
AI.conclusion: Prioritize mechanisms that reduce distributional shift during search over solely improving model or value accuracy; with proper techniques, search can achieve leading performance in standard benchmarks.

title: Depth-Recurrent Attention Mixtures: Giving Latent Reasoning the Attention it Deserves
summary: Depth-recurrence facilitates latent reasoning by sharing parameters across depths. However, prior work lacks combined FLOP-, parameter-, and memory-matched baselines, underutilizes depth-recurrence due to partially fixed layer stacks, and ignores the bottleneck of constant hidden-sizes that restricts many-step latent reasoning. To address this, we introduce a modular framework of depth-recurrent attention mixtures (Dreamer), combining sequence attention, depth attention, and sparse expert attention. It alleviates the hidden-size bottleneck through attention along depth, decouples scaling dimensions, and allows depth-recurrent models to scale efficiently and effectively. Across language reasoning benchmarks, our models require 2 to 8x fewer training tokens for the same accuracy as FLOP-, parameter-, and memory-matched SOTA, and outperform ca. 2x larger SOTA models with the same training tokens. We further present insights into knowledge usage across depths, e.g., showing 2 to 11x larger expert selection diversity than SOTA MoEs.

AI.tldr: Dreamer is a modular depth-recurrent attention framework that uses depth attention and sparse experts to overcome the hidden-size bottleneck, achieving strong data efficiency and surpassing state-of-the-art baselines with fewer training tokens while maintaining or exceeding accuracy.
AI.motivation: Prior work lacks FLOP-/parameter-/memory-matched baselines, underutilizes depth-recurrence due to fixed layer stacks, and is constrained by constant hidden sizes that limit long-horizon latent reasoning; a modular framework is needed to scale depth recurrence efficiently.
AI.method: Introduce Dreamer, a modular framework combining sequence attention, depth attention, and sparse expert attention. Depth attention decouples scaling across depth to mitigate the hidden-size bottleneck and enables depth-recurrent computation. The framework allows flexible depth recurrence and scalable attention mixtures.
AI.result: Across language reasoning benchmarks, Dreamer requires 2–8x fewer training tokens to achieve the same accuracy as FLOP-/parameter-/memory-matched SOTA methods, and can outperform roughly 2x larger SOTA models using the same tokens. It also reveals 2–11x larger expert-selection diversity than SOTA Mixture-of-Experts methods across depths.
AI.conclusion: Depth-recurrent attention mixtures (Dreamer) enable scalable, resource-efficient latent reasoning by decoupling depth and scaling dimensions, improving data efficiency and knowledge usage across depths, and providing a practical framework for efficient deep reasoning models.

title: MMFineReason: Closing the Multimodal Reasoning Gap via Open Data-Centric Methods
summary: Recent advances in Vision Language Models (VLMs) have driven significant progress in visual reasoning. However, open-source VLMs still lag behind proprietary systems, largely due to the lack of high-quality reasoning data. Existing datasets offer limited coverage of challenging domains such as STEM diagrams and visual puzzles, and lack consistent, long-form Chain-of-Thought (CoT) annotations essential for eliciting strong reasoning capabilities. To bridge this gap, we introduce MMFineReason, a large-scale multimodal reasoning dataset comprising 1.8M samples and 5.1B solution tokens, featuring high-quality reasoning annotations distilled from Qwen3-VL-235B-A22B-Thinking. The dataset is established via a systematic three-stage pipeline: (1) large-scale data collection and standardization, (2) CoT rationale generation, and (3) comprehensive selection based on reasoning quality and difficulty awareness. The resulting dataset spans STEM problems, visual puzzles, games, and complex diagrams, with each sample annotated with visually grounded reasoning traces. We fine-tune Qwen3-VL-Instruct on MMFineReason to develop MMFineReason-2B/4B/8B versions. Our models establish new state-of-the-art results for their size class. Notably, MMFineReason-4B succesfully surpasses Qwen3-VL-8B-Thinking, and MMFineReason-8B even outperforms Qwen3-VL-30B-A3B-Thinking while approaching Qwen3-VL-32B-Thinking, demonstrating remarkable parameter efficiency. Crucially, we uncover a "less is more" phenomenon via our difficulty-aware filtering strategy: a subset of just 7\% (123K samples) achieves performance comparable to the full dataset. Notably, we reveal a synergistic effect where reasoning-oriented data composition simultaneously boosts general capabilities.

AI.tldr: MMFineReason is a large-scale multimodal reasoning dataset (1.8M samples, 5.1B solution tokens) built via a three-stage pipeline to provide high-quality, visually grounded CoT annotations; fine-tuned models achieve state-of-the-art results for their size, with a surprising 'less is more' subset effect; dataset spans STEM, visual puzzles, games, and diagrams and fosters synergy between reasoning data and general capabilities.
AI.motivation: Fill the gap in open-source VLMs by providing high-quality, long-form Chain-of-Thought data and broad domain coverage (STEM diagrams, visual puzzles) to improve reasoning capabilities and parameter efficiency.
AI.method: Three-stage pipeline: (1) large-scale data collection and standardization, (2) CoT rationale generation, (3) quality/difficulty-aware selection; dataset annotated with visually grounded reasoning traces; fine-tuned Qwen3-VL-Instruct on MMFineReason to produce MMFineReason-2B/4B/8B; evaluation against baselines demonstrates efficiency gains.
AI.result: Achieves new state-of-the-art results for its size class; MMFineReason-4B surpasses Qwen3-VL-8B-Thinking; MMFineReason-8B outperforms Qwen3-VL-30B-A3B-Thinking and nears Qwen3-VL-32B-Thinking; a subset of 7% (123K samples) matches full-dataset performance; reasoning-focused data composition also enhances general capabilities.
AI.conclusion: The work demonstrates parameter-efficient improvements via high-quality CoT data and difficulty-aware filtering, with cross-domain benefits; supports the viability of large-scale open-source VLMs trained with principled reasoning data.

title: Transferable Graph Condensation from the Causal Perspective
summary: The increasing scale of graph datasets has significantly improved the performance of graph representation learning methods, but it has also introduced substantial training challenges. Graph dataset condensation techniques have emerged to compress large datasets into smaller yet information-rich datasets, while maintaining similar test performance. However, these methods strictly require downstream applications to match the original dataset and task, which often fails in cross-task and cross-domain scenarios. To address these challenges, we propose a novel causal-invariance-based and transferable graph dataset condensation method, named \textbf{TGCC}, providing effective and transferable condensed datasets. Specifically, to preserve domain-invariant knowledge, we first extract domain causal-invariant features from the spatial domain of the graph using causal interventions. Then, to fully capture the structural and feature information of the original graph, we perform enhanced condensation operations. Finally, through spectral-domain enhanced contrastive learning, we inject the causal-invariant features into the condensed graph, ensuring that the compressed graph retains the causal information of the original graph. Experimental results on five public datasets and our novel \textbf{FinReport} dataset demonstrate that TGCC achieves up to a 13.41\% improvement in cross-task and cross-domain complex scenarios compared to existing methods, and achieves state-of-the-art performance on 5 out of 6 datasets in the single dataset and task scenario.

AI.tldr: Proposes TGCC, a causal-invariance-based transferable graph dataset condensation method that achieves significant cross-task/domain improvements and strong single-task performance by extracting domain-invariant causal features, enhanced condensation, and spectral contrastive learning.
AI.motivation: Current graph dataset condensation methods struggle in cross-task and cross-domain settings and often require task-specific compatibility, limiting practical transferability of condensed datasets.
AI.method: A three-stage pipeline: (1) extract domain-invariant causal features from the graph spatial domain via causal interventions; (2) perform enhanced condensation to preserve both structural and feature information; (3) apply spectral-domain enhanced contrastive learning to inject the causal-invariant features into the condensed graph, maintaining original causal information.
AI.result: Empirical validation on five public datasets and a novel FinReport dataset shows TGCC achieves up to 13.41% improvement in cross-task/cross-domain scenarios and attains state-of-the-art performance on 5 of 6 datasets in single-task/single-dataset settings.
AI.conclusion: TGCC delivers effective and transferable graph dataset condensation by preserving causal information, enabling cross-task and cross-domain applicability without sacrificing single-task performance.

title: Beyond Imitation: Reinforcement Learning for Active Latent Planning
summary: Aiming at efficient and dense chain-of-thought (CoT) reasoning, latent reasoning methods fine-tune Large Language Models (LLMs) to substitute discrete language tokens with continuous latent tokens. These methods consume fewer tokens compared to the conventional language CoT reasoning and have the potential to plan in a dense latent space. However, current latent tokens are generally supervised based on imitating language labels. Considering that there can be multiple equivalent but diverse CoT labels for a question, passively imitating an arbitrary one may lead to inferior latent token representations and latent reasoning policies, undermining the potential planning ability and resulting in clear gaps between training and testing. In this work, we emphasize the importance of active planning over the representation space of latent tokens in achieving the optimal latent reasoning policy. So, we propose the \underline{A}c\underline{t}ive Latent \underline{P}lanning method (ATP-Latent), which models the supervision process of latent tokens as a conditional variational auto-encoder (VAE) to obtain a smoother latent space. Moreover, to facilitate the most reasonable latent reasoning policy, ATP-Latent conducts reinforcement learning (RL) with an auxiliary coherence reward, which is calculated based on the consistency between VAE-decoded contents of latent tokens, enabling a guided RL process. In experiments on LLaMA-1B, ATP-Latent demonstrates +4.1\% accuracy and -3.3\% tokens on four benchmarks compared to advanced baselines. Codes are available on https://github.com/zz1358m/ATP-Latent-master.

AI.tldr: ATP-Latent introduces Active Latent Planning to improve dense latent CoT reasoning by modeling latent token supervision with a conditional VAE and guiding RL with a coherence-based auxiliary reward; it achieves higher accuracy and fewer tokens on LLaMA-1B across four benchmarks and releases code.
AI.motivation: Latent CoT methods traditionally imitate linguistic labels, but multiple equivalent CoT labels exist; passive imitation can yield suboptimal latent representations and misaligned policies between training and inference. Active planning over latent representations is needed to learn better latent reasoning policies.
AI.method: Model supervision of latent tokens via a conditional variational auto-encoder (VAE) to create a smoother latent space. Use reinforcement learning to optimize latent reasoning policies with an auxiliary coherence reward that measures consistency between VAE-decoded contents of latent tokens, guiding policy updates.
AI.result: On LLaMA-1B, ATP-Latent yields +4.1% accuracy and -3.3% tokens across four benchmarks compared to strong baselines; code available at the provided GitHub link.
AI.conclusion: Active latent planning via a VAE-conditioned supervision and coherence-guided RL improves latent reasoning quality and efficiency, addressing the non-uniqueness of CoT labels and promoting more effective latent token policies.

title: Trajectory-Guided Diffusion for Foreground-Preserving Background Generation in Multi-Layer Documents
summary: We present a diffusion-based framework for document-centric background generation that achieves foreground preservation and multi-page stylistic consistency through latent-space design rather than explicit constraints. Instead of suppressing diffusion updates or applying masking heuristics, our approach reinterprets diffusion as the evolution of stochastic trajectories through a structured latent space. By shaping the initial noise and its geometric alignment, background generation naturally avoids designated foreground regions, allowing readable content to remain intact without auxiliary mechanisms. To address the long-standing issue of stylistic drift across pages, we decouple style control from text conditioning and introduce cached style directions as persistent vectors in latent space. Once selected, these directions constrain diffusion trajectories to a shared stylistic subspace, ensuring consistent appearance across pages and editing iterations. This formulation eliminates the need for repeated prompt-based style specification and provides a more stable foundation for multi-page generation. Our framework admits a geometric and physical interpretation, where diffusion paths evolve on a latent manifold shaped by preferred directions, and foreground regions are rarely traversed as a consequence of trajectory initialization rather than explicit exclusion. The proposed method is training-free, compatible with existing diffusion backbones, and produces visually coherent, foreground-preserving results across complex documents. By reframing diffusion as trajectory design in latent space, we offer a principled approach to consistent and structured generative modeling.

AI.tldr: A training-free diffusion framework for document background generation that preserves foregrounds and ensures multi-page stylistic consistency by redesigning diffusion as latent-space trajectory planning, using initial noise shaping and cached style directions; avoids explicit masking or retraining.
AI.motivation: Address foreground preservation and cross-page style drift in diffusion-based document generation without additional training or masking heuristics, ensuring readability and consistent appearance across pages.
AI.method: Reinterpret diffusion as evolution of stochastic trajectories on a structured latent manifold. Shape initial noise and its geometry so diffusion updates rarely traverse foreground regions, enabling natural background generation without masking. Introduce cached style directions as persistent latent vectors that constrain trajectories to a shared stylistic subspace, decoupling style from text conditioning. Training-free and compatible with existing diffusion backbones; provides a geometric interpretation of diffusion paths.
AI.result: Produces visually coherent, foreground-preserving backgrounds across complex documents with consistent style across pages and edits, without repeated prompt-based style specification.
AI.conclusion: Frames diffusion as trajectory design in latent space, offering a principled, training-free approach to stable, multi-page document generation with foreground preservation and cross-page stylistic consistency; compatible with existing diffusion architectures.

title: Few-Shot Learning for Dynamic Operations of Automated Electric Taxi Fleets under Evolving Charging Infrastructure: A Meta-Deep Reinforcement Learning Approach
summary: With the rapid expansion of electric vehicles (EVs) and charging infrastructure, the effective management of Autonomous Electric Taxi (AET) fleets faces a critical challenge in environments with dynamic and uncertain charging availability. While most existing research assumes a static charging network, this simplification creates a significant gap between theoretical models and real-world operations. To bridge this gap, we propose GAT-PEARL, a novel meta-reinforcement learning framework that learns an adaptive operational policy. Our approach integrates a graph attention network (GAT) to effectively extract robust spatial representations under infrastructure layouts and model the complex spatiotemporal relationships of the urban environment, and employs probabilistic embeddings for actor-critic reinforcement learning (PEARL) to enable rapid, inference-based adaptation to changes in charging network layouts without retraining. Through extensive simulations on real-world data in Chengdu, China, we demonstrate that GAT-PEARL significantly outperforms conventional reinforcement learning baselines, showing superior generalization to unseen infrastructure layouts and achieving higher overall operational efficiency in dynamic settings.

AI.tldr: A meta-reinforcement learning framework (GAT-PEARL) combines graph attention networks with probabilistic embeddings for rapid adaptation, addressing dynamic charging network layout in autonomous electric taxi fleets and showing improved generalization and efficiency over standard RL baselines in Chengdu data.
AI.motivation: Existing RL for autonomous taxi fleets often assumes static charging networks, which mismatches real-world operations where charging availability is dynamic and uncertain; robust adaptation to changing infrastructure is needed.
AI.method: Integrates a graph attention network (GAT) to capture robust spatial representations from infrastructure layouts and spatiotemporal patterns, with PEARL (probabilistic embeddings for actor-critic RL) to enable rapid, inference-based adaptation to unseen charging network layouts without retraining; evaluated via simulations using real Chengdu data.
AI.result: GAT-PEARL outperforms conventional RL baselines, generalizes to unseen infrastructure layouts, and improves overall operational efficiency in dynamic charging environments.
AI.conclusion: GAT-PEARL provides a scalable, adaptive policy for AET fleet management amidst dynamic charging networks, leveraging graph-based spatial representations and meta-RL adaptation to improve performance without retraining.

title: Improving Classifier-Free Guidance of Flow Matching via Manifold Projection
summary: Classifier-free guidance (CFG) is a widely used technique for controllable generation in diffusion and flow-based models. Despite its empirical success, CFG relies on a heuristic linear extrapolation that is often sensitive to the guidance scale. In this work, we provide a principled interpretation of CFG through the lens of optimization. We demonstrate that the velocity field in flow matching corresponds to the gradient of a sequence of smoothed distance functions, which guides latent variables toward the scaled target image set. This perspective reveals that the standard CFG formulation is an approximation of this gradient, where the prediction gap, the discrepancy between conditional and unconditional outputs, governs guidance sensitivity. Leveraging this insight, we reformulate the CFG sampling as a homotopy optimization with a manifold constraint. This formulation necessitates a manifold projection step, which we implement via an incremental gradient descent scheme during sampling. To improve computational efficiency and stability, we further enhance this iterative process with Anderson Acceleration without requiring additional model evaluations. Our proposed methods are training-free and consistently refine generation fidelity, prompt alignment, and robustness to the guidance scale. We validate their effectiveness across diverse benchmarks, demonstrating significant improvements on large-scale models such as DiT-XL-2-256, Flux, and Stable Diffusion 3.5.

AI.tldr: Classifier-free guidance (CFG) is reinterpreted as a gradient-based optimization on smoothed distance functions, reframing sampling as a homotopy problem with a manifold constraint and an incremental gradient projection augmented by Anderson Acceleration. The approach is training-free and yields consistent gains in fidelity, prompt alignment, and robustness across large models.
AI.motivation: CFG is widely used but relies on a heuristic linear extrapolation and is sensitive to the guidance scale. A principled, optimization-based understanding and a training-free refinement method are desirable to improve stability and efficiency.
AI.method: Interpret the flow-matching velocity as the gradient of a sequence of smoothed distance functions, showing CFG as a gradient approximation governed by the prediction gap between conditional and unconditional outputs. Reformulate sampling as a homotopy optimization with a manifold constraint, requiring a projection step implemented via incremental gradient descent during sampling. Enhance this iterative scheme with Anderson Acceleration to improve convergence without extra model evaluations. The approach is training-free.
AI.result: The proposed method yields consistent improvements in generation fidelity, prompt alignment, and robustness to guidance scale across diverse benchmarks, including large-scale models such as DiT-XL-2-256, Flux, and Stable Diffusion 3.5.
AI.conclusion: A principled, efficient, and training-free CFG refinement framework that stabilizes guidance-driven generation and enhances performance on large diffusion models.

title: Distributionally Robust Classification for Multi-source Unsupervised Domain Adaptation
summary: Unsupervised domain adaptation (UDA) is a statistical learning problem when the distribution of training (source) data is different from that of test (target) data. In this setting, one has access to labeled data only from the source domain and unlabeled data from the target domain. The central objective is to leverage the source data and the unlabeled target data to build models that generalize to the target domain. Despite its potential, existing UDA approaches often struggle in practice, particularly in scenarios where the target domain offers only limited unlabeled data or spurious correlations dominate the source domain. To address these challenges, we propose a novel distributionally robust learning framework that models uncertainty in both the covariate distribution and the conditional label distribution. Our approach is motivated by the multi-source domain adaptation setting but is also directly applicable to the single-source scenario, making it versatile in practice. We develop an efficient learning algorithm that can be seamlessly integrated with existing UDA methods. Extensive experiments under various distribution shift scenarios show that our method consistently outperforms strong baselines, especially when target data are extremely scarce.

AI.tldr: Proposes a distributionally robust learning framework for unsupervised domain adaptation (UDA) that accounts for uncertainty in both covariate and conditional label distributions, applicable to single- and multi-source settings, with an efficient algorithm and strong empirical gains when target data are scarce.
AI.motivation: UDA models often fail under distribution shifts, especially when target unlabeled data are limited or when spurious source correlations mislead learning. A robust framework that hedges against uncertainty in both input and label distributions can improve generalization to the target domain.
AI.method: Develops a distributionally robust learning framework inspired by multi-source domain adaptation. It models uncertainty in covariate distributions and conditional label distributions, provides an efficient learning algorithm that can be integrated with existing UDA methods, and is applicable to both multi-source and single-source scenarios.
AI.result: Extensive experiments across various distribution shift scenarios show the proposed method consistently outperforms strong baselines, with larger gains when target data are extremely scarce.
AI.conclusion: The work delivers a robust, versatile approach to UDA that remains effective under limited target data and distribution shifts, and can be plugged into existing UDA pipelines to enhance performance.

title: Search-Based Risk Feature Discovery in Document Structure Spaces under a Constrained Budget
summary: Enterprise-grade Intelligent Document Processing (IDP) systems support high-stakes workflows across finance, insurance, and healthcare. Early-phase system validation under limited budgets mandates uncovering diverse failure mechanisms, rather than identifying a single worst-case document. We formalize this challenge as a Search-Based Software Testing (SBST) problem, aiming to identify complex interactions between document variables, with the objective to maximize the number of distinct failure types discovered within a fixed evaluation budget. Our methodology operates on a combinatorial space of document configurations, rendering instances of structural \emph{risk features} to induce realistic failure conditions. We benchmark a diverse portfolio of search strategies spanning evolutionary, swarm-based, quality-diversity, learning-based, and quantum under identical budget constraints. Through configuration-level exclusivity, win-rate, and cross-temporal overlap analyses, we show that different solvers consistently uncover failure modes that remain undiscovered by specific alternatives at comparable budgets. Crucially, cross-temporal analysis reveals persistent solver-specific discoveries across all evaluated budgets, with no single strategy exhibiting absolute dominance. While the union of all solvers eventually recovers the observed failure space, reliance on any individual method systematically delays the discovery of important risks. These results demonstrate intrinsic solver complementarity and motivate portfolio-based SBST strategies for robust industrial IDP validation.

AI.tldr: Formulates IDP validation as SBST to maximize diverse failures under budget; reveals solver complementarity across diverse search strategies and advocates portfolio SBST for robust validation.
AI.motivation: Industrial IDP systems need early validation under limited budgets to uncover diverse failure modes, not just a single worst-case case.
AI.method: Model document configurations as combinatorial space with risk features; evaluate under fixed budget; benchmark diverse search strategies (evolutionary, swarm-based, quality-diversity, learning-based, quantum); analyze exclusivity, win-rate, and cross-temporal overlap.
AI.result: Different solvers uncover distinct failure modes; no single method dominates; cross-temporal persistence of solver-specific discoveries; the union of all solvers recovers the observed failure space but reliance on any single method delays risk discovery.
AI.conclusion: Intrinsic solver complementarity motivates portfolio-based SBST for robust industrial IDP validation.

title: Past- and Future-Informed KV Cache Policy with Salience Estimation in Autoregressive Video Diffusion
summary: Video generation is pivotal to digital media creation, and recent advances in autoregressive video generation have markedly enhanced the efficiency of real-time video synthesis. However, existing approaches generally rely on heuristic KV Cache policies, which ignore differences in token importance in long-term video generation. This leads to the loss of critical spatiotemporal information and the accumulation of redundant, invalid cache, thereby degrading video generation quality and efficiency. To address this limitation, we first observe that token contributions to video generation are highly time-heterogeneous and accordingly propose a novel Past- and Future-Informed KV Cache Policy (PaFu-KV). Specifically, PaFu-KV introduces a lightweight Salience Estimation Head distilled from a bidirectional teacher to estimate salience scores, allowing the KV cache to retain informative tokens while discarding less relevant ones. This policy yields a better quality-efficiency trade-off by shrinking KV cache capacity and reducing memory footprint at inference time. Extensive experiments on benchmarks demonstrate that our method preserves high-fidelity video generation quality while enables accelerated inference, thereby enabling more efficient long-horizon video generation. Our code will be released upon paper acceptance.

AI.tldr: PaFu-KV is a time-aware KV cache policy for autoregressive video generation that uses a Salience Estimation Head (from a bidirectional teacher) to retain informative tokens and discard less relevant ones, improving the quality-efficiency trade-off for long-horizon video generation.
AI.motivation: Long-horizon autoregressive video generation suffers from inefficient KV caching when using heuristic retention policies; token importance is time-heterogeneous, causing loss of spatiotemporal information and accumulation of redundant/invalid cache.
AI.method: Introduce Past- and Future-Informed KV Cache Policy (PaFu-KV) with a lightweight Salience Estimation Head distilled from a bidirectional teacher to estimate token salience and selectively retain informative KV entries while discarding less relevant ones, reducing memory footprint during inference.
AI.result: Experiments on benchmarks show maintained high-fidelity video quality with accelerated inference; PaFu-KV achieves a better quality-efficiency trade-off and enables efficient long-horizon video generation.
AI.conclusion: Code release is planned upon acceptance; the approach yields efficient, high-quality long-horizon video generation through salience-guided KV caching.

title: Heterogeneous Vertiport Selection Optimization for On-Demand Air Taxi Services: A Deep Reinforcement Learning Approach
summary: Urban Air Mobility (UAM) has emerged as a transformative solution to alleviate urban congestion by utilizing low-altitude airspace, thereby reducing pressure on ground transportation networks. To enable truly efficient and seamless door-to-door travel experiences, UAM requires close integration with existing ground transportation infrastructure. However, current research on optimal integrated routing strategies for passengers in air-ground mobility systems remains limited, with a lack of systematic exploration.To address this gap, we first propose a unified optimization model that integrates strategy selection for both air and ground transportation. This model captures the dynamic characteristics of multimodal transport networks and incorporates real-time traffic conditions alongside passenger decision-making behavior. Building on this model, we propose a Unified Air-Ground Mobility Coordination (UAGMC) framework, which leverages deep reinforcement learning (RL) and Vehicle-to-Everything (V2X) communication to optimize vertiport selection and dynamically plan air taxi routes. Experimental results demonstrate that UAGMC achieves a 34\% reduction in average travel time compared to conventional proportional allocation methods, enhancing overall travel efficiency and providing novel insights into the integration and optimization of multimodal transportation systems. This work lays a solid foundation for advancing intelligent urban mobility solutions through the coordination of air and ground transportation modes. The related code can be found at https://github.com/Traffic-Alpha/UAGMC.

AI.tldr: Unified air-ground mobility coordination (UAGMC) using deep reinforcement learning and V2X to optimize vertiport selection and air taxi routes, achieving a 34% reduction in average travel time over proportional allocation.
AI.motivation: Addresses the gap in research on integrated, efficient door-to-door routing for multimodal air–ground mobility, considering dynamic traffic and passenger decision-making.
AI.method: Proposes a unified optimization model for strategy selection across air and ground modes. Builds the UAGMC framework that combines deep reinforcement learning (DRL) with V2X communication to optimize vertiport choice and dynamically plan air taxi routes, using real-time traffic conditions and passenger behavior.
AI.result: Empirical results show a 34% reduction in average travel time compared with conventional proportional allocation methods, improving overall travel efficiency and offering insights into multimodal coordination; code available at the provided GitHub link.
AI.conclusion: Establishes a foundational framework for intelligent urban mobility by coordinating air and ground transportation, enabling more efficient multimodal travel and guiding future research in integrated routing and control.

title: RecNet: Self-Evolving Preference Propagation for Agentic Recommender Systems
summary: Agentic recommender systems leverage Large Language Models (LLMs) to model complex user behaviors and support personalized decision-making. However, existing methods primarily model preference changes based on explicit user-item interactions, which are sparse, noisy, and unable to reflect the real-time, mutual influences among users and items. To address these limitations, we propose RecNet, a self-evolving preference propagation framework that proactively propagates real-time preference updates across related users and items. RecNet consists of two complementary phases. In the forward phase, the centralized preference routing mechanism leverages router agents to integrate preference updates and dynamically propagate them to the most relevant agents. To ensure accurate and personalized integration of propagated preferences, we further introduce a personalized preference reception mechanism, which combines a message buffer for temporary caching and an optimizable, rule-based filter memory to guide selective preference assimilation based on past experience and interests. In the backward phase, the feedback-driven propagation optimization mechanism simulates a multi-agent reinforcement learning framework, using LLMs for credit assignment, gradient analysis, and module-level optimization, enabling continuous self-evolution of propagation strategies. Extensive experiments on various scenarios demonstrate the effectiveness of RecNet in modeling preference propagation for recommender systems.

AI.tldr: Introduces RecNet, a self-evolving, real-time preference propagation framework for agentic recommender systems that uses router agents and memory modules, with a backward RL-like optimization loop to continuously evolve propagation strategies.
AI.motivation: To address sparsity, noise, and the inability of explicit-interaction models to capture real-time mutual influences among users and items.
AI.method: Two-phase design: (1) forward phase with centralized preference routing via router agents that propagate updates to relevant agents; includes a personalized preference reception module with a message buffer and a rule-based filter memory to selectively assimilate preferences based on past interactions; (2) backward phase with feedback-driven propagation optimization that simulates a multi-agent RL framework, employing LLMs for credit assignment, gradient analysis, and module-level optimization to continuously evolve propagation strategies.
AI.result: Extensive experiments across diverse scenarios show that RecNet effectively models and propagates dynamic preferences, improving propagation quality and downstream recommendation performance relative to baselines.
AI.conclusion: RecNet provides a scalable, adaptive framework for agentic recommender systems, enabling real-time preference propagation and self-evolution of propagation strategies through a forward-backward, LLM-assisted multi-agent architecture.

title: TraceRouter: Robust Safety for Large Foundation Models via Path-Level Intervention
summary: Despite their capabilities, large foundation models (LFMs) remain susceptible to adversarial manipulation. Current defenses predominantly rely on the "locality hypothesis", suppressing isolated neurons or features. However, harmful semantics act as distributed, cross-layer circuits, rendering such localized interventions brittle and detrimental to utility. To bridge this gap, we propose \textbf{TraceRouter}, a path-level framework that traces and disconnects the causal propagation circuits of illicit semantics. TraceRouter operates in three stages: (1) it pinpoints a sensitive onset layer by analyzing attention divergence; (2) it leverages sparse autoencoders (SAEs) and differential activation analysis to disentangle and isolate malicious features; and (3) it maps these features to downstream causal pathways via feature influence scores (FIS) derived from zero-out interventions. By selectively suppressing these causal chains, TraceRouter physically severs the flow of harmful information while leaving orthogonal computation routes intact. Extensive experiments demonstrate that TraceRouter significantly outperforms state-of-the-art baselines, achieving a superior trade-off between adversarial robustness and general utility. Our code will be publicly released. WARNING: This paper contains unsafe model responses.

AI.tldr: TraceRouter introduces a path-level defense for large foundation models to trace and sever causal propagation circuits of illicit semantics. It identifies a sensitive onset layer via attention divergence, disentangles/masks malicious features with sparse autoencoders and differential activation, and maps features to downstream causal pathways using feature influence scores from zero-out interventions, aiming to suppress harmful information while preserving orthogonal computation. Claims superior robustness-utility trade-offs and will release code; notes unsafe model responses in the paper.
AI.motivation: Current defenses focus on local, brittle interventions (locality hypothesis) like pruning isolated neurons. However, harmful semantics are distributed across layers and cross-cut causal circuits, making local defenses insufficient and potentially utility-damaging. A path-level approach promises more precise disruption of harmful information flow.
AI.method: Three-stage approach: (1) onset-layer identification through analysis of attention divergence to locate where harmful semantics begin; (2) use of sparse autoencoders and differential activation analysis to disentangle and isolate malicious features; (3) mapping to downstream causal paths via feature influence scores derived from zero-out interventions, enabling selective suppression of causal chains and severing harmful information flow while preserving other computations.
AI.result: Empirical evaluation shows TraceRouter achieves a superior trade-off between adversarial robustness and general utility compared to state-of-the-art baselines. Code will be publicly released.
AI.conclusion: TraceRouter provides a principled, path-level framework to interrupt the cross-layer causal circuits that carry illicit semantics in LFMs, preserving orthogonal computation paths. It advances robustness without sacrificing utility, though the paper notes safety considerations due to unsafe model responses.

title: Semantic Content Determines Algorithmic Performance
summary: Counting should not depend on what is being counted; more generally, any algorithm's behavior should be invariant to the semantic content of its arguments. We introduce WhatCounts to test this property in isolation. Unlike prior work that conflates semantic sensitivity with reasoning complexity or prompt variation, WhatCounts is atomic: count items in an unambiguous, delimited list with no duplicates, distractors, or reasoning steps for different semantic types. Frontier LLMs show over 40% accuracy variation depending solely on what is being counted - cities versus chemicals, names versus symbols. Controlled ablations rule out confounds. The gap is semantic, and it shifts unpredictably with small amounts of unrelated fine-tuning. LLMs do not implement algorithms; they approximate them, and the approximation is argument-dependent. As we show with an agentic example, this has implications beyond counting: any LLM function may carry hidden dependencies on the meaning of its inputs.

AI.tldr: WhatCounts provides an atomic benchmark to test whether counting algorithms in LLMs are invariant to semantic content; results show large accuracy gaps across different semantic types, suggesting LLMs rely on argument meaning rather than implementing true algorithms.
AI.motivation: To isolate semantic sensitivity from reasoning complexity or prompt variation and assess whether LLMs perform counting as a content-agnostic algorithm.
AI.method: Introduce WhatCounts: a controlled, unambiguous counting task using a delimited list with no duplicates, distractors, or required reasoning steps; evaluate frontier LLMs across semantic types (e.g., cities vs chemicals, names vs symbols); perform controlled ablations to remove confounds; include an agentic example to illustrate broader implications.
AI.result: Frontier LLMs show over 40% accuracy variation solely due to what is being counted; a semantic gap exists that shifts with minor fine-tuning; ablations rule out confounds; LLMs do not implement true algorithms but approximate them, with the approximation depending on input meaning.
AI.conclusion: Counting invariance is not inherently guaranteed in LLMs; semantic content can subtly influence a wide range of LLM functions; implications extend beyond counting to general reliability and the design of evaluation benchmarks.

title: Beyond Global Alignment: Fine-Grained Motion-Language Retrieval via Pyramidal Shapley-Taylor Learning
summary: As a foundational task in human-centric cross-modal intelligence, motion-language retrieval aims to bridge the semantic gap between natural language and human motion, enabling intuitive motion analysis, yet existing approaches predominantly focus on aligning entire motion sequences with global textual representations. This global-centric paradigm overlooks fine-grained interactions between local motion segments and individual body joints and text tokens, inevitably leading to suboptimal retrieval performance.
