To address this limitation, we draw inspiration from the pyramidal process of human motion perception (from joint dynamics to segment coherence, and finally to holistic comprehension) and propose a novel Pyramidal Shapley-Taylor (PST) learning framework for fine-grained motion-language retrieval. Specifically, the framework decomposes human motion into temporal segments and spatial body joints, and learns cross-modal correspondences through progressive joint-wise and segment-wise alignment in a pyramidal fashion, effectively capturing both local semantic details and hierarchical structural relationships. Extensive experiments on multiple public benchmark datasets demonstrate that our approach significantly outperforms state-of-the-art methods, achieving precise alignment between motion segments and body joints and their corresponding text tokens. The code of this work will be released upon acceptance.

AI.tldr: Proposes Pyramidal Shapley-Taylor (PST) learning for fine-grained motion-language retrieval, aligning motion joints, segments, and text tokens in a hierarchical pyramid.
AI.motivation: Global sequence-to-text alignment overlooks local interactions between body joints, motion segments, and individual text tokens, limiting retrieval performance.
AI.method: Decompose motion into temporal segments and spatial joints, and perform progressive joint-wise and segment-wise cross-modal alignment in a pyramidal (coarse-to-fine) manner. Incorporates Shapley-Taylor-based attribution to quantify contributions of local components to textual tokens, enabling fine-grained alignment and interpretability.
AI.result: Empirical results on multiple public benchmarks show significant improvements over state-of-the-art methods, with precise alignment between motion segments, joints, and corresponding text tokens.
AI.conclusion: The PST framework captures hierarchical, fine-grained cross-modal relationships and offers improved retrieval performance, with interpretable attributions; code will be released upon acceptance.

title: An introductory Generalization of the standard SVMs loss and its applications to Shallow and Deep Neural Networks
summary: We propose a new convex loss for SVMs, both for the binary classification and for the regression models. Therefore, we show the mathematical derivation of the dual problems and we experiment them with several small data-sets. The minimal dimension of those data-sets is due to the difficult scalability of the SVM method to bigger instances. This preliminary study should prove that using pattern correlations inside the loss function could enhance the generalisation performances. Coherently, results show that generalisation measures are never worse than the standard losses and several times they are better. In our opinion, it should be considered a careful study of this loss, coupled with shallow and deep neural networks. In fact, we present some novel results obtained with those architectures.

AI.tldr: Introduces a new convex loss for SVMs applicable to binary classification and regression, derives the duals, and validates on small datasets; claims pattern-aware loss improves or matches generalization compared with standard losses; suggests applicability with shallow and deep networks.
AI.motivation: Address scalability and generalization in SVMs by embedding pattern correlations into the loss function, and demonstrate a unified convex loss for both classification and regression that can be used with neural networks.
AI.method: Formulate a new convex loss for SVMs; derive the corresponding dual optimization problems; conduct experiments on several small datasets due to scalability limitations; extend the investigation to shallow and deep neural networks.
AI.result: Generalization measures with the new loss are never worse than standard losses and are often better; the approach yields novel results when used with neural networks.
AI.conclusion: The convex, pattern-correlated loss for SVMs shows promise for improved generalization and compatibility with neural networks, though study is preliminary and limited by dataset size; warrants further exploration on larger datasets.

title: ScholarGym: Benchmarking Deep Research Workflows on Academic Literature Retrieval
summary:
Tool-augmented large language models have advanced from single-turn question answering to deep research workflows that iteratively plan queries, invoke external tools, and synthesize information to address complex information needs. Evaluating such workflows presents a fundamental challenge: reliance on live APIs introduces non-determinism, as tool invocations may yield different results across runs due to temporal drift, rate limiting, and evolving backend states. This variance undermines reproducibility and invalidates cross-system comparisons.
  We present ScholarGym, a simulation environment for reproducible evaluation of deep research workflows on academic literature. The environment decouples workflow components into query planning, tool invocation, and relevance assessment, enabling fine-grained analysis of each stage under controlled conditions. Built on a static corpus of 570K papers with deterministic retrieval, ScholarGym provides 2,536 queries with expert-annotated ground truth. Experiments across diverse backbone models reveal how reasoning capabilities, planning strategies, and selection mechanisms interact over iterative refinement.

AI.tldr: ScholarGym provides a reproducible simulation environment for evaluating deep, tool-augmented research workflows on academic literature by decoupling planning, tool invocation, and relevance assessment within a static corpus and deterministic retrieval.
AI.motivation: Reproducibility in tool-augmented LLM workflows is hampered by non-deterministic live APIs (temporal drift, rate limits, evolving states); a controlled, reproducible setting is needed to compare approaches fairly.
AI.method: Construct a static corpus of 570k papers with deterministic retrieval, and a workflow simulator that separates query planning, tool invocation, and relevance assessment. It provides 2,536 expert-annotated queries as ground truth and evaluates various backbone models to study interaction among reasoning, planning, and selection over iterative refinement.
AI.result: Demonstrates that decoupled, deterministic simulation can enable fine-grained analysis of each workflow stage and reveals how reasoning, planning strategies, and selection mechanisms influence iterative refinement across models; supports reproducible comparisons and systematic ablation studies.
AI.conclusion: ScholarGym offers a reproducible framework for evaluating deep research workflows with tool augmentation, highlighting the importance of component-level analysis and controlled evaluation. Its static corpus and ground-truth queries provide a stable baseline, though generalization to dynamic, real-world data remains a consideration.

title: VideoAesBench: Benchmarking the Video Aesthetics Perception Capabilities of Large Multimodal Models
summary: Large multimodal models (LMMs) have demonstrated outstanding capabilities in various visual perception tasks, which has in turn made the evaluation of LMMs significant. However, the capability of video aesthetic quality assessment, which is a fundamental ability for human, remains underexplored for LMMs. To address this, we introduce VideoAesBench, a comprehensive benchmark for evaluating LMMs' understanding of video aesthetic quality. VideoAesBench has several significant characteristics: (1) Diverse content including 1,804 videos from multiple video sources including user-generated (UGC), AI-generated (AIGC), compressed, robotic-generated (RGC), and game videos. (2) Multiple question formats containing traditional single-choice questions, multi-choice questions, True or False questions, and a novel open-ended questions for video aesthetics description. (3) Holistic video aesthetics dimensions including visual form related questions from 5 aspects, visual style related questions from 4 aspects, and visual affectiveness questions from 3 aspects. Based on VideoAesBench, we benchmark 23 open-source and commercial large multimodal models. Our findings show that current LMMs only contain basic video aesthetics perception ability, their performance remains incomplete and imprecise. We hope our VideoAesBench can be served as a strong testbed and offer insights for explainable video aesthetics assessment.

AI.tldr: VideoAesBench is a new benchmark to evaluate large multimodal models on video aesthetic quality using diverse content, multiple question formats (including open-ended aesthetics description), and holistic dimensions; evaluated 23 models; results show limited aesthetics understanding; aims to enable evaluation and explainability.
AI.motivation: Assessing video aesthetic understanding in LMMs is underexplored; need standardized, comprehensive benchmarks to measure perception across content types, formats, and aesthetics dimensions.
AI.method: Proposed VideoAesBench: 1,804 videos from UGC, AIGC, compressed, RGC, and game sources; diverse question formats (single-choice, multiple-choice, true/false, open-ended); aesthetics dimensions across visual form (5), visual style (4), visual affectiveness (3); evaluated 23 open-source and commercial LMMs.
AI.result: Current LMMs show only basic video aesthetics perception; performance is incomplete and imprecise; Benchmark reveals gaps in understanding and explainability; potential for insights into explainable assessment.
AI.conclusion: VideoAesBench serves as a strong testbed for evaluating and improving LMMs' understanding of video aesthetics and supporting explainable assessment.

title: Memorization Control in Diffusion Models from Denoising-centric Perspective
summary: Controlling memorization in diffusion models is critical for applications that require generated data to closely match the training distribution. Existing approaches mainly focus on data centric or model centric modifications, treating the diffusion model as an isolated predictor. In this paper, we study memorization in diffusion models from a denoising centric perspective. We show that uniform timestep sampling leads to unequal learning contributions across denoising steps due to differences in signal to noise ratio, which biases training toward memorization. To address this, we propose a timestep sampling strategy that explicitly controls where learning occurs along the denoising trajectory. By adjusting the width of the confidence interval, our method provides direct control over the memorization generalization trade off. Experiments on image and 1D signal generation tasks demonstrate that shifting learning emphasis toward later denoising steps consistently reduces memorization and improves distributional alignment with training data, validating the generality and effectiveness of our approach.

AI.tldr: A denoising-centric approach to controlling memorization in diffusion models: uniform timestep sampling biases learning toward memorization due to SNR differences across denoising steps; a timestep sampling strategy that controls learning along the denoising trajectory (via the width of a confidence interval) enables direct management of the memorization-generalization trade-off; experiments show emphasizing later denoising steps reduces memorization and improves alignment with training data in image and 1D signal generation.
AI.motivation: To mitigate memorization in diffusion models by addressing learning dynamics along the denoising process, rather than relying solely on data- or model-centric modifications.
AI.method: Introduce a timestep sampling strategy that explicitly allocates learning emphasis along the denoising trajectory and adjust the width of the confidence interval to modulate the memorization-generalization balance.
AI.result: Shifting learning emphasis toward later denoising steps consistently reduces memorization and improves distributional alignment with training data across image and 1D signal generation tasks.
AI.conclusion: A denoising-centric viewpoint provides direct, controllable means to regulate memorization via trajectory-aware timestep sampling, enhancing generalization and data fidelity across domains.

title: SONIC-O1: A Real-World Benchmark for Evaluating Multimodal Large Language Models on Audio-Video Understanding
summary: Multimodal Large Language Models (MLLMs) are a major focus of recent AI research. However, most prior work focuses on static image understanding, while their ability to process sequential audio-video data remains underexplored. This gap highlights the need for a high-quality benchmark to systematically evaluate MLLM performance in a real-world setting. We introduce SONIC-O1, a comprehensive, fully human-verified benchmark spanning 13 real-world conversational domains with 4,958 annotations and demographic metadata. SONIC-O1 evaluates MLLMs on key tasks, including open-ended summarization, multiple-choice question (MCQ) answering, and temporal localization with supporting rationales (reasoning). Experiments on closed- and open-source models reveal limitations. While the performance gap in MCQ accuracy between two model families is relatively small, we observe a substantial 22.6% performance difference in temporal localization between the best performing closed-source and open-source models. Performance further degrades across demographic groups, indicating persistent disparities in model behavior. Overall, SONIC-O1 provides an open evaluation suite for temporally grounded and socially robust multimodal understanding. We release SONIC-O1 for reproducibility and research: Project page: https://vectorinstitute.github.io/sonic-o1/ Dataset: https://huggingface.co/datasets/vector-institute/sonic-o1 Github: https://github.com/vectorinstitute/sonic-o1 Leaderboard: https://huggingface.co/spaces/vector-institute/sonic-o1-leaderboard

AI.tldr: A comprehensive, human-verified benchmark (SONIC-O1) for temporally grounded multimodal understanding across 13 domains, evaluating summarization, MCQ, and temporal localization; reveals performance gaps between model families and demographic disparities; released publicly with data and code.
AI.motivation: Address the lack of high-quality benchmarks that evaluate real-world, temporally grounded multimodal understanding and social robustness beyond static images, including demographic analysis.
AI.method: Constructed and fully human-verified SONIC-O1 dataset spanning 13 real-world conversational domains, with 4,958 annotations and demographic metadata. Evaluated multimodal LLMs on open-ended summarization, multiple-choice question answering, and temporal localization with rationales. Conducted experiments on closed- and open-source models to assess performance gaps and demographic biases.
AI.result: Found a relatively small MCQ accuracy gap between two model families, but a substantial 22.6% performance gap in temporal localization between the best closed-source and open-source models. Performance degrades across demographic groups, indicating persistent disparities. The benchmark is open and reproducible.
AI.conclusion: SONIC-O1 provides an open, temporally grounded, and socially robust evaluation suite for multimodal understanding, enabling reproducibility and further research. The authors release project pages, dataset, code, and leaderboard for community use.

title: Zero-Shot Video Restoration and Enhancement with Assistance of Video Diffusion Models
summary: Although diffusion-based zero-shot image restoration and enhancement methods have achieved great success, applying them to video restoration or enhancement will lead to severe temporal flickering. In this paper, we propose the first framework that utilizes the rapidly-developed video diffusion model to assist the image-based method in maintaining more temporal consistency for zero-shot video restoration and enhancement. We propose homologous latents fusion, heterogenous latents fusion, and a COT-based fusion ratio strategy to utilize both homologous and heterogenous text-to-video diffusion models to complement the image method. Moreover, we propose temporal-strengthening post-processing to utilize the image-to-video diffusion model to further improve temporal consistency. Our method is training-free and can be applied to any diffusion-based image restoration and enhancement methods. Experimental results demonstrate the superiority of the proposed method.

AI.tldr: A training-free framework for zero-shot video restoration/enhancement that fuses homologous and heterogeneous video diffusion latents with an image-based method to improve temporal consistency, aided by a COT-based fusion ratio and temporal-strengthening post-processing.
AI.motivation: Diffusion-based image restoration/enhancement often causes severe temporal flickering when applied to video; there is a need to leverage video diffusion models to maintain temporal coherence without retraining.
AI.method: Introduce homologous latents fusion, heterogeneous latents fusion, and a COT-based fusion ratio to combine image-to-video diffusion models with text-to-video diffusion models; add temporal-strengthening post-processing; the approach is training-free and compatible with any diffusion-based image restoration/enhancement method.
AI.result: Experimental results indicate superior temporal consistency and image quality compared to baselines, validating the proposed fusion and post-processing strategy in a zero-shot setting.
AI.conclusion: The framework effectively improves temporal consistency in zero-shot video restoration/enhancement by leveraging video diffusion models to complement image methods; it is training-free and broadly applicable.

title: L2R: Low-Rank and Lipschitz-Controlled Routing for Mixture-of-Experts
summary: Mixture-of-Experts (MoE) models scale neural networks by conditionally activating a small subset of experts, where the router plays a central role in determining expert specialization and overall model performance. However, many modern MoE systems still adopt linear routers in raw high-dimensional representation spaces, where representation mismatch, angular concentration, and scale-sensitive scoring can jointly undermine routing discriminability and stable expert specialization. In this work, we propose Low-rank \& Lipschitz-controlled Routing (L2R), a unified routing framework that reshapes both the routing space and scoring geometry. L2R performs expert assignment in a shared low-rank latent routing space and introduces Saturated Inner-Product Scoring (SIPS) to explicitly control the Lipschitz behavior of routing functions, yielding smoother and more stable routing geometry. In addition, L2R incorporates a parameter-efficient multi-anchor routing mechanism to enhance expert expressiveness. Extensive experiments on a large-scale language MoE model and a vision MoE setting on ImageNet demonstrate that L2R consistently improves routing stability, expert specialization, and overall model performance.

AI.tldr: L2R is a unified MoE routing framework that reshapes routing into a low-rank latent space and uses Saturated Inner-Product Scoring (SIPS) to bound Lipschitz behavior, plus a parameter-efficient multi-anchor routing mechanism, achieving improved routing stability, expert specialization, and overall performance in language and vision MoEs.
AI.motivation: Linear routers operating in high-dimensional spaces cause representation mismatch, angular concentration, and scale-sensitive scoring, which degrade routing discriminability and stable expert specialization in MoE models.
AI.method: 1) Route in a shared low-rank latent space; 2) apply Saturated Inner-Product Scoring (SIPS) to constrain Lipschitz continuity and smooth routing; 3) introduce parameter-efficient multi-anchor routing to enhance expressiveness.
AI.result: Extensive experiments on large-scale language MoE and ImageNet-vision MoE show consistent improvements in routing stability, expert specialization, and overall model performance.
AI.conclusion: L2R reshapes routing geometry and scoring to improve MoE routing quality, yielding stable, expressive, and higher-performing models across language and vision domains.

title: TCAP: Tri-Component Attention Profiling for Unsupervised Backdoor Detection in MLLM Fine-Tuning
summary: Fine-Tuning-as-a-Service (FTaaS) facilitates the customization of Multimodal Large Language Models (MLLMs) but introduces critical backdoor risks via poisoned data. Existing defenses either rely on supervised signals or fail to generalize across diverse trigger types and modalities. In this work, we uncover a universal backdoor fingerprint-attention allocation divergence-where poisoned samples disrupt the balanced attention distribution across three functional components: system instructions, vision inputs, and user textual queries, regardless of trigger morphology. Motivated by this insight, we propose Tri-Component Attention Profiling (TCAP), an unsupervised defense framework to filter backdoor samples. TCAP decomposes cross-modal attention maps into the three components, identifies trigger-responsive attention heads via Gaussian Mixture Model (GMM) statistical profiling, and isolates poisoned samples through EM-based vote aggregation. Extensive experiments across diverse MLLM architectures and attack methods demonstrate that TCAP achieves consistently strong performance, establishing it as a robust and practical backdoor defense in MLLMs.

AI.tldr: Introduces Tri-Component Attention Profiling (TCAP), an unsupervised defense against backdoor attacks in Fine-Tuning-as-a-Service for Multimodal LLMs by detecting trigger-induced imbalances in system, vision, and user attention.
AI.motivation: Backdoor data in FTaaS can exploit poisoned samples; existing defenses lack generalization across trigger types and modalities; there is a universal fingerprint in attention allocation.
AI.method: Decompose cross-modal attention into system, vision, and text components; use Gaussian Mixture Model to profile trigger-responsive heads; apply EM-based vote aggregation to flag poisoned samples.
AI.result: Empirical validation across multiple MLLM architectures and attack methods; TCAP consistently performs well, improving detection of backdoor samples.
AI.conclusion: Unsupervised, cross-modal defense framework that is robust and practical for backdoor mitigation in MLLMs, generalizes across trigger types and modalities.

title: Just Noticeable Difference Modeling for Deep Visual Features
summary: Deep visual features are increasingly used as the interface in vision systems, motivating the need to describe feature characteristics and control feature quality for machine perception. Just noticeable difference (JND) characterizes the maximum imperceptible distortion for images under human or machine vision. Extending it to deep visual features naturally meets the above demand by providing a task-aligned tolerance boundary in feature space, offering a practical reference for controlling feature quality under constrained resources. We propose FeatJND, a task-aligned JND formulation that predicts the maximum tolerable per-feature perturbation map while preserving downstream task performance. We propose a FeatJND estimator at standardized split points and validate it across image classification, detection, and instance segmentation. Under matched distortion strength, FeatJND-based distortions consistently preserve higher task performance than unstructured Gaussian perturbations, and attribution visualizations suggest FeatJND can suppress non-critical feature regions. As an application, we further apply FeatJND to token-wise dynamic quantization and show that FeatJND-guided step-size allocation yields clear gains over random step-size permutation and global uniform step size under the same noise budget. Our code will be released after publication.

AI.tldr: FeatJND defines a task-aligned JND for deep visual features, predicting per-feature perturbation limits to preserve downstream task performance; validated on classification, detection, and segmentation; outperforms Gaussian noise; enables FeatJND-guided token-wise dynamic quantization with improved efficiency.
AI.motivation: To quantify and control perceptual tolerance in deep feature space for vision systems, enabling quality control under resource constraints and improving robustness by focusing perturbations on non-critical features.
AI.method: Introduce FeatJND estimator at standardized split points to compute maximum tolerable perturbation per feature; validate across tasks; compare with unstructured Gaussian perturbations; use attribution visualizations to show suppression of non-critical regions; apply to token-wise dynamic quantization with FeatJND-guided step-size allocation; compare against random and global uniform step sizes.
AI.result: FeatJND-distorted features retain higher task performance than Gaussian perturbations when distortions are matched; attribution analysis indicates focus on critical regions; FeatJND-guided quantization shows gains over baselines at the same noise budget.
AI.conclusion: FeatJND provides a practical, task-aligned perturbation tolerance for deep features, enabling better maintenance of performance under distortion and enabling more efficient feature quantization, with broad applicability to recognition and localization tasks.

title: Factored Causal Representation Learning for Robust Reward Modeling in RLHF
summary: A reliable reward model is essential for aligning large language models with human preferences through reinforcement learning from human feedback. However, standard reward models are susceptible to spurious features that are not causally related to human labels. This can lead to reward hacking, where high predicted reward does not translate into better behavior. In this work, we address this problem from a causal perspective by proposing a factored representation learning framework that decomposes the model's contextual embedding into (1) causal factors that are sufficient for reward prediction and (2) non-causal factors that capture reward-irrelevant attributes such as length or sycophantic bias. The reward head is then constrained to depend only on the causal component. In addition, we introduce an adversarial head trained to predict reward from the non-causal factors, while applying gradient reversal to discourage them from encoding reward-relevant information. Experiments on both mathematical and dialogue tasks demonstrate that our method learns more robust reward models and consistently improves downstream RLHF performance over state-of-the-art baselines. Analyses on length and sycophantic bias further validate the effectiveness of our method in mitigating reward hacking behaviors.

AI.tldr: Disentangles causal from non-causal features in reward models via factored embeddings and an adversarial head with gradient reversal, reducing reward hacking and improving RLHF across math and dialogue tasks.
AI.motivation: Spurious, non-causal features in reward models lead to reward hacking and misalignment. A causal, disentangled representation should force the reward predictor to rely on genuinely informative signals, improving robustness and generalization in RLHF.
AI.method: Decompose the model's contextual embedding into (1) causal factors sufficient for reward prediction and (2) non-causal factors capturing reward-irrelevant attributes (e.g., length, sycophantic bias). Constrain the reward head to depend only on the causal component. Add an adversarial head that predicts reward from non-causal factors with gradient reversal to discourage non-causal encoding of reward-relevant information.
AI.result: Empirical evaluation on mathematical and dialogue tasks shows more robust reward models and consistent improvements in downstream RLHF performance over strong baselines. Analyses of length and sycophantic bias indicate reduced reward hacking.
AI.conclusion: A factored, causally-inspired reward-model framework with an adversarial non-causal head effectively mitigates reward hacking and enhances RLHF performance, supporting causal/disentangled approaches in reward modeling.

title: FBS: Modeling Native Parallel Reading inside a Transformer
summary: Large language models (LLMs) excel across many tasks, yet inference is still dominated by strictly token-by-token autoregression. Existing acceleration methods largely patch this pipeline and miss core human-reading ingredients: content-adaptive foresight, chunk-structure-aware compute allocation, and train--test consistency for preview/skimming. We propose the \textbf{Fovea-Block-Skip Transformer} (FBS), which injects a causal, trainable loop into Transformers via Parafovea-Attention Window (PAW), Chunk-Head (CH), and Skip-Gate (SG). Across diverse benchmarks, FBS improves the quality-efficiency trade-off without increasing parameters, and ablations show the three modules are complementary.

AI.tldr: Introduces the Fovea-Block-Skip Transformer (FBS), a trainable, loop-enabled Transformer that uses Parafovea-Attention Window (PAW), Chunk-Head (CH), and Skip-Gate (SG) to accelerate inference. It improves the quality-efficiency trade-off without adding parameters, with ablations showing the three modules are complementary.
AI.motivation: Standard LLM inference remains strictly token-by-token autoregression, and existing acceleration methods patch this pipeline without capturing core human-reading strategies: content-adaptive foresight, chunk-structure-aware compute allocation, and train-test consistency for preview/skimming.
AI.method: Incorporate a causal, trainable loop into Transformers via three components: Parafovea-Attention Window (PAW) for adaptive attention scope, Chunk-Head (CH) for chunked compute allocation, and Skip-Gate (SG) for selective token skipping. The design induces trainable preview/skimming behavior and aims to align training and inference.
AI.result: Across diverse benchmarks, FBS improves the quality-efficiency trade-off without increasing the number of parameters. Ablation studies indicate that PAW, CH, and SG are complementary and contribute jointly to performance gains.
AI.conclusion: FBS offers a practical path to more efficient LLM inference by embedding a trainable loop with content-adaptive attention, chunked computation, and skipping, achieving better efficiency without parameter growth and with complementary module interactions.

title: BookNet: Book Image Rectification via Cross-Page Attention Network
summary: Book image rectification presents unique challenges in document image processing due to complex geometric distortions from binding constraints, where left and right pages exhibit distinctly asymmetric curvature patterns. However, existing single-page document image rectification methods fail to capture the coupled geometric relationships between adjacent pages in books. In this work, we introduce BookNet, the first end-to-end deep learning framework specifically designed for dual-page book image rectification. BookNet adopts a dual-branch architecture with cross-page attention mechanisms, enabling it to estimate warping flows for both individual pages and the complete book spread, explicitly modeling how left and right pages influence each other. Moreover, to address the absence of specialized datasets, we present Book3D, a large-scale synthetic dataset for training, and Book100, a comprehensive real-world benchmark for evaluation. Extensive experiments demonstrate that BookNet outperforms existing state-of-the-art methods on book image rectification. Code and dataset will be made publicly available.

AI.tldr: Proposes BookNet: a dual-page, end-to-end neural network for rectifying book images by modeling left-right page coupling with cross-page attention; introduces Book3D (synthetic) and Book100 (real) datasets; reports state-of-the-art results and releases code/datasets.
AI.motivation: Address the geometric distortions in book scanning caused by binding constraints, where left and right pages have coupled, asymmetric curvature. Existing single-page rectification methods ignore inter-page dependencies, leading to suboptimal results for dual-page spreads.
AI.method: A dual-branch network with cross-page attention that jointly estimates warping flows for individual pages and the full book spread. The model explicitly captures cross-page influence to improve rectification. It is trained on a large synthetic dataset Book3D and evaluated on the real-world Book100 benchmark.
AI.result: Extensive experiments show that BookNet outperforms state-of-the-art single-page rectification methods on book image rectification tasks.
AI.conclusion: BookNet is the first end-to-end dual-page rectification framework; Book3D and Book100 datasets are introduced to support training and evaluation; code and datasets will be publicly available.

title: Theoretically Optimal Attention/FFN Ratios in Disaggregated LLM Serving
summary: Attention-FFN disaggregation (AFD) is an emerging architecture for LLM decoding that separates state-heavy, KV-cache-dominated Attention computation from stateless, compute-intensive FFN computation, connected by per-step communication. While AFD enables independent scaling of memory and compute resources, its performance is highly sensitive to the Attention/FFN provisioning ratio: mis-sizing induces step-level blocking and costly device idle time. We develop a tractable analytical framework for sizing AFD bundles in an $r$A-$1$F topology, where the key difficulty is that Attention-side work is nonstationary-token context grows and requests are continuously replenished with random lengths-while FFN work is stable given the aggregated batch. Using a probabilistic workload model, we derive closed-form rules for the optimal A/F ratio that maximize average throughput per instance across the system. A trace-calibrated AFD simulator validates the theory: across workloads, the theoretical optimal A/F ratio matches the simulation-optimal within 10%, and consistently reduces idle time.

AI.tldr: Analytical provisioning framework for Attention-FFN disaggregation (AFD) in an rA-1F topology, deriving optimal Attention/FFN ratio to maximize throughput; validated by a trace-calibrated simulator, achieving near-optimal performance (within ~10%).
AI.motivation: Mitigate mis-sizing in AFD architectures that leads to step-level blocking and idle time by jointly sizing memory-heavy Attention and compute-heavy FFN components.
AI.method: Develop probabilistic workload model with nonstationary Attention workload (growing context) and stable FFN workload; derive closed-form optimal A/F ratio; validate with a trace-calibrated AFD simulator across workloads.
AI.result: Closed-form rules for the optimal Attention/FFN ratio; simulation shows theory matches simulation-optimal within 10% and reduces idle time consistently.
AI.conclusion: A properly sized AFD bundle yields near-optimal throughput in LLM decoding across varying workloads; the framework provides practical provisioning guidance and solid validation via simulation.

title: E-mem: Multi-agent based Episodic Context Reconstruction for LLM Agent Memory
summary: The evolution of Large Language Model (LLM) agents towards System~2 reasoning, characterized by deliberative, high-precision problem-solving, requires maintaining rigorous logical integrity over extended horizons. However, prevalent memory preprocessing paradigms suffer from destructive de-contextualization. By compressing complex sequential dependencies into pre-defined structures (e.g., embeddings or graphs), these methods sever the contextual integrity essential for deep reasoning. To address this, we propose E-mem, a framework shifting from Memory Preprocessing to Episodic Context Reconstruction. Inspired by biological engrams, E-mem employs a heterogeneous hierarchical architecture where multiple assistant agents maintain uncompressed memory contexts, while a central master agent orchestrates global planning. Unlike passive retrieval, our mechanism empowers assistants to locally reason within activated segments, extracting context-aware evidence before aggregation. Evaluations on the LoCoMo benchmark demonstrate that E-mem achieves over 54\% F1, surpassing the state-of-the-art GAM by 7.75\%, while reducing token cost by over 70\%.

AI.tldr: E-mem: Episodic context reconstruction for LLM agent memory, preserving uncompressed memories with hierarchical agents and a master planner; enables local reasoning within segments and improved, cost-efficient long-horizon reasoning.
AI.motivation: To overcome destructive de-contextualization from memory preprocessing that collapses dependencies; preserve contextual integrity for deep, System-2 style reasoning in LLM agents.
AI.method: A heterogeneous hierarchical architecture where multiple assistant agents each hold uncompressed memory contexts; a central master agent orchestrates global planning. Assistants reason within activated memory segments to extract context-aware evidence before aggregation, rather than passively retrieving pre-structured representations.
AI.result: Empirical results on the LoCoMo benchmark show E-mem attaining over 54% F1, beating the state-of-the-art GAM by 7.75 percentage points, and reducing token costs by over 70%.
AI.conclusion: E-mem demonstrates that episodic, context-preserving memory with decentralized yet coordinated reasoning yields stronger, more efficient long-horizon performance, highlighting episodic context reconstruction as a viable alternative to memory preprocessing.

title: Deep Models, Shallow Alignment: Uncovering the Granularity Mismatch in Neural Decoding
summary: Neural visual decoding is a central problem in brain computer interface research, aiming to reconstruct human visual perception and to elucidate the structure of neural representations. However, existing approaches overlook a fundamental granularity mismatch between human and machine vision, where deep vision models emphasize semantic invariance by suppressing local texture information, whereas neural signals preserve an intricate mixture of low-level visual attributes and high-level semantic content. To address this mismatch, we propose Shallow Alignment, a novel contrastive learning strategy that aligns neural signals with intermediate representations of visual encoders rather than their final outputs, thereby striking a better balance between low-level texture details and high-level semantic features. Extensive experiments across multiple benchmarks demonstrate that Shallow Alignment significantly outperforms standard final-layer alignment, with performance gains ranging from 22% to 58% across diverse vision backbones. Notably, our approach effectively unlocks the scaling law in neural visual decoding, enabling decoding performance to scale predictably with the capacity of pre-trained vision backbones. We further conduct systematic empirical analyses to shed light on the mechanisms underlying the observed performance gains.

AI.tldr: A contrastive learning method, Shallow Alignment, aligns neural signals with intermediate representations from visual encoders to bridge low-level texture and high-level semantics, improving neural visual decoding and enabling scaling with backbone capacity.
AI.motivation: Existing neural decoding overlooks granularity mismatch: neural signals retain low-level attributes; vision models suppress them for semantic invariance. Aligning intermediate features aims to reconcile this.
AI.method: Contrastive learning aligning neural data with intermediate-layer representations (not final outputs) of pre-trained vision encoders across backbones; evaluate on benchmarks; analyze scaling behavior.
AI.result: Significant improvements over final-layer alignment, with 22%-58% gains across backbones; unlocks predictable scaling with backbone capacity; extensive empirical analyses revealing mechanisms.
AI.conclusion: Shallow Alignment effectively bridges granularity gap, leveraging intermediate representations to improve decoding and scalability; provides a new direction for neural decoding research.

title: Expected Improvement via Gradient Norms
summary: Bayesian Optimization (BO) is a principled approach for optimizing expensive black-box functions, with Expected Improvement (EI) being one of the most widely used acquisition functions. Despite its empirical success, EI is known to be overly exploitative and can converge to suboptimal stationary points. We propose Expected Improvement via Gradient Norms (EI-GN), a novel acquisition function that applies the improvement principle to a gradient-aware auxiliary objective, thereby promoting sampling in regions that are both high-performing and approaching first-order stationarity. EI-GN relies on gradient observations used to learn gradient-enhanced surrogate models that enable principled gradient inference from function evaluations. We derive a tractable closed-form expression for EI-GN that allows efficient optimization and show that the proposed acquisition is consistent with the improvement-based acquisition framework. Empirical evaluations on standard BO benchmarks demonstrate that EI-GN yields consistent improvements against standard baselines. We further demonstrate applicability of EI-GN to control policy learning problems.

AI.tldr: Introduces EI-GN, a gradient-norm–based acquisition function for Bayesian optimization that uses gradient-enhanced surrogates to encourage sampling near first-order stationary points; provides a tractable closed-form and shows empirical gains on standard benchmarks and control problems.
AI.motivation: Standard Expected Improvement (EI) can be overly exploitative and may miss regions approaching stationarity, leading to suboptimal optima. Incorporating gradient information aims to steer sampling toward areas with high performance and near-stationarity.
AI.method: Define an auxiliary objective based on gradient norms and apply the improvement principle to this objective. Use gradient observations to train gradient-enhanced surrogate models, enabling principled gradient inference. Derive a tractable closed-form EI-GN expression, preserving the improvement-based framework.
AI.result: Empirical evaluations on standard BO benchmarks show consistent improvements over standard baselines. Demonstrates applicability to control policy learning problems.
AI.conclusion: EI-GN extends the improvement-based acquisition framework to gradient-aware settings, yielding improved sample efficiency by targeting regions near first-order stationarity; the approach is practical due to a closed-form EI-GN and gradient-enhanced surrogates.

title: DropoutTS: Sample-Adaptive Dropout for Robust Time Series Forecasting
summary: Deep time series models are vulnerable to noisy data ubiquitous in real-world applications. Existing robustness strategies either prune data or rely on costly prior quantification, failing to balance effectiveness and efficiency. In this paper, we introduce DropoutTS, a model-agnostic plugin that shifts the paradigm from "what" to learn to "how much" to learn. DropoutTS employs a Sample-Adaptive Dropout mechanism: leveraging spectral sparsity to efficiently quantify instance-level noise via reconstruction residuals, it dynamically calibrates model learning capacity by mapping noise to adaptive dropout rates - selectively suppressing spurious fluctuations while preserving fine-grained fidelity. Extensive experiments across diverse noise regimes and open benchmarks show DropoutTS consistently boosts superior backbones' performance, delivering advanced robustness with negligible parameter overhead and no architectural modifications. Our code is available at https://github.com/CityMind-Lab/DropoutTS.

AI.tldr: A model-agnostic robustness plugin for time series: DropoutTS uses sample-adaptive dropout guided by spectral sparsity to estimate instance noise and dynamically adjust learning capacity, boosting robustness with minimal overhead and no architecture changes.
AI.motivation: Deep-time-series models struggle with noisy data; existing robustness methods either prune data or require costly noise quantification, often sacrificing efficiency or performance. There is a need for a lightweight, effective, and architecture-agnostic robustness mechanism.
AI.method: Introduce Sample-Adaptive Dropout (DropoutTS). It exploits spectral sparsity to estimate reconstruction residuals and quantify instance-level noise. The method maps estimated noise to adaptive dropout rates, suppressing spurious fluctuations while preserving fine-grained signals, without modifying model architecture.
AI.result: Empirical results across diverse noise regimes and open benchmarks show consistent robustness improvements for strong backbones, with negligible parameter overhead and no architectural changes. Code is publicly available.
AI.conclusion: DropoutTS provides a lightweight, model-agnostic robustness plugin for deep time series models, achieving improved performance under noise without modifying the underlying architecture; easy to integrate and computationally efficient.

title: PaddleOCR-VL-1.5: Towards a Multi-Task 0.9B VLM for Robust In-the-Wild Document Parsing
summary: We introduce PaddleOCR-VL-1.5, an upgraded model achieving a new state-of-the-art (SOTA) accuracy of 94.5% on OmniDocBench v1.5. To rigorously evaluate robustness against real-world physical distortions, including scanning, skew, warping, screen-photography, and illumination, we propose the Real5-OmniDocBench benchmark. Experimental results demonstrate that this enhanced model attains SOTA performance on the newly curated benchmark. Furthermore, we extend the model's capabilities by incorporating seal recognition and text spotting tasks, while remaining a 0.9B ultra-compact VLM with high efficiency. Code: https://github.com/PaddlePaddle/PaddleOCR

AI.tldr: PaddleOCR-VL-1.5 achieves state-of-the-art 94.5% on OmniDocBench v1.5; introduces Real5-OmniDocBench for robustness to real-world distortions; extends with seal recognition and text spotting while maintaining a compact 0.9B VLM; code released.
AI.motivation: Address the need for robust, efficient Vision-Linguistic OCR that performs well under real-world document distortions and supports additional tasks (seal recognition, text spotting) without sacrificing compactness.
AI.method: Upgrade PaddleOCR-VL to version 1.5; curate Real5-OmniDocBench to evaluate distortions (scanning, skew, warping, screen photography, illumination); add seal recognition and text spotting capabilities; maintain a 0.9B parameter, ultra-compact VLM; release code at the provided repository.
AI.result: Achieves SOTA accuracy of 94.5% on OmniDocBench v1.5; attains SOTA on the Real5-OmniDocBench benchmark; demonstrates capability expansion to seal recognition and text spotting; preserves high efficiency with a 0.9B parameter model.
AI.conclusion: PaddleOCR-VL-1.5 delivers robust, efficient OCR with expanded tasks and new robustness benchmarks, suitable for practical deployment where distortions and multi-task requirements are common; code is publicly available.

title: Epistemic Context Learning: Building Trust the Right Way in LLM-Based Multi-Agent Systems
comment: Codes and data are available at https://github.com/skyriver-2000/epistemic-context-learning
summary: Individual agents in multi-agent (MA) systems often lack robustness, tending to blindly conform to misleading peers. We show this weakness stems from both sycophancy and inadequate ability to evaluate peer reliability. To address this, we first formalize the learning problem of history-aware reference, introducing the historical interactions of peers as additional input, so that agents can estimate peer reliability and learn from trustworthy peers when uncertain. This shifts the task from evaluating peer reasoning quality to estimating peer reliability based on interaction history. We then develop Epistemic Context Learning (ECL): a reasoning framework that conditions predictions on explicitly-built peer profiles from history. We further optimize ECL by reinforcement learning using auxiliary rewards. Our experiments reveal that our ECL enables small models like Qwen 3-4B to outperform a history-agnostic baseline 8x its size (Qwen 3-30B) by accurately identifying reliable peers. ECL also boosts frontier models to near-perfect (100%) performance. We show that ECL generalizes well to various MA configurations and we find that trust is modeled well by LLMs, revealing a strong correlation in trust modeling accuracy and final answer quality.

AI.tldr: Epistemic Context Learning (ECL) introduces history-aware peer profiles to estimate peer reliability, enabling smaller models to outperform larger baselines and improving robustness in multi-agent systems.
AI.motivation: Sycophancy and poor evaluation of peer reliability cause agents to blindly follow misleading peers. Incorporating historical interactions as context aims to shift focus from judging peer reasoning to assessing peer reliability over time.
AI.method: Formalize learning of history-aware reference. Build explicit peer profiles from historical interactions and condition predictions on them. Develop ECL as a reasoning framework and optimize with reinforcement learning using auxiliary rewards.
AI.result: Small models (Qwen 3-4B) outperformed history-agnostic baselines (Qwen 3-30B) by identifying reliable peers. ECL enhanced frontier models toward near-perfect (100%) performance and generalizes across MA configurations. A strong correlation exists between trust modeling accuracy and final answer quality.
AI.conclusion: History-informed reliability estimation via ECL improves robustness and performance in multi-agent settings; trust modeling by LLMs is predictive of final outcome quality.

title: Perceptrons and localization of attention's mean-field landscape
summary: The forward pass of a Transformer can be seen as an interacting particle system on the unit sphere: time plays the role of layers, particles that of token embeddings, and the unit sphere idealizes layer normalization. In some weight settings the system can even be seen as a gradient flow for an explicit energy, and one can make sense of the infinite context length (mean-field) limit thanks to Wasserstein gradient flows. In this paper we study the effect of the perceptron block in this setting, and show that critical points are generically atomic and localized on subsets of the sphere.

AI.tldr: Critical points in a Transformer interpreted as a gradient flow on the unit sphere, with the perceptron block, are generically atomic and localized on sphere subsets.
AI.motivation: To understand Transformer forward dynamics as an interacting particle system and to analyze how the perceptron block affects the mean-field (infinite context) limit and energy landscape.
AI.method: Model the Transformer forward pass as interacting particles on the unit sphere; interpret layer normalization as the sphere; show under certain weight regimes the dynamics form a Wasserstein gradient flow of an explicit energy; analyze the mean-field limit; study the perceptron block's impact on the energy landscape and critical points.
AI.result: In the presence of the perceptron block, critical points of the system are generically atomic (supported on discrete points) and localized on subsets of the sphere.
AI.conclusion: The perceptron block drives the system toward highly localized, discrete modes on the unit sphere, providing insight into the structure of learned representations and the energy landscape governing Transformer dynamics in the mean-field regime.

title: Language-based Trial and Error Falls Behind in the Era of Experience
summary: While Large Language Models (LLMs) excel in language-based agentic tasks, their applicability to unseen, nonlinguistic environments (e.g., symbolic or spatial tasks) remains limited. Previous work attributes this performance gap to the mismatch between the pretraining distribution and the testing distribution. In this work, we demonstrate the primary bottleneck is the prohibitive cost of exploration: mastering these tasks requires extensive trial-and-error, which is computationally unsustainable for parameter-heavy LLMs operating in a high dimensional semantic space. To address this, we propose SCOUT (Sub-Scale Collaboration On Unseen Tasks), a novel framework that decouples exploration from exploitation. We employ lightweight "scouts" (e.g., small MLPs) to probe environmental dynamics at a speed and scale far exceeding LLMs. The collected trajectories are utilized to bootstrap the LLM via Supervised Fine-Tuning (SFT), followed by multi-turn Reinforcement Learning (RL) to activate its latent world knowledge. Empirically, SCOUT enables a Qwen2.5-3B-Instruct model to achieve an average score of 0.86, significantly outperforming proprietary models, including Gemini-2.5-Pro (0.60), while saving about 60% GPU hours consumption.

AI.tldr: SCOUT decouples exploration from exploitation using lightweight scouts to quickly map environmental dynamics, enabling supervised fine-tuning and subsequent RL of an LLM, achieving strong performance and efficiency gains on unseen tasks.
AI.motivation: Exploration cost in high-dimensional, nonlinguistic environments is the primary bottleneck limiting LLM applicability; distribution mismatch is not the sole issue.
AI.method: Use scouts (e.g., small MLPs) to probe dynamics and collect trajectories; bootstrap LLM via supervised fine-tuning with these trajectories; apply multi-turn RL to activate latent world knowledge.
AI.result: On Qwen2.5-3B-Instruct, SCOUT achieves average score 0.86, outperforming Gemini-2.5-Pro at 0.60 and saving about 60% of GPU hours.
AI.conclusion: Decoupling exploration from exploitation with scalable scouts improves efficiency and performance of LLMs in unseen tasks, validating SCOUT as a viable framework for cross-modal or nonlinguistic task generalization.

title: Drive-JEPA: Video JEPA Meets Multimodal Trajectory Distillation for End-to-End Driving
summary: End-to-end autonomous driving increasingly leverages self-supervised video pretraining to learn transferable planning representations. However, pretraining video world models for scene understanding has so far brought only limited improvements. This limitation is compounded by the inherent ambiguity of driving: each scene typically provides only a single human trajectory, making it difficult to learn multimodal behaviors. In this work, we propose Drive-JEPA, a framework that integrates Video Joint-Embedding Predictive Architecture (V-JEPA) with multimodal trajectory distillation for end-to-end driving. First, we adapt V-JEPA for end-to-end driving, pretraining a ViT encoder on large-scale driving videos to produce predictive representations aligned with trajectory planning. Second, we introduce a proposal-centric planner that distills diverse simulator-generated trajectories alongside human trajectories, with a momentum-aware selection mechanism to promote stable and safe behavior. When evaluated on NAVSIM, the V-JEPA representation combined with a simple transformer-based decoder outperforms prior methods by 3 PDMS in the perception-free setting. The complete Drive-JEPA framework achieves 93.3 PDMS on v1 and 87.8 EPDMS on v2, setting a new state-of-the-art.

AI.tldr: Drive-JEPA combines Video Joint-Embedding Predictive Architecture with multimodal trajectory distillation to learn predictive planning representations for end-to-end driving, yielding state-of-the-art results on NAVSIM.
AI.motivation: Address the limited gains from video-only pretraining of world models for driving and the inherent ambiguity of driving scenes, where a single human trajectory limits learning of multimodal behaviors.
AI.method: Adapt V-JEPA to end-to-end driving by pretraining a ViT encoder on large-scale driving videos to produce predictive representations aligned with trajectory planning; introduce a proposal-centric planner that distills diverse simulator-generated trajectories alongside human trajectories with a momentum-aware selection mechanism to promote stability and safety.
AI.result: On NAVSIM, the V-JEPA representation with a simple transformer-based decoder outperforms prior methods by 3 PDMS in the perception-free setting; Drive-JEPA achieves 93.3 PDMS on v1 and 87.8 EPDMS on v2, setting a new state-of-the-art.
AI.conclusion: Drive-JEPA demonstrates that combining predictive video representations with multimodal trajectory distillation improves end-to-end driving planning, achieving strong state-of-the-art results; the approach leverages simulator-generated trajectories to capture multimodal behaviors and enhances stability and safety through momentum-aware selection.

title: Rethinking Federated Graph Foundation Models: A Graph-Language Alignment-based Approach
summary:
Recent studies of federated graph foundational models (FedGFMs) break the idealized and untenable assumption of having centralized data storage to train graph foundation models, and accommodate the reality of distributed, privacy-restricted data silos. Despite their simplicity and intuition, existing studies that project aligned generalizable knowledge onto a discrete token space via vector-quantized backbones suffer from irreversible knowledge loss during the quantization process. In this context, we argue that reconciling the semantic-structural orthogonality and integrity between pre-trained language models (PLMs) and graph neural networks (GNNs) is paramount for developing effective FedGFMs while simultaneously mitigating the severe data heterogeneity and communication constraints inherent in distributed, resource-limited environments.
  To address these issues, we propose FedGALA (Federated Graph And Language Alignment), a framework that resolves graph-based semantic-structural orthogonality and integrity in federated settings by employing unsupervised contrastive learning to align GNNs and frozen PLMs within a continuous embedding space, thereby capturing robust, transferable general knowledge. Subsequently, FedGALA leverages a communication-efficient prompt tuning mechanism to steer these pre-aligned encoders and frozen PLMs, facilitating effective adaptation to diverse downstream tasks while circumventing the prohibitive overhead of full-parameter fine-tuning. The comprehensive experiments validate that FedGALA outperforms all competitive baselines across multi-domain datasets on multiple tasks with up to 14.37% performance improvement.

AI.tldr: FedGALA aligns GNNs with frozen PLMs in federated settings using unsupervised contrastive learning in a continuous embedding space, plus prompt-tuning for task adaptation, achieving superior performance while reducing communication overhead.
AI.motivation: Address the semantic-structural orthogonality between PLMs and GNNs, mitigate data heterogeneity and stringent communication constraints in federated graph learning, and avoid irreversible knowledge loss from vector-quantized backbones.
AI.method: Use unsupervised contrastive learning to align GNN and frozen PLM embeddings in a shared continuous space; employ a communication-efficient prompt-tuning mechanism to adapt to downstream tasks without full-parameter fine-tuning.
AI.result: Empirical results show FedGALA outperforms competitive baselines across multi-domain datasets on multiple tasks, with up to 14.37% performance improvement.
AI.conclusion: FedGALA provides effective graph-language alignment in federated settings, enabling robust knowledge transfer and efficient adaptation under data heterogeneity and communication constraints.

title: Zero-Shot Statistical Downscaling via Diffusion Posterior Sampling
summary: Conventional supervised climate downscaling struggles to generalize to Global Climate Models (GCMs) due to the lack of paired training data and inherent domain gaps relative to reanalysis. Meanwhile, current zero-shot methods suffer from physical inconsistencies and vanishing gradient issues under large scaling factors. We propose Zero-Shot Statistical Downscaling (ZSSD), a zero-shot framework that performs statistical downscaling without paired data during training. ZSSD leverages a Physics-Consistent Climate Prior learned from reanalysis data, conditioned on geophysical boundaries and temporal information to enforce physical validity. Furthermore, to enable robust inference across varying GCMs, we introduce Unified Coordinate Guidance. This strategy addresses the vanishing gradient problem in vanilla DPS and ensures consistency with large-scale fields. Results show that ZSSD significantly outperforms existing zero-shot baselines in 99th percentile errors and successfully reconstructs complex weather events, such as tropical cyclones, across heterogeneous GCMs.

AI.tldr: Proposes ZSSD, a zero-shot statistical downscaling framework with a physics-consistent reanalysis-based prior and Unified Coordinate Guidance to achieve robust, physically valid downscaling across heterogeneous GCMs without paired data.
AI.motivation: Addresses the lack of paired training data and domain gaps between downscaling models and reanalysis, and counters zero-shot methods' physical inconsistencies and gradient issues under large scaling.
AI.method: Zero-Shot Statistical Downscaling (ZSSD) uses a Physics-Consistent Climate Prior learned from reanalysis data, conditioned on geophysical boundaries and temporal information, plus Unified Coordinate Guidance to mitigate vanishing gradients and enforce consistency with large-scale fields, enabling training without paired data across diverse GCMs.
AI.result: Outperforms existing zero-shot baselines in 99th percentile error reductions and reconstructs complex weather events like tropical cyclones across heterogeneous GCMs.
AI.conclusion: ZSSD offers a viable zero-shot path for physically valid, cross-GCM downscaling, improving extreme-event reconstruction and generalization without paired data; further validation across more GCMs and explicit physical constraint analyses would strengthen the claim.

title: DA-SPS: A Dual-stage Network based on Singular Spectrum Analysis, Patching-strategy and Spearman-correlation for Multivariate Time-series Prediction
comment: 12 pages, 7 figures, 6 tables, submitted to IEEE Transactions on Emerging Topics in Computational Intelligence
summary: Multivariate time-series forecasting, as a typical problem in the field of time series prediction, has a wide range of applications in weather forecasting, traffic flow prediction, and other scenarios. However, existing works do not effectively consider the impact of extraneous variables on the prediction of the target variable. On the other hand, they fail to fully extract complex sequence information based on various time patterns of the sequences. To address these drawbacks, we propose a DA-SPS model, which adopts different modules for feature extraction based on the information characteristics of different variables. DA-SPS mainly consists of two stages: the target variable processing stage (TVPS) and the extraneous variables processing stage (EVPS). In TVPS, the model first uses Singular Spectrum Analysis (SSA) to process the target variable sequence and then uses Long Short-Term Memory (LSTM) and P-Conv-LSTM which deploys a patching strategy to extract features from trend and seasonality components, respectively. In EVPS, the model filters extraneous variables that have a strong correlation with the target variate by using Spearman correlation analysis and further analyses them using the L-Attention module which consists of LSTM and attention mechanism. Finally, the results obtained by TVPS and EVPS are combined through weighted summation and linear mapping to produce the final prediction. The results on four public datasets demonstrate that the DA-SPS model outperforms existing state-of-the-art methods. Additionally, its performance in real-world scenarios is further validated using a private dataset collected by ourselves, which contains the test items' information on laptop motherboards.

AI.tldr: DA-SPS: a two-stage, variable-aware framework for multivariate time-series forecasting that separates target and extraneous variables for specialized processing and combines results for improved accuracy.
AI.motivation: Addresses limitations of existing models that ignore extraneous variable effects and fail to exploit complex time-pattern information across sequences.
AI.method: Two-stage design: TVPS processes the target through SSA, LSTM, and P-Conv-LSTM to capture trend and seasonality; EVPS selects extraneous variables via Spearman correlation and analyzes them with an L-Attention module (LSTM + attention). Final prediction is obtained by weighted summation and linear mapping of TVPS and EVPS outputs.
AI.result: Demonstrates superior performance on four public datasets compared to state-of-the-art methods and validates applicability on a private laptop motherboard dataset.
AI.conclusion: DA-SPS effectively leverages both target and correlated extraneous variables with tailored feature extractors, yielding robust multivariate forecasting across datasets and real-world data.

title: Abstract Concept Modelling in Conceptual Spaces: A Study on Chess Strategies
summary: We present a conceptual space framework for modelling abstract concepts that unfold over time, demonstrated through a chess-based proof-of-concept. Strategy concepts, such as attack or sacrifice, are represented as geometric regions across interpretable quality dimensions, with chess games instantiated and analysed as trajectories whose directional movement toward regions enables recognition of intended strategies. This approach also supports dual-perspective modelling, capturing how players interpret identical situations differently. Our implementation demonstrates the feasibility of trajectory-based concept recognition, with movement patterns aligning with expert commentary. This work explores extending the conceptual spaces theory to temporally realised, goal-directed concepts. The approach establishes a foundation for broader applications involving sequential decision-making and supports integration with knowledge evolution mechanisms for learning and refining abstract concepts over time.

AI.tldr: A conceptual spaces framework models temporally evolving abstract concepts (e.g., chess strategies) as geometric regions in interpretable quality dimensions, with game trajectories used to recognize strategies. It supports dual perspectives and shows feasibility for trajectory-based concept recognition, forming a foundation for temporally realized, goal-directed concepts and sequential decision-making applications.
AI.motivation: Extend conceptual spaces to temporally realized, goal-directed concepts and enable recognition of evolving abstract strategies in sequential decision tasks (illustrated via chess), addressing interpretation diversity and learning of concepts over time.
AI.method: Abstract concepts (like attack or sacrifice) are represented as geometric regions in a space of interpretable quality dimensions. Chess games are instantiated as trajectories through this space; the directional movement toward regions indicates the intended strategy. The framework supports dual-perspective modelling to capture different interpretations, and results are compared to expert commentary.
AI.result: The approach demonstrates feasibility: movement patterns of games align with expert commentary, dual-perspective modelling is viable, and the method provides a tractable path toward trajectory-based concept recognition in temporally structured settings.
AI.conclusion: This work establishes a foundation for temporally realized, goal-directed concepts within the conceptual spaces framework and points toward broader applications in sequential decision-making, with potential integration into knowledge evolution mechanisms for learning and refining abstract concepts over time.

title: Urban Neural Surface Reconstruction from Constrained Sparse Aerial Imagery with 3D SAR Fusion
summary: Neural surface reconstruction (NSR) has recently shown strong potential for urban 3D reconstruction from multi-view aerial imagery. However, existing NSR methods often suffer from geometric ambiguity and instability, particularly under sparse-view conditions. This issue is critical in large-scale urban remote sensing, where aerial image acquisition is limited by flight paths, terrain, and cost. To address this challenge, we present the first urban NSR framework that fuses 3D synthetic aperture radar (SAR) point clouds with aerial imagery for high-fidelity reconstruction under constrained, sparse-view settings. 3D SAR can efficiently capture large-scale geometry even from a single side-looking flight path, providing robust priors that complement photometric cues from images. Our framework integrates radar-derived spatial constraints into an SDF-based NSR backbone, guiding structure-aware ray selection and adaptive sampling for stable and efficient optimization. We also construct the first benchmark dataset with co-registered 3D SAR point clouds and aerial imagery, facilitating systematic evaluation of cross-modal 3D reconstruction. Extensive experiments show that incorporating 3D SAR markedly enhances reconstruction accuracy, completeness, and robustness compared with single-modality baselines under highly sparse and oblique-view conditions, highlighting a viable route toward scalable high-fidelity urban reconstruction with advanced airborne and spaceborne optical-SAR sensing.

AI.tldr: A cross-modal urban NSR method that fuses 3D SAR point clouds with aerial imagery to achieve high-fidelity reconstruction under sparse views, using an SDF-based backbone with radar priors and a new co-registered SAR-Optical dataset; shows improved accuracy, completeness, and robustness over image-only baselines.
AI.motivation: Neural surface reconstruction in urban settings is ill-posed under sparse-view aerial imagery, leading to geometric ambiguity and instability. 3D SAR offers geometry that is robust to view direction and can complement optical cues, motivating a cross-modal NSR framework.
AI.method: Integrate radar-derived spatial constraints into an SDF-based NSR backbone, guiding structure-aware ray selection and adaptive sampling. Construct a co-registered 3D SAR point clouds dataset with aerial imagery and evaluate cross-modal 3D reconstruction performance under sparse, oblique views.
AI.result: SAR priors improve reconstruction accuracy, completeness, and robustness in highly sparse and oblique-view conditions when fused with imagery, outperforming single-modality baselines.
AI.conclusion: Cross-modal fusion of 3D SAR with aerial imagery in an SDF-based NSR framework is a viable path for scalable, high-fidelity urban reconstruction in constrained data regimes; the dataset enables systematic cross-modal evaluation and will facilitate further research.

title: Sim-MSTNet: sim2real based Multi-task SpatioTemporal Network Traffic Forecasting
summary: Network traffic forecasting plays a crucial role in intelligent network operations, but existing techniques often perform poorly when faced with limited data. Additionally, multi-task learning methods struggle with task imbalance and negative transfer, especially when modeling various service types. To overcome these challenges, we propose Sim-MSTNet, a multi-task spatiotemporal network traffic forecasting model based on the sim2real approach. Our method leverages a simulator to generate synthetic data, effectively addressing the issue of poor generalization caused by data scarcity. By employing a domain randomization technique, we reduce the distributional gap between synthetic and real data through bi-level optimization of both sample weighting and model training. Moreover, Sim-MSTNet incorporates attention-based mechanisms to selectively share knowledge between tasks and applies dynamic loss weighting to balance task objectives. Extensive experiments on two open-source datasets show that Sim-MSTNet consistently outperforms state-of-the-art baselines, achieving enhanced accuracy and generalization.

AI.tldr: Sim-MSTNet uses sim-to-real with domain randomization to train a multi-task spatiotemporal network for traffic forecasting under data scarcity and task imbalance, employing sample-weighted and model-training bi-level optimization, attention-based cross-task sharing, and dynamic loss weighting; it outperforms baselines on two datasets with better generalization.
AI.motivation: Address poor generalization due to limited data and negative transfer/imbalance in multi-task traffic forecasting across diverse service types.
AI.method: Train a multi-task spatiotemporal network (MSTNet) using synthetic data from a simulator; apply domain randomization via bi-level optimization to tune sample weighting and model training; use attention mechanisms to selectively share knowledge across tasks; employ dynamic loss weighting to balance task objectives.
AI.result: Extensive experiments on two open-source datasets show consistent improvements over state-of-the-art baselines in accuracy and generalization.
AI.conclusion: Sim-MSTNet effectively mitigates data scarcity and task imbalance in multi-task traffic forecasting through sim2real, domain randomization, and adaptive sharing/weighting mechanisms, yielding superior performance.

title: BioAgent Bench: An AI Agent Evaluation Suite for Bioinformatics
summary: This paper introduces BioAgent Bench, a benchmark dataset and an evaluation suite designed for measuring the performance and robustness of AI agents in common bioinformatics tasks. The benchmark contains curated end-to-end tasks (e.g., RNA-seq, variant calling, metagenomics) with prompts that specify concrete output artifacts to support automated assessment, including stress testing under controlled perturbations. We evaluate frontier closed-source and open-weight models across multiple agent harnesses, and use an LLM-based grader to score pipeline progress and outcome validity. We find that frontier agents can complete multi-step bioinformatics pipelines without elaborate custom scaffolding, often producing the requested final artifacts reliably. However, robustness tests reveal failure modes under controlled perturbations (corrupted inputs, decoy files, and prompt bloat), indicating that correct high-level pipeline construction does not guarantee reliable step-level reasoning. Finally, because bioinformatics workflows may involve sensitive patient data, proprietary references, or unpublished IP, closed-source models can be unsuitable under strict privacy constraints; in such settings, open-weight models may be preferable despite lower completion rates. We release the dataset and evaluation suite publicly.

AI.tldr: BioAgent Bench provides a benchmark and evaluation suite for assessing AI agents on bioinformatics pipelines, emphasizing end-to-end task performance and robustness under perturbations; findings show agents can complete pipelines but may fail at step-level reasoning under perturbations; privacy concerns favor open-weight models; dataset released publicly.
AI.motivation: Address the need for standardized, reproducible evaluation of AI agents in bioinformatics workflows and to investigate robustness and privacy implications across model types.
AI.method: Curated end-to-end tasks (RNA-seq, variant calling, metagenomics) with concrete prompts for automated assessment; stress-testing via controlled perturbations (corrupted inputs, decoy files, prompt bloat); evaluation across frontier closed-source and open-weight models using multiple agent harnesses; LLM-based grader scores pipeline progress and outcome validity.
AI.result: Frontier agents can complete multi-step pipelines without elaborate scaffolding and often produce final artifacts reliably. Robustness tests reveal failure modes under perturbations; high-level pipeline construction does not guarantee reliable step-level reasoning. Closed data constraints may limit use; in privacy-sensitive settings open-weight models may be preferable despite lower completion rates.
AI.conclusion: Dataset and evaluation suite are released publicly, enabling reproducible assessment; privacy considerations may drive choice toward open-weight models in sensitive bioinformatics contexts, highlighting trade-offs between completion rates and data confidentiality.

title: PLANING: A Loosely Coupled Triangle-Gaussian Framework for Streaming 3D Reconstruction
summary: Streaming reconstruction from monocular image sequences remains challenging, as existing methods typically favor either high-quality rendering or accurate geometry, but rarely both. We present PLANING, an efficient on-the-fly reconstruction framework built on a hybrid representation that loosely couples explicit geometric primitives with neural Gaussians, enabling geometry and appearance to be modeled in a decoupled manner. This decoupling supports an online initialization and optimization strategy that separates geometry and appearance updates, yielding stable streaming reconstruction with substantially reduced structural redundancy. PLANING improves dense mesh Chamfer-L2 by 18.52% over PGSR, surpasses ARTDECO by 1.31 dB PSNR, and reconstructs ScanNetV2 scenes in under 100 seconds, over 5x faster than 2D Gaussian Splatting, while matching the quality of offline per-scene optimization. Beyond reconstruction quality, the structural clarity and computational efficiency of \modelname~make it well suited for a broad range of downstream applications, such as enabling large-scale scene modeling and simulation-ready environments for embodied AI. Project page: https://city-super.github.io/PLANING/ .

AI.tldr: PLANING is a real-time monocular streaming reconstruction framework that decouples geometry and appearance via a hybrid representation of explicit primitives and neural Gaussians, enabling online initialization/optimization and efficient, high-quality reconstruction.
AI.motivation: Streaming monocular reconstruction must balance accurate geometry with high-quality rendering in real time; existing methods often specialize in one aspect and require offline optimization, leading to redundancy and latency. A decoupled representation with online updates can improve stability and efficiency.
AI.method: Hybrid representation combining explicit geometric primitives with neural Gaussians; decoupled geometry and appearance updates; online initialization and optimization to reduce redundancy and enable streaming reconstruction; evaluation on ScanNetV2 against baselines like PGSR, ARTDECO, and Gauss Splatting.
AI.result: Dense mesh Chamfer-L2 improved by 18.52% over PGSR; PSNR improved by 1.31 dB over ARTDECO; reconstructs ScanNetV2 scenes in under 100 seconds, over 5x faster than 2D Gaussian Splatting; achieves comparable quality to offline per-scene optimization.
AI.conclusion: PLANING delivers efficient, stable online 3D reconstruction with clear geometry and appearance modeling, enabling large-scale scene modeling and simulation-ready environments for embodied AI; demonstrated gains in speed and quality and applicability to downstream tasks.

title: A Unified XAI-LLM Approach for EndotrachealSuctioning Activity Recognition
summary: Endotracheal suctioning (ES) is an invasive yet essential clinical procedure that requires a high degree of skill to minimize patient risk - particularly in home care and educational settings, where consistent supervision may be limited.
