It uses a four-stage pipeline (supervised warmup, MCTS-based Process Reward Model, PRM-guided reasoning refinement, and process-supervised RL with a dual-granularity mechanism) and demonstrates superior performance on five benchmarks with available code.
AI.motivation: Outcome-based RL on complex RAG tasks suffers from reward sparsity and weak credit assignment to individual reasoning steps, leading to process hallucinations where correct answers arise from flawed reasoning. Existing process-aware methods lack on-policy exploration and fine-grained feedback necessary to decouple step-level credit from global outcomes.
AI.method: Four-stage framework: (1) Supervised Policy Warmup to initialize reasoning structure; (2) construct an MCTS-based Process Reward Model (PRM) to quantify intermediate reasoning quality; (3) PRM-Guided Reasoning Refinement to align policy with fine-grained process preferences; (4) Process-Supervised Reinforcement Learning with a dual-granularity advantage mechanism that aggregates step-level process rewards with global outcome signals, enabling on-policy exploration and precise action-wise feedback.
AI.result: Empirical evaluation on five multi-hop reasoning benchmarks shows ProRAG achieves superior performance compared to strong outcome-based and process-aware RL baselines, with pronounced gains on long-horizon tasks; results validate the effectiveness of fine-grained process supervision.
AI.conclusion: Integrating step-level supervision into the online RL loop yields precise, per-action feedback that reduces process hallucinations and improves complex reasoning in RAG. ProRAG's dual-granularity approach and PRM-guided refinement offer a robust pathway for enhancing long-horizon tasks; code is publicly available.

title: PI-Light: Physics-Inspired Diffusion for Full-Image Relighting
summary: Full-image relighting remains a challenging problem due to the difficulty of collecting large-scale structured paired data, the difficulty of maintaining physical plausibility, and the limited generalizability imposed by data-driven priors. Existing attempts to bridge the synthetic-to-real gap for full-scene relighting remain suboptimal. To tackle these challenges, we introduce Physics-Inspired diffusion for full-image reLight ($π$-Light, or PI-Light), a two-stage framework that leverages physics-inspired diffusion models. Our design incorporates (i) batch-aware attention, which improves the consistency of intrinsic predictions across a collection of images, (ii) a physics-guided neural rendering module that enforces physically plausible light transport, (iii) physics-inspired losses that regularize training dynamics toward a physically meaningful landscape, thereby enhancing generalizability to real-world image editing, and (iv) a carefully curated dataset of diverse objects and scenes captured under controlled lighting conditions. Together, these components enable efficient finetuning of pretrained diffusion models while also providing a solid benchmark for downstream evaluation. Experiments demonstrate that $π$-Light synthesizes specular highlights and diffuse reflections across a wide variety of materials, achieving superior generalization to real-world scenes compared with prior approaches.

AI.tldr: PI-Light is a two-stage physics-inspired diffusion framework for full-image relighting, using batch-aware attention, physics-guided neural rendering, physics-based losses, and a curated dataset, to finetune diffusion models efficiently and generalize to real-world scenes, outperforming prior methods in specular/diffuse rendering.
AI.motivation: Full-image relighting is hampered by scarce structured paired data, lack of physical plausibility, and poor generalization due to data-driven priors; bridging synthetic-to-real gaps remains suboptimal.
AI.method: Two-stage diffusion framework; batch-aware attention for intrinsic consistency; physics-guided neural rendering enforcing light transport physics; physics-inspired losses regularizing training dynamics; curated controlled-lighting dataset; efficient finetuning of pretrained diffusion models.
AI.result: PI-Light produces specular highlights and diffuse reflections across diverse materials and scenes, with superior real-world generalization relative to prior approaches.
AI.conclusion: Integrating physics-inspired priors into diffusion-based full-image relighting yields better physical plausibility and generalization, with a practical benchmark and dataset for evaluation.

title: HER: Human-like Reasoning and Reinforcement Learning for LLM Role-playing
summary: LLM role-playing, i.e., using LLMs to simulate specific personas, has emerged as a key capability in various applications, such as companionship, content creation, and digital games. While current models effectively capture character tones and knowledge, simulating the inner thoughts behind their behaviors remains a challenge. Towards cognitive simulation in LLM role-play, previous efforts mainly suffer from two deficiencies: data with high-quality reasoning traces, and reliable reward signals aligned with human preferences. In this paper, we propose HER, a unified framework for cognitive-level persona simulation. HER introduces dual-layer thinking, which distinguishes characters' first-person thinking from LLMs' third-person thinking. To bridge these gaps, we curate reasoning-augmented role-playing data via reverse engineering and construct human-aligned principles and reward models. Leveraging these resources, we train \method models based on Qwen3-32B via supervised and reinforcement learning. Extensive experiments validate the effectiveness of our approach. Notably, our models significantly outperform the Qwen3-32B baseline, achieving a 30.26 improvement on the CoSER benchmark and a 14.97 gain on the Minimax Role-Play Bench. Our datasets, principles, and models will be released to facilitate future research.

AI.tldr: Proposes HER, a cognitive-level persona simulation framework for LLM role-play using dual-layer thinking, reasoning-augmented data, and reward models; achieves significant gains on CoSER and Minimax Role-Play Bench and will release datasets/models.
AI.motivation: To enable inner-thought-like cognitive simulation in LLM role-play beyond surface-level persona control, addressing the lack of high-quality reasoning traces and reliable reward signals.
AI.method: Introduce dual-layer thinking (first-person vs. third-person), curate reasoning-augmented data via reverse engineering, develop human-aligned principles and reward models, train HER-based models on Qwen3-32B with supervised learning and reinforcement learning.
AI.result: Outperforms Qwen3-32B baseline; 30.26 improvement on the CoSER benchmark and a 14.97 gain on the Minimax Role-Play Bench.
AI.conclusion: Claims effectiveness of cognitive-level persona simulation; contributes datasets, principles, and models to the research community to advance reproducibility and future work.

title: JADE: Bridging the Strategic-Operational Gap in Dynamic Agentic RAG
summary: The evolution of Retrieval-Augmented Generation (RAG) has shifted from static retrieval pipelines to dynamic, agentic workflows where a central planner orchestrates multi-turn reasoning. However, existing paradigms face a critical dichotomy: they either optimize modules jointly within rigid, fixed-graph architectures, or empower dynamic planning while treating executors as frozen, black-box tools. We identify that this \textit{decoupled optimization} creates a ``strategic-operational mismatch,'' where sophisticated planning strategies fail to materialize due to unadapted local executors, often leading to negative performance gains despite increased system complexity. In this paper, we propose \textbf{JADE} (\textbf{J}oint \textbf{A}gentic \textbf{D}ynamic \textbf{E}xecution), a unified framework for the joint optimization of planning and execution within dynamic, multi-turn workflows. By modeling the system as a cooperative multi-agent team unified under a single shared backbone, JADE enables end-to-end learning driven by outcome-based rewards. This approach facilitates \textit{co-adaptation}: the planner learns to operate within the capability boundaries of the executors, while the executors evolve to align with high-level strategic intent. Empirical results demonstrate that JADE transforms disjoint modules into a synergistic system, yielding remarkable performance improvements via joint optimization and enabling a flexible balance between efficiency and effectiveness through dynamic workflow orchestration.

AI.tldr: JADE unifies planning and execution in Retrieval-Augmented Generation by joint optimization on a shared backbone, addressing decoupled optimization and enabling co-adaptation for improved performance.
AI.motivation: Decoupled optimization creates a strategic-operational mismatch where planning strategies fail to materialize due to unadapted executors, leading to suboptimal or negative gains despite increased complexity.
AI.method: Model the system as a cooperative multi-agent team with a single shared backbone, enabling end-to-end learning with outcome-based rewards to jointly optimize planning and execution in dynamic, multi-turn workflows.
AI.result: Empirical results show that JADE turns disjoint modules into a synergistic system, achieving notable performance gains and allowing a flexible balance between efficiency and effectiveness through dynamic workflow orchestration.
AI.conclusion: Joint optimization yields co-adaptation between planners and executors, transforming modular components into a cohesive, high-performing system.

title: Do VLMs Perceive or Recall? Probing Visual Perception vs. Memory with Classic Visual Illusions
comment: 26 pages, 31 figures, 13 tables. Project Page: https://sites.google.com/view/vi-probe/
summary: Large Vision-Language Models (VLMs) often answer classic visual illusions "correctly" on original images, yet persist with the same responses when illusion factors are inverted, even though the visual change is obvious to humans. This raises a fundamental question: do VLMs perceive visual changes or merely recall memorized patterns? While several studies have noted this phenomenon, the underlying causes remain unclear. To move from observations to systematic understanding, this paper introduces VI-Probe, a controllable visual-illusion framework with graded perturbations and matched visual controls (without illusion inducer) that disentangles visually grounded perception from language-driven recall. Unlike prior work that focuses on averaged accuracy, we measure stability and sensitivity using Polarity-Flip Consistency, Template Fixation Index, and an illusion multiplier normalized against matched controls. Experiments across different families reveal that response persistence arises from heterogeneous causes rather than a single mechanism. For instance, GPT-5 exhibits memory override, Claude-Opus-4.1 shows perception-memory competition, while Qwen variants suggest visual-processing limits. Our findings challenge single-cause views and motivate probing-based evaluation that measures both knowledge and sensitivity to controlled visual change. Data and code are available at https://sites.google.com/view/vi-probe/.

AI.tldr: VI-Probe introduces a controllable visual-illusion framework to discern whether VLMs rely on visually grounded perception or memory recall, revealing heterogeneous, model-dependent causes across GPT-5, Claude-Opus-4.1, and Qwen variants.
AI.motivation: To move beyond averaged accuracy in studying illusion robustness of large vision-language models and to disentangle visual perception from language-driven recall by controlled perturbations and matched controls.
AI.method: Proposes VI-Probe with graded perturbations and matched (no illusion inducer) controls. Measures stability and sensitivity via Polarity-Flip Consistency, Template Fixation Index, and an illusion multiplier normalized to controls. Evaluates multiple model families (GPT-5, Claude-Opus-4.1, Qwen variants).
AI.result: Reveals multiple, heterogeneous causes for response persistence: memory override (GPT-5), perception-memory competition (Claude-Opus-4.1), and visual-processing limits (Qwen variants). Challenges single-cause explanations and supports probing-based evaluation that captures both knowledge and sensitivity to controlled visual changes.
AI.conclusion: Advocates a probing framework for assessing VLM visual robustness, with publicly available data/code, enabling systematic separation of knowledge and perceptual sensitivity; highlights the need for multi-cause analysis and model-specific behavior.

title: L$^3$: Large Lookup Layers
summary: Modern sparse language models typically achieve sparsity through Mixture-of-Experts (MoE) layers, which dynamically route tokens to dense MLP "experts." However, dynamic hard routing has a number of drawbacks, such as potentially poor hardware efficiency and needing auxiliary losses for stable training. In contrast, the tokenizer embedding table, which is natively sparse, largely avoids these issues by selecting a single embedding per token at the cost of not having contextual information. In this work, we introduce the Large Lookup Layer (L$^3$), which unlocks a new axis of sparsity by generalizing embedding tables to model decoder layers. L$^3$ layers use static token-based routing to aggregate a set of learned embeddings per token in a context-dependent way, allowing the model to efficiently balance memory and compute by caching information in embeddings. L$^3$ has two main components: (1) a systems-friendly architecture that allows for fast training and CPU-offloaded inference with no overhead, and (2) an information-theoretic embedding allocation algorithm that effectively balances speed and quality. We empirically test L$^3$ by training transformers with up to 2.6B active parameters and find that L$^3$ strongly outperforms both dense models and iso-sparse MoEs in both language modeling and downstream tasks.

AI.tldr: L3 generalizes embedding tables to model decoder layers with static, token-based routing to a set of learned embeddings per token, creating a new sparsity axis that balances memory and compute; supported by a systems-friendly design and an information-theoretic allocation algorithm, achieving strong gains over dense and iso-sparse MoEs on language modeling and downstream tasks.
AI.motivation: Mitigate drawbacks of dynamic MoE routing (hardware inefficiency, need for auxiliary training losses) and overcome the context-limited nature of single-token embeddings by introducing contextualized, token-specific embedding aggregations for decoders.
AI.method: Introduce Large Lookup Layer (L3) with two components: (1) a systems-friendly architecture enabling fast training and CPU-offloaded inference with no overhead, and (2) an information-theoretic embedding allocation algorithm that balances speed and quality. L3 replaces or augments decoder layers by aggregating a per-token set of embeddings in a context-dependent manner. Empirically evaluated on transformers up to 2.6B parameters, comparing against dense baselines and iso-sparse MoEs across language modeling and downstream tasks.
AI.result: L3 outperforms both dense models and iso-sparse MoEs in language modeling and downstream tasks, demonstrating efficient sparsity-enabled scaling and favorable compute/memory tradeoffs.
AI.conclusion: L3 provides a viable, context-aware sparsity mechanism for decoder layers beyond traditional dense or MoE architectures. It combines static token routing with learned embeddings and a systems-focused design to enable efficient training and CPU-offloaded inference, showing strong empirical gains and scalability.

title: Self-Compression of Chain-of-Thought via Multi-Agent Reinforcement Learning
summary: The inference overhead induced by redundant reasoning undermines the interactive experience and severely bottlenecks the deployment of Large Reasoning Models. Existing reinforcement learning (RL)-based solutions tackle this problem by coupling a length penalty with outcome-based rewards. This simplistic reward weighting struggles to reconcile brevity with accuracy, as enforcing brevity may compromise critical reasoning logic. In this work, we address this limitation by proposing a multi-agent RL framework that selectively penalizes redundant chunks, while preserving essential reasoning logic. Our framework, Self-Compression via MARL (SCMA), instantiates redundancy detection and evaluation through two specialized agents: \textbf{a Segmentation Agent} for decomposing the reasoning process into logical chunks, and \textbf{a Scoring Agent} for quantifying the significance of each chunk. The Segmentation and Scoring agents collaboratively define an importance-weighted length penalty during training, incentivizing \textbf{a Reasoning Agent} to prioritize essential logic without introducing inference overhead during deployment. Empirical evaluations across model scales demonstrate that SCMA reduces response length by 11.1\% to 39.0\% while boosting accuracy by 4.33\% to 10.02\%. Furthermore, ablation studies and qualitative analysis validate that the synergistic optimization within the MARL framework fosters emergent behaviors, yielding more powerful LRMs compared to vanilla RL paradigms.

AI.tldr: SCMA introduces a two-agent MARL framework to prune redundant reasoning chunks without sacrificing essential logic, leading to shorter responses and higher accuracy compared to vanilla RL.
AI.motivation: Inference overhead from redundant reasoning degrades interactivity and scalability of Large Reasoning Models. Existing RL approaches with simple length penalties fail to balance brevity with correctness.
AI.method: A multi-agent setup with a Segmentation Agent that splits reasoning into chunks and a Scoring Agent that evaluates each chunk's importance. These agents define an importance-weighted length penalty used during training to guide a Reasoning Agent, aiming to reduce deploy-time overhead while preserving essential logic.
AI.result: Empirical results show 11.1%–39.0% reduction in response length and 4.33%–10.02% improvements in accuracy across model scales. Ablations and qualitative analyses indicate emergent, better LRMs under MARL than vanilla RL.
AI.conclusion: A carefully designed MARL collaboration can achieve efficient, accurate reasoning by penalizing redundant chunks proportionally to their importance, enabling deployment-friendly inference without sacrificing reasoning quality.

title: UEval: A Benchmark for Unified Multimodal Generation
summary: We introduce UEval, a benchmark to evaluate unified models, i.e., models capable of generating both images and text. UEval comprises 1,000 expert-curated questions that require both images and text in the model output, sourced from 8 real-world tasks. Our curated questions cover a wide range of reasoning types, from step-by-step guides to textbook explanations. Evaluating open-ended multimodal generation is non-trivial, as simple LLM-as-a-judge methods can miss the subtleties. Different from previous works that rely on multimodal Large Language Models (MLLMs) to rate image quality or text accuracy, we design a rubric-based scoring system in UEval. For each question, reference images and text answers are provided to a MLLM to generate an initial rubric, consisting of multiple evaluation criteria, and human experts then refine and validate these rubrics. In total, UEval contains 10,417 validated rubric criteria, enabling scalable and fine-grained automatic scoring. UEval is challenging for current unified models: GPT-5-Thinking scores only 66.4 out of 100, while the best open-source model reaches merely 49.1. We observe that reasoning models often outperform non-reasoning ones, and transferring reasoning traces from a reasoning model to a non-reasoning model significantly narrows the gap. This suggests that reasoning may be important for tasks requiring complex multimodal understanding and generation.

AI.tldr: UEval is a new benchmark for unified image-and-text models, featuring 1,000 questions requiring outputs in both modalities and 10,417 rubric criteria derived via rubric design and human validation. It uses a rubric-based scoring system (not LLM-only judgments) to enable fine-grained automatic scoring. Results show current models lag behind; reasoning capabilities boost performance and transferring reasoning traces helps weaker models.
AI.motivation: Evaluate open-ended multimodal generation beyond simple LLM-based judgments; existing metrics either separate image/text evaluation or rely on LLMs for scoring, which can miss subtleties. A need for a scalable, fine-grained, rubric-based evaluation for unified models.
AI.method: Select 1,000 expert-curated questions from 8 real-world tasks requiring both images and text. Provide reference images and text answers to a multimodal LLM (MLLM) to generate an initial rubric with multiple criteria. Have human experts refine and validate the rubrics, yielding 10,417 validated criteria. Use these rubrics for scalable automatic scoring of model outputs.
AI.result: GPT-5-Thinking scores 66.4/100; best open-source model 49.1. Reasoning models outperform non-reasoning ones, and transferring reasoning traces from a reasoning model to a non-reasoning model narrows the gap, indicating reasoning is beneficial for complex multimodal tasks.
AI.conclusion: Reasoning is important for complex multimodal understanding and generation. UEval provides a challenging, rubric-based benchmark and demonstrates that leveraging reasoning capabilities and fine-grained rubrics can better evaluate unified models and guide future improvements.

title: Partial Feedback Online Learning
summary: We study partial-feedback online learning, where each instance admits a set of correct labels, but the learner only observes one correct label per round; any prediction within the correct set is counted as correct. This model captures settings such as language generation, where multiple responses may be valid but data provide only a single reference. We give a near-complete characterization of minimax regret for both deterministic and randomized learners in the set-realizable regime, i.e., in the regime where sublinear regret is generally attainable. For deterministic learners, we introduce the Partial-Feedback Littlestone dimension (PFLdim) and show it precisely governs learnability and minimax regret; technically, PFLdim cannot be defined via the standard version space, requiring a new collection version space viewpoint and an auxiliary dimension used only in the proof. We further develop the Partial-Feedback Measure Shattering dimension (PMSdim) to obtain tight bounds for randomized learners. We identify broad conditions ensuring inseparability between deterministic and randomized learnability (e.g., finite Helly number or nested-inclusion label structure), and extend the argument to set-valued online learning, resolving an open question of Raman et al. [2024b]. Finally, we show a sharp separation from weaker realistic and agnostic variants: outside set realizability, the problem can become information-theoretically intractable, with linear regret possible even for $|H|=2$. This highlights the need for fundamentally new, noise-sensitive complexity measures to meaningfully characterize learnability beyond set realizability.

AI.tldr: Near-complete minimax regret characterization for partial-feedback online learning under set realizability; introduces deterministic PFLdim and randomized PMSdim, with a collection-version-space framework; establishes separations between deterministic and randomized learnability; extends to set-valued learning and resolves an open question; shows hardness outside realizability and motivates new noise-sensitive complexity measures.
AI.motivation: In many real tasks (e.g., language generation), multiple outputs can be correct, but data provide only one reference. The partial-feedback model captures this and prompts a refinement of learnability/complexity notions.
AI.method: Develop a new collection-based version-space viewpoint. Define Partial-Feedback Littlestone dimension (PFLdim) for deterministic learners and Partial-Feedback Measure Shattering dimension (PMSdim) for randomized learners. Prove tight minimax regret bounds in the set-realizable regime. Identify conditions (e.g., finite Helly number, nested-inclusion label structure) that cause deterministic and randomized learnability to diverge. Extend to set-valued online learning and resolve Raman et al. 2024b. Compare with weaker realizability and agnostic models.
AI.result: PFLdim exactly characterizes learnability and minimax regret for deterministic learners; PMSdim yields tight bounds for randomized learners. The paper provides a sharp separation between deterministic and randomized learnability under broad conditions. It extends to set-valued predictions, resolving an open question. Outside set realizability, linear regret is possible even for |H|=2, indicating intractability with respect to traditional measures, and signaling the need for new noise-sensitive complexity benchmarks.
AI.conclusion: The standard version-space framework is insufficient in partial-feedback settings. The introduced PFLdim and PMSdim capture the essential complexity, enabling sharp regret bounds and separations. Outside set realizability, learnability becomes information-theoretically constrained, underscoring the necessity for new analytic tools in online learning with partial feedback.

title: AgenticSimLaw: A Juvenile Courtroom Multi-Agent Debate Simulation for Explainable High-Stakes Tabular Decision Making
summary: We introduce AgenticSimLaw, a role-structured, multi-agent debate framework that provides transparent and controllable test-time reasoning for high-stakes tabular decision-making tasks. Unlike black-box approaches, our courtroom-style orchestration explicitly defines agent roles (prosecutor, defense, judge), interaction protocols (7-turn structured debate), and private reasoning strategies, creating a fully auditable decision-making process. We benchmark this framework on young adult recidivism prediction using the NLSY97 dataset, comparing it against traditional chain-of-thought (CoT) prompting across almost 90 unique combinations of models and strategies. Our results demonstrate that structured multi-agent debate provides more stable and generalizable performance compared to single-agent reasoning, with stronger correlation between accuracy and F1-score metrics. Beyond performance improvements, AgenticSimLaw offers fine-grained control over reasoning steps, generates complete interaction transcripts for explainability, and enables systematic profiling of agent behaviors. While we instantiate this framework in the criminal justice domain to stress-test reasoning under ethical complexity, the approach generalizes to any deliberative, high-stakes decision task requiring transparency and human oversight. This work addresses key LLM-based multi-agent system challenges: organization through structured roles, observability through logged interactions, and responsibility through explicit non-deployment constraints for sensitive domains. Data, results, and code will be available on github.com under the MIT license.

AI.tldr: AgenticSimLaw presents a role-structured, 7-turn multi-agent debate framework for high-stakes tabular decisions, claiming improved stability and generalization over chain-of-thought prompting, with full transcripts and auditable reasoning; applied to recidivism prediction on NLSY97 and released under MIT license.
AI.motivation: Tackle lack of transparency, controllability, and accountability in single-agent LLM reasoning for high-stakes decisions; enable auditable, ethical oversight through structured roles and transcripts; test generalizability across models/strategies.
AI.method: Define explicit agent roles (prosecutor, defense, judge), a 7-turn debate protocol, and private reasoning strategies; apply to young adult recidivism prediction using the NLSY97 dataset; compare against traditional chain-of-thought prompting across ~90 combinations of models and strategies; generate complete interaction transcripts and agent behavior profiles; release data, results, and code under MIT license.
AI.result: Structured multi-agent debate yields more stable and generalizable performance than single-agent reasoning; stronger correlation between accuracy and F1-score; provides fine-grained control over reasoning steps and auditable transcripts; enhances explainability and enables systematic profiling of agent behaviors; claim of generalizability beyond criminal justice; results benchmarked against CoT across many model/strategy combos.
AI.conclusion: AgenticSimLaw offers transparent, auditable decision-making with explicit roles and constraints for sensitive domains; applicable to any deliberative, high-stakes task requiring human oversight; addresses organizational, observability, and responsibility gaps in LLM-based multi-agent systems; code and data to be released on GitHub under MIT license.

title: One-step Latent-free Image Generation with Pixel Mean Flows
summary: Modern diffusion/flow-based models for image generation typically exhibit two core characteristics: (i) using multi-step sampling, and (ii) operating in a latent space. Recent advances have made encouraging progress on each aspect individually, paving the way toward one-step diffusion/flow without latents. In this work, we take a further step towards this goal and propose "pixel MeanFlow" (pMF). Our core guideline is to formulate the network output space and the loss space separately. The network target is designed to be on a presumed low-dimensional image manifold (i.e., x-prediction), while the loss is defined via MeanFlow in the velocity space. We introduce a simple transformation between the image manifold and the average velocity field. In experiments, pMF achieves strong results for one-step latent-free generation on ImageNet at 256x256 resolution (2.22 FID) and 512x512 resolution (2.48 FID), filling a key missing piece in this regime. We hope that our study will further advance the boundaries of diffusion/flow-based generative models.

AI.tldr: Introduces Pixel MeanFlow (pMF) for one-step latent-free image generation by predicting on a low-dimensional image manifold while training with a MeanFlow loss in velocity space; achieves competitive FID on ImageNet at 256x256 (2.22) and 512x512 (2.48).
AI.motivation: Reduce diffusion models to a single step without latent representations by decoupling the target manifold from the loss in velocity space; advance toward practical one-step generation.
AI.method: Formulate separate network output and loss spaces; define x-prediction target on the image manifold; define MeanFlow in velocity space; establish a transformation between image manifold and average velocity field; implement one-step generation without latent variables; evaluate on ImageNet at 256x256 and 512x512.
AI.result: Achieves FID 2.22 at 256x256 and 2.48 at 512x512 in a one-step latent-free setup; demonstrates viability of pMF approach.
AI.conclusion: pMF shows that decoupling target and loss spaces enables competitive one-step latent-free diffusion/flow; contributes a practical piece toward end-to-end one-step generation in the latent-free regime.

title: A block-coordinate descent framework for non-convex composite optimization. Application to sparse precision matrix estimation
summary: Block-coordinate descent (BCD) is the method of choice to solve numerous large scale optimization problems, however their theoretical study for non-convex optimization, has received less attention. In this paper, we present a new block-coordinate descent (BCD) framework to tackle non-convex composite optimization problems, ensuring decrease of the objective function and convergence to a solution. This framework is general enough to include variable metric proximal gradient updates, proximal Newton updates, and alternated minimization updates. This generality allows to encompass three versions of the most used solvers in the sparse precision matrix estimation problem, deemed Graphical Lasso: graphical ISTA, Primal GLasso, and QUIC. We demonstrate the value of this new framework on non-convex sparse precision matrix estimation problems, providing convergence guarantees and up to a $100$-fold reduction in the number of iterations required to reach state-of-the-art estimation quality.

AI.tldr: A universal block-coordinate descent framework for non-convex composite optimization is proposed, enabling variable-metric proximal-gradient, proximal-Newton, and alternating-minimization updates, and unifying Graphical Lasso solvers with significant empirical speedups.
AI.motivation: Non-convex BCD has limited theoretical understanding. A general framework is needed to ensure objective decrease and convergence while encompassing practical solvers for sparse precision matrix estimation.
AI.method: Introduce a general BCD framework for non-convex composite optimization that guarantees descent and convergence. The framework supports diverse update schemes—variable-metric proximal gradient, proximal Newton, and alternating minimization—and applies to Graphical Lasso variants (graphical ISTA, Primal GLasso, QUIC).
AI.result: The framework provides convergence guarantees and, on non-convex sparse precision matrix estimation problems, achieves up to 100× reduction in iterations to reach state-of-the-art estimation quality.
AI.conclusion: A flexible, efficient unifying framework for non-convex BCD is established, enabling faster solvers for sparse precision matrix estimation and broad applicability.

title: Retrieval-Infused Reasoning Sandbox: A Benchmark for Decoupling Retrieval and Reasoning Capabilities
summary: Despite strong performance on existing benchmarks, it remains unclear whether large language models can reason over genuinely novel scientific information. Most evaluations score end-to-end RAG pipelines, where reasoning is confounded with retrieval and toolchain choices, and the signal is further contaminated by parametric memorization and open-web volatility. We introduce DeR2, a controlled deep-research sandbox that isolates document-grounded reasoning while preserving core difficulties of deep search: multi-step synthesis, denoising, and evidence-based conclusion making. DeR2 decouples evidence access from reasoning via four regimes--Instruction-only, Concepts (gold concepts without documents), Related-only (only relevant documents), and Full-set (relevant documents plus topically related distractors)--yielding interpretable regime gaps that operationalize retrieval loss vs. reasoning loss and enable fine-grained error attribution. To prevent parametric leakage, we apply a two-phase validation that requires parametric failure without evidence while ensuring oracle-concept solvability. To ensure reproducibility, each instance provides a frozen document library (drawn from 2023-2025 theoretical papers) with expert-annotated concepts and validated rationales. Experiments across a diverse set of state-of-the-art foundation models reveal substantial variation and significant headroom: some models exhibit mode-switch fragility, performing worse with the Full-set than with Instruction-only, while others show structural concept misuse, correctly naming concepts but failing to execute them as procedures.

AI.tldr: Introduces DeR2 sandbox to isolate document-grounded reasoning from retrieval in LLM evaluation; uses four regimes; two-phase validation; reproducible doc library; reveals heterogeneity and headroom in model reasoning.
AI.motivation: Address confounds in end-to-end retrieval-augmented generation evaluations (retrieval quality, toolchain choices, memorization, open-web volatility) by providing a controlled setting that isolates reasoning over novel scientific information.
AI.method: Four regimes (Instruction-only, Concepts with gold concepts, Related-only with relevant documents, Full-set with relevant and topically related distractors); two-phase validation to prevent parametric leakage; frozen document library drawn from 2023-2025 theoretical papers with expert-annotated concepts and validated rationales; cross-model experiments on state-of-the-art foundation models to measure regime gaps and error attribution.
AI.result: Models show substantial variation and headroom: some exhibit mode-switch fragility (worse performance with Full-set than Instruction-only); others show structural concept misuse (correct concept names but struggle to execute them as procedures).
AI.conclusion: DeR2 enables interpretable, regime-based assessment of document-grounded reasoning, disentangling retrieval from reasoning and enabling fine-grained error attribution; highlights remaining gaps in genuine reasoning with novel scientific information and sets the stage for reproducible, controlled benchmarking.

title: PPI-SVRG: Unifying Prediction-Powered Inference and Variance Reduction for Semi-Supervised Optimization
summary: We study semi-supervised stochastic optimization when labeled data is scarce but predictions from pre-trained models are available. PPI and SVRG both reduce variance through control variates -- PPI uses predictions, SVRG uses reference gradients. We show they are mathematically equivalent and develop PPI-SVRG, which combines both. Our convergence bound decomposes into the standard SVRG rate plus an error floor from prediction uncertainty. The rate depends only on loss geometry; predictions affect only the neighborhood size. When predictions are perfect, we recover SVRG exactly. When predictions degrade, convergence remains stable but reaches a larger neighborhood. Experiments confirm the theory: PPI-SVRG reduces MSE by 43--52\% under label scarcity on mean estimation benchmarks and improves test accuracy by 2.7--2.9 percentage points on MNIST with only 10\% labeled data.

AI.tldr: Unifies PPI and SVRG for semi-supervised stochastic optimization with scarce labels; introduces PPI-SVRG; shows convergence bound with an error floor from prediction uncertainty; experiments show substantial MSE and accuracy gains under label scarcity.
AI.motivation: Leverage pre-trained model predictions to reduce variance in stochastic optimization when labeled data is scarce; reconcile two variance-reduction approaches (PPI and SVRG).
AI.method: Prove equivalence between PPI and SVRG; propose PPI-SVRG combining both control variates; derive convergence bound as SVRG rate + prediction-uncertainty error floor; analyze dependence on loss geometry; characterize effect of prediction quality on neighborhood of convergence.
AI.result: Theoretical: convergence rate remains SVRG-like with an additive error floor determined by prediction uncertainty; perfect predictions yield standard SVRG; with degraded predictions, convergence stabilizes within a larger neighborhood; empirical: 43–52% MSE reduction on mean estimation benchmarks; MNIST accuracy gain of 2.7–2.9 percentage points with only 10% labeled data.
AI.conclusion: PPI-SVRG offers a principled way to fuse predictions from pre-trained models into SVRG-based optimization, yielding robust improvements under label scarcity and gracefully degrading as prediction quality worsens.

title: ToolWeaver: Weaving Collaborative Semantics for Scalable Tool Use in Large Language Models
summary: Prevalent retrieval-based tool-use pipelines struggle with a dual semantic challenge: their retrievers often employ encoders that fail to capture complex semantics, while the Large Language Model (LLM) itself lacks intrinsic tool knowledge from its natural language pretraining. Generative methods offer a powerful alternative by unifying selection and execution, tasking the LLM to directly learn and generate tool identifiers. However, the common practice of mapping each tool to a unique new token introduces substantial limitations: it creates a scalability and generalization crisis, as the vocabulary size explodes and each tool is assigned a semantically isolated token. This approach also creates a semantic bottleneck that hinders the learning of collaborative tool relationships, as the model must infer them from sparse co-occurrences of monolithic tool IDs within a vast library. To address these limitations, we propose ToolWeaver, a novel generative tool learning framework that encodes tools into hierarchical sequences. This approach makes vocabulary expansion logarithmic to the number of tools. Crucially, it enables the model to learn collaborative patterns from the dense co-occurrence of shared codes, rather than the sparse co-occurrence of monolithic tool IDs. We generate these structured codes through a novel tokenization process designed to weave together a tool's intrinsic semantics with its extrinsic co-usage patterns. These structured codes are then integrated into the LLM through a generative alignment stage, where the model is fine-tuned to produce the hierarchical code sequences. Evaluation results with nearly 47,000 tools show that ToolWeaver significantly outperforms state-of-the-art methods, establishing a more scalable, generalizable, and semantically-aware foundation for advanced tool-augmented agents.

AI.tldr: ToolWeaver introduces hierarchical tool encoding to replace one-token-per-tool mappings, achieving log-scale vocabulary growth and enabling dense, collaborative learning of tool relationships; it yields substantial performance gains on large toolsets.
AI.motivation: Current retrieval-based tool-use pipelines suffer from semantic gaps in encoders and lack intrinsic tool knowledge in LLMs. Mapping each tool to a unique token causes vocabulary explosion and hinders learning tool relationships, limiting scalability and generalization.
AI.method: Encode tools as hierarchical sequences via a novel tokenization that blends intrinsic tool semantics with extrinsic co-usage patterns. The vocabulary expands logarithmically with tool count. A generative alignment stage fine-tunes the LLM to produce hierarchical code sequences.
AI.result: Empirical evaluation on ~47,000 tools shows ToolWeaver significantly outperforms state-of-the-art methods, offering a scalable, generalizable, and semantically-aware foundation for tool-augmented agents.
AI.conclusion: Hierarchical tool codes enable dense learning of collaborative tool relationships and scalable vocabulary growth, addressing the limitations of monolithic tool IDs and enhancing tool-augmented AI systems.

title: Best Arm Identification with LLM Judges and Limited Human
summary: We study fixed-confidence best-arm identification (BAI) where a cheap but potentially biased proxy (e.g., LLM judge) is available for every sample, while an expensive ground-truth label can only be acquired selectively when using a human for auditing. Unlike classical multi-fidelity BAI, the proxy is biased (arm- and context-dependent) and ground truth is selectively observed. Consequently, standard multi-fidelity methods can mis-select the best arm, and uniform auditing, though accurate, wastes scarce resources and is inefficient. We prove that without bias correction and propensity adjustment, mis-selection probability may not vanish (even with unlimited proxy data). We then develop an estimator for the mean of each arm that combines proxy scores with inverse-propensity-weighted residuals and form anytime-valid confidence sequences for that estimator. Based on the estimator and confidence sequence, we propose an algorithm that adaptively selects and audits arms. The algorithm concentrates audits on unreliable contexts and close arms and we prove that a plug-in Neyman rule achieves near-oracle audit efficiency. Numerical experiments confirm the theoretical guarantees and demonstrate the superior empirical performance of the proposed algorithm.

AI.tldr: Adaptive, bias-aware fixed-confidence BAI using a biased proxy and selective ground-truth audits; introduces inverse-propensity weighting and anytime-valid confidence sequences; achieves near-oracle audit efficiency with a plug-in Neyman rule; validated theoretically and empirically.
AI.motivation: Classical multi-fidelity BAI assumes unbiased proxies. When proxies are biased and ground-truth labels are expensive and observed selectively, standard methods may misidentify the best arm. The work aims to correct bias and efficiently allocate auditing resources.
AI.method: Develop an arm-mean estimator that combines proxy scores with inverse-propensity-weighted residuals. Construct anytime-valid confidence sequences for the estimator. Propose an adaptive auditing algorithm that concentrates audits on unreliable contexts and arms with similar means, using a plug-in Neyman rule for near-oracle audit efficiency.
AI.result: Theoretical guarantees show mis-selection can persist without bias correction and propensity adjustment. The estimator with confidence sequences enables valid inference under adaptive auditing. The algorithm achieves near-oracle audit efficiency, with numerical experiments corroborating performance.
AI.conclusion: Bias-corrected, propensity-adjusted auditing in biased-proxy BAI enables efficient, valid fixed-confidence identification of the best arm. The framework is practical for settings with cheap biased proxies and expensive selective ground truth; future work may explore broader bias models and extensions to contextual or multi-arm scenarios.

title: How do Visual Attributes Influence Web Agents? A Comprehensive Evaluation of User Interface Design Factors
summary: Web agents have demonstrated strong performance on a wide range of web-based tasks. However, existing research on the effect of environmental variation has mostly focused on robustness to adversarial attacks, with less attention to agents' preferences in benign scenarios. Although early studies have examined how textual attributes influence agent behavior, a systematic understanding of how visual attributes shape agent decision-making remains limited. To address this, we introduce VAF, a controlled evaluation pipeline for quantifying how webpage Visual Attribute Factors influence web-agent decision-making. Specifically, VAF consists of three stages: (i) variant generation, which ensures the variants share identical semantics as the original item while only differ in visual attributes; (ii) browsing interaction, where agents navigate the page via scrolling and clicking the interested item, mirroring how human users browse online; (iii) validating through both click action and reasoning from agents, which we use the Target Click Rate and Target Mention Rate to jointly evaluate the effect of visual attributes. By quantitatively measuring the decision-making difference between the original and variant, we identify which visual attributes influence agents' behavior most. Extensive experiments, across 8 variant families (48 variants total), 5 real-world websites (including shopping, travel, and news browsing), and 4 representative web agents, show that background color contrast, item size, position, and card clarity have a strong influence on agents' actions, whereas font styling, text color, and item image clarity exhibit minor effects.

AI.tldr: VAF: a controlled pipeline to quantify how webpage visual attributes influence web-agent decision-making; key findings show background contrast, item size/position, and card clarity strongly affect agents, while font styling, text color, and image clarity have smaller effects.
AI.motivation: Address the gap in understanding how benign visual variations, beyond textual attributes and adversarial robustness, influence web-agent behavior; extend evaluation beyond textual cues to systematic visual cue analysis.
AI.method: Three-stage pipeline: (1) variant generation that preserves semantics while altering only visual attributes; (2) browsing interaction simulating human-like scrolling and clicking; (3) validation via Target Click Rate and Target Mention Rate to assess impact; extensive experiments across 8 variant families (48 variants), 5 real websites, and 4 agents.
AI.result: Identified strong influence of background color contrast, item size, position, and card clarity on agent actions; weaker effects for font styling, text color, and item image clarity.
AI.conclusion: Visual attributes meaningfully shape web-agent decisions; VAF offers a quantitative framework to study these effects and can guide design for robust agent behavior and improved user experience.

title: ETS: Energy-Guided Test-Time Scaling for Training-Free RL Alignment
summary: Reinforcement Learning (RL) post-training alignment for language models is effective, but also costly and unstable in practice, owing to its complicated training process. To address this, we propose a training-free inference method to sample directly from the optimal RL policy. The transition probability applied to Masked Language Modeling (MLM) consists of a reference policy model and an energy term. Based on this, our algorithm, Energy-Guided Test-Time Scaling (ETS), estimates the key energy term via online Monte Carlo, with a provable convergence rate. Moreover, to ensure practical efficiency, ETS leverages modern acceleration frameworks alongside tailored importance sampling estimators, substantially reducing inference latency while provably preserving sampling quality. Experiments on MLM (including autoregressive models and diffusion language models) across reasoning, coding, and science benchmarks show that our ETS consistently improves generation quality, validating its effectiveness and design.

AI.tldr: Energy-Guided Test-Time Scaling (ETS): a training-free inference method for sampling from the optimal RL policy in language models, using an energy term estimated online with Monte Carlo to achieve efficient, high-quality generation with convergence guarantees.
AI.motivation: Reinforcement learning-based post-training alignment of language models yields improvement but incurs high cost and instability; a training-free, sampling-from-optimal-policy approach can reduce training burden while maintaining or improving generation quality.
AI.method: Unguided transition probability for masked LM sampling composed of a reference policy plus an energy term. The energy term is estimated online via Monte Carlo with provable convergence. ETS employs acceleration frameworks and tailored importance sampling estimators to reduce latency while preserving sampling quality.
AI.result: ETS consistently improves generation quality across MLMs (autoregressive and diffusion language models) and tasks including reasoning, coding, and science benchmarks, while substantially reducing inference latency and maintaining sampling quality with convergence guarantees.
AI.conclusion: ETS provides a practical, training-free, scalable approach for RL-alignment in language models, achieving quality gains and efficiency with provable convergence in energy estimation.

title: The Energy Impact of Domain Model Design in Classical Planning
comment: 2026 IEEE/ACM 5th International Conference on AI Engineering - Software Engineering for AI (CAIN '26)
summary: AI research has traditionally prioritised algorithmic performance, such as optimising accuracy in machine learning or runtime in automated planning. The emerging paradigm of Green AI challenges this by recognising energy consumption as a critical performance dimension. Despite the high computational demands of automated planning, its energy efficiency has received little attention. This gap is particularly salient given the modular planning structure, in which domain models are specified independently of algorithms. On the other hand, this separation also enables systematic analysis of energy usage through domain model design. We empirically investigate how domain model characteristics affect the energy consumption of classical planners. We introduce a domain model configuration framework that enables controlled variation of features, such as element ordering, action arity, and dead-end states. Using five benchmark domains and five state-of-the-art planners, we analyse energy and runtime impacts across 32 domain variants per benchmark. Results demonstrate that domain-level modifications produce measurable energy differences across planners, with energy consumption not always correlating with runtime.

AI.tldr: Domain design choices in automated planning influence energy use, not just runtime. The study shows measurable energy differences across domain variants and planners, indicating energy-aware domain modeling is a viable lever for Green AI in planning.
AI.motivation: Green AI emphasizes energy efficiency as a core performance metric. In automated planning, domain models and algorithms are decoupled, enabling systematic analysis of how domain features affect energy consumption.
AI.method: Introduce a domain model configuration framework to vary features such as element ordering, action arity, and dead-end states. Evaluate across five benchmark domains and five state-of-the-art planners, totaling 32 domain variants per domain. Measure both energy consumption and runtime; analyze relationships between energy and runtime.
AI.result: Domain-level modifications produce measurable energy differences across planners. Energy consumption does not always correlate with runtime, and effects vary by domain and planner.
AI.conclusion: Domain model design is a tunable lever for energy efficiency in automated planning. The separation of domain models from algorithms enables targeted energy optimization and motivates energy-aware domain design in future research.

title: Task-Awareness Improves LLM Generations and Uncertainty
summary: In many applications of LLMs, natural language responses often have an underlying structure such as representing discrete labels, numerical values, or graphs. Yet, existing decoding and uncertainty estimation methods operate only in language space and largely disregard structural information. We address this by modeling LLM outputs directly in a task-dependent latent structure. By equipping this structure with a dissimilarity measure, we can compute Bayes-optimal responses. These are not selected from sampled generations but are newly synthesized by combining individual responses in the latent space. Across different tasks, Bayes-optimal responses consistently outperform standard decoding methods like beam search. Moreover, quantifying uncertainty via the induced Bayesian risk captures variations in terms of the latent structure and improves alignment with output quality and correctness. Our decision-theoretic framework is applicable to any problem that admits a latent response structure and enables reliable task-aware LLM predictions.

AI.tldr: Introduces a Bayesian, task-dependent latent-structure framework for LLM outputs that synthesizes Bayes-optimal responses in latent space, improving decoding and uncertainty estimation over language-space methods.
AI.motivation: Current decoding and uncertainty estimation operate in pure language space and ignore latent structural information (labels, values, graphs). Incorporating a task-specific latent structure could yield more accurate, reliable predictions.
AI.method: Model outputs directly in a task-dependent latent structure endowed with a dissimilarity measure; compute Bayes-optimal responses by risk minimization in latent space; synthesize responses by combining latent-space components rather than sampling from generations; quantify uncertainty via induced Bayesian risk.
AI.result: Bayes-optimal responses consistently outperform standard decoding methods (e.g., beam search) across tasks; Bayesian risk-based uncertainty correlates with output quality and correctness.
AI.conclusion: A general decision-theoretic framework applicable to any problem with a latent response structure, enabling reliable, task-aware LLM predictions.

title: Learning Decentralized LLM Collaboration with Multi-Agent Actor Critic
summary: Recent work has explored optimizing LLM collaboration through Multi-Agent Reinforcement Learning (MARL). However, most MARL fine-tuning approaches rely on predefined execution protocols, which often require centralized execution. Decentralized LLM collaboration is more appealing in practice, as agents can run inference in parallel with flexible deployments. Also, current approaches use Monte Carlo methods for fine-tuning, which suffer from high variance and thus require more samples to train effectively. Actor-critic methods are prevalent in MARL for dealing with these issues, so we developed Multi-Agent Actor-Critic (MAAC) methods to optimize decentralized LLM collaboration. In this paper, we analyze when and why these MAAC methods are beneficial. We propose 2 MAAC approaches, \textbf{CoLLM-CC} with a \textbf{C}entralized \textbf{C}ritic and \textbf{CoLLM-DC} with \textbf{D}ecentralized \textbf{C}ritics. Our experiments across writing, coding, and game-playing domains show that Monte Carlo methods and CoLLM-DC can achieve performance comparable to CoLLM-CC in short-horizon and dense-reward settings. However, they both underperform CoLLM-CC on long-horizon or sparse-reward tasks, where Monte Carlo methods require substantially more samples and CoLLM-DC struggles to converge. Our code is available at https://github.com/OpenMLRL/CoMLRL/releases/tag/v1.3.2.

AI.tldr: Introduces CoLLM-CC and CoLLM-DC MAAC methods for decentralized LLM collaboration; centralized critic excels on long-horizon and sparse rewards, while decentralized critics match centralized in short-horizon/dense settings but struggle with convergence; MC-based fine-tuning remains sample-inefficient.
AI.motivation: Address high variance and sample inefficiency of Monte Carlo fine-tuning and move from centralized, predefined execution protocols to decentralized, parallel LLM collaboration using actor-critic MARL.
AI.method: Propose two MAAC variants: CoLLM-CC (Centralized Critic) and CoLLM-DC (Decentralized Critics). Evaluate on writing, coding, and game-playing tasks; compare against MC-based fine-tuning; analyze performance across horizon length and reward density.
AI.result: CoLLM-DC and MC methods approach CoLLM-CC performance in short-horizon, dense-reward tasks; all underperform CoLLM-CC on long-horizon or sparse-reward tasks; Monte Carlo methods require more samples; CoLLM-DC may struggle to converge in some settings; code released at provided URL.
AI.conclusion: Centralized critics offer robustness for long-horizon and sparse rewards; decentralized critics can be competitive in favorable settings but often face convergence and sample-efficiency challenges; overall, hybrid or improved stability strategies may be needed for robust decentralized MARL in LLM collaboration.

title: Cascaded Transfer: Learning Many Tasks under Budget Constraints
summary: Many-Task Learning refers to the setting where a large number of related tasks need to be learned, the exact relationships between tasks are not known. We introduce the Cascaded Transfer Learning, a novel many-task transfer learning paradigm where information (e.g. model parameters) cascades hierarchically through tasks that are learned by individual models of the same class, while respecting given budget constraints. The cascade is organized as a rooted tree that specifies the order in which tasks are learned and refined. We design a cascaded transfer mechanism deployed over a minimum spanning tree structure that connects the tasks according to a suitable distance measure, and allocates the available training budget along its branches. Experiments on synthetic and real many-task settings show that the resulting method enables more accurate and cost effective adaptation across large task collections compared to alternative approaches.

AI.tldr: Cascaded Transfer Learning for many-task learning using a root-tree cascade over a minimum spanning tree with budget-aware training, improving accuracy and cost efficiency.
AI.motivation: In many-task settings, task relationships are unknown; there is a need for effective, budget-aware transfer to leverage related tasks.
AI.method: Construct a cascaded transfer mechanism on a rooted tree by connecting tasks via a minimum spanning tree using a task-distance metric; propagate and refine model parameters along branches under allocated training budgets; learn tasks hierarchically within the cascade.
AI.result: Empirical evaluation on synthetic and real many-task datasets shows improved accuracy and cost effectiveness compared to baseline approaches.
AI.conclusion: A tree-structured, budget-aware cascaded transfer framework is effective for adapting models across large collections of related tasks.

title: Mind the Gap: How Elicitation Protocols Shape the Stated-Revealed Preference Gap in Language Models
summary: Recent work identifies a stated-revealed (SvR) preference gap in language models (LMs): a mismatch between the values models endorse and the choices they make in context. Existing evaluations rely heavily on binary forced-choice prompting, which entangles genuine preferences with artifacts of the elicitation protocol. We systematically study how elicitation protocols affect SvR correlation across 24 LMs. Allowing neutrality and abstention during stated preference elicitation allows us to exclude weak signals, substantially improving Spearman's rank correlation ($ρ$) between volunteered stated preferences and forced-choice revealed preferences. However, further allowing abstention in revealed preferences drives $ρ$ to near-zero or negative values due to high neutrality rates. Finally, we find that system prompt steering using stated preferences during revealed preference elicitation does not reliably improve SvR correlation on AIRiskDilemmas. Together, our results show that SvR correlation is highly protocol-dependent and that preference elicitation requires methods that account for indeterminate preferences.

AI.tldr: SvR correlation in language models is highly protocol-dependent. Allowing neutrality/abstention in stated preferences can improve correlation with forced-choice revealed preferences, but abstention in revealed preferences harms correlation due to high neutrality. System-prompt steering does not reliably improve correlation. Elicitation methods must account for indeterminate preferences.
AI.motivation: To understand how elicitation protocols shape the relationship between stated and revealed preferences in language models and to identify protocol features that inflate or obscure genuine preferences.
AI.method: Empirical study across 24 language models. manipulated elicitation protocols to include neutrality and abstention in stated preferences; measured Spearman correlation (rho) between volunteered stated preferences and forced-choice revealed preferences. examined abstention effects in revealed preferences. evaluated system-prompt steering using stated preferences during revealed preference elicitation on AIRiskDilemmas.
AI.result: Neutrality in stated-preference elicitation enhances Spearman correlation; excluding weak signals via abstention further improves correlation. Allowing abstention in revealed preferences yields near-zero or negative rho due to high neutrality rates. System-prompt steering with stated preferences did not reliably improve rho on AIRiskDilemmas.
AI.conclusion: SvR correlation is highly contingent on elicitation protocol. To reliably assess preferences, elicitation must account for indeterminate preferences and avoid protocol-induced artifacts.

title: A Unified SPD Token Transformer Framework for EEG Classification: Systematic Comparison of Geometric Embeddings
summary: Spatial covariance matrices of EEG signals are Symmetric Positive Definite (SPD) and lie on a Riemannian manifold, yet the theoretical connection between embedding geometry and optimization dynamics remains unexplored. We provide a formal analysis linking embedding choice to gradient conditioning and numerical stability for SPD manifolds, establishing three theoretical results: (1) BWSPD's $\sqrtκ$ gradient conditioning (vs $κ$ for Log-Euclidean) via Daleckii-Kreĭn matrices provides better gradient conditioning on high-dimensional inputs ($d \geq 22$), with this advantage reducing on low-dimensional inputs ($d \leq 8$) where eigendecomposition overhead dominates; (2) Embedding-Space Batch Normalization (BN-Embed) approximates Riemannian normalization up to $O(\varepsilon^2)$ error, yielding $+26\%$ accuracy on 56-channel ERP data but negligible effect on 8-channel SSVEP data, matching the channel-count-dependent prediction; (3) bi-Lipschitz bounds prove BWSPD tokens preserve manifold distances with distortion governed solely by the condition ratio $κ$. We validate these predictions via a unified Transformer framework comparing BWSPD, Log-Euclidean, and Euclidean embeddings within identical architecture across 1,500+ runs on three EEG paradigms (motor imagery, ERP, SSVEP; 36 subjects). Our Log-Euclidean Transformer achieves state-of-the-art performance on all datasets, substantially outperforming classical Riemannian classifiers and recent SPD baselines, while BWSPD offers competitive accuracy with similar training time.

AI.tldr: The paper analyzes SPD embeddings for EEG covariance matrices on Riemannian manifolds, linking embedding choice to optimization dynamics and stability. It presents three theoretical results: BWSPD yields sqrt(κ) gradient conditioning (vs κ for Log-Euclidean); Embedding-Space Batch Normalization (BN-Embed) approximates Riemannian normalization with O(ε^2) error and channel-count–dependent gains; bi-Lipschitz bounds show BWSPD preserves manifold distances with distortion tied to κ. Empirically, a unified Transformer framework on 1,500+ runs across motor imagery, ERP, and SSVEP shows Log-Euclidean Transformer achieves state-of-the-art, BWSPD is competitive in accuracy and training time.
AI.motivation: Understand how SPD embedding geometry affects optimization and generalization for EEG-based deep learning, by quantifying gradient conditioning, normalization behavior, and distance preservation on SPD manifolds, and validating with extensive empirical evaluation across diverse EEG paradigms.
AI.method: Theoretical analysis using Daleckii–Kreĭn matrices to derive gradient conditioning for BWSPD versus Log-Euclidean; derive BN-Embed approximation error to Riemannian normalization; prove bi-Lipschitz bounds for BWSPD token distances; extensive empirical validation with a unified Transformer architecture comparing BWSPD, Log-Euclidean, and Euclidean embeddings across 1,500+ runs on three EEG paradigms (motor imagery, ERP with 56 channels, SSVEP with 8 channels).
AI.result: BWSPD exhibits sqrt(κ) gradient conditioning compared to κ for Log-Euclidean (easier optimization in high dimensions; effect diminished when d≤8 due to eigen-decomposition costs); BN-Embed yields ~O(ε^2) error in approximating Riemannian normalization and improves ERP accuracy by ~26% on 56-channel data, with negligible effect on 8-channel data; BWSPD preserves manifold distances with distortion depending solely on κ via bi-Lipschitz bounds; Log-Euclidean Transformer achieves state-of-the-art across all datasets and outperforms classical Riemannian and SPD baselines, while BWSPD offers competitive accuracy with similar training time.
AI.conclusion: Embedding choice critically shapes optimization dynamics and normalization on SPD EEG representations. Log-Euclidean emerges as a strong practical baseline for high performance across diverse EEG tasks; BWSPD offers favorable gradient conditioning and competitive efficiency; BN-Embed provides a channel-count–dependent normalization benefit; the theoretical results offer principled guidelines for selecting SPD embeddings in neural architectures handling EEG covariance matrices.

title: VERSA: Verified Event Data Format for Reliable Soccer Analytics
summary: Event stream data is a critical resource for fine-grained analysis across various domains, including financial transactions, system operations, and sports. In sports, it is actively used for fine-grained analyses such as quantifying player contributions and identifying tactical patterns. However, the reliability of these models is fundamentally limited by inherent data quality issues that cause logical inconsistencies (e.g., incorrect event ordering or missing events). To this end, this study proposes VERSA (Verified Event Data Format for Reliable Soccer Analytics), a systematic verification framework that ensures the integrity of event stream data within the soccer domain. VERSA is based on a state-transition model that defines valid event sequences, thereby enabling the automatic detection and correction of anomalous patterns within the event stream data. Notably, our examination of event data from the K League 1 (2024 season), provided by Bepro, detected that 18.81% of all recorded events exhibited logical inconsistencies. Addressing such integrity issues, our experiments demonstrate that VERSA significantly enhances cross-provider consistency, ensuring stable and unified data representation across heterogeneous sources. Furthermore, we demonstrate that data refined by VERSA significantly improves the robustness and performance of a downstream task called VAEP, which evaluates player contributions. These results highlight that the verification process is highly effective in increasing the reliability of data-driven analysis.

AI.tldr: VERSA verifies and corrects soccer event streams using a state-transition model, improving data quality and downstream analytics (e.g., VAEP).
AI.motivation: Event streams suffer from logical inconsistencies that undermine analytics; automatic validation and correction is needed to ensure reliable, cross-provider data for soccer analytics.
AI.method: Define a state-transition model of valid event sequences; automatically detect/correct anomalous patterns; test on Bepro data from K League 1 2024; assess cross-provider consistency and impact on VAEP.
AI.result: Found 18.81% of events with logical inconsistencies; VERSA improves cross-provider consistency and data quality; refined data enhances robustness and performance of VAEP (player contributions).
AI.conclusion: Verification framework effectively enhances reliability of data-driven soccer analytics and enables unified data representation across providers; improves downstream analytics such as player contribution evaluation.

title: More Bang for the Buck: Improving the Inference of Large Language Models at a Fixed Budget using Reset and Discard (ReD)
summary: The performance of large language models (LLMs) on verifiable tasks is usually measured by pass@k, the probability of answering a question correctly at least once in k trials. At a fixed budget, a more suitable metric is coverage@cost, the average number of unique questions answered as a function of the total number of attempts. We connect the two metrics and show that the empirically-observed power-law behavior in pass@k leads to a sublinear growth of the coverage@cost (diminishing returns). To solve this problem, we propose Reset-and-Discard (ReD), a query method of LLMs that increases coverage@cost for any given budget, regardless of the pass@k form. Moreover, given a pass@k, we can quantitatively predict the savings in the total number of attempts using ReD. If pass@k is not available for the model, ReD can infer its power-law exponent. Experiments on three LLMs using HumanEval demonstrate that ReD substantially reduces the required attempts, tokens, and USD cost to reach a desired coverage, while also offering an efficient way to measure inference power-laws.

AI.tldr: Proposes Reset-and-Discard (ReD) to improve coverage@cost for LLMs and to relate it to pass@k; ReD increases unique-question coverage under a fixed budget and can infer or predict the power-law exponent of pass@k. Demonstrates substantial cost reductions (attempts, tokens, USD) in HumanEval across three LLMs.
AI.motivation: Pass@k and coverage@cost capture model reliability under budget constraints, but pass@k shows diminishing returns due to empirical power-law behavior. A method that improves coverage without relying on large k and that can infer the underlying power-law exponent is desirable for efficient evaluation and deployment of LLMs.
AI.method: Introduce Reset-and-Discard (ReD), a query strategy for LLMs that resets the conversation context and discards previously used attempts to maximize the number of unique questions answered within a fixed budget. Provide theoretical linkage between pass@k power-law and coverage@cost, and develop predictive formulas for savings in total attempts given pass@k (or infer its exponent when unknown). Validate on HumanEval with three LLMs, showing reduced attempts, tokens, and cost while enabling efficient measurement of inference power-laws.
AI.result: ReD substantially increases coverage@cost within a fixed budget, reducing the number of attempts, tokens, and USD expenditure to achieve a desired coverage. It also enables practical estimation of the power-law exponent governing pass@k, providing a reliable method for evaluating and comparing LLM inference power across models.
AI.conclusion: Reset-and-Discard is a practical, model-agnostic strategy to boost evaluation efficiency for LLMs and to characterize their inference power laws, offering tangible cost savings and a principled way to measure performance under budget constraints.

title: Liquid Interfaces: A Dynamic Ontology for the Interoperability of Autonomous Systems
summary: Contemporary software architectures struggle to support autonomous agents whose reasoning is adaptive, probabilistic, and context-dependent, while system integration remains dominated by static interfaces and deterministic contracts. This paper introduces Liquid Interfaces, a coordination paradigm in which interfaces are not persistent technical artifacts, but ephemeral relational events that emerge through intention articulation and semantic negotiation at runtime.We formalize this model and present the Liquid Interface Protocol (LIP),which governs intention-driven interaction, negotiated execution, and enforce ephemerality under semantic uncertainty. We further discuss the governance implications of this approach and describe a reference architecture that demonstrates practical feasibility. Liquid Interfaces provide a principled foundation for adaptive coordination in agent-based systems

AI.tldr: Liquid Interfaces propose a shift from persistent, deterministic interfaces to ephemeral, intention-driven relational events that emerge through runtime semantic negotiation; the Liquid Interface Protocol (LIP) formalizes this interaction under semantic uncertainty, enabling adaptive coordination in agent-based systems, with a reference architecture demonstrating feasibility and governance considerations.
AI.motivation: Current software architectures rely on static interfaces and deterministic contracts, which hinder adaptive, probabilistic, and context-dependent autonomous agents. A runtime, intention-driven, semantically negotiated coordination model is needed to improve interoperability and adaptability.
AI.method: Formalize the Liquid Interfaces model, design the Liquid Interface Protocol (LIP) for intention-driven interaction and negotiated execution, analyze governance implications, and present a reference architecture to demonstrate practical feasibility.
AI.result: A formal model and protocol (LIP) for ephemeral, intention-driven interfaces are introduced, along with governance considerations and a reference architecture that demonstrates practical feasibility, collectively providing a principled foundation for adaptive coordination in agent-based systems.
AI.conclusion: Liquid Interfaces offer a principled foundation for adaptive coordination in agent-based systems, enabling runtime semantic negotiation and ephemeral interfaces that adapt to context and uncertainty.

title: Explicit Credit Assignment through Local Rewards and Dependence Graphs in Multi-Agent Reinforcement Learning
summary: To promote cooperation in Multi-Agent Reinforcement Learning, the reward signals of all agents can be aggregated together, forming global rewards that are commonly known as the fully cooperative setting. However, global rewards are usually noisy because they contain the contributions of all agents, which have to be resolved in the credit assignment process. On the other hand, using local reward benefits from faster learning due to the separation of agents' contributions, but can be suboptimal as agents myopically optimize their own reward while disregarding the global optimality. In this work, we propose a method that combines the merits of both approaches. By using a graph of interaction between agents, our method discerns the individual agent contribution in a more fine-grained manner than a global reward, while alleviating the cooperation problem with agents' local reward. We also introduce a practical approach for approximating such a graph. Our experiments demonstrate the flexibility of the approach, enabling improvements over the traditional local and global reward settings.

AI.tldr: A graph-based credit assignment method for cooperative MARL that blends global and local rewards; approximates inter-agent interactions to improve credit assignment and learning, showing improvements over standard baselines.
AI.motivation: Global rewards are noisy and hinder credit assignment; local rewards enable fast learning but risk suboptimal global outcomes due to myopic optimization; a middle-ground leveraging inter-agent interactions is desirable.
AI.method: Introduce a graph of agent interactions to discern individual contributions more finely than a global reward; propose a practical approach to approximate this interaction graph; integrate the graph-based credit signals with learning to balance local/global incentives.
AI.result: Experiments show the approach is flexible and yields improvements over traditional local and global reward settings across tasks.
AI.conclusion: Graph-informed, approximated interaction models for credit assignment improve cooperation in MARL by combining the advantages of local and global rewards with practical applicability.

title: Heterogeneous Computing: The Key to Powering the Future of AI Agent Inference
summary: AI agent inference is driving an inference heavy datacenter future and exposes bottlenecks beyond compute - especially memory capacity, memory bandwidth and high-speed interconnect. We introduce two metrics - Operational Intensity (OI) and Capacity Footprint (CF) - that jointly explain regimes the classic roofline analysis misses, including the memory capacity wall. Across agentic workflows (chat, coding, web use, computer use) and base model choices (GQA/MLA, MoE, quantization), OI/CF can shift dramatically, with long context KV cache making decode highly memory bound. These observations motivate disaggregated serving and system level heterogeneity: specialized prefill and decode accelerators, broader scale up networking, and decoupled compute-memory enabled by optical I/O. We further hypothesize agent-hardware co design, multiple inference accelerators within one system, and high bandwidth, large capacity memory disaggregation as foundations for adaptation to evolving OI/CF. Together, these directions chart a path to sustain efficiency and capability for large scale agentic AI inference.
