AI.tldr: Proposes Operational Intensity (OI) and Capacity Footprint (CF) as complementary metrics to roofline to explain memory capacity and bandwidth bottlenecks in large-scale AI inference; shows long context KV caches can become memory-bound; argues for disaggregated serving and hardware/software co-design to sustain efficiency.
AI.motivation: Memory capacity walls and memory bandwidth bottlenecks are inadequately captured by traditional roofline models in AI agent inference; need system-level metrics to guide hardware-software co-design as models and contexts grow.
AI.method: Define two metrics, Operational Intensity (OI) and Capacity Footprint (CF); analyze across agentic workflows (chat, coding, web use, computer use) and base models (GQA/MLA, MoE, quantization); examine impact of long context KV caches on decode; discuss implications for architecture.
AI.result: OI and CF show regime shifts across workloads and models that are not captured by roofline; long-context KV caching makes decoding memory-bound; supports need for disaggregated serving, dedicated prefill/decode accelerators, broader high-bandwidth networking, and memory-centric system designs.
AI.conclusion: Advocates agent-hardware co-design with multiple inference accelerators, memory-disaggregated high-bandwidth memory, and optical I/O to adapt to evolving OI/CF; outlines directions to sustain efficiency and capability for large-scale agentic AI inference.

title: Fast and Geometrically Grounded Lorentz Neural Networks
summary: Hyperbolic space is quickly gaining traction as a promising geometry for hierarchical and robust representation learning. A core open challenge is the development of a mathematical formulation of hyperbolic neural networks that is both efficient and captures the key properties of hyperbolic space. The Lorentz model of hyperbolic space has been shown to enable both fast forward and backward propagation. However, we prove that, with the current formulation of Lorentz linear layers, the hyperbolic norms of the outputs scale logarithmically with the number of gradient descent steps, nullifying the key advantage of hyperbolic geometry. We propose a new Lorentz linear layer grounded in the well-known ``distance-to-hyperplane" formulation. We prove that our formulation results in the usual linear scaling of output hyperbolic norms with respect to the number of gradient descent steps. Our new formulation, together with further algorithmic efficiencies through Lorentzian activation functions and a new caching strategy results in neural networks fully abiding by hyperbolic geometry while simultaneously bridging the computation gap to Euclidean neural networks. Code available at: https://github.com/robertdvdk/hyperbolic-fully-connected.

AI.tldr: Introduces a Lorentz-linear layer for hyperbolic neural networks to fix a scaling issue in existing formulations; proves that the proposed distance-to-hyperplane Lorentz layer restores linear scaling of output hyperbolic norms with gradient steps; augmentations with Lorentzian activations and caching yield practical, geometry-consistent networks with Euclidean efficiency; code released.
AI.motivation: Hyperbolic space offers hierarchical representations with robustness, but current Lorentz-based layers cause the hyperbolic norms to scale only logarithmically with optimization steps, undermining hyperbolic advantages. A formulation that preserves hyperbolic geometry during learning and scales like Euclidean networks is needed.
AI.method: Introduce a Lorentz linear layer based on distance-to-hyperplane formulation. Provide theoretical proofs that this formulation yields linear scaling of output hyperbolic norms with respect to gradient steps. Enhance with Lorentzian activation functions and a caching strategy to improve efficiency while keeping hyperbolic geometry.
AI.result: Theoretical proof of desired linear scaling, plus practical algorithmic strategies (activations and caching) that align hyperbolic computations with Euclidean-like performance. Code is publicly available.
AI.conclusion: A new Lorentz-linear formulation preserves hyperbolic geometry during training and scales linearly with optimization steps, closing the gap with Euclidean networks and enabling more practical hyperbolic neural networks.

title: CAR-bench: Evaluating the Consistency and Limit-Awareness of LLM Agents under Real-World Uncertainty
summary: Existing benchmarks for Large Language Model (LLM) agents focus on task completion under idealistic settings but overlook reliability in real-world, user-facing applications. In domains, such as in-car voice assistants, users often issue incomplete or ambiguous requests, creating intrinsic uncertainty that agents must manage through dialogue, tool use, and policy adherence. We introduce CAR-bench, a benchmark for evaluating consistency, uncertainty handling, and capability awareness in multi-turn, tool-using LLM agents in an in-car assistant domain. The environment features an LLM-simulated user, domain policies, and 58 interconnected tools spanning navigation, productivity, charging, and vehicle control. Beyond standard task completion, CAR-bench introduces Hallucination tasks that test agents' limit-awareness under missing tools or information, and Disambiguation tasks that require resolving uncertainty through clarification or internal information gathering. Baseline results reveal large gaps between occasional and consistent success on all task types. Even frontier reasoning LLMs achieve less than 50% consistent pass rate on Disambiguation tasks due to premature actions, and frequently violate policies or fabricate information to satisfy user requests in Hallucination tasks, underscoring the need for more reliable and self-aware LLM agents in real-world settings.

AI.tldr: CAR-bench benchmarks LLM agents in in-car assistants for consistency, uncertainty handling, and tool use; introduces Hallucination and Disambiguation tasks; finds significant reliability gaps across models.
AI.motivation: Existing benchmarks miss reliability in real-world, user-facing settings; in-car interactions involve incomplete/ambiguous requests requiring dialogue, policy adherence, and tool use.
AI.method: Simulated in-car environment with an LLM-based user, domain policies, and 58 interconnected tools across navigation, productivity, charging, and vehicle control; multi-turn interactions; evaluation of consistency, uncertainty handling, and capability awareness; tasks include Hallucination (missing info/tools) and Disambiguation (clarification/internal gathering).
AI.result: Baseline results show large gaps between occasional and consistent success; frontier LLMs <50% consistent on Disambiguation due to premature actions; frequent policy violations and fabrication in Hallucination tasks.
AI.conclusion: Highlights need for more reliable, self-aware LLM agents in real-world settings; improve consistency, uncertainty handling, and policy adherence; further research required.

title: Multi-Modal Time Series Prediction via Mixture of Modulated Experts
summary: Real-world time series exhibit complex and evolving dynamics, making accurate forecasting extremely challenging. Recent multi-modal forecasting methods leverage textual information such as news reports to improve prediction, but most rely on token-level fusion that mixes temporal patches with language tokens in a shared embedding space. However, such fusion can be ill-suited when high-quality time-text pairs are scarce and when time series exhibit substantial variation in scale and characteristics, thus complicating cross-modal alignment. In parallel, Mixture-of-Experts (MoE) architectures have proven effective for both time series modeling and multi-modal learning, yet many existing MoE-based modality integration methods still depend on token-level fusion. To address this, we propose Expert Modulation, a new paradigm for multi-modal time series prediction that conditions both routing and expert computation on textual signals, enabling direct and efficient cross-modal control over expert behavior. Through comprehensive theoretical analysis and experiments, our proposed method demonstrates substantial improvements in multi-modal time series prediction. The current code is available at https://github.com/BruceZhangReve/MoME

AI.tldr: MoE-based Expert Modulation (MoME) enables cross-modal control for time-series forecasting by modulating both routing and expert computation with text, addressing token-level fusion limitations and improving multi-modal prediction.
AI.motivation: Time-series forecasting with textual signals is hindered by scarcity of high-quality time-text pairs and scale/characteristic variation; token-level fusion is brittle for cross-modal alignment; MoE-based modality integration offers flexible control.
AI.method: Introduce Expert Modulation (MoME): a Mixture-of-Experts framework where textual signals condition both routing (gating) and expert computation, enabling direct cross-modal control over expert behavior; includes theoretical analysis and empirical validation; code provided.
AI.result: Demonstrates substantial improvements in multi-modal time-series prediction compared with baselines, supported by theoretical analysis and ablation studies.
AI.conclusion: MoME provides a scalable, effective paradigm for multi-modal time-series forecasting with textual cues, enabling explicit cross-modal modulation of expert behavior; code is publicly available.

title: Optimizing Agentic Workflows using Meta-tools
summary: Agentic AI enables LLM to dynamically reason, plan, and interact with tools to solve complex tasks. However, agentic workflows often require many iterative reasoning steps and tool invocations, leading to significant operational expense, end-to-end latency and failures due to hallucinations. This work introduces Agent Workflow Optimization (AWO), a framework that identifies and optimizes redundant tool execution patterns to improve the efficiency and robustness of agentic workflows. AWO analyzes existing workflow traces to discover recurring sequences of tool calls and transforms them into meta-tools, which are deterministic, composite tools that bundle multiple agent actions into a single invocation. Meta-tools bypass unnecessary intermediate LLM reasoning steps and reduce operational cost while also shortening execution paths, leading to fewer failures. Experiments on two agentic AI benchmarks show that AWO reduces the number of LLM calls up to 11.9% while also increasing the task success rate by up to 4.2 percent points.

AI.tldr: AWO optimizes agentic AI workflows by converting recurring tool-call sequences into meta-tools, reducing LLM invocations and improving success rates.
AI.motivation: To reduce operational cost, latency, and vulnerability to hallucinations in iterative agent reasoning with tool invocations.
AI.method: Analyze existing workflow traces to discover recurring sequences of tool calls; transform them into deterministic, composite meta-tools that bundle multiple agent actions into a single invocation, bypassing unnecessary intermediate LLM steps.
AI.result: Reduces the number of LLM calls by up to 11.9% and increases task success rate by up to 4.2 percentage points across two agentic AI benchmarks.
AI.conclusion: Meta-tools improve efficiency and robustness of agentic workflows by pruning redundant reasoning steps and tool invocations.

title: HistoPrism: Unlocking Functional Pathway Analysis from Pan-Cancer Histology via Gene Expression Prediction
summary: Predicting spatial gene expression from H&E histology offers a scalable and clinically accessible alternative to sequencing, but realizing clinical impact requires models that generalize across cancer types and capture biologically coherent signals. Prior work is often limited to per-cancer settings and variance-based evaluation, leaving functional relevance underexplored. We introduce HistoPrism, an efficient transformer-based architecture for pan-cancer prediction of gene expression from histology. To evaluate biological meaning, we introduce a pathway-level benchmark, shifting assessment from isolated gene-level variance to coherent functional pathways. HistoPrism not only surpasses prior state-of-the-art models on highly variable genes , but also more importantly, achieves substantial gains on pathway-level prediction, demonstrating its ability to recover biologically coherent transcriptomic patterns. With strong pan-cancer generalization and improved efficiency, HistoPrism establishes a new standard for clinically relevant transcriptomic modeling from routinely available histology.

AI.tldr: Transformer-based pan-cancer model HistoPrism predicts spatial gene expression from H&E histology; introduces a pathway-level benchmark; outperforms prior models for variable genes and pathway coherence; demonstrates strong cross-cancer generalization and efficiency.
AI.motivation: Address the need for clinically relevant, generalizable histology-to-transcriptomics models. Prior work is often limited to single-cancer settings with variance-focused metrics and lacks evaluation of functional, pathway-level biology.
AI.method: Efficient transformer-based architecture (HistoPrism) trained and evaluated across multiple cancer types (pan-cancer). Introduces a pathway-level benchmark to assess functional coherence of predicted transcriptomic signals.
AI.result: Outperforms prior state-of-the-art on highly variable genes and shows substantial gains at the pathway level, indicating recovery of coherent transcriptomic patterns. Exhibits strong pan-cancer generalization and improved efficiency.
AI.conclusion: HistoPrism sets a new standard for clinically relevant transcriptomic modeling from routinely available histology, enabling scalable, biologically meaningful cross-cancer inference.

title: Defining Operational Conditions for Safety-Critical AI-Based Systems from Data
summary: Artificial Intelligence (AI) has been on the rise in many domains, including numerous safety-critical applications. However, for complex systems found in the real world, or when data already exist, defining the underlying environmental conditions is extremely challenging. This often results in an incomplete description of the environment in which the AI-based system must operate. Nevertheless, this description, called the Operational Design Domain (ODD), is required in many domains for the certification of AI-based systems. Traditionally, the ODD is created in the early stages of the development process, drawing on sophisticated expert knowledge and related standards. This paper presents a novel Safety-by-Design method to a posteriori define the ODD from previously collected data using a multi-dimensional kernel-based representation. This approach is validated through both Monte Carlo methods and a real-world aviation use case for a future safety-critical collision-avoidance system. Moreover, by defining under what conditions two ODDs are equal, the paper shows that the data-driven ODD can equal the original, underlying hidden ODD of the data. Utilizing the novel, Safe-by-Design kernel-based ODD enables future certification of data-driven, safety-critical AI-based systems.

AI.tldr: A data-driven, kernel-based method to define ODD a posteriori from data; validated via Monte Carlo and an aviation use case; proposes a notion of ODD equality; aims to aid certification of safety-critical AI systems.
AI.motivation: ODD characterization is essential for certification but difficult to specify for complex, real-world environments. A posteriori data-driven methods can fill gaps where expert knowledge is incomplete.
AI.method: Proposes a multi-dimensional kernel-based representation to define the Operational Design Domain (ODD) from collected data after the fact (a posteriori). Introduces a formal notion of when two ODDs are equal. Validation includes Monte Carlo experiments and a real-world aviation use case for a collision-avoidance system.
AI.result: Demonstrates that the data-driven ODD can be equal to the original, underlying hidden ODD under certain conditions, supporting certification of data-driven, safety-critical AI systems.
AI.conclusion: Safe-by-Design kernel-based ODD enables certification of data-driven, safety-critical AI systems by providing a rigorous, data-driven ODD definition and equivalence notion.

title: Visual-Guided Key-Token Regularization for Multimodal Large Language Model Unlearning
summary: Unlearning in Multimodal Large Language Models (MLLMs) prevents the model from revealing private information when queried about target images. Existing MLLM unlearning methods largely adopt approaches developed for LLMs. They treat all answer tokens uniformly, disregarding their varying importance in the unlearning process. Moreover, these methods focus exclusively on the language modality, disregarding visual cues that indicate key tokens in answers. In this paper, after formulating the problem of unlearning in multimodal question answering for MLLMs, we propose Visual-Guided Key-Token Regularization (ViKeR). We leverage irrelevant visual inputs to predict ideal post-unlearning token-level distributions and use these distributions to regularize the unlearning process, thereby prioritizing key tokens. Further, we define key tokens in unlearning via information entropy and discuss ViKeR's effectiveness through token-level gradient reweighting, which amplifies updates on key tokens. Experiments on MLLMU and CLEAR benchmarks demonstrate that our method effectively performs unlearning while mitigating forgetting and maintaining response coherence.

AI.tldr: ViKeR offers a multimodal unlearning method for MLLMs by using visual cues to guide token-level unlearning, emphasizing key tokens via entropy-based selection and gradient reweighting, achieving effective unlearning with less forgetting on MLLMU and CLEAR benchmarks.
AI.motivation: Current unlearning approaches for MLLMs treat answer tokens uniformly and ignore visual cues, risking incomplete removal of sensitive information and degraded coherence; integrate visual signals to identify and protect key tokens during unlearning.
AI.method: Propose Visual-Guided Key-Token Regularization (ViKeR). Use irrelevant visual inputs to predict ideal post-unlearning token distributions; regularize model outputs to align with these distributions; define key tokens via information entropy; apply token-level gradient reweighting to amplify updates on key tokens.
AI.result: On MLLMU and CLEAR benchmarks, ViKeR achieves effective unlearning while mitigating forgetting and preserving response coherence.
AI.conclusion: Incorporating multimodal signals and entropy-based key-token regulation enables more precise unlearning in MLLMs, balancing privacy with performance.

title: SAL: Selective Adaptive Learning for Backpropagation-Free Training with Sparsification
summary: Standard deep learning relies on Backpropagation (BP), which is constrained by biologically implausible weight symmetry and suffers from significant gradient interference within dense representations. To mitigate these bottlenecks, we propose Selective Adaptive Learning (SAL), a training method that combines selective parameter activation with adaptive area partitioning. Specifically, SAL decomposes the parameter space into mutually exclusive, sample-dependent regions. This decoupling mitigates gradient interference across divergent semantic patterns and addresses explicit weight symmetry requirements through our refined feedback alignment. Empirically, SAL demonstrates competitive convergence rates, leading to improved classification performance across 10 standard benchmarks. Additionally, SAL achieves numerical consistency and competitive accuracy even in deep regimes (up to 128 layers) and large-scale models (up to 1B parameters). Our approach is loosely inspired by biological learning mechanisms, offering a plausible alternative that contributes to the study of scalable neural network training.

AI.tldr: Proposes Selective Adaptive Learning (SAL) that partitions parameters into sample-dependent regions and uses selective activation with adaptive area partitioning and refined feedback alignment to reduce gradient interference and remove strict weight symmetry, achieving competitive convergence and scalability across deep nets and large models.
AI.motivation: Backpropagation relies on weight symmetry and suffers gradient interference in dense representations; a biologically inspired, scalable alternative is desirable.
AI.method: Decompose parameter space into mutually exclusive, sample-dependent regions; apply selective parameter activation; adapt partitions (area partitioning); employ refined feedback alignment to relax weight symmetry constraints.
AI.result: SAL shows competitive convergence rates, improved classification across 10 standard benchmarks, numerical consistency, and competitive accuracy in deep regimes (up to 128 layers) and large models (up to 1B parameters).
AI.conclusion: SAL offers a biologically inspired, scalable alternative for neural network training, contributing to the study of training methods beyond standard backpropagation.

title: Routing the Lottery: Adaptive Subnetworks for Heterogeneous Data
summary: In pruning, the Lottery Ticket Hypothesis posits that large networks contain sparse subnetworks, or winning tickets, that can be trained in isolation to match the performance of their dense counterparts. However, most existing approaches assume a single universal winning ticket shared across all inputs, ignoring the inherent heterogeneity of real-world data. In this work, we propose Routing the Lottery (RTL), an adaptive pruning framework that discovers multiple specialized subnetworks, called adaptive tickets, each tailored to a class, semantic cluster, or environmental condition. Across diverse datasets and tasks, RTL consistently outperforms single- and multi-model baselines in balanced accuracy and recall, while using up to 10 times fewer parameters than independent models and exhibiting semantically aligned. Furthermore, we identify subnetwork collapse, a performance drop under aggressive pruning, and introduce a subnetwork similarity score that enables label-free diagnosis of oversparsification. Overall, our results recast pruning as a mechanism for aligning model structure with data heterogeneity, paving the way toward more modular and context-aware deep learning.

AI.tldr: RTL (Routing the Lottery) introduces adaptive tickets—multiple specialized subnetworks trained for data heterogeneity (class, cluster, or environment). It outperforms single/multi baselines with up to 10x fewer parameters and semantically aligned subnetworks, while exposing subnetwork collapse under aggressive pruning and a label-free subnetwork similarity score for diagnosing oversparsification.
AI.motivation: Address the limitation of the Lottery Ticket Hypothesis that assumes a single universal winning ticket; real-world data are heterogeneous, calling for modular, context-aware subnetworks that can specialize to different data regimes.
AI.method: RTL discovers and routes inputs to multiple adaptive tickets (subnetworks) tailored to classes, semantic clusters, or environmental conditions, enabling specialized pruning and dynamic subnetwork selection.
AI.result: Across diverse datasets and tasks, RTL achieves higher balanced accuracy and recall than single- and multi-model baselines while using up to 10x fewer parameters than independent models; subnetworks are semantically aligned to data, though aggressive pruning can cause subnetwork collapse; introduces a subnetwork similarity score for label-free diagnosis of oversparsification.
AI.conclusion: Pruning can be reframed as aligning model structure with data heterogeneity, enabling modular, context-aware neural networks and paving the way for more flexible, efficient deep learning.

title: Representation Unlearning: Forgetting through Information Compression
summary: Machine unlearning seeks to remove the influence of specific training data from a model, a need driven by privacy regulations and robustness concerns. Existing approaches typically modify model parameters, but such updates can be unstable, computationally costly, and limited by local approximations. We introduce Representation Unlearning, a framework that performs unlearning directly in the model's representation space. Instead of modifying model parameters, we learn a transformation over representations that imposes an information bottleneck: maximizing mutual information with retained data while suppressing information about data to be forgotten. We derive variational surrogates that make this objective tractable and show how they can be instantiated in two practical regimes: when both retain and forget data are available, and in a zero-shot setting where only forget data can be accessed. Experiments across several benchmarks demonstrate that Representation Unlearning achieves more reliable forgetting, better utility retention, and greater computational efficiency than parameter-centric baselines.

AI.tldr: A representation-space unlearning method that applies an information-bottleneck transformation to representations to forget specified data while preserving retained data, offering a tractable objective via variational surrogates and two practical regimes (with/without access to retained data).
AI.motivation: To address privacy and robustness demands by removing the influence of specific training data without fragile parameter updates; existing parameter-centric unlearning is unstable, costly, and locally approximated.
AI.method: Introduce a transformation over model representations that enforces an information bottleneck by maximizing mutual information with retained data and minimizing mutual information with forgotten data. Derive variational surrogates to make the objective tractable and implement in two regimes: (i) both retain and forget data available; (ii) zero-shot setting where only forget data is accessible.
AI.result: Empirical evaluations show representation unlearning yields more reliable forgetting, better utility retention, and greater computational efficiency compared to parameter-focused baselines across multiple benchmarks.
AI.conclusion: Representational unlearning provides a robust, efficient alternative to parameter-centric unlearning by performing unlearning in representation space with a principled information-theoretic objective and tractable surrogates, adaptable to scenarios with varying access to retained data.

title: World of Workflows: a Benchmark for Bringing World Models to Enterprise Systems
summary: Frontier large language models (LLMs) excel as autonomous agents in many domains, yet they remain untested in complex enterprise systems where hidden workflows create cascading effects across interconnected databases. Existing enterprise benchmarks evaluate surface-level agentic task completion similar to general consumer benchmarks, ignoring true challenges in enterprises, such as limited observability, large database state, and hidden workflows with cascading side effects. We introduce World of Workflows (WoW), a realistic ServiceNow-based environment incorporating 4,000+ business rules and 55 active workflows embedded in the system, alongside WoW-bench, a benchmark of 234 tasks evaluating constrained agentic task completion and enterprise dynamics modeling capabilities. We reveal two major takeaways: (1) Frontier LLMs suffer from dynamics blindness, consistently failing to predict the invisible, cascading side effects of their actions, which leads to silent constraint violations, and (2) reliability in opaque systems requires grounded world modeling, where agents must mentally simulate hidden state transitions to bridge the observability gap when high-fidelity feedback is unavailable. For reliable and useful enterprise agents, WoW motivates a new paradigm to explicitly learn system dynamics. We release our GitHub for setting up and evaluating WoW.

AI.tldr: World of Workflows (WoW) and WoW-bench provide a realistic enterprise evaluation for frontier LLMs; results show dynamics blindness and the need to ground models in system dynamics.
AI.motivation: Enterprise environments feature hidden workflows, limited observability, and cascading effects across databases; existing benchmarks miss these challenges; need to explicitly study LLMs' modeling of system dynamics.
AI.method: Develop WoW (ServiceNow-based) with 4,000+ business rules and 55 active workflows; construct WoW-bench with 234 tasks; evaluate frontier LLMs on constrained task completion and enterprise dynamics.
AI.result: Two main findings: (1) Frontier LLMs exhibit dynamics blindness, failing to predict cascading side effects and causing silent constraint violations; (2) Reliability in opaque systems requires grounded world modeling to simulate hidden state transitions; WoW prompts a shift to learning system dynamics.
AI.conclusion: To build reliable enterprise agents, explicitly learn and reason about system dynamics; provide open-source tooling (GitHub) for WoW setup and evaluation.

title: FlexCausal: Flexible Causal Disentanglement via Structural Flow Priors and Manifold-Aware Interventions
summary: Causal Disentangled Representation Learning(CDRL) aims to learn and disentangle low dimensional representations and their underlying causal structure from observations. However, existing disentanglement methods rely on a standard mean-field approximation with a diagonal posterior covariance, which decorrelates all latent dimensions. Additionally, these methods often assume isotropic Gaussian priors for exogenous noise, failing to capture the complex, non-Gaussian statistical properties prevalent in real-world causal factors. Therefore, we propose FlexCausal, a novel CDRL framework based on a block-diagonal covariance VAE. FlexCausal utilizes a Factorized Flow-based Prior to realistically model the complex densities of exogenous noise, effectively decoupling the learning of causal mechanisms from distributional statistics. By integrating supervised alignment objectives with counterfactual consistency constraints, our framework ensures a precise structural correspondence between the learned latent subspaces and the ground-truth causal relations. Finally, we introduce a manifold-aware relative intervention strategy to ensure high-fidelity generation. Experimental results on both synthetic and real-world datasets demonstrate that FlexCausal significantly outperforms other methods.

AI.tldr: FlexCausal advances causal disentangled representation learning by replacing diagonal VAEs with a block-diagonal covariance VAE and a factorized flow prior for exogenous noise, coupled with supervision and counterfactual constraints to align latent subspaces with true causal relations and a manifold-aware intervention strategy for high-fidelity generation.
AI.motivation: Standard mean-field VAEs enforce diagonal posterior covariances, which induces spurious independence among latent factors and fails to capture non-Gaussian, structured exogenous noise typical of real causal factors. This limits accurate causal discovery and disentanglement.
AI.method: A block-diagonal covariance VAE architecture; a Factorized Flow-based Prior to model complex exogenous noise distributions; integration of supervised alignment objectives with counterfactual consistency constraints to enforce structural correspondence; and a manifold-aware relative intervention strategy to improve generation fidelity.
AI.result: Empirical results on synthetic and real-world datasets show FlexCausal significantly outperforms existing CDRL methods in terms of disentanglement, causal structure recovery, and generation quality.
AI.conclusion: FlexCausal decouples learning of causal mechanisms from distributional statistics, achieves more accurate latent-to-causal-structure mapping, and delivers high-fidelity generation through task-aligned supervision, counterfactual constraints, and manifold-aware interventions.

title: Bridging Functional and Representational Similarity via Usable Information
summary: We present a unified framework for quantifying the similarity between representations through the lens of \textit{usable information}, offering a rigorous theoretical and empirical synthesis across three key dimensions. First, addressing functional similarity, we establish a formal link between stitching performance and conditional mutual information. We further reveal that stitching is inherently asymmetric, demonstrating that robust functional comparison necessitates a bidirectional analysis rather than a unidirectional mapping. Second, concerning representational similarity, we prove that reconstruction-based metrics and standard tools (e.g., CKA, RSA) act as estimators of usable information under specific constraints. Crucially, we show that similarity is relative to the capacity of the predictive family: representations that appear distinct to a rigid observer may be identical to a more expressive one. Third, we demonstrate that representational similarity is sufficient but not necessary for functional similarity. We unify these concepts through a task-granularity hierarchy: similarity on a complex task guarantees similarity on any coarser derivative, establishing representational similarity as the limit of maximum granularity: input reconstruction.

AI.tldr: A unified framework links usable information to both functional and representational similarity, revealing asymmetry in stitching, estimator behavior of common metrics, predictive-capacity dependence, sufficiency vs necessity, and a task-granularity hierarchy culminating in input reconstruction as the finest granularity.
AI.motivation: To reconcile diverse similarity measures (functional, representational) under a single information-theoretic concept of usable information, and to understand how task granularity and observer capacity affect similarity assessments.
AI.method: Theoretical development establishing: (i) a link between stitching performance and conditional mutual information, (ii) a demonstration of bidirectional asymmetry in functional comparison, (iii) proofs that reconstruction-based metrics and tools like CKA/RSA estimate usable information under certain constraints and that similarity depends on the predictive family's capacity, (iv) argument that representational similarity is sufficient but not necessary for functional similarity, and (v) introduction of a task-granularity hierarchy showing that similarity on a complex task implies similarity on coarser derivatives, with input reconstruction as the limit of maximum granularity.
AI.result: Key findings: (1) Stitching performance is tied to conditional mutual information, and robust functional comparison requires bidirectional analysis. (2) Reconstruction-based metrics and standard tools approximate usable information given constraints, with similarity contingent on the observer/predictive family capacity. (3) Representational similarity is not necessary for functional similarity; it is a sufficient condition under the hierarchy. (4) A task-granularity hierarchy formalizes that similarity at fine granularity guarantees similarity at coarser levels; input reconstruction represents the maximum granularity.
AI.conclusion: A cohesive theory where usable information governs both representation and function, with a hierarchical, capacity-aware view of similarity. This framework clarifies when common metrics are informative and highlights the limits of representational similarity as a proxy for functional equivalence, all scoped within a hierarchical notion of task granularity.

title: Exploring Reasoning Reward Model for Agents
summary: Agentic Reinforcement Learning (Agentic RL) has achieved notable success in enabling agents to perform complex reasoning and tool use. However, most methods still relies on sparse outcome-based reward for training. Such feedback fails to differentiate intermediate reasoning quality, leading to suboptimal training results. In this paper, we introduce Agent Reasoning Reward Model (Agent-RRM), a multi-faceted reward model that produces structured feedback for agentic trajectories, including (1) an explicit reasoning trace , (2) a focused critique that provides refinement guidance by highlighting reasoning flaws, and (3) an overall score that evaluates process performance. Leveraging these signals, we systematically investigate three integration strategies: Reagent-C (text-augmented refinement), Reagent-R (reward-augmented guidance), and Reagent-U (unified feedback integration). Extensive evaluations across 12 diverse benchmarks demonstrate that Reagent-U yields substantial performance leaps, achieving 43.7% on GAIA and 46.2% on WebWalkerQA, validating the effectiveness of our reasoning reward model and training schemes. Code, models, and datasets are all released to facilitate future research.

AI.tldr: Agent-RRM provides a multi-faceted reward signal (explicit reasoning traces, focused critique, and an overall score) to guide agentic RL; three integration strategies (Reagent-C, Reagent-R, Reagent-U) show unified feedback integration yielding notable gains on GAIA (43.7%) and WebWalkerQA (46.2%); code released.
AI.motivation: Sparse outcome-based rewards fail to differentiate intermediate reasoning quality, leading to suboptimal training for agentic tasks; richer, structured feedback is needed to improve reasoning and tool-use performance.
AI.method: Introduce Agent Reasoning Reward Model (Agent-RRM) with three feedback components: explicit reasoning trace, focused critique for refinement guidance, and an overall process score. Evaluate three integration strategies Reagent-C (text-augmented refinement), Reagent-R (reward-augmented guidance), and Reagent-U (unified feedback integration) across 12 benchmarks.
AI.result: Unified feedback integration (Reagent-U) yields substantial performance gains, achieving 43.7% on GAIA and 46.2% on WebWalkerQA, demonstrating effectiveness across diverse tasks.
AI.conclusion: Structured reasoning reward signals and unified integration substantially improve agentic RL training; the approach enables richer supervision, reproducibility, and broader applicability; resources (code, models, datasets) released to support further research.

title: Shaping capabilities with token-level data filtering
summary: Current approaches to reducing undesired capabilities in language models are largely post hoc, and can thus be easily bypassed by adversaries. A natural alternative is to shape capabilities during pretraining itself. On the proxy task of removing medical capabilities, we show that the simple intervention of filtering pretraining data is highly effective, robust, and inexpensive at scale. Inspired by work on data attribution, we show that filtering tokens is more effective than filtering documents, achieving the same hit to undesired capabilities at a lower cost to benign ones. Training models spanning two orders of magnitude, we then demonstrate that filtering gets more effective with scale: for our largest models, token filtering leads to a 7000x compute slowdown on the forget domain. We also show that models trained with token filtering can still be aligned on the forget domain. Along the way, we introduce a methodology for labeling tokens with sparse autoencoders and distilling cheap, high-quality classifiers. We also demonstrate that filtering can be robust to noisy labels with sufficient pretraining compute.

AI.tldr: Token-level filtering of pretraining data effectively reduces undesired medical capabilities, outperforming document-level filtering in cost and robustness, and scales with model size; introduces token labeling via sparse autoencoders and cheap classifiers, showing large compute slowdowns for forget-domain tasks while preserving alignment.
AI.motivation: Address the vulnerability of post hoc alignment methods and reduce undesired capabilities during pretraining by shaping the data the model sees, enabling cheaper, scalable control over model behavior.
AI.method: Compare token-level vs document-level filtering on pretraining data across model scales; label tokens using sparse autoencoders and distilled classifiers; evaluate on a 'forget' domain; assess robustness to noisy labels; quantify compute slowdown and alignment of final models with respect to controlled capabilities.
AI.result: Token filtering achieves the same reduction in undesired capabilities as document filtering but at a lower cost to benign capabilities; scale increases effectiveness, with the largest models showing up to a 7000x compute slowdown on the forget domain; models trained with token filtering remain alignable on the forget domain; a labeling pipeline using sparse autoencoders and cheap classifiers is effective and robust to label noise with enough pretraining compute.
AI.conclusion: Pretraining-time data shaping via token-level filtering is an effective, scalable strategy to constrain undesired capabilities, outperforming document-level filtering and enabling robust, inexpensive control over model behavior at scale.

title: Signal-Adaptive Trust Regions for Gradient-Free Optimization of Recurrent Spiking Neural Networks
summary: Recurrent spiking neural networks (RSNNs) are a promising substrate for energy-efficient control policies, but training them for high-dimensional, long-horizon reinforcement learning remains challenging. Population-based, gradient-free optimization circumvents backpropagation through non-differentiable spike dynamics by estimating gradients. However, with finite populations, high variance of these estimates can induce harmful and overly aggressive update steps. Inspired by trust-region methods in reinforcement learning that constrain policy updates in distribution space, we propose \textbf{Signal-Adaptive Trust Regions (SATR)}, a distributional update rule that constrains relative change by bounding KL divergence normalized by an estimated signal energy. SATR automatically expands the trust region under strong signals and contracts it when updates are noise-dominated. We instantiate SATR for Bernoulli connectivity distributions, which have shown strong empirical performance for RSNN optimization. Across a suite of high-dimensional continuous-control benchmarks, SATR improves stability under limited populations and reaches competitive returns against strong baselines including PPO-LSTM. In addition, to make SATR practical at scale, we introduce a bitset implementation for binary spiking and binary weights, substantially reducing wall-clock training time and enabling fast RSNN policy search.

AI.tldr: Introduces Signal-Adaptive Trust Regions (SATR) for gradient-free training of recurrent spiking neural networks (RSNNs). It bounds update steps by KL divergence normalized by estimated signal energy, automatically expanding/contracts the region based on signal strength. Instantiated for Bernoulli connectivity; demonstrates improved stability and competitive performance, aided by a bitset acceleration for binary spiking/weights.
AI.motivation: Training RSNNs with finite, high-variance gradient-free updates is challenging for high-dimensional, long-horizon RL. A principled, adaptive trust-region mechanism in distribution space can stabilize learning without backprop through non-differentiable spike dynamics.
AI.method: Propose SATR as a distributional update rule that constrains relative changes by bounding KL divergence divided by estimated signal energy. Apply to Bernoulli connectivity; leverage a bitset implementation to accelerate binary spiking and weights for scalable RSNN policy search.
AI.result: SATR improves stability under limited populations and achieves competitive returns against strong baselines (e.g., PPO-LSTM) across high-dimensional continuous-control tasks. The bitset implementation substantially reduces wall-clock training time, enabling fast RSNN policy search.
AI.conclusion: SATR provides a principled, adaptive trust-region framework for gradient-free RSNN optimization, enabling scalable, stable learning in high-dimensional control problems; Bernoulli connectivity and bitset acceleration contribute to practical efficiency and competitiveness.

title: Learning the Mechanism of Catastrophic Forgetting: A Perspective from Gradient Similarity
summary: Catastrophic forgetting during knowledge injection severely undermines the continual learning capability of large language models (LLMs). Although existing methods attempt to mitigate this issue, they often lack a foundational theoretical explanation. We establish a gradient-based theoretical framework to explain catastrophic forgetting. We first prove that strongly negative gradient similarity is a fundamental cause of forgetting. We then use gradient similarity to identify two types of neurons: conflicting neurons that induce forgetting and account for 50%-75% of neurons, and collaborative neurons that mitigate forgetting and account for 25%-50%. Based on this analysis, we propose a knowledge injection method, Collaborative Neural Learning (CNL). By freezing conflicting neurons and updating only collaborative neurons, CNL theoretically eliminates catastrophic forgetting under an infinitesimal learning rate eta and an exactly known mastered set. Experiments on five LLMs, four datasets, and four optimizers show that CNL achieves zero forgetting in in-set settings and reduces forgetting by 59.1%-81.7% in out-of-set settings.

AI.tldr: Proposes a gradient-based theory of catastrophic forgetting in knowledge injection for LLMs, classifies neurons as conflicting or collaborative, and introduces Collaborative Neural Learning (CNL) that freezes conflicting neurons to eliminate forgetting under ideal conditions, with strong in-dataset and substantial out-of-dataset improvements empirically.
AI.motivation: Address the lack of foundational theory for catastrophic forgetting in knowledge injection and provide a principled mechanism to mitigate it.
AI.method: Develop gradient similarity-based framework; prove negative gradient similarity causes forgetting; identify two neuron types (conflicting 50-75%, collaborative 25-50%); propose CNL that freezes conflicting neurons and updates collaborative neurons; provide theoretical guarantee under infinitesimal learning rate and exact mastered set; validate on five LLMs, four datasets, four optimizers.
AI.result: Theoretically, forgetting is eliminated under ideal conditions; empirically, zero forgetting in in-set tasks and 59.1%-81.7% reduction in out-of-set forgetting across multiple configurations.
AI.conclusion: CNL offers a principled, gradient-theory-backed strategy to mitigate catastrophic forgetting with strong empirical support, though its guarantees rely on strong assumptions (infinitesimal learning rate and exact mastered set) and practical implementation details require careful handling.

title: Evaluating Prediction Uncertainty Estimates from BatchEnsemble
summary: Deep learning models struggle with uncertainty estimation. Many approaches are either computationally infeasible or underestimate uncertainty. We investigate \textit{BatchEnsemble} as a general and scalable method for uncertainty estimation across both tabular and time series tasks. To extend BatchEnsemble to sequential modeling, we introduce GRUBE, a novel BatchEnsemble GRU cell. We compare the BatchEnsemble to Monte Carlo dropout and deep ensemble models. Our results show that BatchEnsemble matches the uncertainty estimation performance of deep ensembles, and clearly outperforms Monte Carlo dropout. GRUBE achieves similar or better performance in both prediction and uncertainty estimation. These findings show that BatchEnsemble and GRUBE achieve similar performance with fewer parameters and reduced training and inference time compared to traditional ensembles.

AI.tldr: BatchEnsemble provides a scalable, general uncertainty estimation method for both tabular and time-series data. The authors introduce GRUBE, a BatchEnsemble GRU cell, to extend to sequential models. Comparisons with Monte Carlo dropout and deep ensembles show BatchEnsemble matches deep ensembles in uncertainty performance and outperforms MC dropout; GRUBE matches or exceeds baseline performance in prediction and uncertainty estimation, with fewer parameters and faster training/inference than traditional ensembles.
AI.motivation: Uncertainty estimation in deep learning is challenging: many methods are either computationally prohibitive or fail to capture uncertainty accurately. A scalable approach that works across data modalities (tabular and time series) is needed.
AI.method: Extend BatchEnsemble to sequential models by introducing GRUBE, a BatchEnsemble-enabled GRU cell. Conduct empirical comparisons against Monte Carlo dropout and deep ensembles on both tabular and time-series tasks.
AI.result: BatchEnsemble achieves uncertainty estimation performance comparable to deep ensembles and superior to Monte Carlo dropout. GRUBE achieves similar or better predictive and uncertainty performance.
AI.conclusion: BatchEnsemble and the GRUBE extension provide competitive uncertainty estimation with fewer parameters and reduced training/inference time relative to traditional ensembles, applicable across tabular and sequential data.

title: CORDS: Continuous Representations of Discrete Structures
summary: Many learning problems require predicting sets of objects when the number of objects is not known beforehand. Examples include object detection, molecular modeling, and scientific inference tasks such as astrophysical source detection. Existing methods often rely on padded representations or must explicitly infer the set size, which often poses challenges. We present a novel strategy for addressing this challenge by casting prediction of variable-sized sets as a continuous inference problem. Our approach, CORDS (Continuous Representations of Discrete Structures), provides an invertible mapping that transforms a set of spatial objects into continuous fields: a density field that encodes object locations and count, and a feature field that carries their attributes over the same support. Because the mapping is invertible, models operate entirely in field space while remaining exactly decodable to discrete sets. We evaluate CORDS across molecular generation and regression, object detection, simulation-based inference, and a mathematical task involving recovery of local maxima, demonstrating robust handling of unknown set sizes with competitive accuracy.

AI.tldr: CORDS provides an invertible continuous representation for variable-sized sets, mapping to a density field and a feature field, enabling end-to-end learning in field space with exact decodability to discrete sets; demonstrated across diverse tasks with unknown set sizes.
AI.motivation: Address the challenge of predicting variable-sized sets without padding or explicit size estimation, which can hinder performance and scalability in many domains.
AI.method: Define an invertible mapping from a discrete, variable-sized set to two continuous fields: a density field encoding locations/count and a feature field encoding attributes over the same support. Models operate in field space and can exactly decode to discrete sets.
AI.result: Demonstrates robust handling of unknown set sizes and competitive accuracy across tasks including molecular generation/regression, object detection, simulation-based inference, and a mathematical maxima recovery task.
AI.conclusion: CORDS offers a general, invertible continuous-representation framework for variable-sized set prediction that preserves exact decodability and performs well across diverse domains.

title: Heterogeneity-Aware Knowledge Sharing for Graph Federated Learning
summary: Graph Federated Learning (GFL) enables distributed graph representation learning while protecting the privacy of graph data. However, GFL suffers from heterogeneity arising from diverse node features and structural topologies across multiple clients. To address both types of heterogeneity, we propose a novel graph Federated learning method via Semantic and Structural Alignment (FedSSA), which shares the knowledge of both node features and structural topologies. For node feature heterogeneity, we propose a novel variational model to infer class-wise node distributions, so that we can cluster clients based on inferred distributions and construct cluster-level representative distributions. We then minimize the divergence between local and cluster-level distributions to facilitate semantic knowledge sharing. For structural heterogeneity, we employ spectral Graph Neural Networks (GNNs) and propose a spectral energy measure to characterize structural information, so that we can cluster clients based on spectral energy and build cluster-level spectral GNNs. We then align the spectral characteristics of local spectral GNNs with those of cluster-level spectral GNNs to enable structural knowledge sharing. Experiments on six homophilic and five heterophilic graph datasets under both non-overlapping and overlapping partitioning settings demonstrate that FedSSA consistently outperforms eleven state-of-the-art methods.

AI.tldr: FedSSA tackles both feature and structural heterogeneity in Graph Federated Learning by semantic alignment of node features via variational class-wise distributions and cluster-level distributions, and by structural alignment via spectral energy-based clustering and cluster-level spectral GNNs, achieving state-of-the-art performance on diverse datasets.
AI.motivation: Heterogeneity in client data—both node features and graph topologies—limits knowledge transfer and performance in GFL. A method that aligns semantic (features) and structural (topology) information across clients under privacy constraints is needed.
AI.method: 1) Semantic alignment: infer class-wise node distributions with a variational model, cluster clients by these distributions, create cluster-level representative distributions, and minimize divergence between local and cluster-level distributions to share semantic knowledge. 2) Structural alignment: compute a spectral energy measure to characterize graph structures, cluster clients by spectral energy, build cluster-level spectral GNNs, and align local spectral GNNs with cluster-level spectral GNNs to share structural knowledge.
AI.result: Empirical evaluation on six homophilic and five heterophilic graph datasets, under both non-overlapping and overlapping partitioning, shows FedSSA consistently outperforms eleven state-of-the-art methods.
AI.conclusion: FedSSA effectively mitigates both feature and topology heterogeneity in Graph Federated Learning by integrating semantic and structural alignment through cluster-level representations, leading to robust performance across varied datasets and partitioning schemes.

title: Scalable Power Sampling: Unlocking Efficient, Training-Free Reasoning for LLMs via Distribution Sharpening
summary: Reinforcement learning (RL) post-training is a dominant approach for improving the reasoning performance of large language models (LLMs), yet growing evidence suggests that its gains arise primarily from distribution sharpening rather than the acquisition of new capabilities. Recent work has shown that sampling from the power distribution of LLMs using Markov chain Monte Carlo (MCMC) can recover performance comparable to RL post-training without relying on external rewards; however, the high computational cost of MCMC makes such approaches impractical for widespread adoption. In this work, we propose a theoretically grounded alternative that eliminates the need for iterative MCMC. We derive a novel formulation showing that the global power distribution can be approximated by a token-level scaled low-temperature one, where the scaling factor captures future trajectory quality. Leveraging this insight, we introduce a training-free and verifier-free algorithm that sharpens the base model's generative distribution autoregressively. Empirically, we evaluate our method on math, QA, and code tasks across four LLMs, and show that our method matches or surpasses one-shot GRPO without relying on any external rewards, while reducing inference latency by over 10x compared to MCMC-based sampling.

AI.tldr: A training-free, verifier-free autoregressive sharpening method approximates the global power distribution with a token-level low-temperature scale, achieving RL post-training-like gains without external rewards and with significantly lower latency than MCMC-based sampling.
AI.motivation: To overcome the computational cost and dependency on external rewards in RL post-training and MCMC sampling for improving LLM reasoning, by deriving a scalable, training-free distribution sharpening method.
AI.method: Derives that the global power distribution can be approximated by a token-level scaled low-temperature distribution, where the temperature scaling captures future trajectory quality. Proposes a training-free, verifier-free autoregressive sharpening algorithm.
AI.result: Empirical evaluation on math, QA, and code tasks across four LLMs shows the method matches or surpasses one-shot GRPO without external rewards and reduces inference latency by more than 10x compared to MCMC-based sampling.
AI.conclusion: The proposed token-level temperature-based sharpening provides a practical, efficient alternative to RL post-training and MCMC sampling, delivering comparable gains with lower computational cost and no external rewards.

title: Dynamics Reveals Structure: Challenging the Linear Propagation Assumption
summary: Neural networks adapt through first-order parameter updates, yet it remains unclear whether such updates preserve logical coherence. We investigate the geometric limits of the Linear Propagation Assumption (LPA), the premise that local updates coherently propagate to logical consequences. To formalize this, we adopt relation algebra and study three core operations on relations: negation flips truth values, converse swaps argument order, and composition chains relations. For negation and converse, we prove that guaranteeing direction-agnostic first-order propagation necessitates a tensor factorization separating entity-pair context from relation content. However, for composition, we identify a fundamental obstruction. We show that composition reduces to conjunction, and prove that any conjunction well-defined on linear features must be bilinear. Since bilinearity is incompatible with negation, this forces the feature map to collapse. These results suggest that failures in knowledge editing, the reversal curse, and multi-hop reasoning may stem from common structural limitations inherent to the LPA.

AI.tldr: Under Linear Propagation Assumption (LPA), first-order updates are insufficient to preserve logical coherence across relations; two core results show a fundamental structural limitation: negation/converse require a tensor factorization separating entity-pair context from relation content for direction-agnostic propagation; composition is problematic, reducing to conjunction, which in linear features implies bilinearity and conflicts with negation, forcing an eventual collapse of the feature map.
AI.motivation: Clarify whether local parameter updates in neural networks can coherently propagate to logical consequences, by formalizing LPA with relation algebra to identify necessary structural assumptions and obstructions.
AI.method: Formal analysis of three relation-algebraic operations (negation, converse, composition) on linear features under LPA; derive necessary factorization conditions and obstructions; relate results to knowledge editing, reversal curse, and multi-hop reasoning.
AI.result: Negation and converse require tensor factorization separating entity-pair context from relation content to ensure direction-agnostic propagation. Composition presents an obstruction: it reduces to conjunction; any conjunction well-defined on linear features must be bilinear, which is incompatible with negation, forcing a collapse of the feature map.
AI.conclusion: The Linear Propagation Assumption encounters fundamental structural limitations: (i) to achieve direction-agnostic updates for negation/converse, a factorized representation is necessary; (ii) composition constraints imply a bilinear conjunction on linear features, incompatible with negation, leading to a collapse of representational capacity; these limitations may underlie observed failures in knowledge editing, reversal phenomena, and multi-hop reasoning.

title: Beyond Parameter Finetuning: Test-Time Representation Refinement for Node Classification
summary: Graph Neural Networks frequently exhibit significant performance degradation in the out-of-distribution test scenario. While test-time training (TTT) offers a promising solution, existing Parameter Finetuning (PaFT) paradigm suffer from catastrophic forgetting, hindering their real-world applicability. We propose TTReFT, a novel Test-Time Representation FineTuning framework that transitions the adaptation target from model parameters to latent representations. Specifically, TTReFT achieves this through three key innovations: (1) uncertainty-guided node selection for specific interventions, (2) low-rank representation interventions that preserve pre-trained knowledge, and (3) an intervention-aware masked autoencoder that dynamically adjust masking strategy to accommodate the node selection scheme. Theoretically, we establish guarantees for TTReFT in OOD settings. Empirically, extensive experiments across five benchmark datasets demonstrate that TTReFT achieves consistent and superior performance. Our work establishes representation finetuning as a new paradigm for graph TTT, offering both theoretical grounding and immediate practical utility for real-world deployment.

AI.tldr: TTReFT introduces a test-time representation finetuning framework for graph neural networks, shifting adaptation from model parameters to latent representations via uncertainty-guided node selection, low-rank interventions, and an intervention-aware masked autoencoder; it provides theoretical guarantees and achieves superior results on five benchmarks.
AI.motivation: GNNs lose performance under distribution shift. Parameter finetuning (PaFT) at test time risks catastrophic forgetting, limiting real-world use. Representations offer a way to adapt without overwriting pre-trained knowledge.
AI.method: Three components: (1) uncertainty-guided node selection for targeted interventions, (2) low-rank representation interventions to preserve pre-trained information, (3) an intervention-aware masked autoencoder that adapts masking based on the node selection. The framework provides theoretical guarantees for OOD settings.
AI.result: Empirical evaluation across five benchmark datasets shows TTReFT achieves consistent and superior performance versus baselines, indicating effective OOD adaptation with reduced forgetting.
AI.conclusion: Representation fine-tuning is a viable new paradigm for graph test-time training, combining theoretical grounding with practical utility for robust deployment.

title: Breaking the Overscaling Curse: Thinking Parallelism Before Parallel Thinking
summary: Parallel thinking enhances LLM reasoning by multi-path sampling and aggregation. In system-level evaluations, a global parallelism level N is allocated to all samples, typically set large to maximize overall dataset accuracy. However, due to sample heterogeneity, some samples can achieve comparable performance with a smaller N'< N, causing budget redundancy. This incompatibility between system-level efficacy and sample-level efficiency constitutes the overscaling curse. In this paper, we formalize and quantify the overscaling curse, showing its universality and severity in practice, and analyze its trigger mechanism. We then propose a lightweight method, T2, to break the overscaling curse, which utilizes latent representations to estimate the optimal parallelism level for each sample before decoding. Experiments show that T2 significantly reduces cost while maintaining comparable performance, enabling more efficient parallel thinking.

AI.tldr: Overscaling curse in parallel thinking: applying a single global parallelism level to all samples causes budget waste due to sample heterogeneity. The paper formalizes and quantifies this issue, analyzes its triggers, and introduces T2, a lightweight latent-representation-based method to estimate per-sample optimal parallelism before decoding, achieving substantial cost reductions without sacrificing performance.
AI.motivation: Mitigate compute inefficiency in multi-path LLM reasoning where a global parallelism setting (N) is used for all samples, disregarding sample-specific needs and variability.
AI.method: 1) Formalize and quantify overscaling curse and its universality/severity; 2) analyze the trigger mechanism; 3) propose T2 that uses latent representations to predict the optimal per-sample parallelism before decoding; 4) empirical evaluation to validate cost savings and performance.
AI.result: T2 significantly reduces computational cost while maintaining comparable performance to the baseline with higher global parallelism; demonstrates practical efficiency gains for parallel thinking.
AI.conclusion: Overscaling is a universal and impactful efficiency pitfall in system-level parallel thinking. Per-sample adaptive parallelism via latent representations (T2) effectively breaks the curse, enabling more cost-efficient multi-path reasoning without sacrificing accuracy.

title: LAMP: Look-Ahead Mixed-Precision Inference of Large Language Models
summary: Mixed-precision computations are a hallmark of the current stage of AI, driving the progress in large language models towards efficient, locally deployable solutions. This article addresses the floating-point computation of compositionally-rich functions, concentrating on transformer inference. Based on the rounding error analysis of a composition $f(g(\mathrm{x}))$, we provide an adaptive strategy that selects a small subset of components of $g(\mathrm{x})$ to be computed more accurately while all other computations can be carried out with lower accuracy. We then explain how this strategy can be applied to different compositions within a transformer and illustrate its overall effect on transformer inference. We study the effectiveness of this algorithm numerically on GPT-2 models and demonstrate that already very low recomputation rates allow for improvements of up to two orders of magnitude in accuracy.

AI.tldr: An adaptive mixed-precision strategy for transformer inference that uses rounding-error analysis of nested functions to selectively recompute a subset of a layer's components at higher precision, enabling significant accuracy gains with low recomputation, demonstrated on GPT-2.
AI.motivation: Mitigate precision-induced errors in mixed-precision transformer inference while maintaining efficiency and local deployability.
AI.method: Perform rounding-error analysis on f(g(x)); select a small subset of g(x) components to compute with higher precision while the rest use lower precision; apply to various compositions within a transformer; quantify impact on inference.
AI.result: Numerical experiments on GPT-2 show that very small recomputation rates yield up to two orders of magnitude improvement in accuracy.
AI.conclusion: Adaptive selective recomputation is effective for reducing error in mixed-precision transformer inference and can be applied across different transformer compositions to improve accuracy with minimal recomputation.

title: Training Memory in Deep Neural Networks: Mechanisms, Evidence, and Measurement Gaps
summary: Modern deep-learning training is not memoryless. Updates depend on optimizer moments and averaging, data-order policies (random reshuffling vs with-replacement, staged augmentations and replay), the nonconvex path, and auxiliary state (teacher EMA/SWA, contrastive queues, BatchNorm statistics). This survey organizes mechanisms by source, lifetime, and visibility. It introduces seed-paired, function-space causal estimands; portable perturbation primitives (carry/reset of momentum/Adam/EMA/BN, order-window swaps, queue/teacher tweaks); and a reporting checklist with audit artifacts (order hashes, buffer/BN checksums, RNG contracts). The conclusion is a protocol for portable, causal, uncertainty-aware measurement that attributes how much training history matters across models, data, and regimes.

AI.tldr: A survey asserting that modern deep-learning training history matters and proposing a portable, causal measurement protocol to attribute its impact across models and data.
AI.motivation: To understand and quantify how optimizer state, data ordering, augmentation, nonconvex paths, and auxiliary state affect training outcomes, enabling reproducible attribution across regimes.
AI.method: Taxonomy of mechanisms by source/lifetime/visibility; introduces seed-paired, function-space causal estimands; portable perturbations (carry/reset momentum/Adam/EMA/BN, order-window swaps, queue/teacher tweaks); reporting checklist with audit artifacts (order hashes, buffer/BN checksums, RNG contracts).
AI.result: A concrete protocol for portable, causal, uncertainty-aware measurement that attributes how much training history matters across models, data, and regimes; provides audit artifacts and reporting standards.
AI.conclusion: Promotes adoption of standardized, causal measurement to improve reproducibility and interpretability of training dynamics across diverse settings.

title: Sampling-Free Privacy Accounting for Matrix Mechanisms under Random Allocation
summary: We study privacy amplification for differentially private model training with matrix factorization under random allocation (also known as the balls-in-bins model). Recent work by Choquette-Choo et al. (2025) proposes a sampling-based Monte Carlo approach to compute amplification parameters in this setting. However, their guarantees either only hold with some high probability or require random abstention by the mechanism. Furthermore, the required number of samples for ensuring $(ε,δ)$-DP is inversely proportional to $δ$. In contrast, we develop sampling-free bounds based on Rényi divergence and conditional composition. The former is facilitated by a dynamic programming formulation to efficiently compute the bounds. The latter complements it by offering stronger privacy guarantees for small $ε$, where Rényi divergence bounds inherently lead to an over-approximation. Our framework applies to arbitrary banded and non-banded matrices. Through numerical comparisons, we demonstrate the efficacy of our approach across a broad range of matrix mechanisms used in research and practice.

AI.tldr: Proposes sampling-free DP bounds for matrix mechanisms under random allocation (balls-in-bins) using Rényi divergence and conditional composition; uses dynamic programming to accelerate bound computation; shows efficacy across banded/non-banded matrices and compares favorably to Monte Carlo sampling methods that require many samples or abstention.
AI.motivation: Privacy amplification for differentially private model training with matrix factorization under random allocation; existing sampling-based approaches (e.g., Choquette-Choo et al. 2025) have high-variance guarantees, rely on abstention, or require many samples proportional to 1/δ.
AI.method: Develop sampling-free bounds based on Rényi divergence and conditional composition. Use a dynamic programming formulation to efficiently compute Rényi-based bounds. Apply conditional composition to tighten guarantees for small ε. The framework handles arbitrary banded and non-banded matrices and evaluates across a variety of matrix mechanisms.
AI.result: Provide computable, sampling-free DP bounds; dynamic programming enables efficient calculation; Rényi-based bounds are complemented by conditional composition to yield stronger guarantees for small ε; numerical comparisons show broad efficacy across common matrix mechanisms in theory and practice.
AI.conclusion: The framework delivers robust, sampling-free privacy amplification bounds for matrix mechanisms under random allocation, applicable to a wide class of matrices. It mitigates reliance on sampling-based guarantees, offers efficient computation, and provides stronger small-ε guarantees through conditional composition, with empirical validation across diverse mechanisms.

title: Generative Design of Ship Propellers using Conditional Flow Matching
summary:
In this paper, we explore the use of generative artificial intelligence (GenAI) for ship propeller design. While traditional forward machine learning models predict the performance of mechanical components based on given design parameters, GenAI models aim to generate designs that achieve specified performance targets. In particular, we employ conditional flow matching to establish a bidirectional mapping between design parameters and simulated noise that is conditioned on performance labels. This approach enables the generation of multiple valid designs corresponding to the same performance targets by sampling over the noise vector.
  To support model training, we generate data using a vortex lattice method for numerical simulation and analyze the trade-off between model accuracy and the amount of available data. We further propose data augmentation using pseudo-labels derived from less data-intensive forward surrogate models, which can often improve overall model performance. Finally, we present examples of distinct propeller geometries that exhibit nearly identical performance characteristics, illustrating the versatility and potential of GenAI in engineering design.

AI.tldr: GenAI-based propeller design using conditional flow matching to map design parameters to performance-conditioned noise, enabling generation of multiple valid designs for a given target. Data for training generated via vortex lattice method; data augmentation via pseudo-labels from cheaper forward surrogates; demonstrates distinct geometries with similar performance.
AI.motivation: Address the need for design generation that attains targeted performance while offering design diversity, and to improve data efficiency in engineering design using GenAI.
AI.method: Train a conditional flow-matching model to establish a bidirectional mapping between propeller design parameters and simulated noise, conditioned on performance labels. Generate designs by sampling noise vectors. Create training data via vortex lattice method simulations; study accuracy vs data quantity; augment data with pseudo-labels from low-data forward surrogate models to improve performance.
AI.result: The approach can generate multiple valid propeller geometries achieving the same performance targets. Empirical analysis shows a trade-off between model accuracy and data availability; pseudo-label-based augmentation improves overall performance; examples demonstrate distinct shapes with nearly identical performance.
AI.conclusion: Conditional flow-matching GenAI is a viable, data-efficient pathway for constrained engineering design, offering design diversity and potential applicability beyond propellers.

title: Seg-MoE: Multi-Resolution Segment-wise Mixture-of-Experts for Time Series Forecasting Transformers
summary: Transformer-based models have recently made significant advances in accurate time-series forecasting, but even these architectures struggle to scale efficiently while capturing long-term temporal dynamics. Mixture-of-Experts (MoE) layers are a proven solution to scaling problems in natural language processing. However, existing MoE approaches for time-series forecasting rely on token-wise routing mechanisms, which may fail to exploit the natural locality and continuity of temporal data. In this work, we introduce Seg-MoE, a sparse MoE design that routes and processes contiguous time-step segments rather than making independent expert decisions. Token segments allow each expert to model intra-segment interactions directly, naturally aligning with inherent temporal patterns. We integrate Seg-MoE layers into a time-series Transformer and evaluate it on multiple multivariate long-term forecasting benchmarks. Seg-MoE consistently achieves state-of-the-art forecasting accuracy across almost all prediction horizons, outperforming both dense Transformers and prior token-wise MoE models. Comprehensive ablation studies confirm that segment-level routing is the key factor driving these gains. Our results show that aligning the MoE routing granularity with the inherent structure of time series provides a powerful, yet previously underexplored, inductive bias, opening new avenues for conditionally sparse architectures in sequential data modeling.

AI.tldr: Seg-MoE introduces segment-level routing for Mixture-of-Experts in time-series Transformers, achieving state-of-the-art long-horizon multivariate forecasting by routing contiguous time-step segments rather than tokens.
AI.motivation: To scale Transformers for long-horizon time-series forecasting while preserving temporal locality; token-wise MoE routing ignores segment-level continuity and temporal structure.
AI.method: Propose Seg-MoE: sparse MoE where each expert handles contiguous time-step segments; integrate into a time-series Transformer; conduct experiments on multivariate long-term forecasting benchmarks; perform ablations to assess segment routing.
AI.result: Seg-MoE delivers state-of-the-art forecasting accuracy across nearly all horizons, outperforming dense Transformer baselines and previous token-wise MoE methods; ablations indicate segment-level routing as the key contributor to gains.
AI.conclusion: Segment-level MoE routing aligns with intrinsic temporal structure, providing a strong inductive bias for sequential modeling and enabling more efficient, scalable MoE architectures in time-series forecasting.

title: Identifiable Equivariant Networks are Layerwise Equivariant
summary: We investigate the relation between end-to-end equivariance and layerwise equivariance in deep neural networks. We prove the following: For a network whose end-to-end function is equivariant with respect to group actions on the input and output spaces, there is a parameter choice yielding the same end-to-end function such that its layers are equivariant with respect to some group actions on the latent spaces. Our result assumes that the parameters of the model are identifiable in an appropriate sense. This identifiability property has been established in the literature for a large class of networks, to which our results apply immediately, while it is conjectural for others. The theory we develop is grounded in an abstract formalism, and is therefore architecture-agnostic. Overall, our results provide a mathematical explanation for the emergence of equivariant structures in the weights of neural networks during training -- a phenomenon that is consistently observed in practice.

AI.tldr: If a network’s end-to-end mapping is equivariant under input/output group actions, there exists a parameterization yielding the same end-to-end function where layers are equivariant on latent spaces, under identifiable-parameters assumptions; the result is architecture-agnostic and explains observed weight symmetries during training.
