AI.motivation: Deterministic training of LLMs requires numerical-consistent gradient accumulation, which serializes computations and causes substantial throughput loss (e.g., up to 37.9% on FlashAttention-3). A scheduling reformulation aims to minimize the critical path and improve hardware utilization.
AI.method: Model the backward pass of deterministic attention as a DAG scheduling problem and derive optimal/near-optimal schedules to minimize the critical path. Introduce two strategies: (1) Descending Q-Tile Iteration (reversed query-block traversal to reduce stalls in causal attention) and (2) Shift Scheduling (theoretically optimal DAG schedule for both full and causal masks).
AI.result: Empirical evaluation on NVIDIA H800 GPUs shows up to 1.28× throughput improvement for the backward pass over the baseline, narrowing the deterministic attention performance gap. The work advances reproducible LLM training efficiency and provides open-source code at the given repository.
AI.conclusion: DASH effectively reduces the determinism-induced inefficiency in attention backward passes by leveraging DAG-based scheduling, delivering meaningful throughput gains and making reproducible LLM training more practical.

title: Goal-Driven Adaptive Sampling Strategies for Machine Learning Models Predicting Fields
summary: Machine learning models are widely regarded as a way forward to tackle multi-query challenges that arise once expensive black-box simulations such as computational fluid dynamics are investigated. However, ensuring the desired level of accuracy for a certain task at minimal computational cost, e.g. as few black-box samples as possible, remains a challenges. Active learning strategies are used for scalar quantities to overcome this challenges and different so-called infill criteria exists and are commonly employed in several scenarios. Even though needed in various field an extension of active learning strategies towards field predictions is still lacking or limited to very specific scenarios and/or model types. In this paper we propose an active learning strategy for machine learning models that are capable if predicting field which is agnostic to the model architecture itself. For doing so, we combine a well-established Gaussian process model for a scalar reference value and simultaneously aim at reducing the epistemic model error and the difference between scalar and field predictions. Different specific forms of the above-mentioned approach are introduced and compared to each other as well as only scalar-valued based infill. Results are presented for the NASA common research model for an uncertainty propagation task showcasing high level of accuracy at significantly smaller cost compared to an approach without active learning.

AI.tldr: An active-learning framework for field-predicting ML models using a Gaussian-process scalar reference and dual objectives (epistemic uncertainty and scalar-field discrepancy), with multiple variants; improves efficiency on NASA CRM uncertainty propagation.
AI.motivation: Reduce the cost of high-fidelity simulations by enabling accurate field predictions with as few black-box evaluations as possible; extend active-learning to field predictions in a model-agnostic way.
AI.method: Use a Gaussian process surrogate for a scalar reference value and formulate infill criteria that jointly minimize epistemic model error and the mismatch between scalar and field predictions; introduce and compare several variants against scalar-only infill; evaluate on NASA Common Research Model for uncertainty propagation.
AI.result: Attains high accuracy at significantly lower computational cost compared to an approach that does not employ active learning.
AI.conclusion: The approach extends active learning to field predictions in a model-agnostic manner, with multiple viable variants, and shows promising efficiency gains for CFD surrogate modeling.

title: Scalable Linearized Laplace Approximation via Surrogate Neural Kernel
comment: 6 pages, 1 table. Accepted at European Symposium on Artificial Neural Networks (ESANN 2026) as oral presentation
summary: We introduce a scalable method to approximate the kernel of the Linearized Laplace Approximation (LLA). For this, we use a surrogate deep neural network (DNN) that learns a compact feature representation whose inner product replicates the Neural Tangent Kernel (NTK). This avoids the need to compute large Jacobians. Training relies solely on efficient Jacobian-vector products, allowing to compute predictive uncertainty on large-scale pre-trained DNNs. Experimental results show similar or improved uncertainty estimation and calibration compared to existing LLA approximations. Notwithstanding, biasing the learned kernel significantly enhances out-of-distribution detection. This remarks the benefits of the proposed method for finding better kernels than the NTK in the context of LLA to compute prediction uncertainty given a pre-trained DNN.

AI.tldr: A scalable method to approximate the Linearized Laplace Approximation (LLA) kernel by training a surrogate DNN to reproduce the Neural Tangent Kernel (NTK) via a compact feature representation, enabling efficient predictive uncertainty on large DNNs; experiments show comparable/improved uncertainty and calibration vs existing LLA, with biasing the kernel enhancing out-of-distribution (OOD) detection, suggesting better kernels than NTK for LLA on pre-trained models.
AI.motivation: Compute reliable predictive uncertainty for large pre-trained DNNs using LLA requires handling large Jacobians. NTK-based kernels can be limiting; a scalable learned kernel could improve uncertainty estimation and OOD detection by tailoring the kernel to the data and model.
AI.method: Train a surrogate DNN to learn a compact feature representation whose inner product matches the NTK, using efficient Jacobian-vector products instead of full Jacobians. This yields a scalable kernel approximation for LLA, enabling uncertainty estimation on large models.
AI.result: Experiments show similar or improved uncertainty estimation and calibration compared with existing LLA approximations. Additionally, biasing the learned kernel enhances out-of-distribution detection.
AI.conclusion: A scalable, learned kernel approach for LLA can outperform the standard NTK in predictive uncertainty contexts, enabling better-calibrated uncertainty estimates and stronger OOD detection for large pre-trained DNNs.

title: Constrained Meta Reinforcement Learning with Provable Test-Time Safety
summary: Meta reinforcement learning (RL) allows agents to leverage experience across a distribution of tasks on which the agent can train at will, enabling faster learning of optimal policies on new test tasks. Despite its success in improving sample complexity on test tasks, many real-world applications, such as robotics and healthcare, impose safety constraints during testing. Constrained meta RL provides a promising framework for integrating safety into meta RL. An open question in constrained meta RL is how to ensure the safety of the policy on the real-world test task, while reducing the sample complexity and thus, enabling faster learning of optimal policies. To address this gap, we propose an algorithm that refines policies learned during training, with provable safety and sample complexity guarantees for learning a near optimal policy on the test tasks. We further derive a matching lower bound, showing that this sample complexity is tight.

AI.tldr: A constrained meta-RL framework that refines training policies to ensure test-task safety with provable sample complexity bounds and a matching lower bound.
AI.motivation: Real-world safety constraints in meta-RL require guarantees on the safety of policies during testing while maintaining sample efficiency; current approaches lack tight guarantees.
AI.method: Proposes an algorithm that refines policies learned during training to enforce safety on test tasks, and provides theoretical guarantees on safety and sample complexity; includes a matching lower bound to show tightness of the results.
AI.result: Provable safety guarantees and near-optimal (tight) sample complexity for learning a policy on test tasks; a lower bound demonstrating the bound is tight.
AI.conclusion: The work offers a principled approach to safe constrained meta-RL with tight characterization of sample complexity, enabling faster, safer adaptation to new tasks.

title: READY: Reward Discovery for Meta-Black-Box Optimization
summary: Meta-Black-Box Optimization (MetaBBO) is an emerging avenue within Optimization community, where algorithm design policy could be meta-learned by reinforcement learning to enhance optimization performance. So far, the reward functions in existing MetaBBO works are designed by human experts, introducing certain design bias and risks of reward hacking. In this paper, we use Large Language Model~(LLM) as an automated reward discovery tool for MetaBBO. Specifically, we consider both effectiveness and efficiency sides. On effectiveness side, we borrow the idea of evolution of heuristics, introducing tailored evolution paradigm in the iterative LLM-based program search process, which ensures continuous improvement. On efficiency side, we additionally introduce multi-task evolution architecture to support parallel reward discovery for diverse MetaBBO approaches. Such parallel process also benefits from knowledge sharing across tasks to accelerate convergence. Empirical results demonstrate that the reward functions discovered by our approach could be helpful for boosting existing MetaBBO works, underscoring the importance of reward design in MetaBBO. We provide READY's project at https://anonymous.4open.science/r/ICML_READY-747F.

AI.tldr: Proposes using LLMs to automatically discover reward functions for MetaBBO, combining evolutionary search over LLM-based programs and a multi-task parallel architecture to improve effectiveness and efficiency; empirical results show benefits across existing MetaBBO methods.
AI.motivation: Human-designed rewards in MetaBBO introduce design bias and vulnerability to reward hacking; an automated, scalable reward discovery approach could reduce bias and accelerate improvement.
AI.method: Introduce an LLM-based reward discovery pipeline with (1) an evolutionary paradigm over iterative LLM-based program search to continuously improve reward signals (effectiveness), and (2) a multi-task evolution architecture enabling parallel reward discovery across diverse MetaBBO approaches with cross-task knowledge sharing to speed convergence (efficiency).
AI.result: Empirical results demonstrate that the discovered reward functions boost existing MetaBBO works, highlighting reward design's importance and the practicality of automated reward discovery.
AI.conclusion: Automated reward discovery via LLMs is effective for MetaBBO, reducing reliance on manually crafted rewards and enabling faster progress; parallel multi-task evolution further enhances efficiency through shared knowledge.

title: Visual Disentangled Diffusion Autoencoders: Scalable Counterfactual Generation for Foundation Models
summary: Foundation models, despite their robust zero-shot capabilities, remain vulnerable to spurious correlations and 'Clever Hans' strategies. Existing mitigation methods often rely on unavailable group labels or computationally expensive gradient-based adversarial optimization. To address these limitations, we propose Visual Disentangled Diffusion Autoencoders (DiDAE), a novel framework integrating frozen foundation models with disentangled dictionary learning for efficient, gradient-free counterfactual generation directly for the foundation model. DiDAE first edits foundation model embeddings in interpretable disentangled directions of the disentangled dictionary and then decodes them via a diffusion autoencoder. This allows the generation of multiple diverse, disentangled counterfactuals for each factual, much faster than existing baselines, which generate single entangled counterfactuals. When paired with Counterfactual Knowledge Distillation, DiDAE-CFKD achieves state-of-the-art performance in mitigating shortcut learning, improving downstream performance on unbalanced datasets.

AI.tldr: Proposes DiDAE, a gradient-free counterfactual generator for foundation models using disentangled dictionary learning with a diffusion autoencoder; it yields multiple disentangled counterfactuals and, when paired with Counterfactual Knowledge Distillation, sets new state-of-the-art in mitigating shortcut learning on unbalanced data.
AI.motivation: Foundation models exhibit vulnerability to spurious correlations and Clever Hans strategies. Existing mitigation often requires unavailable group labels or expensive gradient-based optimization; there is a need for efficient, gradient-free counterfactual generation directly for the foundation model.
AI.method: Visual Disentangled Diffusion Autoencoders (DiDAE) freeze foundation models and use disentangled dictionary learning to edit embeddings along interpretable directions, then decode with a diffusion autoencoder to produce multiple diverse, disentangled counterfactuals per factual, without gradients. When combined with Counterfactual Knowledge Distillation (CFKD), it forms DiDAE-CFKD.
AI.result: DiDAE generates multiple diverse counterfactuals per factual and runs faster than baselines that generate a single entangled counterfactual. DiDAE-CFKD achieves state-of-the-art mitigation of shortcut learning and improves downstream performance on unbalanced datasets.
AI.conclusion: The framework provides an efficient, gradient-free pathway to counterfactual generation for foundation models and, via CFKD, delivers strong gains in mitigating shortcut learning on imbalanced data.

title: MoHETS: Long-term Time Series Forecasting with Mixture-of-Heterogeneous-Experts
summary: Real-world multivariate time series can exhibit intricate multi-scale structures, including global trends, local periodicities, and non-stationary regimes, which makes long-horizon forecasting challenging. Although sparse Mixture-of-Experts (MoE) approaches improve scalability and specialization, they typically rely on homogeneous MLP experts that poorly capture the diverse temporal dynamics of time series data. We address these limitations with MoHETS, an encoder-only Transformer that integrates sparse Mixture-of-Heterogeneous-Experts (MoHE) layers. MoHE routes temporal patches to a small subset of expert networks, combining a shared depthwise-convolution expert for sequence-level continuity with routed Fourier-based experts for patch-level periodic structures. MoHETS further improves robustness to non-stationary dynamics by incorporating exogenous information via cross-attention over covariate patch embeddings. Finally, we replace parameter-heavy linear projection heads with a lightweight convolutional patch decoder, improving parameter efficiency, reducing training instability, and allowing a single model to generalize across arbitrary forecast horizons. We validate across seven multivariate benchmarks and multiple horizons, with MoHETS consistently achieving state-of-the-art performance, reducing the average MSE by $12\%$ compared to strong recent baselines, demonstrating effective heterogeneous specialization for long-term forecasting.

AI.tldr: MoHETS is an encoder-only Transformer with sparse Mixture-of-Heterogeneous-Experts (MoHE) for long-horizon multivariate time-series forecasting. It routes patches to heterogeneous experts (shared depthwise-convolution for sequence continuity and Fourier-based experts for patch periodicities), uses cross-attention for exogenous covariates, and employs a convolutional patch decoder for efficiency and horizon generalization. It achieves state-of-the-art across seven benchmarks, with ~12% MSE reduction on average.
AI.motivation: Real-world multivariate time series exhibit multi-scale, non-stationary structure (global trends, local periodicities, regime shifts). Sparse MoEs with homogeneous MLP experts struggle to capture diverse temporal dynamics and generalize across horizons. There is a need for heterogeneous expertise and robust horizon-generalizable architectures.
AI.method: An encoder-only Transformer augmented with sparse Mixture-of-Heterogeneous-Experts (MoHE). Temporal patches are routed to a small subset of expert networks: a shared depthwise-convolution expert for sequence-level continuity and routed Fourier-based experts for patch-level periodic structures. Exogenous information is incorporated via cross-attention over covariate patch embeddings. A lightweight convolutional patch decoder replaces heavy linear heads, enabling parameter efficiency and horizon generalization. The model is trained end-to-end and evaluated across multiple horizons.
AI.result: MoHETS consistently achieves state-of-the-art performance across seven multivariate benchmarks and several horizons, reducing average MSE by about 12% compared to strong recent baselines.
AI.conclusion: Heterogeneous specialization via MoHE within an encoder-only Transformer yields robust long-horizon forecasting for real-world multivariate time series. The combination of diverse experts, cross-attention for exogenous factors, and a convolutional patch decoder affords improved accuracy, robustness to non-stationarity, and horizon-generalization with a single model.

title: Low-Rank Plus Sparse Matrix Transfer Learning under Growing Representations and Ambient Dimensions
summary:
Learning systems often expand their ambient features or latent representations over time, embedding earlier representations into larger spaces with limited new latent structure. We study transfer learning for structured matrix estimation under simultaneous growth of the ambient dimension and the intrinsic representation, where a well-estimated source task is embedded as a subspace of a higher-dimensional target task.
  We propose a general transfer framework in which the target parameter decomposes into an embedded source component, low-dimensional low-rank innovations, and sparse edits, and develop an anchored alternating projection estimator that preserves transferred subspaces while estimating only low-dimensional innovations and sparse modifications. We establish deterministic error bounds that separate target noise, representation growth, and source estimation error, yielding strictly improved rates when rank and sparsity increments are small.
  We demonstrate the generality of the framework by applying it to two canonical problems. For Markov transition matrix estimation from a single trajectory, we derive end-to-end theoretical guarantees under dependent noise. For structured covariance estimation under enlarged dimensions, we provide complementary theoretical analysis in the appendix and empirically validate consistent transfer gains.

AI.tldr: Study of transfer learning for structured matrix estimation under simultaneous growth of ambient and intrinsic representations; transfers a previously learned source subspace to a higher-dimensional target via an anchored projection approach, with error bounds and gains.
AI.motivation: Address transfer learning when both ambient dimension and latent representation grow, by decomposing the target parameter into an embedded source component, low-rank innovations, and sparse edits, and by preserving the transferred subspace during estimation.
AI.method: Propose an anchored alternating projection estimator that maintains the transferred source subspace while estimating low-rank innovations and sparse edits; derive deterministic error bounds that separate target noise, representation growth, and source estimation error; demonstrate framework on two canonical problems.
AI.result: Deterministic error bounds show improved rates when rank and sparsity increments are small; provides end-to-end guarantees for Markov transition matrix estimation under dependent noise and complementary analysis for structured covariance estimation, with empirical validation of transfer gains.
AI.conclusion: The proposed framework is general for growing-dimension structured matrix estimation, enabling reliable transfer of a source task and yielding improved statistical rates, with concrete guarantees for Markov and covariance settings and potential broader applicability.

title: Managing Solution Stability in Decision-Focused Learning with Cost Regularization
summary: Decision-focused learning integrates predictive modeling and combinatorial optimization by training models to directly improve decision quality rather than prediction accuracy alone. Differentiating through combinatorial optimization problems represents a central challenge, and recent approaches tackle this difficulty by introducing perturbation-based approximations. In this work, we focus on estimating the objective function coefficients of a combinatorial optimization problem. Our study demonstrates that fluctuations in perturbation intensity occurring during the learning phase can lead to ineffective training, by establishing a theoretical link to the notion of solution stability in combinatorial optimization. We propose addressing this issue by introducing a regularization of the estimated cost vectors which improves the robustness and reliability of the learning process, as demonstrated by extensive numerical experiments.

AI.tldr: Fluctuations in perturbation intensity during training for estimating objective coefficients in combinatorial optimization degrade learning. The paper links these fluctuations to solution stability and proposes regularizing the estimated cost vectors to enhance robustness and decision quality, supported by numerical experiments.
AI.motivation: Decision-focused learning aims to optimize decision quality directly via differentiating through optimization; perturbation-based approximations are common but can cause unstable training when perturbation strength varies.
AI.method: Theoretically relate perturbation intensity fluctuations to solution stability in combinatorial optimization. Introduce a regularization term on the estimated cost vectors to reduce sensitivity to perturbations. Validate via extensive numerical experiments showing improved robustness and reliability of learning.
AI.result: Regularization reduces sensitivity to perturbation fluctuations, leading to more stable training and better decision-quality outcomes in experiments.
AI.conclusion: Regularizing estimated cost vectors provides a robust enhancement to perturbation-based decision-focused learning, improving stability and performance across numerical studies.

title: Not All Code Is Equal: A Data-Centric Study of Code Complexity and LLM Reasoning
summary: Large Language Models (LLMs) increasingly exhibit strong reasoning abilities, often attributed to their capacity to generate chain-of-thought-style intermediate reasoning. Recent work suggests that exposure to code can further enhance these skills, but existing studies largely treat code as a generic training signal, leaving open the question of which properties of code actually contribute to improved reasoning. To address this gap, we study the structural complexity of code, which captures control flow and compositional structure that may shape how models internalise multi-step reasoning during fine-tuning. We examine two complementary settings: solution-driven complexity, where complexity varies across multiple solutions to the same problem, and problem-driven complexity, where complexity reflects variation in the underlying tasks. Using cyclomatic complexity and logical lines of code to construct controlled fine-tuning datasets, we evaluate a range of open-weight LLMs on diverse reasoning benchmarks. Our findings show that although code can improve reasoning, structural properties strongly determine its usefulness. In 83% of experiments, restricting fine-tuning data to a specific structural complexity range outperforms training on structurally diverse code, pointing to a data-centric path for improving reasoning beyond scaling.

AI.tldr: Structural complexity of code used in fine-tuning LLMs shapes reasoning; restricting fine-tuning to a targeted complexity range often outperforms using diverse code, indicating a data-centric approach to improving reasoning.
AI.motivation: Identify which properties of code contribute to improved reasoning in LLMs, beyond mere exposure, by focusing on code's structural complexity.
AI.method: Construct controlled fine-tuning datasets based on cyclomatic complexity and logical lines of code (LOC). Examine two settings: solution-driven complexity (varying complexity across multiple solutions) and problem-driven complexity (varying underlying tasks). Evaluate open-weight LLMs on diverse reasoning benchmarks.
AI.result: Code exposure improves reasoning, but the structural properties of the code determine usefulness. In 83% of experiments, training on a restricted structural complexity range outperforms training on structurally diverse code.
AI.conclusion: Targeted selection of training data by code structural complexity can yield stronger reasoning improvements than simply increasing data diversity or scale, suggesting a data-centric path for enhancing LLM reasoning.

title: A Low-Complexity Plug-and-Play Deep Learning Model for Generalizable Massive MIMO Precoding
summary: Massive multiple-input multiple-output (mMIMO) downlink precoding offers high spectral efficiency but remains challenging to deploy in practice because near-optimal algorithms such as the weighted minimum mean squared error (WMMSE) are computationally expensive, and sensitive to SNR and channel-estimation quality, while existing deep learning (DL)-based solutions often lack robustness and require retraining for each deployment site. This paper proposes a plug-and-play precoder (PaPP), a DL framework with a backbone that can be trained for either fully digital (FDP) or hybrid beamforming (HBF) precoding and reused across sites, transmit-power levels, and with varying amounts of channel estimation error, avoiding the need to train a new model from scratch at each deployment. PaPP combines a high-capacity teacher and a compact student with a self-supervised loss that balances teacher imitation and normalized sum-rate, trained using meta-learning domain-generalization and transmit-power-aware input normalization. Numerical results on ray-tracing data from three unseen sites show that the PaPP FDP and HBF models both outperform conventional and deep learning baselines, after fine-tuning with a small set of local unlabeled samples. Across both architectures, PaPP achieves more than 21$\times$ reduction in modeled computation energy and maintains good performance under channel-estimation errors, making it a practical solution for energy-efficient mMIMO precoding.

AI.tldr: Plug-and-play precoder PaPP for FDP/HBF with teacher-student self-supervised meta-learning; generalizes across deployment sites and power levels, reducing compute energy and robust to channel-estimation error.
AI.motivation: WMMSE is computationally intensive and sensitive to SNR and channel-estimation quality; existing DL methods lack robustness and require retraining for each deployment site. A universal, energy-efficient, site-agnostic DL precoder is needed.
AI.method: PaPP uses a high-capacity teacher and a compact student with a self-supervised loss that balances teacher imitation and normalized sum-rate. It employs meta-learning for domain generalization and transmit-power-aware input normalization. The framework supports both fully digital (FDP) and hybrid beamforming (HBF) precoding and can be reused across sites, transmit-power levels, and varying channel-estimation error without retraining from scratch.
AI.result: On ray-tracing data from three unseen sites, PaPP FDP and HBF outperform conventional and DL baselines after fine-tuning with a small set of local unlabeled samples. Across architectures, PaPP achieves >21× reduction in modeled computation energy and maintains robust performance under channel-estimation errors.
AI.conclusion: PaPP provides a practical, energy-efficient DL-based precoder that generalizes across deployment sites and power levels without full retraining, suitable for both FDP and HBF mMIMO precoding.

title: Breaking the Regional Barrier: Inductive Semantic Topology Learning for Worldwide Air Quality Forecasting
summary: Global air quality forecasting grapples with extreme spatial heterogeneity and the poor generalization of existing transductive models to unseen regions. To tackle this, we propose OmniAir, a semantic topology learning framework tailored for global station-level prediction. By encoding invariant physical environmental attributes into generalizable station identities and dynamically constructing adaptive sparse topologies, our approach effectively captures long-range non-Euclidean correlations and physical diffusion patterns across unevenly distributed global networks. We further curate WorldAir, a massive dataset covering over 7,800 stations worldwide. Extensive experiments show that OmniAir achieves state-of-the-art performance against 18 baselines, maintaining high efficiency and scalability with speeds nearly 10 times faster than existing models, while effectively bridging the monitoring gap in data-sparse regions.

AI.tldr: OmniAir introduces semantic topology learning for global station-level air quality forecasting by encoding invariant attributes into station identities and constructing adaptive sparse graphs, enabling long-range non-Euclidean modeling and diffusion patterns; paired with WorldAir dataset (7,800+ stations) for scalable evaluation, achieving state-of-the-art performance and ~10× speedups.
AI.motivation: Tackling extreme spatial heterogeneity and poor generalization of existing transductive models to unseen regions in global air quality forecasting, especially in data-sparse areas.
AI.method: Encode invariant physical environmental attributes into generalizable station identities and dynamically construct adaptive sparse topologies to capture long-range non-Euclidean correlations and physical diffusion across uneven global networks.
AI.result: OmniAir achieves state-of-the-art performance against 18 baselines, maintains high efficiency and scalability with speeds ~10× faster than existing models, and effectively reduces monitoring gaps in data-sparse regions; WorldAir dataset covers over 7,800 stations.
AI.conclusion: A scalable, generalizable framework for global station-level air quality forecasting that leverages semantic topology learning to generalize across heterogeneous and sparsely observed regions.

title: Hardware-Triggered Backdoors
summary: Machine learning models are routinely deployed on a wide range of computing hardware. Although such hardware is typically expected to produce identical results, differences in its design can lead to small numerical variations during inference. In this work, we show that these variations can be exploited to create backdoors in machine learning models. The core idea is to shape the model's decision function such that it yields different predictions for the same input when executed on different hardware. This effect is achieved by locally moving the decision boundary close to a target input and then refining numerical deviations to flip the prediction on selected hardware. We empirically demonstrate that these hardware-triggered backdoors can be created reliably across common GPU accelerators. Our findings reveal a novel attack vector affecting the use of third-party models, and we investigate different defenses to counter this threat.

AI.tldr: Hardware-induced numerical variations can be weaponized to create backdoors in ML models; demonstrated across common GPU accelerators; signals new security risks for third-party models and requires defenses.
AI.motivation: Assess security risks from non-deterministic floating-point behavior and cross-hardware inconsistencies, revealing a novel attack surface in ML deployment.
AI.method: Manipulate the model's decision boundary near a target input and tailor numerical deviations so that inference results flip on specific hardware; validate the approach by empirical experiments on GPUs and discuss countermeasures.
AI.result: Show that hardware-triggered backdoors can be created reliably across GPU accelerators; highlights a new threat vector in the model supply chain and explores potential defenses.
AI.conclusion: Hardware variability introduces a new backdoor vector; urges hardware-aware ML verification and robust defenses to mitigate cross-device inference vulnerabilities.

title: Optimistic Transfer under Task Shift via Bellman Alignment
summary:
We study online transfer reinforcement learning (RL) in episodic Markov decision processes, where experience from related source tasks is available during learning on a target task. A fundamental difficulty is that task similarity is typically defined in terms of rewards or transitions, whereas online RL algorithms operate on Bellman regression targets. As a result, naively reusing source Bellman updates introduces systematic bias and invalidates regret guarantees.
  We identify one-step Bellman alignment as the correct abstraction for transfer in online RL and propose re-weighted targeting (RWT), an operator-level correction that retargets continuation values and compensates for transition mismatch via a change of measure. RWT reduces task mismatch to a fixed one-step correction and enables statistically sound reuse of source data.
  This alignment yields a two-stage RWT $Q$-learning framework that separates variance reduction from bias correction. Under RKHS function approximation, we establish regret bounds that scale with the complexity of the task shift rather than the target MDP. Empirical results in both tabular and neural network settings demonstrate consistent improvements over single-task learning and naïve pooling, highlighting Bellman alignment as a model-agnostic transfer principle for online RL.

AI.tldr: Proposes one-step Bellman alignment for transfer in online episodic RL and a re-weighted targeting (RWT) operator to correct for transition mismatch. This yields a two-stage Q-learning framework with regret guarantees under RKHS, and empirical gains in tabular and neural settings.
AI.motivation: To enable statistically valid transfer learning in online RL, where conventional source data reuse biases Bellman updates due to misalignment between task similarity (rewards/transitions) and Bellman regression targets.
AI.method: Introduce one-step Bellman alignment as the transfer abstraction and RWT as an operator-level correction that retargets continuation values via a change of measure. Develop a two-stage RWT Q-learning framework that separates variance reduction from bias correction. Provide regret analysis under RKHS function approximation.
AI.result: Regret bounds scale with the complexity of the task shift rather than the target MDP. Empirical results in tabular and neural network settings show improvements over single-task learning and naïve pooling.
AI.conclusion: Bellman alignment is a model-agnostic transfer principle for online RL; RWT enables statistically sound reuse of source data and improves performance across settings.

title: LoRIF: Low-Rank Influence Functions for Scalable Training Data Attribution
summary: Training data attribution (TDA) identifies which training examples most influenced a model's prediction. The best-performing TDA methods exploits gradients to define an influence function. To overcome the scalability challenge arising from gradient computation, the most popular strategy is random projection (e.g., TRAK, LoGRA). However, this still faces two bottlenecks when scaling to large training sets and high-quality attribution: \emph{(i)} storing and loading projected per-example gradients for all $N$ training examples, where query latency is dominated by I/O; and \emph{(ii)} forming the $D \times D$ inverse Hessian approximation, which costs $O(D^2)$ memory. Both bottlenecks scale with the projection dimension $D$, yet increasing $D$ is necessary for attribution quality -- creating a quality-scalability tradeoff. We introduce \textbf{LoRIF (Low-Rank Influence Functions)}, which exploits low-rank structures of gradient to address both bottlenecks. First, we store rank-$c$ factors of the projected per-example gradients rather than full matrices, reducing storage and query-time I/O from $O(D)$ to $O(c\sqrt{D})$ per layer per sample. Second, we use truncated SVD with the Woodbury identity to approximate the Hessian term in an $r$-dimensional subspace, reducing memory from $O(D^2)$ to $O(Dr)$. On models from 0.1B to 70B parameters trained on datasets with millions of examples, LoRIF achieves up to 20$\times$ storage reduction and query-time speedup compared to LoGRA, while matching or exceeding its attribution quality. LoRIF makes gradient-based TDA practical at frontier scale.

AI.tldr: LoRIF uses low-rank gradient representations and truncated SVD with Woodbury to substantially reduce storage and computation in gradient-based training data attribution, achieving up to 20x savings while maintaining attribution quality.
AI.motivation: Address scalability bottlenecks of gradient-based TDA (per-example gradient storage and D^2 Hessian inverse) when using random projections to accelerate inference; projection dimension D increases with model size and data scale, creating a quality-scalability trade-off.
AI.method: Store rank-c factors of projected per-example gradients instead of full matrices; apply truncated SVD with Woodbury identity to approximate the Hessian term in an r-dimensional subspace, reducing memory from O(D^2) to O(Dr).
AI.result: On models ranging from 0.1B to 70B parameters trained on datasets with millions of examples, LoRIF achieves up to 20× storage reduction and query-time speedup compared to LoGRA, while matching or exceeding attribution quality.
AI.conclusion: LoRIF makes gradient-based training data attribution practical at frontier-scale models and data.

title: Robust Multimodal Representation Learning in Healthcare
summary: Medical multimodal representation learning aims to integrate heterogeneous data into unified patient representations to support clinical outcome prediction. However, real-world medical datasets commonly contain systematic biases from multiple sources, which poses significant challenges for medical multimodal representation learning. Existing approaches typically focus on effective multimodal fusion, neglecting inherent biased features that affect the generalization ability. To address these challenges, we propose a Dual-Stream Feature Decorrelation Framework that identifies and handles the biases through structural causal analysis introduced by latent confounders. Our method employs a causal-biased decorrelation framework with dual-stream neural networks to disentangle causal features from spurious correlations, utilizing generalized cross-entropy loss and mutual information minimization for effective decorrelation. The framework is model-agnostic and can be integrated into existing medical multimodal learning methods. Comprehensive experiments on MIMIC-IV, eICU, and ADNI datasets demonstrate consistent performance improvements.

AI.tldr: A dual-stream causal decorrelation framework for medical multimodal learning that disentangles causal features from spurious biases to improve generalization across datasets.
AI.motivation: Medical multimodal data harbor systematic biases from multiple sources; existing fusion methods overlook these biases, limiting generalization.
AI.method: Dual-stream neural networks with causal-biased decorrelation, latent confounder modeling, generalized cross-entropy loss, and mutual information minimization; model-agnostic and integrable with existing methods.
AI.result: Experiments on MIMIC-IV, eICU, and ADNI show consistent performance improvements.
AI.conclusion: The framework enhances generalization by separating causal features from biased correlations and can be readily integrated into current medical multimodal learning pipelines.

title: Entropy-Based Dimension-Free Convergence and Loss-Adaptive Schedules for Diffusion Models
summary: Diffusion generative models synthesize samples by discretizing reverse-time dynamics driven by a learned score (or denoiser). Existing convergence analyses of diffusion models typically scale at least linearly with the ambient dimension, and sharper rates often depend on intrinsic-dimension assumptions or other geometric restrictions on the target distribution. We develop an alternative, information-theoretic approach to dimension-free convergence that avoids any geometric assumptions. Under mild assumptions on the target distribution, we bound KL divergence between the target and generated distributions by $O(H^2/K)$ (up to endpoint factors), where $H$ is the Shannon entropy and $K$ is the number of sampling steps. Moreover, using a reformulation of the KL divergence, we propose a Loss-Adaptive Schedule (LAS) for efficient discretization of reverse SDE which is lightweight and relies only on the training loss, requiring no post-training heavy computation. Empirically, LAS improves sampling quality over common heuristic schedules.

AI.tldr: Dimension-free convergence for diffusion models via an information-theoretic bound: KL divergence between target and generated distributions scales as O(H^2/K) with K steps; introduces Loss-Adaptive Schedule (LAS) for reverse SDE discretization using only training loss; LAS improves sampling quality over common schedules.
AI.motivation: Provide a dimension-free convergence framework that avoids geometric assumptions and heavy post-training computations, addressing limitations of existing analyses that scale with ambient or intrinsic dimensions.
AI.method: Develop an information-theoretic bound on the KL divergence using the target distribution's Shannon entropy H and the number of sampling steps K. Reformulate KL to derive a Loss-Adaptive Schedule (LAS) for discretizing the reverse SDE, where step sizes adapt based on training loss and require no post-training computation.
AI.result: KL divergence between target and generated distributions bounded by O(H^2/K) up to endpoint factors; LAS yields improved sampling quality compared to common heuristic schedules in experiments.
AI.conclusion: The work provides dimension-free convergence guarantees under mild assumptions and a practical, loss-based discretization strategy for diffusion models, enabling more efficient sampling without geometry-based restrictions.

title: Clarity: The Flexibility-Interpretability Trade-Off in Sparsity-aware Concept Bottleneck Models
summary: The widespread adoption of Vision-Language Models (VLMs) across fields has amplified concerns about model interpretability. Distressingly, these models are often treated as black-boxes, with limited or non-existent investigation of their decision making process. Despite numerous post- and ante-hoc interepretability methods, systematic and objective evaluation of the learned representations remains limited, particularly for sparsity-aware methods that are increasingly considered to "induce interpretability". In this work, we focus on Concept Bottleneck Models and investigate how different modeling decisions affect the emerging representations. We introduce the notion of clarity, a measure, capturing the interplay between the downstream performance and the sparsity and precision of the concept representation, while proposing an interpretability assessment framework using datasets with ground truth concept annotations. We consider both VLM- and attribute predictor-based CBMs, and three different sparsity-inducing strategies: per example $\ell_1, \ell_0$ and Bernoulli-based formulations. Our experiments reveal a critical trade-off between flexibility and interpretability, under which a given method can exhibit markedly different behaviors even at comparable performance levels. The code will be made publicly available upon publication.

AI.tldr: Study on Concept Bottleneck Models in Vision-Language Models introducing 'clarity' as a trade-off metric between performance and concept sparsity/precision; evaluates sparsity-inducing strategies (per-example l1, l0, Bernoulli) across VLM- and attribute-based CBMs; finds a flexibility-interpretability trade-off; code to be released.
AI.motivation: Address the lack of objective, systematic evaluation of CBMs' internal representations and interpretability in VLMs; explore how modeling choices impact concepts and downstream performance.
AI.method: Define 'clarity' to quantify trade-offs between accuracy and concept sparsity/precision; use an interpretability assessment framework with datasets having ground-truth concept annotations; compare VLM-based CBMs and attribute-predictor CBMs across three sparsity strategies: per-example L1, L0, Bernoulli.
AI.result: Observation of a critical trade-off between flexibility and interpretability; methods can behave very differently at similar performance levels; results underscore the non-trivial effect of sparsity-inducing choices on representations.
AI.conclusion: Framework for evaluating interpretability of CBMs in VLMs; emphasizes need to balance sparsity, precision, and performance; code will be publicly available.

title: Dependence of Equilibrium Propagation Training Success on Network Architecture
summary: The rapid rise of artificial intelligence has led to an unsustainable growth in energy consumption. This has motivated progress in neuromorphic computing and physics-based training of learning machines as alternatives to digital neural networks. Many theoretical studies focus on simple architectures like all-to-all or densely connected layered networks. However, these may be challenging to realize experimentally, e.g. due to connectivity constraints. In this work, we investigate the performance of the widespread physics-based training method of equilibrium propagation for more realistic architectural choices, specifically, locally connected lattices. We train an XY model and explore the influence of architecture on various benchmark tasks, tracking the evolution of spatially distributed responses and couplings during training. Our results show that sparse networks with only local connections can achieve performance comparable to dense networks. Our findings provide guidelines for further scaling up architectures based on equilibrium propagation in realistic settings.

AI.tldr: Equilibrium propagation can work well on locally connected lattices, achieving comparable performance to dense networks, offering a path to realistic, energy-efficient neuromorphic architectures.
AI.motivation: Address the energy growth of AI and explore physics-based training (equilibrium propagation) under realistic connectivity constraints.
AI.method: Train an XY model on locally connected lattices using equilibrium propagation; analyze benchmark tasks and monitor spatially distributed responses and couplings during training.
AI.result: Sparse, locally connected networks attain performance comparable to dense networks, suggesting local connectivity suffices for effective learning; results guide scaling of architectures in equilibrium propagation.
AI.conclusion: Local connectivity can maintain performance while aligning with realistic hardware constraints; the work provides practical guidelines for scaling neuromorphic, physics-based training architectures.

title: Embracing Aleatoric Uncertainty in Medical Multimodal Learning with Missing Modalities
summary: Medical multimodal learning faces significant challenges with missing modalities prevalent in clinical practice. Existing approaches assume equal contribution of modality and random missing patterns, neglecting inherent uncertainty in medical data acquisition. In this regard, we propose the Aleatoric Uncertainty Modeling (AUM) that explicitly quantifies unimodal aleatoric uncertainty to address missing modalities. Specifically, AUM models each unimodal representation as a multivariate Gaussian distribution to capture aleatoric uncertainty and enable principled modality reliability quantification. To adaptively aggregate captured information, we develop a dynamic message-passing mechanism within a bipartite patient-modality graph using uncertainty-aware aggregation mechanism. Through this process, missing modalities are naturally accommodated, while more reliable information from available modalities is dynamically emphasized to guide representation generation. Our AUM framework achieves an improvement of 2.26% AUC-ROC on MIMIC-IV mortality prediction and 2.17% gain on eICU, outperforming existing state-of-the-art approaches.

AI.tldr: Aleatoric Uncertainty Modeling (AUM) for multimodal medical learning; models unimodal representations as Gaussian to quantify aleatoric uncertainty; uses a dynamic, uncertainty-aware bipartite patient-modality graph for fusion; improves mortality prediction on MIMIC-IV and eICU.
AI.motivation: Medical multimodal data often has missing modalities and inherent acquisition uncertainty. Existing methods assume equal modality contribution and ignore uncertainty, leading to suboptimal fusion and unreliable predictions.
AI.method: Represent each unimodal feature as a multivariate Gaussian to capture aleatoric uncertainty; dynamic message-passing on a bipartite graph where modalities and patient nodes exchange messages; uncertainty-aware aggregation to emphasize reliable modalities and gracefully handle missing ones.
AI.result: Improves AUC-ROC by 2.26 percentage points on MIMIC-IV mortality prediction and 2.17 percentage points on eICU, outperforming current state-of-the-art methods.
AI.conclusion: Modeling unimodal aleatoric uncertainty and adaptive, uncertainty-aware fusion improves robustness to missing modalities and predictive performance in clinical multimodal tasks.

title: Uncertainty-Aware Data-Based Method for Fast and Reliable Shape Optimization
summary: Data-based optimization (DBO) offers a promising approach for efficiently optimizing shape for better aerodynamic performance by leveraging a pretrained surrogate model for offline evaluations during iterations. However, DBO heavily relies on the quality of the training database. Samples outside the training distribution encountered during optimization can lead to significant prediction errors, potentially misleading the optimization process. Therefore, incorporating uncertainty quantification into optimization is critical for detecting outliers and enhancing robustness. This study proposes an uncertainty-aware data-based optimization (UA-DBO) framework to monitor and minimize surrogate model uncertainty during DBO. A probabilistic encoder-decoder surrogate model is developed to predict uncertainties associated with its outputs, and these uncertainties are integrated into a model-confidence-aware objective function to penalize samples with large prediction errors during data-based optimization process. The UA-DBO framework is evaluated on two multipoint optimization problems aimed at improving airfoil drag divergence and buffet performance. Results demonstrate that UA-DBO consistently reduces prediction errors in optimized samples and achieves superior performance gains compared to original DBO. Moreover, compared to multipoint optimization based on full computational simulations, UA-DBO offers comparable optimization effectiveness while significantly accelerating optimization speed.

AI.tldr: UA-DBO uses a probabilistic encoder-decoder surrogate to quantify uncertainty and integrate it into a confidence-aware objective, improving robustness and speed in aerodynamic data-based optimization.
AI.motivation: DBO effectiveness hinges on the training data; samples encountered during optimization can lie outside the training distribution, causing large prediction errors. Uncertainty quantification is needed to detect outliers and enhance robustness.
AI.method: Develop a probabilistic encoder-decoder surrogate that predicts output uncertainty and integrate these uncertainties into a model-confidence-aware objective, penalizing high-uncertainty samples during the DBO process; evaluate on two multipoint airfoil optimization problems.
AI.result: UA-DBO consistently reduces surrogate-prediction errors in optimized samples and achieves superior performance over baseline DBO; under full-physics multipoint optimization, UA-DBO provides comparable optimization effectiveness with significantly faster optimization.
AI.conclusion: Uncertainty-aware data-based optimization improves robustness and efficiency in aerodynamic optimization by quantifying and incorporating surrogate uncertainties into the optimization objective.

title: Bridging Graph Structure and Knowledge-Guided Editing for Interpretable Temporal Knowledge Graph Reasoning
summary: Temporal knowledge graph reasoning (TKGR) aims to predict future events by inferring missing entities with dynamic knowledge structures. Existing LLM-based reasoning methods prioritize contextual over structural relations, struggling to extract relevant subgraphs from dynamic graphs. This limits structural information understanding, leading to unstructured, hallucination-prone inferences especially with temporal inconsistencies. To address this problem, we propose IGETR (Integration of Graph and Editing-enhanced Temporal Reasoning), a hybrid reasoning framework that combines the structured temporal modeling capabilities of Graph Neural Networks (GNNs) with the contextual understanding of LLMs. IGETR operates through a three-stage pipeline. The first stage aims to ground the reasoning process in the actual data by identifying structurally and temporally coherent candidate paths through a temporal GNN, ensuring that inference starts from reliable graph-based evidence. The second stage introduces LLM-guided path editing to address logical and semantic inconsistencies, leveraging external knowledge to refine and enhance the initial paths. The final stage focuses on integrating the refined reasoning paths to produce predictions that are both accurate and interpretable. Experiments on standard TKG benchmarks show that IGETR achieves state-of-the-art performance, outperforming strong baselines with relative improvements of up to 5.6% on Hits@1 and 8.1% on Hits@3 on the challenging ICEWS datasets. Additionally, we execute ablation studies and additional analyses confirm the effectiveness of each component.

AI.tldr: Hybrid TKGR framework IGETR integrates Graph Neural Networks with LLM-guided editing for grounded, interpretable temporal reasoning, achieving SOTA on ICEWS with notable Hits@1 and Hits@3 gains.
AI.motivation: Address the limitations of LLM-only temporal reasoning in TKGR by leveraging structured temporal modeling and external knowledge to reduce hallucinations and improve subgraph grounding.
AI.method: Three-stage pipeline: (1) ground reasoning via temporal GNN to extract structurally/temporally coherent candidate paths; (2) LLM-guided path editing to fix logical/semantic inconsistencies using external knowledge; (3) integrate refined paths to produce accurate, interpretable predictions. Includes ablation studies.
AI.result: State-of-the-art performance on standard TKGR benchmarks, with relative improvements up to 5.6% in Hits@1 and 8.1% in Hits@3 on ICEWS datasets; ablation studies confirm effectiveness of each component.
AI.conclusion: A principled hybrid approach combining structured temporal modeling (GNNs) and contextual LLM reasoning yields accurate, interpretable TKGR predictions and better resistance to temporal inconsistencies.

title: Investigation into using stochastic embedding representations for evaluating the trustworthiness of the Fréchet Inception Distance
summary: Feature embeddings acquired from pretrained models are widely used in medical applications of deep learning to assess the characteristics of datasets; e.g. to determine the quality of synthetic, generated medical images. The Fréchet Inception Distance (FID) is one popular synthetic image quality metric that relies on the assumption that the characteristic features of the data can be detected and encoded by an InceptionV3 model pretrained on ImageNet1K (natural images). While it is widely known that this makes it less effective for applications involving medical images, the extent to which the metric fails to capture meaningful differences in image characteristics is not obviously known. Here, we use Monte Carlo dropout to compute the predictive variance in the FID as well as a supplemental estimate of the predictive variance in the feature embedding model's latent representations. We show that the magnitudes of the predictive variances considered exhibit varying degrees of correlation with the extent to which test inputs (ImageNet1K validation set augmented at various strengths, and other external datasets) are out-of-distribution relative to its training data, providing some insight into the effectiveness of their use as indicators of the trustworthiness of the FID.

AI.tldr: The paper investigates whether the Fréchet Inception Distance (FID) remains a reliable metric for medical images by incorporating predictive uncertainty through Monte Carlo dropout in both the FID computation and the embedding model, finding that uncertainty correlates with out-of-distribution shifts and can inform the trustworthiness of FID.
AI.motivation: FID relies on a pretrained InceptionV3 (ImageNet) feature space, which may poorly capture medical image characteristics. There is a need to quantify how model uncertainty and domain shift affect FID's reliability when used to assess medical image quality or synthetic data.
AI.method: Apply Monte Carlo dropout to estimate predictive variance for the FID score and for the latent representations of the embedding model. Evaluate on augmented ImageNet-1K validation samples at varying corruption/augmentation strengths and on other external datasets to induce OOD, then analyze correlations between predictive variances and OOD extent.
AI.result: The magnitudes of predictive variances show varying correlations with how out-of-distribution the test inputs are relative to training data. This suggests that uncertainty estimates can reflect the trustworthiness of FID signals in distinguishing meaningful image characteristics.
AI.conclusion: Predictive uncertainty in FID and in embedding representations can serve as indicators of when FID is a reliable measure for medical images and when domain mismatch undermines its interpretability; incorporating uncertainty can improve the assessment of synthetic medical image quality.

title: PowerGenie: Analytically-Guided Evolutionary Discovery of Superior Reconfigurable Power Converters
summary: Discovering superior circuit topologies requires navigating an exponentially large design space-a challenge traditionally reserved for human experts. Existing AI methods either select from predefined templates or generate novel topologies at a limited scale without rigorous verification, leaving large-scale performance-driven discovery underexplored. We present PowerGenie, a framework for automated discovery of higher-performance reconfigurable power converters at scale. PowerGenie introduces: (1) an automated analytical framework that determines converter functionality and theoretical performance limits without component sizing or SPICE simulation, and (2) an evolutionary finetuning method that co-evolves a generative model with its training distribution through fitness selection and uniqueness verification. Unlike existing methods that suffer from mode collapse and overfitting, our approach achieves higher syntax validity, function validity, novelty rate, and figure-of-merit (FoM). PowerGenie discovers a novel 8-mode reconfigurable converter with 23% higher FoM than the best training topology. SPICE simulations confirm average absolute efficiency gains of 10% across 8 modes and up to 17% at a single mode. Code is available at https://github.com/xz-group/PowerGenie.

AI.tldr: PowerGenie automates discovery of high-performance reconfigurable power converters by coupling an analytical, sizing-free performance bound framework with evolutionary finetuning of a generative model. It achieves >23% FoM gain on an 8-mode topology and ~10-17% efficiency gains in SPICE, mitigating mode collapse and overfitting; code released.
AI.motivation: Overcome the exponential design-space and verification bottlenecks in topology optimization for power converters, where existing AI methods rely on templates or limited-scale generation with insufficient validation.
AI.method: (1) An automated analytical framework that determines converter functionality and theoretical performance limits without component sizing or SPICE; (2) An evolutionary finetuning procedure that co-evolves a generative model with its training distribution via fitness selection and uniqueness verification to avoid mode collapse.
AI.result: Discovered a novel 8-mode reconfigurable converter with 23% higher FoM than the best training topology; SPICE simulations show average absolute efficiency gains of 10% across 8 modes and up to 17% in a single mode; improved syntax validity, function validity, and novelty rate; code available.
AI.conclusion: Demonstrates scalable, performance-driven topology discovery for power converters, addressing mode collapse and overfitting and enabling large-scale exploration; provides open-source resources.

title: Elign: Equivariant Diffusion Model Alignment from Foundational Machine Learning Force Fields
summary: Generative models for 3D molecular conformations must respect Euclidean symmetries and concentrate probability mass on thermodynamically favorable, mechanically stable structures. However, E(3)-equivariant diffusion models often reproduce biases from semi-empirical training data rather than capturing the equilibrium distribution of a high-fidelity Hamiltonian. While physics-based guidance can correct this, it faces two computational bottlenecks: expensive quantum-chemical evaluations (e.g., DFT) and the need to repeat such queries at every sampling step. We present Elign, a post-training framework that amortizes both costs. First, we replace expensive DFT evaluations with a faster, pretrained foundational machine-learning force field (MLFF) to provide physical signals. Second, we eliminate repeated run-time queries by shifting physical steering to the training phase. To achieve the second amortization, we formulate reverse diffusion as a reinforcement learning problem and introduce Force--Energy Disentangled Group Relative Policy Optimization (FED-GRPO) to fine-tune the denoising policy. FED-GRPO includes a potential-based energy reward and a force-based stability reward, which are optimized and group-normalized independently. Experiments show that Elign generates conformations with lower gold-standard DFT energies and forces, while improving stability. Crucially, inference remains as fast as unguided sampling, since no energy evaluations are required during generation.

AI.tldr: Elign amortizes both data and compute bottlenecks in E(3)-equivariant diffusion for molecular conformations by replacing DFT with a pretrained ML force field and moving energy guidance into training via FED-GRPO RL, enabling fast, accurate generation without runtime energy evaluations.
AI.motivation: Overcome the computational cost of frequent quantum-chemical evaluations (DFT) and biases from semi-empirical data in diffusion-based conformational generation by aligning with a high-fidelity Hamiltonian's equilibrium distribution.
AI.method: Use a pretrained ML force field to provide physical signals during generation; reformulate reverse diffusion as a reinforcement learning problem and train a denoising policy with Force–Energy Disentangled Group Relative Policy Optimization (FED-GRPO), incorporating a potential-based energy reward and a force-based stability reward with group normalization.
AI.result: Conformations exhibit lower gold-standard DFT energies and forces and improved stability; inference remains as fast as unguided sampling since no energy evaluations are required during generation.
AI.conclusion: Elign effectively amortizes both data and computation costs, achieving alignment with higher-fidelity thermodynamics while preserving fast inference through training-time guidance.

title: Geometry of Drifting MDPs with Path-Integral Stability Certificates
summary: Real-world reinforcement learning is often \emph{nonstationary}: rewards and dynamics drift, accelerate, oscillate, and trigger abrupt switches in the optimal action. Existing theory often represents nonstationarity with coarse-scale models that measure \emph{how much} the environment changes, not \emph{how} it changes locally -- even though acceleration and near-ties drive tracking error and policy chattering. We take a geometric view of nonstationary discounted Markov Decision Processes (MDPs) by modeling the environment as a differentiable homotopy path and tracking the induced motion of the optimal Bellman fixed point. This yields a length-curvature-kink signature of intrinsic complexity: cumulative drift, acceleration/oscillation, and action-gap-induced nonsmoothness. We prove a solver-agnostic path-integral stability bound and derive gap-safe feasible regions that certify local stability away from switch regimes. Building on these results, we introduce \textit{Homotopy-Tracking RL (HT-RL)} and \textit{HT-MCTS}, lightweight wrappers that estimate replay-based proxies of length, curvature, and near-tie proximity online and adapt learning or planning intensity accordingly. Experiments show improved tracking and dynamic regret over matched static baselines, with the largest gains in oscillatory and switch-prone regimes.

AI.tldr: Geometric, homotopy-based nonstationary RL tracking; introduces HT-RL/HT-MCTS to adapt to local complexity and improves dynamic regret, especially under oscillations and switches.
AI.motivation: Nonstationarity in real-world RL is poorly captured by coarse metrics; local dynamics (drift, acceleration, near ties) drive tracking error; need a framework to quantify and exploit local changes.
AI.method: Model nonstationarity as a differentiable homotopy path; analyze the movement of the optimal Bellman fixed point; define length-curvature-kink signature; prove a path-integral stability bound; derive gap-safe feasible regions; implement HT-RL and HT-MCTS as wrappers that estimate proxies online to adapt learning/planning.
AI.result: Demonstrates improved tracking and dynamic regret over static baselines; most gains in oscillatory/switch-prone regimes; provides solver-agnostic stability results and practical adaptive mechanisms.
AI.conclusion: Offers a solver-agnostic, geometry-based framework for adaptive RL under nonstationarity; enables online adaptation to local environment changes via lightweight wrappers, with strong empirical benefits in challenging regimes.

title: Negatives-Dominant Contrastive Learning for Generalization in Imbalanced Domains
summary: Imbalanced Domain Generalization (IDG) focuses on mitigating both domain and label shifts, both of which fundamentally shape the model's decision boundaries, particularly under heterogeneous long-tailed distributions across domains. Despite its practical significance, it remains underexplored, primarily due to the technical complexity of handling their entanglement and the paucity of theoretical foundations. In this paper, we begin by theoretically establishing the generalization bound for IDG, highlighting the role of posterior discrepancy and decision margin. This bound motivates us to focus on directly steering decision boundaries, marking a clear departure from existing methods. Subsequently, we technically propose a novel Negative-Dominant Contrastive Learning (NDCL) for IDG to enhance discriminability while enforce posterior consistency across domains. Specifically, inter-class decision-boundary separation is enhanced by placing greater emphasis on negatives as the primary signal in our contrastive learning, naturally amplifying gradient signals for minority classes to avoid the decision boundary being biased toward majority classes. Meanwhile, intra-class compactness is encouraged through a re-weighted cross-entropy strategy, and posterior consistency across domains is enforced through a prediction-central alignment strategy. Finally, rigorous yet challenging experiments on benchmarks validate the effectiveness of our NDCL. The code is available at https://github.com/Alrash/NDCL.

AI.tldr: Proposes Negative-Dominant Contrastive Learning (NDCL) for Imbalanced Domain Generalization (IDG), anchored by a theoretical generalization bound; combines inter-class boundary emphasis via negative-dominated contrastive loss, intra-class compactness with re-weighted cross-entropy, and posterior consistency through prediction-centered alignment; validated on benchmarks with code release.
AI.motivation: IDG involves simultaneous domain shift and label shift under long-tailed distributions, which jointly shape decision boundaries. The problem is theoretically underexplored and practically challenging due to entanglement of shifts and insufficient theoretical foundations. The work seeks to ground IDG in a generalization bound and to steer decision boundaries directly.
AI.method: (1) Derive a generalization bound for IDG emphasizing posterior discrepancy and decision margin; (2) Propose NDCL: enhance inter-class separation by foregrounding negatives in contrastive learning, produce intra-class compactness with a re-weighted cross-entropy, and enforce cross-domain posterior consistency via a prediction-centered alignment strategy.
AI.result: The approach yields improved discriminability and better handling of minority classes, with validation on standard benchmarks. Code for replication is provided at the stated repository.
AI.conclusion: Directly shaping decision boundaries under IDG via NDCL is theoretically motivated and empirically effective, offering a principled path beyond existing methods and highlighting the role of posterior alignment and boundary-focused learning in imbalanced domain settings.

title: Rate-Distortion Optimization for Transformer Inference
summary: Transformers achieve superior performance on many tasks, but impose heavy compute and memory requirements during inference. This inference can be made more efficient by partitioning the process across multiple devices, which, in turn, requires compressing its intermediate representations. In this work, we introduce a principled rate-distortion-based framework for lossy compression that learns compact encodings that explicitly trade off bitrate against accuracy. Experiments on language benchmarks show that the proposed codec achieves substantial savings with improved accuracy in some cases, outperforming more complex baseline methods. We characterize and analyze the rate-distortion performance of transformers, offering a unified lens for understanding performance in representation coding. This formulation extends information-theoretic concepts to define the gap between rate and entropy, and derive some of its bounds. We further develop probably approximately correct (PAC)-style bounds for estimating this gap. For different architectures and tasks, we empirically demonstrate that their rates are driven by these bounds, adding to the explainability of the formulation.

AI.tldr: A rate-distortion-based lossy compression framework for transformers enables efficient multi-device inference by learning compact encodings that trade bitrate for accuracy; it provides a unified rate-distortion view, entropy-gap bounds, and PAC-style bounds, with empirical gains on language tasks and outperforming complex baselines.
AI.motivation: Reduce compute and memory during transformer inference by compressing intermediate representations across device partitions, while preserving accuracy through a principled, quantitative tradeoff between bitrate and distortion (accuracy).
AI.method: Develop a rate-distortion framework for a lossy codec that encodes transformer representations. Derive a rate-distance (rate-entropy-gap) formulation, and establish PAC-style bounds to estimate this gap. Empirically evaluate on language benchmarks across architectures/tasks, comparing bitrate and accuracy against baselines, and analyze how rates align with theoretical bounds.
AI.result: The codec achieves substantial bitrate savings and, in some cases, improved accuracy, outperforming more complex baselines. The rate-distortion formulation provides a unified analytical lens for transformer representations, and the authors derive bounds on the rate-entropy gap with PAC-style estimators that correlate with observed rates across architectures and tasks.
AI.conclusion: A principled information-theoretic framework extends rate-distortion concepts to neural representation coding in transformers, offering explainability for efficiency gains in distributed/inference-time compression and guiding the design of compact encodings with predictable performance.

title: Exploring Diverse Generation Paths via Inference-time Stiefel Activation Steering
comment: 34 pages, 2 figures. Accepted for publication at ICLR 2026
summary: Language models often default to a narrow set of high-probability outputs, leaving their generation paths homogeneous and prone to mode collapse. Sampling-based strategies inject randomness but still struggle to guarantee diversity across multiple concurrent generation runs. We address this limitation by introducing STARS ($\textbf{St}$iefel-based $\textbf{A}$ctivation Steering for Diverse $\textbf{R}$ea$\textbf{S}$oning), a training-free, inference-time intervention method that transforms activation steering into an exploration engine. At each token, STARS collects the hidden activations of concurrent generation runs and optimizes multiple additive steering directions jointly on the Stiefel manifold. STARS maximizes the geometric volume of the steered activations, while the Stiefel manifold induces orthogonality of the steering interventions. This formulation explicitly promotes divergent activation vectors of concurrent generation runs, and implicitly promotes divergent generation trajectories. This manifold optimization formulation can be solved using a Riemannian gradient descent algorithm with convergence guarantees, but this algorithm is too time-consuming for real-time inference. To guarantee low latency, we further design a lightweight one-step update with an aggressive, closed-form stepsize. For test case generation and scientific discovery benchmarks, STARS consistently outperforms standard sampling methods, achieving greater diversity without sacrificing qualitative performance.

AI.tldr: Training-free, inference-time activation steering (STARS) using Stiefel-manifold optimization to promote diversity across concurrent generation runs; achieves low-latency diversification without retraining.
AI.motivation: LMs tend to produce a narrow set of high-probability outputs, leading to homogeneous generations and potential mode collapse across parallel sampling runs; need a method to actively diversify trajectories during inference without retraining.
AI.method: At each token, collect hidden activations from concurrent generations and jointly optimize multiple additive steering directions on the Stiefel manifold to maximize the geometric volume of steered activations while enforcing orthogonality. Implement a Riemannian gradient descent with a fast one-step closed-form update for low latency.
AI.result: STARS outperforms standard sampling methods on test-case generation and scientific discovery benchmarks, achieving greater diversity without sacrificing qualitative performance.
AI.conclusion: STARS provides a training-free, inference-time mechanism for diverse generation by steering activations on a constrained manifold, achieving lower latency with competitive quality.

title: Putting a Face to Forgetting: Continual Learning meets Mechanistic Interpretability
summary: Catastrophic forgetting in continual learning is often measured at the performance or last-layer representation level, overlooking the underlying mechanisms. We introduce a mechanistic framework that offers a geometric interpretation of catastrophic forgetting as the result of transformations to the encoding of individual features. These transformations can lead to forgetting by reducing the allocated capacity of features (worse representation) and disrupting their readout by downstream computations. Analysis of a tractable model formalizes this view, allowing us to identify best- and worst-case scenarios. Through experiments on this model, we empirically test our formal analysis and highlight the detrimental effect of depth. Finally, we demonstrate how our framework can be used in the analysis of practical models through the use of Crosscoders. We present a case study of a Vision Transformer trained on sequential CIFAR-10. Our work provides a new, feature-centric vocabulary for continual learning.

AI.tldr: A mechanistic, feature-centric view of catastrophic forgetting in continual learning, modeling forgetting as feature-encoding transformations that shrink capacity and disrupt readout; validated via a tractable model, depth analysis, and Crosscoders with a Vision Transformer on sequential CIFAR-10.
AI.motivation: Current forgetting metrics focus on last-layer performance and task boundaries; there is a need for a mechanistic, geometry-based understanding of how encoding changes drive forgetting at the feature level, to unify theory and practice.
AI.method: Propose a geometric/mechanistic framework that treats forgetting as transformations to feature encodings. Formalize it with a tractable model to identify best- and worst-case scenarios. Validate via experiments on the model, examine depth effects, and apply Crosscoders to analyze practical models, including a Vision Transformer trained on sequential CIFAR-10.
AI.result: The framework links encoding transformations to two forgetting pathways: reduced feature capacity (poorer representations) and disrupted downstream readout. The tractable model yields analytic best- and worst-case scenarios, with experiments supporting depth as detrimental. Crosscoders enable analysis of practical models, demonstrated in a Vision Transformer trained on sequential CIFAR-10.
AI.conclusion: Offers a new, feature-centric vocabulary for continual learning and demonstrates how a mechanistic framing can guide analysis and understanding of forgetting in both synthetic and practical models.

title: TBDFiltering: Sample-Efficient Tree-Based Data Filtering
summary: The quality of machine learning models depends heavily on their training data. Selecting high-quality, diverse training sets for large language models (LLMs) is a difficult task, due to the lack of cheap and reliable quality metrics. While querying existing LLMs for document quality is common, this is not scalable to the large number (billions) of documents used in training. Instead, practitioners often use classifiers trained on sparse quality signals. In this paper, we propose a text-embedding-based hierarchical clustering approach that adaptively selects the documents to be evaluated by the LLM to estimate cluster quality.
