We prove that our method is query efficient: under the assumption that the hierarchical clustering contains a subtree such that each leaf cluster in the tree is pure enough (i.e., it mostly contains either only good or only bad documents), with high probability, the method can correctly predict the quality of each document after querying a small number of documents. The number of such documents is proportional to the size of the smallest subtree with (almost) pure leaves, without the algorithm knowing this subtree in advance. Furthermore, in a comprehensive experimental study, we demonstrate the benefits of our algorithm compared to other classifier-based filtering methods.

AI.tldr: A query-efficient, embedding-based hierarchical clustering method for estimating LLM training-data quality, with theoretical guarantees and empirical gains over classifier-based filtering.
AI.motivation: Ensuring high-quality, diverse training data for large language models is hard due to the lack of cheap quality metrics. Traditional approaches rely on expensive LLM queries or sparse signals, which do not scale to billions of documents. There is a need for scalable, data-driven quality estimation.
AI.method: Use text embeddings to build a hierarchical clustering; adaptively select a subset of documents to query an LLM for quality estimates. The method provides a probabilistic guarantee: if there exists a subtree where leaves are almost pure (mostly good or bad), then, with high probability, the overall quality of each document can be predicted by querying a small number of documents. The query budget scales with the size of the smallest almost-pure subtree, without knowing which subtree in advance. Experiments compare this approach to classifier-based filtering methods.
AI.result: The authors establish a theoretical result on query efficiency under the subtree-purity assumption and demonstrate, through comprehensive experiments, that their method offers benefits over classifier-based filtering baselines.
AI.conclusion: The proposed embedding-based hierarchical, adaptive querying framework yields a scalable, query-efficient mechanism for assessing and filtering training data quality for LLMs, with both theoretical guarantees and empirical improvements.

title: From Logits to Latents: Contrastive Representation Shaping for LLM Unlearning
summary: Most LLM unlearning methods aim to approximate retrain-from-scratch behaviors with minimal distribution shift, often via alignment-style objectives defined in the prediction space. While effective at reducing forgotten content generation, such approaches may act as suppression: forgotten concepts can persist in representations and remain entangled with retained knowledge. We introduce CLReg, a contrastive representation regularizer that identifies forget features while pushing them away from retain features, explicitly reducing forget-retain interference with minimal shifts on retain features. We provide first theoretical insights that relate representation shaping to entanglement reduction. Across unlearning benchmarks and LLMs of different sizes, CLReg decreases forget-retain representation entanglement that facilitates mainstream unlearning methods without positing extra privacy risks, inspiring future work that reshapes the representation space to remove forget concepts.

AI.tldr: Introduces CLReg, a contrastive representation regularizer for unlearning that reduces forget-retain entanglement in representations by pushing forget features away from retain features, with minimal shifts to retain features.
AI.motivation: Current unlearning approaches focus on prediction-space alignment but may leave forgotten concepts entangled in internal representations, enabling leakage or residual interference with retained knowledge.
AI.method: CLReg identifies forget features via contrastive signals and applies a regularizer that pushes them away from retain features in representation space, thereby reducing interference without large alterations to retained representations.
AI.result: Empirical evaluation on multiple unlearning benchmarks and LLMs of varying sizes shows reduced memory of forgotten concepts due to lower forget-retain representation entanglement; approach aligns with or enhances existing unlearning methods and does not introduce extra privacy risks.
AI.conclusion: Shaping the representation space to remove forget concepts is a viable path for unlearning; theoretical insights link representation shaping to entanglement reduction, suggesting future work to redesign representation spaces for forgetting adversaries.

title: The Ensemble Inverse Problem: Applications and Methods
summary: We introduce a new multivariate statistical problem that we refer to as the Ensemble Inverse Problem (EIP). The aim of EIP is to invert for an ensemble that is distributed according to the pushforward of a prior under a forward process. In high energy physics (HEP), this is related to a widely known problem called unfolding, which aims to reconstruct the true physics distribution of quantities, such as momentum and angle, from measurements that are distorted by detector effects. In recent applications, the EIP also arises in full waveform inversion (FWI) and inverse imaging with unknown priors. We propose non-iterative inference-time methods that construct posterior samplers based on a new class of conditional generative models, which we call ensemble inverse generative models. For the posterior modeling, these models additionally use the ensemble information contained in the observation set on top of single measurements. Unlike existing methods, our proposed methods avoid explicit and iterative use of the forward model at inference time via training across several sets of truth-observation pairs that are consistent with the same forward model, but originate from a wide range of priors. We demonstrate that this training procedure implicitly encodes the likelihood model. The use of ensemble information helps posterior inference and enables generalization to unseen priors. We benchmark the proposed method on several synthetic and real datasets in inverse imaging, HEP, and FWI. The codes are available at https://github.com/ZhengyanHuan/The-Ensemble-Inverse-Problem--Applications-and-Methods.

AI.tldr: Proposes Ensemble Inverse Problem (EIP) with non-iterative, ensemble-aware posterior samplers built via ensemble inverse generative models. Trains across multiple truth–observation sets under the same forward model to implicitly encode the likelihood and leverage ensemble information for better generalization to unseen priors. Applicable to unfolding, full waveform inversion, and inverse imaging; code available.
AI.motivation: Inverse problems where the target is an ensemble distributed as the pushforward of a prior through a forward model. In fields like high-energy physics, FWI, and inverse imaging, existing methods often rely on explicit likelihoods and iterative inference. The goal is non-iterative, inference-time posterior sampling that exploits ensemble information and generalizes to unseen priors.
AI.method: Introduce ensemble inverse generative models (conditional generative models) that produce posterior samples. These models use ensemble information from the observation set in addition to single measurements. Training spans multiple truth–observation sets sharing the same forward model but arising from diverse priors, enabling the implicit encoding of the likelihood. Inference does not require repeated forward-model calls at test time.
AI.result: Benchmarks on synthetic and real datasets in inverse imaging, high-energy physics, and full waveform inversion demonstrate improved posterior inference and generalization when using ensemble information. The approach yields non-iterative posterior samples and scales to unseen priors; code is provided at the authors' GitHub.
AI.conclusion: Ensemble-aware conditional generative modeling offers a practical, non-iterative solution to the Ensemble Inverse Problem. By embedding ensemble information and training across varied priors, the method implicitly captures the likelihood and generalizes beyond the training priors, with broad applicability across domains like HEP unfolding, FWI, and inverse imaging.

title: Per-parameter Task Arithmetic for Unlearning in Large Language Models
summary: In large language model (LLM) unlearning, private information is required to be removed. Task arithmetic unlearns by subtracting a specific task vector (TV)--defined as the parameter difference between a privacy-information-tuned model and the original model. While efficient, it can cause over-forgetting by disrupting parameters essential for retaining other information. Motivated by the observation that each parameter exhibits different importance for forgetting versus retention, we propose a per-parameter task arithmetic (PerTA) mechanism to rescale the TV, allowing per-parameter adjustment. These weights quantify the relative importance of each parameter for forgetting versus retention, estimated via gradients (i.e., PerTA-grad) or the diagonal Fisher information approximation (i.e., PerTA-fisher). Moreover, we discuss the effectiveness of PerTA, extend it to a more general form, and provide further analysis. Extensive experiments demonstrate that PerTA consistently improves upon standard TV, and in many cases surpasses widely used training-based unlearning methods in both forgetting effectiveness and overall model utility. By retaining the efficiency of task arithmetic while mitigating over-forgetting, PerTA offers a principled and practical framework for LLM unlearning.

AI.tldr: PerTA uses per-parameter scaling of the task vector (TV) to improve unlearning in LLMs by adjusting forgetting vs retention per parameter, via gradients or Fisher information, balancing efficiency and forgetting.
AI.motivation: To mitigate over-forgetting caused by a uniform TV by recognizing that different parameters have different importance for forgetting and retention.
AI.method: Introduce PerTA: a per-parameter rescaling of the TV. Two variants: PerTA-grad (weights derived from gradients) and PerTA-fisher (weights from diagonal Fisher information). Optionally extended to a more general form and analyzed.
AI.result: PerTA consistently improves standard TV performance and often surpasses training-based unlearning methods in forgetting effectiveness and overall model utility, while preserving efficiency.
AI.conclusion: PerTA offers a principled, practical framework for LLM unlearning with per-parameter adjustment that reduces over-forgetting and maintains model utility.

title: Holographic generative flows with AdS/CFT
summary: We present a framework for generative machine learning that leverages the holographic principle of quantum gravity, or to be more precise its manifestation as the anti-de Sitter/conformal field theory (AdS/CFT) correspondence, with techniques for deep learning and transport theory. Our proposal is to represent the flow of data from a base distribution to some learned distribution using the bulk-to-boundary mapping of scalar fields in AdS. In the language of machine learning, we are representing and augmenting the flow-matching algorithm with AdS physics. Using a checkerboard toy dataset and MNIST, we find that our model achieves faster and higher quality convergence than comparable physics-free flow-matching models. Our method provides a physically interpretable version of flow matching. More broadly, it establishes the utility of AdS physics and geometry in the development of novel paradigms in generative modeling.

AI.tldr: A holography-inspired generative framework uses AdS/CFT bulk-to-boundary mappings to augment flow-matching, improving convergence and interpretability on MNIST and a checkerboard dataset.
AI.motivation: Explore whether AdS geometry and bulk-boundary correspondence can provide physically meaningful priors and dynamics for learning data distributions, potentially improving efficiency and interpretability in flow-based generative models.
AI.method: Represent data flow as bulk-to-boundary maps of scalar fields in AdS, integrate AdS physics into the flow-matching algorithm, evaluate on checkerboard and MNIST.
AI.result: Faster convergence and higher sample quality compared to physics-free flow-matching baselines; yields a physically interpretable flow-matching framework.
AI.conclusion: AdS physics and geometry offer a useful foundation for novel generative modeling paradigms, enabling interpretable, physics-informed flow models and potentially broader applicability.

title: Cross-Fusion Distance: A Novel Metric for Measuring Fusion and Separability Between Data Groups in Representation Space
summary: Quantifying degrees of fusion and separability between data groups in representation space is a fundamental problem in representation learning, particularly under domain shift. A meaningful metric should capture fusion-altering factors like geometric displacement between representation groups, whose variations change the extent of fusion, while remaining invariant to fusion-preserving factors such as global scaling and sampling-induced layout changes, whose variations do not. Existing distributional distance metrics conflate these factors, leading to measures that are not informative of the true extent of fusion between data groups. We introduce Cross-Fusion Distance (CFD), a principled measure that isolates fusion-altering geometry while remaining robust to fusion-preserving variations, with linear computational complexity. We characterize the invariance and sensitivity properties of CFD theoretically and validate them in controlled synthetic experiments. For practical utility on real-world datasets with domain shift, CFD aligns more closely with downstream generalization degradation than commonly used alternatives. Overall, CFD provides a theoretically grounded and interpretable distance measure for representation learning.

AI.tldr: CFD is a principled, scalable distance to quantify fusion vs separability between representation groups by isolating fusion-altering geometry and remaining robust to fusion-preserving variations.
AI.motivation: Quantifying fusion/separability under domain shift is important; existing distance metrics conflate fusion-altering and preserving factors, leading to uninformative measures.
AI.method: Proposes Cross-Fusion Distance (CFD); analyzes its invariance to fusion-preserving variations (e.g., global scaling, sampling-induced layout changes) and sensitivity to fusion-altering geometry; demonstrates linear computational complexity; validates on synthetic data and real-world domain-shift datasets, comparing to baseline metrics; shows CFD correlates with downstream generalization degradation.
AI.result: CFD cleanly captures fusion-altering geometry, is invariant to fusion-preserving variations, has linear-time complexity, and aligns more closely with generalization degradation than standard distributional distances.
AI.conclusion: CFD provides a theoretically grounded, interpretable, and practical distance measure for representation learning under domain shift.

title: Making Foundation Models Probabilistic via Singular Value Ensembles
summary: Foundation models have become a dominant paradigm in machine learning, achieving remarkable performance across diverse tasks through large-scale pretraining. However, these models often yield overconfident, uncalibrated predictions. The standard approach to quantifying epistemic uncertainty, training an ensemble of independent models, incurs prohibitive computational costs that scale linearly with ensemble size, making it impractical for large foundation models. We propose Singular Value Ensemble (SVE), a parameter-efficient implicit ensemble method that builds on a simple, but powerful core assumption: namely, that the singular vectors of the weight matrices constitute meaningful subspaces of the model's knowledge. Pretrained foundation models encode rich, transferable information in their weight matrices. If the singular vectors are indeed meaningful (orthogonal) "knowledge directions". To obtain a model ensemble, we modulate only how strongly each direction contributes to the output. Rather than learning entirely new parameters, we freeze the singular vectors and only train per-member singular values that rescale the contribution of each direction in that shared knowledge basis. Ensemble diversity emerges naturally as stochastic initialization and random sampling of mini-batches during joint training cause different members to converge to different combinations of the same underlying knowledge. SVE achieves uncertainty quantification comparable to explicit deep ensembles while increasing the parameter count of the base model by less than 1%, making principled uncertainty estimation accessible in resource-constrained settings. We validate SVE on NLP and vision tasks with various different backbones and show that it improves calibration while maintaining predictive accuracy.

AI.tldr: SVE is a parameter-efficient implicit ensemble that uses frozen weight matrix singular vectors as a shared knowledge basis and trains only per-member singular values to produce diverse ensembles for uncertainty estimation. It achieves deep-ensemble–level calibration with less than 1% parameter overhead.
AI.motivation: Deep ensembles provide strong epistemic uncertainty estimates but are computationally prohibitive for large foundation models. A compact, scalable alternative is needed that maintains accuracy while improving calibration.
AI.method: Compute the SVD of weight matrices to obtain orthogonal 'knowledge directions'. Freeze the singular vectors and train per-member singular values that scale each direction's contribution for each ensemble member. Diversity arises from random initializations and stochastic training. Ensemble members share the same basis but differ in the combination of directions.
AI.result: SVE attains uncertainty quantification comparable to explicit deep ensembles while incurring <1% parameter increase over the base model. It improves calibration on NLP and vision tasks across various backbones without sacrificing predictive accuracy.
AI.conclusion: SVE provides a practical, scalable approach to principled uncertainty estimation for large foundation models by leveraging the intrinsic structure of weight matrices to form a compact, diverse ensemble.

title: Where Do the Joules Go? Diagnosing Inference Energy Consumption
comment: The ML.ENERGY Leaderboard v3.0 is open https://ml.energy/leaderboard
summary: Energy is now a critical ML computing resource. While measuring energy consumption and observing trends is a valuable first step, accurately understanding and diagnosing why those differences occur is crucial for optimization. To that end, we begin by presenting a large-scale measurement study of inference time and energy across the generative AI landscape with 46 models, 7 tasks, and 1,858 different configurations on NVIDIA H100 and B200 GPUs. Our empirical findings span order-of-magnitude variations: LLM task type can lead to 25$\times$ energy differences, video generation sometimes consumes more than 100$\times$ the energy of images, and GPU utilization differences can result in 3--5$\times$ energy differences. Based on our observations, we present a framework for reasoning about the underlying mechanisms that govern time and energy consumption. The essence is that time and energy are determined by latent metrics like memory and utilization, which are in turn affected by various factors across the algorithm, software, and hardware layers. Our framework also extends directly to throughput per watt, a critical metric for power-constrained datacenters.

AI.tldr: Large-scale energy benchmarking across 46 models, 7 tasks, and 1,858 configurations on NVIDIA H100/B200 reveals vast energy/time variability and a general framework linking energy/time to latent metrics like memory and utilization across algorithm, software, and hardware layers, with applicability to throughput per watt.
AI.motivation: Energy is a critical but poorly understood ML computing resource. Beyond measuring energy, understanding the drivers of energy/time is essential for optimization and for designing power-constrained datacenters.
AI.method: Empirical measurement study benchmarking inference time and energy across 46 models, 7 tasks, and 1,858 configurations on NVIDIA H100 and B200 GPUs; analyze how factors across the algorithm, software, and hardware stack influence energy/time; develop a framework based on latent metrics (e.g., memory, utilization).
AI.result: Found order-of-magnitude energy/time variation: LLM task type can cause ~25x energy differences; video generation can exceed image-energy by >100x; GPU utilization differences yield ~3–5x energy variation. Presented a framework to reason about underlying mechanisms, with latent metrics shaping time and energy, and extended applicability to throughput per watt.
AI.conclusion: A practical framework that explains energy/time variability in ML workloads via latent metrics across layers, enabling better optimization and direct extension to throughput-per-watt in power-constrained datacenters.

title: Latent Adversarial Regularization for Offline Preference Optimization
summary: Learning from human feedback typically relies on preference optimization that constrains policy updates through token-level regularization. However, preference optimization for language models is particularly challenging because token-space similarity does not imply semantic or behavioral similarity. To address this challenge, we leverage latent-space regularization for language model preference optimization. We introduce GANPO, which achieves latent-space regularization by penalizing divergence between the internal representations of a policy model and a reference model. Given that latent representations are not associated with explicit probability densities, we adopt an adversarial approach inspired by GANs to minimize latent-space divergence. We integrate GANPO as a regularizer into existing offline preference optimization objectives. Experiments across multiple model architectures and tasks show consistent improvements from latent-space regularization. Further, by comparing GANPO-induced inferential biases with those from token-level regularization, we find that GANPO provides more robust structural feedback under distributional shift and noise while maintaining comparable downstream performance with minor computational overhead.

AI.tldr: GANPO introduces latent-space regularization for offline language-model preference optimization by adversarially aligning internal representations between a policy model and a reference model, improving robustness to distributional shift/noise with minimal overhead.
AI.motivation: Token-space similarity does not guarantee semantic/behavioral similarity in LM preference learning; latent-space regularization aims to enforce behavioral consistency where token-level metrics fail.
AI.method: Define GANPO: penalize divergence between latent representations of policy and reference models using an adversarial (GAN-like) objective, since latent densities are not well-defined. Integrate this latent-space regularizer into existing offline preference optimization objectives.
AI.result: Across architectures/tasks, GANPO yields consistent improvements; inferential biases from GANPO differ from token-level regularization, offering more robust structure under distributional shift and noise with comparable downstream performance and slight computational overhead.
AI.conclusion: Latent-space regularization via GANPO provides robust, efficient improvement for language-model preference optimization, mitigating token-space misalignment and enhancing resilience to shifts and noise.

title: GeoNorm: Unify Pre-Norm and Post-Norm with Geodesic Optimization
summary: The placement of normalization layers, specifically Pre-Norm and Post-Norm, remains an open question in Transformer architecture design. In this work, we rethink these approaches through the lens of manifold optimization, interpreting the outputs of the Feed-Forward Network (FFN) and attention layers as update directions in optimization. Building on this perspective, we introduce GeoNorm, a novel method that replaces standard normalization with geodesic updates on the manifold. Furthermore, analogous to learning rate schedules, we propose a layer-wise update decay for the FFN and attention components. Comprehensive experiments demonstrate that GeoNorm consistently outperforms existing normalization methods in Transformer models. Crucially, GeoNorm can be seamlessly integrated into standard Transformer architectures, achieving performance improvements with negligible additional computational cost.

AI.tldr: GeoNorm proposes geodesic updates on a manifold as an alternative to standard normalization in Transformers, introducing layer-wise update decay for FFN and attention. It claims consistent performance gains with negligible computational overhead and easy integration into standard architectures.
AI.motivation: Normalization placement (Pre-Norm vs Post-Norm) impacts Transformer optimization and stability. Viewing FFN and attention outputs as optimization update directions motivates a geometric normalization approach using geodesic updates on a manifold.
AI.method: Replace traditional normalization with geodesic updates on a chosen manifold, treating FFN and attention outputs as update vectors. Introduce layer-wise update decay schedules for FFN and attention components. Integrate GeoNorm into standard Transformer architectures without major changes.
AI.result: Empirical experiments indicate GeoNorm consistently outperforms existing normalization methods across Transformer models, with negligible additional computational cost.
AI.conclusion: GeoNorm offers a hardware-friendly, geometrically grounded normalization alternative that can be seamlessly integrated into Transformers, delivering improved performance without significant overhead.

title: Boosting CVaR Policy Optimization with Quantile Gradients
summary: Optimizing Conditional Value-at-risk (CVaR) using policy gradient (a.k.a CVaR-PG) faces significant challenges of sample inefficiency. This inefficiency stems from the fact that it focuses on tail-end performance and overlooks many sampled trajectories. We address this problem by augmenting CVaR with an expected quantile term. Quantile optimization admits a dynamic programming formulation that leverages all sampled data, thus improves sample efficiency. This does not alter the CVaR objective since CVaR corresponds to the expectation of quantile over the tail. Empirical results in domains with verifiable risk-averse behavior show that our algorithm within the Markovian policy class substantially improves upon CVaR-PG and consistently outperforms other existing methods.

AI.tldr: Augments CVaR policy gradient with an expected quantile term to exploit all data via a dynamic programming formulation; preserves the CVaR objective while improving sample efficiency; empirically stronger in risk-averse tasks.
AI.motivation: CVaR-PG is sample-inefficient because it focuses on tail outcomes and ignores most trajectories. There is a need to leverage all sampled data to improve learning efficiency while maintaining risk guarantees.
AI.method: Introduce an expected quantile term that admits a dynamic programming formulation, enabling use of all sampled data to optimize the tail-related objective. Clarify that CVaR equals the expectation of quantile over the tail, so the augmentation does not change the CVaR objective. Implement within a Markovian policy class.
AI.result: Empirical results show substantial improvements over CVaR-PG and competitive performance relative to other methods in domains with verifiable risk-averse behavior.
AI.conclusion: Quantile-based augmentation yields a more sample-efficient CVaR optimization method without altering the underlying CVaR objective, with strong empirical performance in risk-averse domains.

title: StepShield: When, Not Whether to Intervene on Rogue Agents
summary: Existing agent safety benchmarks report binary accuracy, conflating early intervention with post-mortem analysis. A detector that flags a violation at step 8 enables intervention; one that reports it at step 48 provides only forensic value. This distinction is critical, yet current benchmarks cannot measure it. We introduce StepShield, the first benchmark to evaluate when violations are detected, not just whether. StepShield contains 9,213 code agent trajectories, including 1,278 meticulously annotated training pairs and a 7,935-trajectory test set with a realistic 8.1% rogue rate. Rogue behaviors are grounded in real-world security incidents across six categories. We propose three novel temporal metrics: Early Intervention Rate (EIR), Intervention Gap, and Tokens Saved. Surprisingly, our evaluation reveals that an LLM-based judge achieves 59% EIR while a static analyzer achieves only 26%, a 2.3x performance gap that is entirely invisible to standard accuracy metrics. We further show that early detection has direct economic benefits: our cascaded HybridGuard detector reduces monitoring costs by 75% and projects to $108M in cumulative savings over five years at enterprise scale. By shifting the focus of evaluation from whether to when, StepShield provides a new foundation for building safer and more economically viable AI agents. The code and data are released under an Apache 2.0 license.

AI.tldr: First benchmark to evaluate when violations are detected (timing) rather than binary correctness; StepShield uses 9,213 agent trajectories with annotated training pairs and a 7,935-trajectory test set, introducing three temporal metrics; results show large performance gaps between an LLM judge and a static analyzer and claim substantial economic savings with a cascaded detector; data/code released under Apache 2.0.
AI.motivation: Conventional safety benchmarks report only whether a violation is detected, conflating early intervention with post-mortem analysis. There is a need to quantify detection timing to enable proactive interventions and cost-effective safety monitoring.
AI.method: Assemble a large corpus of real-world-grounded rogue trajectories; annotate training pairs; define three temporal metrics (Early Intervention Rate, Intervention Gap, Tokens Saved); evaluate detectors (LLM judge vs static analyzer) and a cascaded HybridGuard detector; report on economic impact and provide code/data release.
AI.result: LLM-based judge achieves 59% Early Intervention Rate (EIR) vs 26% for a static analyzer (2.3x gap). The cascaded detector reduces monitoring costs by 75% and is projected to save $108M over five years at enterprise scale. The dataset comprises 9,213 trajectories (1,278 training pairs annotated; 7,935 test trajectories with 8.1% rogue rate) grounded in six security categories.
AI.conclusion: Shifting evaluation from whether to when provides a foundation for safer and more economically viable AI agents; StepShield enables measuring the crucial dimension of detection timing and offers reproducible data/code under an open license.

title: Prior-Informed Flow Matching for Graph Reconstruction
summary: We introduce Prior-Informed Flow Matching (PIFM), a conditional flow model for graph reconstruction. Reconstructing graphs from partial observations remains a key challenge; classical embedding methods often lack global consistency, while modern generative models struggle to incorporate structural priors. PIFM bridges this gap by integrating embedding-based priors with continuous-time flow matching. Grounded in a permutation equivariant version of the distortion-perception theory, our method first uses a prior, such as graphons or GraphSAGE/node2vec, to form an informed initial estimate of the adjacency matrix based on local information. It then applies rectified flow matching to refine this estimate, transporting it toward the true distribution of clean graphs and learning a global coupling. Experiments on different datasets demonstrate that PIFM consistently enhances classical embeddings, outperforming them and state-of-the-art generative baselines in reconstruction accuracy.

AI.tldr: PIFM combines embedding priors with a rectified continuous-time flow to reconstruct graphs from partial observations, improving over classical embeddings and generative baselines.
AI.motivation: Embedding methods struggle with global consistency in graph reconstruction; generative models often lack structural priors. A method that fuses priors with flow-based refinement can yield better reconstruction.
AI.method: Initialize adjacency with priors (graphons, GraphSAGE, node2vec) in a permutation-equivariant way, then apply rectified flow matching to refine toward the true graph distribution and learn a global coupling.
AI.result: Empirical results across datasets show consistent improvement in reconstruction accuracy over classical embeddings and state-of-the-art generative baselines.
AI.conclusion: PIFM demonstrates the effectiveness of integrating embedding priors with continuous-time flow matching to achieve globally consistent graph reconstruction from partial observations.

title: Physics Informed Reconstruction of Four-Dimensional Atmospheric Wind Fields Using Multi-UAS Swarm Observations in a Synthetic Turbulent Environment
summary: Accurate reconstruction of atmospheric wind fields is essential for applications such as weather forecasting, hazard prediction, and wind energy assessment, yet conventional instruments leave spatio-temporal gaps within the lower atmospheric boundary layer. Unmanned aircraft systems (UAS) provide flexible in situ measurements, but individual platforms sample wind only along their flight trajectories, limiting full wind-field recovery. This study presents a framework for reconstructing four-dimensional atmospheric wind fields using measurements obtained from a coordinated UAS swarm. A synthetic turbulence environment and high-fidelity multirotor simulation are used to generate training and evaluation data. Local wind components are estimated from UAS dynamics using a bidirectional long short-term memory network (Bi-LSTM) and assimilated into a physics-informed neural network (PINN) to reconstruct a continuous wind field in space and time. For local wind estimation, the bidirectional LSTM achieves root-mean-square errors (RMSE) of 0.064 and 0.062 m/s for the north and east components in low-wind conditions, increasing to 0.122 to 0.129 m/s under moderate winds and 0.271 to 0.273 m/s in high-wind conditions, while the vertical component exhibits higher error, with RMSE values of 0.029 to 0.091 m/s. The physics-informed reconstruction recovers the dominant spatial and temporal structure of the wind field up to 1000 m altitude while preserving mean flow direction and vertical shear. Under moderate wind conditions, the reconstructed mean wind field achieves an overall RMSE between 0.118 and 0.154 m/s across evaluated UAS configurations, with the lowest error obtained using a five-UAS swarm. These results demonstrate that coordinated UAS measurements enable accurate and scalable four-dimensional wind-field reconstruction without dedicated wind sensors or fixed infrastructure.

AI.tldr: Coordinated UAS swarm with Bi-LSTM local wind estimation and physics-informed neural network reconstruction enables 4D wind-field recovery without fixed sensors; moderate-wind RMSE ~0.12–0.15 m/s, best with five UAS.
AI.motivation: Address spatio-temporal gaps in lower-atmosphere wind measurements and achieve full 4D wind-field reconstruction using mobile UAS data without fixed infrastructure or dedicated wind sensors.
AI.method: Two-stage approach: (1) estimate local wind components from UAS dynamics with a Bidirectional LSTM (Bi-LSTM) trained on synthetic turbulence/high-fidelity simulation data; (2) assimilate estimates into a physics-informed neural network (PINN) to reconstruct a continuous wind field in space and time up to ~1000 m altitude; evaluate across wind regimes and UAS swarm sizes.
AI.result: Local-wind RMSE (north/east): 0.064/0.062 m/s (low wind); 0.122–0.129 m/s (moderate); 0.271–0.273 m/s (high); vertical RMSE 0.029–0.091 m/s. PINN-reconstructed wind captures dominant spatiotemporal structure and vertical shear, preserving mean flow. Moderate wind mean wind RMSE across configurations: 0.118–0.154 m/s; best performance with five-UAS swarm.
AI.conclusion: Coordinated UAS measurements enable accurate, scalable 4D wind-field reconstruction without dedicated wind sensors or fixed infrastructure; five-UAS configurations often yield optimal accuracy for moderate wind conditions.

title: Learning Hamiltonian Flow Maps: Mean Flow Consistency for Large-Timestep Molecular Dynamics
summary: Simulating the long-time evolution of Hamiltonian systems is limited by the small timesteps required for stable numerical integration. To overcome this constraint, we introduce a framework to learn Hamiltonian Flow Maps by predicting the mean phase-space evolution over a chosen time span $Δt$, enabling stable large-timestep updates far beyond the stability limits of classical integrators. To this end, we impose a Mean Flow consistency condition for time-averaged Hamiltonian dynamics. Unlike prior approaches, this allows training on independent phase-space samples without access to future states, avoiding expensive trajectory generation. Validated across diverse Hamiltonian systems, our method in particular improves upon molecular dynamics simulations using machine-learned force fields (MLFF). Our models maintain comparable training and inference cost, but support significantly larger integration timesteps while trained directly on widely-available trajectory-free MLFF datasets.

AI.tldr: A framework to learn Hamiltonian Flow Maps that predict mean phase-space evolution over a time interval Δt, enabling stable, large-timestep updates beyond classic integrators by enforcing a Mean Flow consistency condition on time-averaged dynamics; trained on independent phase-space samples without future-state data, avoiding costly trajectory generation; validated across diverse Hamiltonian systems and notably improves molecular dynamics with ML force fields while maintaining similar compute costs.
AI.motivation: Overcome the timestep bottleneck in long-time Hamiltonian simulations caused by stability constraints of numerical integrators; reduce dependency on full trajectory data by enabling training from snapshot samples; improve MD performance with ML-based force fields.
AI.method: Introduce a learning framework that outputs mean flow maps over Δt for phase-space coordinates. Impose a Mean Flow consistency condition for time-averaged Hamiltonian dynamics. Train using independent phase-space samples that do not require future states, bypassing trajectory generation. Validate across various Hamiltonian systems and integrate with MLFF datasets.
AI.result: Achieve stable, large-timestep integration across tested Hamiltonians; in molecular dynamics, outperform traditional approaches using MLFFs while keeping training/inference costs comparable. The method enables using widely available trajectory-free MLFF datasets to drive MD simulations with larger Δt.
AI.conclusion: Learning mean Hamiltonian flow maps provides a data-efficient route to long-time, stable simulations of Hamiltonian systems. The approach generalizes across diverse systems and enhances MD with MLFFs by allowing larger Δt without the need for future-state data during training.

title: Late Breaking Results: Conversion of Neural Networks into Logic Flows for Edge Computing
summary:
Neural networks have been successfully applied in various resource-constrained edge devices, where usually central processing units (CPUs) instead of graphics processing units exist due to limited power availability. State-of-the-art research still focuses on efficiently executing enormous numbers of multiply-accumulate (MAC) operations. However, CPUs themselves are not good at executing such mathematical operations on a large scale, since they are more suited to execute control flow logic, i.e., computer algorithms. To enhance the computation efficiency of neural networks on CPUs, in this paper, we propose to convert them into logic flows for execution. Specifically, neural networks are first converted into equivalent decision trees, from which decision paths with constant leaves are then selected and compressed into logic flows. Such logic flows consist of if and else structures and a reduced number of MAC operations. Experimental results demonstrate that the latency can be reduced by up to 14.9 % on a simulated RISC-V CPU without any accuracy degradation.
  The code is open source at https://github.com/TUDa-HWAI/NN2Logic

AI.tldr: Convert neural networks to logic-flow representations (decision-tree-based) to reduce MACs and latency on CPUs, achieving up to 14.9% speed-up on a simulated RISC-V with no accuracy loss; code available.
AI.motivation: CPUs are more suited to control flow than large-scale MACs; edge devices require efficient CPU inference, so transforming NNs into logic flows can improve efficiency.
AI.method: Convert NN to equivalent decision trees; select constant-leaf decision paths; compress into if-else logic flows; reduce MAC operations while preserving accuracy.
AI.result: Latency reduced by up to 14.9% on a simulated RISC-V CPU; no accuracy degradation; open-source implementation.
AI.conclusion: Logic-flow representations of neural nets offer CPU-friendly inference with maintained accuracy and reduced computation latency; practical for edge deployments.

title: Discovering Hidden Gems in Model Repositories
summary: Public repositories host millions of fine-tuned models, yet community usage remains disproportionately concentrated on a small number of foundation checkpoints. We investigate whether this concentration reflects efficient market selection or if superior models are systematically overlooked. Through an extensive evaluation of over 2,000 models, we show the prevalence of "hidden gems", unpopular fine-tunes that significantly outperform their popular counterparts. Notably, within the Llama-3.1-8B family, we find rarely downloaded checkpoints that improve math performance from 83.2% to 96.0% without increasing inference costs. However, discovering these models through exhaustive evaluation of every uploaded model is computationally infeasible. We therefore formulate model discovery as a Multi-Armed Bandit problem and accelerate the Sequential Halving search algorithm by using shared query sets and aggressive elimination schedules. Our method retrieves top models with as few as 50 queries per candidate, accelerating discovery by over 50x.

AI.tldr: Uncovering overlooked yet high-performing fine-tuned models ('hidden gems') in large model zoos using a bandit-based discovery approach, achieving substantial performance gains with far fewer evaluations.
AI.motivation: Public repositories contain millions of fine-tuned models with usage concentrated on a few popular checkpoints; it is unclear whether popular models are genuinely best or if better models are being missed, potentially wasting resources.
AI.method: Large-scale empirical evaluation of 2,000 models; case study on Llama-3.1-8B; formulate discovery as a Multi-Armed Bandit problem; accelerate Sequential Halving with shared query sets and aggressive elimination; evaluate efficiency (queries per candidate) and performance (math accuracy) and compare to exhaustive search.
AI.result: Identification of 'hidden gems' that outperform popular models; e.g., Llama-3.1-8B rarely downloaded checkpoints raise math accuracy from 83.2% to 96.0% without extra inference cost; discovery achieved with as few as 50 queries per candidate and speedups >50x.
AI.conclusion: Market efficiency is incomplete; efficient bandit-based discovery can reveal superior models with reduced evaluation cost, enabling better curation and optimization of model pools; suggests practical deployment of search strategies in model repositories.
